680 An Act To Amend Section 1 Of Act No.

725 Of The Acts Of The General Assembly Of The State Of South Carolina Of 1942 UOU OUO' Entitled An Act Authorizing The State Game Department To Furnish Hunting Licenses Of Other Material Than Metal, As Determined By The Joint Committee On Printing, For A Limited Time As Specified Herein, 80 As To Substitute The State Budget And Control Board For The Joint Committee On Printing, And To Make The Act A Permanent Act.
Act 725 of 1942 amendedmaterial use for hunting licenses.Section 1 of Act No.

725 of the Acts of the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina, 1942, entitled An Act Authorizing the State Game Department to Furnish Hunting Licenses of Other Material than Metal, as Determined by the Joint Committee on Printing, for a Limited Time as Specified Herein, is hereby amended by striking out all of the section and inserting in lieu thereof the following : section 1.

Hunting licenses shall be made of paper or cloth or such other material as shall be determined and specified by the State Budget and Control Board. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 28th day of December, 1951

681 An Act To Amend Section 17871 Of The Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To The Protection Of Wild Birds, Other Than Game Birds, So As To Eliminate From Such Protection All Destructive Birds Except Bald Eagles And Buzzards.

17871, 1942 Code, amendednot kill, possess, purchase or offer for sale wild birds other than game birds or certain destructive birdssale or possession of plumage, skin or body of a bird protected hereinnot take or destroy their nests or egga transportation.Section 17871 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is hereby amended by striking out all of said section and inserting therein a new section which shall read as follows: section 17871.

(1) No person within this state shall kill, catch cr have in his possession, living or dead, any resident or migratory wild bird other than a game bird or a bird, not a bald eagle or buzzard, classified by Section 1757 as destructive.
No person shall within this state purchase, offer or expose for sale any bird protected by this section after it has been killed or caught, except as permitted by section 17872 and 17873.

(2) No part of the plumage, skin or body of any bird protected by this section shall be sold or had in possession for sale, and this irrespective of whether said bird was captured or killed within or without the state.

(3) No person within the state shall take or destroy, or attempt to take or destroy, the nest or the eggs of any bird protected by this section, or have such nest or eggs in his or their possession, except as permitted by section 17872 and 17873.

(4) It shall be unlawful for any person or persons, or any corporation acting as a common carrier, its officers, agents or servants, to ship, carry, take or transport, either within or beyond the confines of the state, any bird protected by this section except as permitted by Section 17873.

(5) Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be liable to a fine of not less than one ($1.00) dollar nor more than five ($5.00) dollars for each bird, living or dead, or part of a bird, or nest or set of eggs, or part thereof, killed or captured or possessed, in violation of this section, or be imprisoned in the county jail for not more than thirty days. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 28th day of December, 1951

682 An Act To Amend section 853 To 857, Both Inclusive, Of The Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To The Discharge Of A Person Arrested In A Civil Action From His Arrest And Confinement And From His Indebtedness, So As To Eliminate The Provisions For Discharge From Indebtedness.

853, 1942 Code, amendedclerk examine as to discharge of prisoner from arrest and confinementoath of petitioner.Section 853 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is hereby amended by inserting after the word appearance in line 1 the word and and by inserting the words from arrest and confinement after the word petitioner in line 5 and after the word discharge in the last line, so that the section, as amended, shall read as follows: section 853.

Upon the day of such appearance, and if any of the creditors so summoned shall neglect or refuse to appear, upon affidavit made of the service of such rule or order, in manner aforesaid, the clerk shall, in a summary way, examine into the matter of the said petition, and hear what shall be alleged for or against the discharge of the said petitioner from arrest and confinement; and, upon such examination, the clerk may, and is hereby required to administer or tender to the petitioner an oath in the following words: T, (A.

), do solemnly swear that the account by me delivered into this honorable court, with my petition, doth contain a true and full account of all my real and personal estate, debts, credits, and effects whatsoever, without exception, which I, or any person in trust for me, have, or at the time of my said petition had, or am, or was, in any respect, entitled unto, in possession, remainder, or reversion; and that I have not at any time since my being sued, arrested, or imprisoned, or before, directly or indirectly, sold, leased, assigned, or otherwise disposed of, or made over, in trust for myself or otherwise, other than is mentioned in such account, any part of my lands, estate, goods, stock, money, debts, or other real or personal estate, whereby to have or expect any benefit or profit to myself, or to defraud any of my creditors to whom I am indebted; and that I will, to the utmost of my power, endeavor to collect all and singular the title deeds to my lands, together with the remainder of my goods and effects contained in my said account, and the vouchers relating to or concerning the aU rare SFU OO same, wheresoever, or in whosoever hands they may be within this State, and will surrender the same to my assignee or assignees as soon as possible after my discharge from arrest and confinement.
So help me God. Section 2.

854, 1942 Code, amendedmay assign unexempted property for benefit of creditorshomestead.Section 854 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is hereby amended by inserting after the word discharge in line 9 the words from arrest and confinement, so that the section, as amended, shall read as follows: section 854.

In case the prisoner shall take the said oath, and upon examination the clerk shall be satisfied with the truth thereof, he shall order the lands, goods, and effects contained in the said accounts, or so much of them as may be sufficient to satisfy the debts wherewith such petitioner shall be charged, and the fees of the keeper of the jail where he shall be in custody, together with the costs of suit which shall be incurred on the suit or prosecution commenced against him, and all other costs and fees which shall arise or become due upon prosecuting and obtaining his discharge from arrest and confinement, by a short indorsement on the back of his petition, signed by the petitioner, to be assigned to some suitable person, to be selected by the clerk, as assignee for the benefit of the plaintiff and such creditors as may appear or establish claims against the debtor: provided, however, that if the petitioner be the head of a family, there shall be reserved to him, out of his real and personal property, a homestead, and such articles as are exempt from attachment, levy and sale under the provisions of the Constitution and laws of this State. Section 3.
855, 1942 Code, amendeddischarge prisoner from arrest and confinement after assignment and delivery of property.
of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is hereby amended by striking it out in its entirety and inserting in lieu thereof a new section to read as follows: section 855.

The petitioner, upon executing the assignment, and when he shall have delivered into the hands of the assignee all and singular his title deeds, vouchers and effects contained in his account, so far as it is in his power to do, shall forthwith he discharged by order from arrest and confinement. Section 4.

856, 1942 Code, amendedmay remand debtor to prison on his failure to comply with oath and  854 and 855.Section 856 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is hereby amended by striking it out in its entirety and inserting in lieu thereof a new section to read as follows: section 856.

In case any such debtor shall neglect or refuse within a reasonable time to comply with his oath set out in Section 853 and the provisions of section 854 and 855, it shall be lawful for the judge of the court, upon application upon oath of the assignee, again to remand the debtor to prison, unless good cause shall be shown by him or them to the contrary, until he shall fully comply with the terms of his oath and of those sections. Section 5.

857, 1942 Code, amendedpenalties for false schedule of effectsSection 857 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is hereby amended by striking it out in its entirety and inserting in lieu thereof a new section to read as follows: section 857.

Any person who shall deliver in a false schedule of his effects shall suffer the penalties of wilful perjury and shall be liable to be arrested again for the same action. Section 6. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 28th day of December, 1951

3211, 1942 Code, repealedState borrow in anticipation of certain taxes.Section 3211,Code of Laws of South Carolina,1942, providing for the borrowing of money by the state in anticipation of certain taxes is hereby repealed.

684 An Act To Amend Section 3379, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Amended, Relating To Licenses For Various Fishing Appliances, Shrimp Boats Of Residents And Nonresidents, So As To Make Certain Changes By Providing Various License Taxes On Fishing Appliances, Resident And Nonresident Shrimp Boats, By Providing For Certain Sworn Statements By Shrimp Boat Owners, By Setting Forth Certain Presumptions In Oriminal And Civil Proceedings, And By MalMing Certain Changes In Penalties For Violations.

3379, 1942 Code, amendedlicense taxes on fishing appliancespresumption as to licensed shrimp trawler violating law relating to fisheryconfiscate unlicensed boat trawling for shrimp.Section 3379, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as amended by Act No.
281, Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1947, is hereby amended by striking out all of Section 3379 and by inserting in lieu thereof the following: section 3379.

The following license tax is hereby levied annually upon the different fishing appliances, except sturgeon nets, used in the waters of South Carolina; anchor gill nets, stake gill nets, and drift gill nets, twentyfive (25) cents for each one hundred (100) yards or fraction thereof.
Shrimp trawl nets, five ($5.00) dollars each.

All owners of shrimp boats who are residents of this state shall, before operating a shrimp boat in the waters of South Carolina, obtain a license for each boat, the licenses to be at the following rates: twenty ($20.00) dollars for each shrimp boat licensed by the State Board of Fisheries upon such form and in such manner as the Board of Fisheries may direct.

All owners of shrimp boats who are nonresidents of this state shall, before operating a shrimp boat in the waters of South Carolina, and in addition to the twenty ($20.00) dollars required above, pay a fee of twentyfive ($25.00) dollars, together with five ($5.00) dollars for each member of the ships crew who is a nonresident of this state.
At the time of securing the license for the boat the owner thereof shall file with the Board of Fisheries a sworn statement giving the name and address of the Master or Captain of the shrimp boat.

If the licensed shrimp trawler is found violating any fisheries law of this state it shall be presumed in all criminal and civil proceedings that the registered Master or Captain were in fact upon the boat, and the presumption shall be prima facie evidence of the presence of the Master or Captain upon the boat and operating it at the time of the violation of the fiw charged.

In addition to the punishment provided for in Section 3407, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, any boat trawling for shrimp in the waters of South Carolina, without first being licensed, shall be confiscated, with its rigging and equipment, and shall be sold by the state at public sale to the highest bidder for cash before the court house door of the county in which captured, after giving ten (10) days notice of the sale in a newspaper published in said county.

Provided, that the provisions of this act shall not become effective uritil January 1, 1952. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent with the provisions of this act are hereby repealed. Approved the 28th day of December, 1951
685 An Act To Fix The Terms Of Office Of The Members Of The South Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission, So As To Change Their Terms Of Office From Four To Six Years.
Whereas, on the 16th day of January, 1952 by concurrent resolution bearing Senate No.
425, Reorganization Plan No.
8 was adopted ; and, Ss Whereas, Reorganization Plan No.

8 reorganized the State Board of Fisheries, the State Game and Fish Commission and the Office of Chief Game Warden into the South Carolina Wildlife Resources Department; and, Whereas, this action was taken pursuant to the provisions of Act No.
621 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1948.
Now, Therefore, Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1.

South Carolina Wildlife Resources Commissionappointmenttermsvacancypayexpenses.The head and govering board of the South Carolina Wildlife Resources Department shall be a commission to be known as the South Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission, which shall be composed of seven members, one from each congressional district in the state, and one at large.
They shall be appointed by the Governor, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate.
One of the members shall be designated by the Governor to serve as chairman.
Two of the original appointees shall he appointed for terms of office oftwo years, two for terms of office of four years, and three for terms of office of six years.
Their successors shall be appointed in like manner for terms of office of six years, and until their successors shall have been appointed and qualifed.
All vacancies on the commission occurring by reason of death, Tesignation, removal, or otherwise, shall be filled for the unexpired term in the manner of original appointment.
Each member shall receive compensation in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per annum, and official expenses as provided by law for state emplovees on public business.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the Ist day of March, 1952.

United States census of 1950 adopted.That the United States Census of 1950 is hereby adopted as the true and correct enumeration of the inhabitants of the several counties, municipalities and other governmental subdivisions of the State of South Carolina.

688 An Act To Amend Section 1 Of An Act Designated No.

885 Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions Of The General Assembly Of South Carolina, 1946, Entitled An Act To Authorize The Clerk Of Court Of Chesterfield County To Have Photostatic Copies Of The Discharges Of Veterans Of World War II Made And To Record Such Copies, So As To Provide For The Photostating Of Discharges Of Veterans Of The Korean War.
Act 885 of 1946 amendedrecording of armed forces discharges of veterans of the Korean War, Chesterfield County.Section 1 of Act No.

885 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly of South Carolina, 1946, is amended by adding after World War II on line 3 the following: and the Korean War, so that when amended Section 1 shall read as follows: section 1.

The Clerk of Court of Chesterfield County is authorized and, upon the request of a veteran, is required to have the Armed Forces Discharge of Veterans of World War II and the Korean War photostated and to record such photostatic copies in a proper record book. 689 An Act To Authorize The Sale Of Bonds Of Marlboro County For County Purposes.
Bonds Marlboro County sell for county purposes.There is hereby authorized the sale of bonds up to the constitutional limit for Marlboro County for county purposes.

680 An Act To Validate Certain General Obligation Bonds Of The Town Of Brunson, In Hampton County, And To Define The Legislative Intent In Enacting The Municipal Bond Act Of 1951 Insofar As It Affects Proceedings Taken Prior To Its Effective Date.

Whereas, heretofore, in pursuance of and in conformity with the provisions of Section 7327, et seq., Volume 4, Code of Laws of South Carolina for 1942, and a petition signed by a majority of the freeholders of the town, as shown by its taxbooks, a special election was held in the Town of Brunson on the 22nd day of May, 1951, to determine the question of whether the town should be empowered to construct, operate, and maintain a waterworks system, and to issue not exceeding seventyfive thousand dollars ($75,000.00) of General Obligation Bonds of the town, the proceeds thereof to be used to defray the cost of constructing a waterworks system, which election resulted favorably upon the question submitted; and, Whereas, subsequent thereto, viz., on July 31, 1951, Section 7327, et seq., was repealed by the Municipal Bond Act of South Carolina (Act No.

409 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina for 1951, the statute recodifying and redefining the procedure by which municipal corporations in this state might issue general obligation bonds) ; and, Whereas, the Town of Brunson has, subsequent to July 31, 1951, adopted an ordinance providing for the issuance and sale of certain of the bonds authorized by the election to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, an agency of the United States of America; and, Whereas, by reason of the repealing clause in the Municipal Bond Act, question has arisen as to whether the proceedings taken prior to July 31, 1951, are of force; and, OY JU NU OY Whereas, it was the intention of the General Assembly, in enacting Act 409 of 1951 that it merely affect proceedings taken subsequent to its effective date, but that it should in no way affect the validity of or right to issue bonds duly voted prior to the effective date of the act, provided all proceedings taken subsequent to such effective date conformed with the act.

Legislative findings and intent as to the effect of Municipal Bond Act on certain bonds.The General Assembly finds that the matters set forth in the preambles to this act are in all respects true and correct and express the correct legislative intent in the enactment of Act 409 of 1951.

Bond election and bonds validated, Brunson.All proceedings taken by the Town of Brunson in ordering, holding and conducting the election heretofore referred to stand validated, confirmed and approved, and all bonds issued or to be issued pursuant thereto shall be valid and binding general obligations of the town, according to their tenor and effect Section 3. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed Section 4. Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor

691 An Act To Provide For The Seizure And Disposition Of Vehicles And Other Personal Property Abandoned On The Roads Or Highways Of The State Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina Section 1.
Act 281 of 1949 amendedseizure and disposition of vehicles and other personalty abandoned on highways.Section 110 of Act No.
281, Acts of 1949, entitled Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways be, and the same is hereby amended by adding a new subsection to be designated as subsection (c) as follows gw => (c) 1.
Any vehicle or other personal property which is left on any right of way of any road or highway in this state for a period of over 48 hours is hereby declared to be abandoned property.

It shall be the duty of every police officer having knowledge of such abandoned property to seize the same and have it removed for safekeeping to such place as may be designated by the sheriff of the county in which it was found, who shall thereupon be charged with its custody and disposition as hereinafter provided.

The sheriff having custody of such abandoned property shall forthwith: (a) Post in three public places within the county a notice, setting forth the fact of his possession, a full description of such property, the place at which it was found, the place at which it is being held, the amount of any charges connected with his possession of it, and that unless said property shall be reclaimed within thirty days after he posting of such notice it will be advertised for sale and sold as hereinafter provided.

(b) Mail such notice by registered mail to the owner of such abandoned property and to the holder or holders of any liens upon said property, if the names and addresses of such owner and/or lien holders can be ascertained by reasonable inquiry.

If thirty days shall elapse after notice, by mail or posting, as required in the preceding paragraph, is given and the property has not been reclaimed, the sheriff shall advertise such property for sale, for cash at public auction, giving such information as is required above for a posted notice along with the time, date and place of proposed sale.
Such advertisement shall be published at least once a week for three succeeding weeks prior to the proposed sale in a newspaper published in the county where such property was abandoned.

Any owner or lien holder having an interest in such property may reclaim the same at any time before such public sale by presenting evidence of right to possession satisfactory to the sheriff in possession, and tendering payment of all charges and fees incurred by the sheriff or his county in possession of such property.

Any person, firm or corporation authorized by a sheriff to tow, haul or store any abandoned property shall have a lien against such property for the reasonable value of such services which shall be prior to all other liens.

If abandoned property is not reclaimed prior to the time of any advertised sale of it, the sheriff shall sell it and pay from the proceeds all costs and charges incurred in handling, in advertising the sale of, and in selling such property, and any balance remaining shall be paid to the county treasurer of his county for credit to the general fund of the county.

For a period of not in excess of two years after the payment of any sum into the general fund of any county on account of the sale of any such abandoned property, county governing boards of the respective counties are authorized and directed to hear and determine claims of any persons claiming to be damaged by the sale of any such abandoned property and to make awards to owners or lien holders as their interests may appear, but in no event shall such award he in excess of the amount received by the county on account of the sale of the property which is the subject of any such claim.
The decision of the county governing body in connection with any such claim shall be final.

This act shall apply to any abandonments which may have occurred prior to the passage of this act in cases where neither the ewner nor lien holder has claimed the property, but in such cases, the first notice required to be given may be given at any time within thirty days after the approval of this act by the Governor. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 25th day of January, 1952.

692 An Act To Amend Section 28562, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To The Forfeited Land Commission For Dorchester County, So As To Increase To Two The Membership Of The Commission And To Further Provide For The Members Compensation.

28562, 1942 Code, amendedDorchester County forfeited land commission.Section 28562, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is amended by striking out the section and inserting in lieu thereof the following: section 28562.
(1) The Forfeited Land Commission of Dorchester County, shall consist of two members.

(2) The members of the Forfeited Land Commission of Dorchester County, hereinabove provided for, shall be appointed by the Legislative Delegation of Dorchester County in the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina, and that their term of office shall be four years and until his successor shall be appointed and qualified.
The legislative delegation shall also have power to fill any vacancy arising in the membership of the Forfeited Land Commission on account of death, resignation or otherwise for the unexpired term.

The legislative delegation shall have the power to fill any and all vacancies arising in the membership of the Forfeited Land Commission, from any and all causes whatsoever, either for the full or unexpired term.

(3) The members of the Forfeited Land Commission of Dorchester County, hereinabove provided for, shall give bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), the premiums on the bond to be paid by the County of Dorchester as in case of other county officers.

(4) The Forfeited Land Commission of Dorchester County is hereby vested with all the rights, powers, duties and privileges with which county forfeited land commissions are now vested under the general law, and in addition thereto, the following: (1) To perfect the title to any property which the Forfeited Land Commission may have title to.

(2) To improve any lands or make repairs upon property owned by the Forfeited Land Commission, provided, the costs of improvement shall not exceed the revenues derived from the lands, in each particular instance.
(3) To lease any lands of the commission on such terms as it shall think best, and waive rent liens to enable tenants to obtain advances to make crops.

(4) To sell all or any lands owned by the Forfeited Land Commission at such price or prices as it shall deem advantageous, either for cash or on credit, as it shall deem best, taking such steps to secure the payment of the purchase price as it shall deem best.

(5) To employ an agent to actually superintend the lands, going upon the same, and actively keeping watch over the same, collecting rents and otherwise, and to obtain such clerical help as it may need.

(6) To be provided with an office in the court house and with authority to purchase such office equipment as is necessary in its opinion for the conducting of the business of the commission, including stationery, stamps, iron safe, and such other items of furniture and fixtures, including typewriter and desk, as it may deem necessary.
all of the equipment to be paid for out of the gross revenue coming to the commission.

(5) The members of the Forfeited Land Commission shall receive for their services each year ten per cent of the gross sales price of any and all lands or property sold in that year, ten per cent of the gross revenues and income otherwise received, same to be paid out of the funds in the hands of the commission and such other compensation as the General Assembly may provide.

(6) The Forfeited Land Commission shall turn over to the county treasurer the net cash on hand as to each particular item of land or property disposed of or handled just as soon as the Forfeited Land Commission is in position to make a final report on the item, that is, just as soon as the item of land or property is finally disposed on in 30 far as the Forfeited Land Commission is concerned, only one report being necessary as to each item of property or land, and such final Teport to show gross receipts, disbursements for expenses, all deductions, and net amount of cash turned over to the county treasurer.
(7) All conveyances or deeds made by former Forfeited Land Commissions of Dorchester County are hereby validated and confirmed.

(8) The Forfeited Land Commission is hereby authorized and empowered to act and function by and through the members for all purposes whatsoever, and the members are hereby authorized and empowered to act for and on behalf of the Forfeited Land Commission for all purposes whatsoever.

The Forfeited Land Commission shall keep a full and detailed set of books or records of their actings and doings, showing everything in detail, and to that end may employ such clerical assistance as it may need, paying for the same out of gross receipts, the costs as to each particular item of property not to exceed the gross receipts from such item of land or property.

In case of perfecting land titles, where court proceedings are necessary, the Forfeited Land Commission may employ attorneys and pay them for their services, the same to be paid out of the gross receipts from the particular item of land or property, and not to exceed the gross receipts derived from such item of land or property.

(9) The Forfeited Land Commission of Dorchester County is authorized and directed to record all conveyances of land made by it and to pay from the proceeds of sale thereof the recording fees of such conveyances. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 25th day of January, 1952.
693 An Act To Change The Fiscal Year For Abbeville County.
Fiscal year, Abbeville County.The fiscal year for Abbeville County shall be from the first day of July to the thirtieth day of June of the following year, inclusive.
694 An Act Providing For The Appointment Of Nine Trustees For School District No.
60 Of Abbeville County.
60, Abbeville Countyterms.The Board of Trustees, School District No.
60, of Abbeville County, shall be composed of nine members and they shall be appointed by the Board of Education of Abbeville County.
The terms of office of the initial appointees shall be as follows: three shall expire on July 1, 1953, three on July 1, 1954, and three on July 1, 1955.
In the order of appointment the county board shall designate the length of the respective terms.
Thereafter, their regular terms shall be for periods of three years.
The appointees shall hold until their successors have been appointed and qualify.
The board as thus constituted shall have and exercise all of the powers and duties now conferred under the general law on boards of school district trustees.
695 An Act To Officially Name The County Health Centers In Chesterfield County In Honor Of The Deceased Veterans Of Chesterfield County.

The Chesterfield County Memorial Health Centers.The county health centers located at Cheraw, Chesterfield, Pageland, Jefferson, Mt. Croghan, Ruby, Patrick and McBee are officially named The Chesterfield County Memorial Health Centers in honor of the deceased veterans of Chesterfield County.
Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 25th day of January, 1952.

696 An Act To Validate The Undertaking Of The City Of Lancaster With The Springs Cotton Mills, A South Carolina Corporation, To Jointly Construct And Operate Sewage Disposal Facilities For The City And Certain Areas Adjacent To The City Owned By Said Corporation, To Empower The City Of Lancaster To Operate Sewage Disposal Facilities Beyond Its Corporate Limits And To Establish Rates And Charges Therefor, And To Validate The Issuance By The City Of Lancaster Of Seven Hundred TwentyFive Thousand Dollars ($725,000.00) Combined Water And Sewer Revenue Bonds Of February 1, 1952.

Whereas, the proximity of the mill village of the Springs Cotton mills (hereinafter referred to as the mill) to Lancaster (hereinafter referred to as the city) and the growth of each has created a sewage disposal problem, requiring prompt solution if proper health conditions in both areas are to be maintained; and, Whereas, as a consequence thereof surveys have been made, indicating that the most economic approach to the problem would be the construction of a sewage disposal plant to treat and dispose of sewage from both areas, and the construction and maintenance of further sewage trunks, mains and laterals in both areas, some of which would serve the two areas jointly; and, Whereas, heretofore, under date of June 19, 1951, the mill and the city entered into an agreement wherein it was provided: (1) That the city and the mill would undertake the construction of the sewage disposal facilities found necessary in order to safeguard the health of both areas; (2) That the cost of such construction would be shared in accordance with the formulas prescribed by such contract; (3) That the city will, upon the completion of the improvements, operate the same as a part of its combined water and sewer system; and, (4) That the cost of operating and maintaining the improvements should be shared, in accordance with the formula prescribed by such contract; and, Whereas, the mill proposes to pay its share of the cost of the improvements, but the city must raise its share of the cost of the improvements through the issuance of combined water and sewer revNo.

69 OU RO enue bonds in the amount of seven hundred twentyfive thousand dollars ($725,000.00), issued pursuant to Chapter 187, Volume 4, Ccde of Laws of South Carolina for 1942, as amended ; and, Whereas, the city has arranged to sell seven hundred twentyfive thousand dollars ($725,000.00) of such bonds, but questions have arisen as to: (a) the right of the city to act jointly with the mill in the program, (b) the right of the city to operate sewage disposal facilities to serve areas beyond its corporate limits, (c) the right of the city to contract with the mill for the cost of operating and maintaining the improvements for an indefinite time, and (d) its right to establish rates and charges for such services beyond its corporate limits; and, Whereas, the General Assembly finds that the construction of the improvements is necessary to safeguard the health of both areas, and that the plan contemplated by the mill and the city is both economical and practical; and, Whereas, by reason thereof, the General Assembly is minded to set at rest any question with respect to such plan, and to validate, approve and confirm the contract between the mill and the city, to affirm the right of the city to maintain sewage disposal facilities beyond its corporate limits, and to empower the city to establish rates and charges for such service.
Facts in preamble true and correct.The General Assembly finds that the facts set forth in the preambles to this act are in all respects true and correct.

Action of Lancaster in entering into contract mentioned in preamble confirmed.The General Assembly validates, ratifies and confirms the action of the city council of Lancaster in entering into the contract mentioned in the preambles to this act.

Lancaster may provide sewerage disposal facilities in certain areas.The General Assembly approves and authorizes and empowers the city council of Lancaster to provide sewage disposal facilities to serve the inhabitants of the city and those in the areas next adjoining the city, known as The Springs Cotton Mills Village.

Combined water and sewer revenue bonds of Lancaster ratified The General Assembly validates, ratifies, approves and confirms all action heretofore or hereafter taken by the city council of Lancaster in issuing seven hundred twentyfive thousand dollars ($725,000.00) of combined water and sewer revenue bonds of February 1, 1952, payable, as contemplated by Chapter 187, Volume 4, Code of Laws of South Carolina for 1942, as amended, from the revenues of its combined water and sewer system, in order to finance the citys share of the cost of the sewage disposal program hereinbefore referred to including a portion of the interest to become due on the bonds during the period of the construction of the facilities.

Charges for sewage disposal facilities furnish beyond limits of Lancaster.The General Assembly authorizes and empowers the city council of Lancaster to establish rates and charges for sewage disposal facilities furnished the areas beyond its corporate limits, and empowers the city to make provision therefor either through a contract of long duration, or through a system of rates and charges on monthly or annual basis.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 25th day of January, 1952.

65, Acts And Joint Resolutions Of South Carolina, 1949, Relating To The Lee County Public Library Commission, So As To Change The Date Of The Annual Meeting Thereof.

The commission shall hold an annual meeting in June of each year, at which time it shall elect a chairman, a secretary, an executive committee and such other officers and committees as it deems necessary, who shall hold office until the next annual meeting; the commission shall have authority to make such rules and regulations, and enforce the same, as are necessary for carrying 0.

701 An Act To Create The Kershaw County Recreation Commission, Prescribe The Membership Thereof, Their Terms Of Office And Their Powers And Duties.
Beit enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1.
Kershaw County Recreation CommissionThere is hereby created the Kershaw County Recreation Commission.

The commission shall be composed of fifteen members and they shall be appointed by the Governor upon the recommendation of a majority of the Kershaw County Legislative Delegation, including the Senator.
Their terms of office shall be for two years and until their successors have been appointed and qualified.
In addition to the appointed members each mayor of each incorporated town of Kershaw County shall be ex officio members of the board.
Immediately after the initial appointment the board shall organize and select one of their members as chairman and one as secretary.
The board shall meet at such time and at such places as the members of the board shall by majority vote determine.

The board shall be charged with the duty of investigating recreational facilities available in Kershaw County, and shall make their recommendation each year to the legislative delegation of Kershaw County as to recreational needs in the county, Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 4th day of February, 1952.
702 An Act Increasing the Members Of The County Board Of Education Of Florence County From Seven To Nine Members.

Florence County Board of Education.The County Board of Education of Florence County shall be composed of nine members, one of whom shall be the county superintendent of education and the other eight shall be appointed by the Governor upon the written recommendation of a majority of the county legislative delegation and the Senator.
Their regular terms of office shall be for a period of four years.
The initial term of the additional members herein provided for shall run from the date of his appointment to July 1, 1956 and thereafter the term of his successor shall be for four years.
The duties and powers of the board as constituted under this act shall be those prescribed by law.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 4th day of February, 1952.

705 An Act To Amend Section 14J Of Act No.

858 Of The Acts Of 1950, Known As The South Carolina Election Law, So As To Provide That Every Candidate In A Municipal Election In Richland County Shall File His Pledge With The City Clerk Or Comparable Official Of The Municipality In Which He Is A Candidate Rather Than With The Clerk Of The Court Of Common Pleas.
Act 858 of 1950 amendedcandidates pledge for municipal elections, Richland County.Section 14J of Act No.

858 of the Acts of 1950 is amended by changing the colon at the end of the first paragraph to a period and by adding the following paragraph after the first paragraph: Provided, that in Richland County every candidate in a municipal electiongeneral, special, or primaryshall make the following pledge and file it with the city clerk or comparable official of the municipality in which he is a candidate: I, the undersigned , of the city or town of , county of , State of South Carolina, candidate for the office of , hereby pledge that I will not give money, or use intoxicating liquors, for the purpose of obtaining or influencing votes, and that I shall, at the conclusion of the campaign and before the election, render to the city clerk (or comparable official), under oath, an itemized statement of all monies spent or provided by me during the campaign for campaign purposes up to that time, and I further pledge that I will, immediately after the election render an itemized statement, under oath, showing all further monies spent or provided by me in said election.

ied The section, when so amended, shall read as follows :Section 14J: Every candidate in an election, general, special or primary, shall make the following pledge and file the same with the clerk of court of common pleas for the county in which he is a candidate, unless he should be a candidate in more than one county, in which case he shall file same with the Secretary of State, before he shall enter upon his campaign, to wit: I, the undersigned , of the county of , and State of South Carolina, candidate for the office of , hereby pledge that I will not give money, or use intoxicating liquors, for the purpose of obtaining or influencing votes, and that I shall, at the conclusion of the campaign and before the election, render to the clerk of court (or Secretary of State as hereinbefore provided), under oath, an itemized statement of all monies spent or provided by me during the campaign for campaign purposes up to that time, and I further pledge that I will, immediately after the election render an itemized statement, under oath, showing all further monies spent or provided by me in said election. Provided, that in Richland County every candidate in a municipal electiongeneral, special, or primaryshall make the following pledge and file it with the city clerk or comparable official of the municipality in which he is a candidate: I, the undersigned , of the city or town of , county of , State of South Carolina, candidate for the office of , hereby pledge that I will not give money, or use intoxicating liquors, for the purpose of obtaining or influencing votes, and that I shall, at the conclusion of the campaign and before the election, render to the city clerk (or comparable official), under oath, an itemized statement of all monies spent or provided by me during the campaign for campaign purposes up to that time, and I further pledge that I will, immediately after the election render an itemized statement, under oath, showing all further monies spent or provided by me in said election. A failure to comply with this provision shall render such election and void, in so far as the candidate who fails to file the statement herein required, but shall not affect the validity of the election of any candidate complying with this section.

Any violation of the provisions of Section 14I or of the pledge required in Section 14J shall be a misdemeanor, and any person, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars nor more than five hundred dollars, or be imprisoned at hard labor for not less than one month nor more than six months, or both fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court. 706 An Act To Provide For A Board Of Assessors And Equalization For The Property Taxes In McCormick County.

Board of assessors and equilization, McCormick County.The Auditor, Treasurer and Superintendent of Education of McCormick County are hereby authorized and directed to appoint and name a county board of assessors to consist of ten taxpayers of McConnick County whose duty it will be to look after the valuation, assessment and return of property for taxation in McCormick County and who shall serve for one year and shall be appointed during the month of March of each year.

The ten men named by the Auditor, Treasurer and Superintendent of Education of McCormick County shall have the duty of equalization of property for taxes as now provided for under the general law of this state.

The ten men who shall compose the County Board of Assessors and Equalization of McCormick County and who will be appointed as above set forth, shall be selected so that each section of McCormick County shall have representation on the board Section 2.

Oathduty.Before assuming their duties as members of the Board of Assessors and Equalization of McCormick County, IU each shall take an oath that he will fairly and impartially assess and equalize property values for the purpose of taxation, which said oath shall be filed in the office of the Clerk of Court for McCormick County, South Carolina.

The ten members of the board shall be charged with the duty and responsibility of fairly and justly equalizing all of the property of McCormick County and make every effort to see that all property is properly assessed for the purpose of taxation.
Pay.Each member of said board so appointed shall receive the sum of fifty dollars per year for his services rendered in the capacity of tax assessor for the county.
Time effective.This act shall take effect July 1, 1952. Approved the 12th day of March, 1952.

9290, 1942 Code, amendedinterest of refunding revenue bonds.Section 9290, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is amended by striking therefrom the words, may bear interest at such rate or rates not exceeding the maximum rate of interest borne by the notes, bonds or other obligations refinanced thereby, and inserting in lieu thereof the following: may bear such rate or rates of interest as the governing body shall determine, so that Section 9290 when amended, shall read as follows: section 9290.

The refunding bonds may be issued in one or more series, may bear such date or dates, may mature at such time or times not exceeding the period of usefulness of the enterprise, as determined by the governing body in its discretion, nor in any event exceeding forty years from their respective dates, may bear such rate or rates of interest as the governing body shall determine, may be in such denomination or denominations, may be in such form, either coupon or registered, may carry such registration and conversion privileges, may be executed in such manner, may be payable in such medium of payment, at such place or places, may be subject to such terms of redemption, with or without premium, may be declared or become due before the maturity date thereof, may provide for the replacement of mutilated, destroyed, stolen or lost bonds, may be authenticated in such manner and upon compliance with such conditions, and may contain such other terms and covenants, as may be provided by resolution or resolutions of the governing body of the municipality.

Pickens County Board of Education The number of members of the County Board of Education of Pickens County is increased from seven to nine, eight of whom shall be appointed by the Governor upon the recommendation of the Senator and at least onehalf of the members of the House of Representatives of said county, and shall serve terms of four years each.

710 An Act To Amend Section 1 Of An Act Entitled An Act To Establish A Commission To Be Known As The Florence CityCounty Agricultural Commission And To Define Its Powers And Duties., Approved February 20, 1950, So As To Provide For The Appointment Of An Additional Member On The Commission.

Florence CityCounty Agricultural Commission.Section 1 of an act entitled An Act To Establish A Commission To Be Known As The Florence CityCounty Agricultural Commission And To Define Its Powers And Duties., approved February 20, 1950, and designated as Act No.

750 of the Acts of 1950, is amended as follows: Strike out on line three the word five and insert in lieu thereof the word six; add on line six immediately after the words Tixtension Service the following: one by the District Supervisor of Agricultural Education,; strike out on line seven the words fifth and four and insert in lieu thereof the words sixth and five, so that when so amended the section shall read as follows: section 1. There is hereby established a commission to be known as the Florence CityCounty Agricultural Commission. It shall be composed of six members, who shall be selected as follows: one by the Legislative Delegation from the County, one by the City Council of the City of Florence, one by the Florence Chamber of Commerce, one by the District Agent of Clemson College Extension Service, one by the District Supervisor of Agricultural Education, and the other, the sixth member, shall be selected by the five members selected as provided above.

Their successors shall be filled as provided for the original appointments: and any vacancy occurring for any cause shall be filled in the manner provided above for filling the office in which the vacancy has occurred.

711 An Act To Amend Section 5573, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, 80 As To Consolidate The School Districts In Dillon County Into Three Centralized School Districts; To Provide For Trustees Thereof And Their Duties And Powers; To Provide For The Issuance Of Bonds For The School Districts And The Payment Of Same.

5573, 1942 Code, amendedschool districts, Dillon Countytrusteesschoolsissuance of bendstaxes.Section 5573, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is amended by striking out all of same and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be Section 5573: section 5573.

(1) The County Board of Education of Dillon County is required to divide the County of Dillon into three centralized school districts by consolidating the present common school districts and high school districts within the county.
The centralized school districts shall be laid off so as to conform with the lines of the present high school districts, and shall be named Lake View District No.
1, Dillon District No.
2 and Latta District No.
Each school district so formed by the county board shall be a body corporate with a board of school trustees as hereinafter provided for.

The board of trustees for each centralized school district are hereby authorized, directed and empowered to establish, maintain and operate schools within its district as they deem to the best interest of the citizens of the district, and each school established and operated shall be entitled to all the privileges and benefits of centralized schools approved and accepted by the state board of education.

(2) The board of school trustees of each centralized school district to be established hereunder shall be composed of five members to be appointed by the county board of education as now provided by law.

The board of trustees of each of the centralized school districts is hereby vested with the power to do all acts necessary to the establishment, maintenance and operation of the schools within the district, and for the purpose of providing the funds for the purchase of lands, construction of buildings and equipment of buildings, the board of trustees may issue and sell bonds of each of the centralized school districts in an amount not exceeding eight per cent of the assessed value of the taxable property within the district.
The money derived from the sale of the bonds shall be deposited with the Treasurer of Dillon County and paid out on order of the board of trustees of the district involved.

(3) The bonds issued pursuant to paragraph 2 hereof shall be signed by the chairman and clerk of the board of trustees of the centralized school district issuing them, and if a corporate seal shall have been adopted it shall be affixed thereto.
The bonds may pledge the full faith, credit and taxing power of the centralized school district issuing same.
The honds shall be serial coupon bonds and shall mature as the board of trustees may determine.
The bonds shall bear such rate or rates of interest as are deemed advisable.
The coupons attached to the bonds may bear the facsimile signature of the chairman and clerk of the board of trustees.

(4) In addition to all other taxes, there is hereby levied upon all of the taxable property of each of the centralized school districts issuing bonds hereunder, a tax sufficient to pay the principal and interest of the bonds when same shall mature.
The Auditor of Dillon County shall levy and the treasurer shall collect such tax as other taxes are levied and collected.
(3) All lawful levies for maintenance and all lawful levies for bonds shall be at the same uniform rate on the assessed valuation of each and all of the school districts consolidated herein.
(6) Any or all bonds issued or to be issued under the authority of this section shall be exempt from state, county and municipal taxation.

No bonds or notes shall be issued by any board of trustees unless they have the approval of a majority of the Dillon County Legislative Delegation, including the Senator. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.

712 An Act Authorizing the State of South Carolina To Enter Into A Compact With Any Other State Of The United States Of America For Mutual Helpfulness In Meeting Any Civil Defense Emergency Or Disaster When The Governor Of This State Shall Consider It Advisable And Shall Issue A Proclamation Agreeing To Such Compact With Any Other State Within The Union.

Whereas, the Congress of the United States of America has granted its consent for the States of the Union to enter into Civil Defense Compacts with each other by an Act, entitled Federal Civil Defense Act of One Thousand Nine Hundred and Fifty (Public Law 920, 81st Congress, Second Session, Approved January 12, One Thousand Nine Hundred and Fifty One), and Whereas, by Act No.

896 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of 1950 the State of South Carolina established a Civil Defense Agency and other organizations for civil defense within this State and prescribing the powers and duties thereof but said Act of 1950 did not authorize the State of South Carolina to enter into compacts with other states, now, therefore, Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina = Section 1.

State may enter into compact with other states for mutual helpfulness in civil defense emergency.The State of South Carolina by and through the Governor of the State is hereby authorized and empowered to enter into a compact with any State of the Union for mutual helpfulness in meeting any civil defense emergency or disaster which may arise in this State or in a State with which South Carolina may enter into a compact.

Terms of compact.The compact authorized by the provision of this act shall be in form as hereinbelow set out with such modifications and restrictions as the Governor may deem necessary for the proper protection of the best interests of the State of South Carolina, towit: INTERSTATE CIVIL DEFENSE DISASTER COMPACT BETWEEN THE STATES OF AND SOUTH CAROLINA The contracting States solemnly agree: Article 1.

The purpose of this compact is to provide mutual aid between the states in meeting any emergency or disaster from enemy attack, including sabotage and subversive acts and direct attacks by bombs, shellfire, and atomic, radiological, chemical, bacteriological means, and other enemy weapons.

The prompt, full and effective utilization of the resources of the respective states, including such resources as may be available from the United States Government or any other source, are essential to the safety, care and welfare of the people of the states in the event of enemy action, and any other resources, including personnel, equipment or supplies, shall be incorporated into a plan or plans of mutual aid to be developed between the civil defense agencies or similar bodies of the states that are parties to the compact.
The Directors of Civil Defense of party states shall constitute a committee to formulate plans and take all necessary steps for the implementation of this compact.
It shall be the duty of each state to formulate civil defense plans and programs for application within the state.

There shall be frequent consultation between the representatives of the states and with the United States Government and the free exchange of information and plans, including inventories of any materials and equipment available for civil defense.

In carrying out the civil defense plans and programs the party states shall so far as possible provide and follow uniform standards, practices, and rules and regulations including (a) Insignia, arm bands and any other distinctive articles to designate and distinguish the different civil defense services (b) Blackouts and practice blackouts, air raid drills, mobilization of civil defense forces and other tests and exercises (c) Warnings and signals for drills or attacks and the mechanical devices to be used in connection therewith (d) The effective screening or extinguishing of all lights and lighting devices and appliances (e) Shutting off water mains, gas mains, electric power connections and the suspension of all other utility services (f{) All materials or equipment used or to be used for civil defense purposes in order to assure that such materials and equipment will be easily and freely interchangeable when used in or by any other party state g) The conduct of civilians and the movement and cessation of movement of pedestrians and vehicular traffic, prior, during and subsequent to drills or attacks.
(h) The safety of public meetings or gatherings.
(i) Mobile support units.
Article 3 Any party state requested to render mutual aid shall take such action as is necessary to provide and make available the resources covered by this compact in accordance with its terms.
The state rendering aid may withold resources to the extent necessary to provide reasonable protection for such state.

Each party state shall extend to the civil defense forces of any other party state, while operating within its state limits under the terms and conditions of this compact, the same powers, except that of arrest unless specifically authorized by the receiving state, duties, rights, privileges and immunities as if they were performing their duties in the state in which normally employed or rendering services.

Civil defense forces will continue under the command and control of their regular leaders but the organizational units will come under the operational control of the civil defense authorities of the state receiving assistance Article 4. Whenever any person holds a license, certificate or other permit issued by any state evidencing the meeting of qualifications for professional, mechanical or other skills, such person may render aid involving the skill in any party state to meet an emergency or disaster and the state shall give due recognition to such license, certificate or other permit as if issued in the state in which aid is rendered for the duration of the emergency or disaster only.

No party state or its officers or employees rendering aid in another state pursuant to this compact shall be liable on account of any act or omission in good faith on the part of such forces while so engaged, or on account of the maintenance or use of any equipment or supplies in that connection.

Inasmuch as it is probable that the pattern and detail of the machinery for mutual aid among two or more states may differ from that appropriate among other party states, this instrument contains elements of a broad base common to all states, and nothing herein shall preclude any state from entering into supplementary agreements with another state or states.

Such supplementary agreements may comprehend, but shall not be limited to, provisions for evacuation and reception of injured and other persons, and the exchange of medical, fire, police, public utility, reconnaisance, welfare, transportation and communications personnel, equipment and supplies.

Each party state shall provide for the payment of compensation and death benefits to injured members of the civil defense forces of that state and the representatives of deceased members of such forces in case such members sustain injuries or are killed while rendering aid pursuant to this compact, in the same manner and on the same terms as if the injury or death were sustained within such state.

Any party state rendering aid in another state pursuant to this compact shall be reimbursed by the party state receiving such aid for any loss or damage to, or expense incurred in the operation of any equipment answering a request for aid, and for the cost incurred in connection with such requests.

Any aiding party state may assume in whole or in part such loss, damage, expense, or other cost, or may loan equipment or donate such services to the receiving party state without charge or cost, and any two or more party states may enter into supplementary agreements establishing a different allocation of costs as among these states.

The United States Government may relieve the state receiving aid from any liability and reimburse the state supplying civil defense forces for the compensation paid to and the transportation, subsistence and maintenance expenses of such forces during the time of the rendition of such aid or assistance outside the state and may also pay fair and reasonable compensation for WU the use or utilization of the supplies, materials, equipment or facilities so utilized or consumed.

Plans for the orderly evacuation and reception of the civilian population as the result of an emergency or disaster shall be worked out between representatives of the party states and the various local civil defense areas.

Such plans shall include the manner of transporting evacuees, the number of evacuees to be received in different areas, the manner in which food, clothing, housing, and medical care will be provided, the registration of the evacuees, the providing of facilities for the notification of relatives or friends and the forwarding of evacuees to other areas or the bringing in of additional materials, supplies, and all other relevant factors.

The plans shall provide that the party state receiving evacuees shall be reimbursed generally for the outofpocket expenses incurred in receiving and caring for the evacuees, for expenditures for transportation, food, clothing, medicines and medical care and like items.
The expenditures shall be reimbursed by the party state of which the evacuees are tesidents.
or by the United States Government under plans approved by it.
After the termination of the emergency or disaster the party state of which the evacuees are residents shall assume the responsibility for the ultimate support or repatriation of such evacuees.

The committee established pursuant to Article 1 of this compact may request the Civil Defense Agency of the United States Government to act as an informational and coordinating body under this compact, and representatives of the agency of the United States Government may attend meetings of the committee.

This compact shall become operative between the State of and the State of South Carolina immediately upon its being entered into by the duly authorized officials of such states, and shall be subject to approval by Congress unless prior Congressional approval has been given.

Duly authenticated copies of this compact and of such supplementary agreements as may be entered into shall, at the time of their approval, be deposited with each of the party states and with the Civil Defense Agency and other appropriate agencies of the United States Government.
This compact shall continue in force and remain binding on each party state until the legislature or the Governor of the party State takes action to withdraw therefrom.
Such action shall not be effective until thirty days after notice has been sent by the Governor of the party state desiring to withdraw to the Governor of the other party state.
The term state shall include any territory or possession of the United States, the District of Columbia, and any neighboring foreign country or province or state thereof.
This compact shall be construed to effectuate the purposes stated in Article 1.

If any provision of this compact is declared unconstitutional, or the applicability to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the constitutionality of the remainder of this compact and the applicability to other persons and circumstances shall not be FOR THE STATE OF FOR THE STATE OFSOUTH CAROLINA Date , 1952 Date 1952 ATTEST: ATTEST: Bes ee 7 ay Secuetany of State Secretary of State Section 3. RepealAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 6th day of February, 1952

713 An Act To Amend Section 13962, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Restricting The Operation Of Certain Mechanical Or Automatic Music Boxes In Clarendon, Richland And Kershaw Counties, So As To Extend Such Restrictions To Include Georgetown County.

13962, 1942 Code, amendedhours operate music machine outside of municipalities in Clarendon, Georgetown, Kershaw and Richland Counties.Section 13962, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is amended by striking out in line 7 of the section the words Clarendon, Richland and Kershaw and inserting in lieu thereof the words Clarendon, Georgetown, Kershaw and Richland, so that when amended the section shall read as follows: 13692.

It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee or custodian or other person, for himself or another, of any nicolodeon, piccolo, phonograph or other mechanical or automatic music box or machine to operate the same, or suffer or permit the operation thereof, in or abeut any store, filling station, highway or other public or semipublic place outside of the limits of any incorporated town in Clarendon, Georgetown, Kershaw and Richland Counties after 10:30 o'clock P. M., or before 7 :00 oclock A. M., or at any time in hearing distance of any church during church or other religious services.

Every violation of the terms hereof shall be a misdemeanor and any person upon conviction shall be subject, for each violation to a fine of not less than five ($5.00) dollars, and not more than fifty ($50.00) dollars, or imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 14th day of February, 1952
714 An Act To Amend Section 6431, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To Cotton Weighers In Lancaster And Heath Springs, In Lancaster County, So As To Increase Their Compensation.

6431, 1942 Code, amendedpay of cotton weighers, Heath Springs and LancasterSection 6431, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, relating to cotton weighers in Lancaster and Heath Springs, in Lancaster County, is amended by striking out on line 9 the word twenty and inserting in lieu thereof the word thirty; by striking out on line 10 the word ten and inserting in lieu thereof the word fifteen; by striking out on line 11 the word ten and inserting in lieu thereof the word fifteen. The section, when amended, shall read as follows: 6431.

The county commissioners of Lancaster County are authorized and directed to order elections to be held in the towns of lancaster, and Heath Springs, in Lancaster County, on the second Tuesday in August, 1899, and every two years thereafter, for the purpose of electing a public cotton weigher for each of said towns, respectively ; and said commissioners shall make such rules and regulations for the government of such elections as to them shall seem proper; they shall also fix the compensation to be received by each of said cotton weighers, said compensation not to exceed thirty cents for each bale weighed by them, fifteen cents of which shall be paid by the seller and fifteen cents by the buyer, and the weighers shall mark each bale weighed in plain letters and figures as required by the buyer.

Said commissioners shall canvass the votes polled at said elections, declare said elections, and issue a commission to the person declared to be elected: provided, that no person elected public cotton weigher under the provisions of this section shall receive a commission to enter upon the discharge of his duties as such public cotton weigher until he has entered into a good and sufficient bond, with two or more sureties, in the sum of one thousand dollars, payable to said commissioners, and conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties as such cotton weigher, said bond to be approved by said commissioners.

Any other person than a duly elected and commissioned cotton weigher, charging or receiving any sum or sums of money or other valuable consideration for weighing cotton in said county of Lancaster, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined a sum not exceeding one hundred dollars, or imprisonment for a term not exceeding thirty days.

The said commissioners are authorized to fill any vacancy caused by the death or resignation of any cotton weigher clected under the provisions of this section by appointment. Section 2. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 14th day of February, 1952

715 An Act To Amend Section 3891, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To The Terms Of Office Of The Supervisor Of Abbeville County, So As To Provide That The Term Of Office Of The Supervisor Which Begins On June 30, 1953, Shall End On December 31, 1956, And Thereafter The Regular Terms Shall Be For Four Years.

3891, 1942 Code, amendedterms of supervisor, Abbeville County.Section 3891, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, relating to the terms of office of the Supervisor of Abbeville County, is amended by striking out the last sentence of the section and by inserting in lieu thereof the following: The term of office of the County Supervisor which begins on June 30, 1953, shall expire on December 31, 1956.

Thereafter and commencing January 1, 1957, the regular terms of office of the supervisor shall be for four years and until his successor qualifies., so that when so amended the section shall read as follows: section 3891.

The present term of office of the auditor for Abbeville County shall expire on June 30th, 1931, and that the term of office for said auditor shall be for a term of four (4) years and shall expire on June 30th of every fourth year thereafter.
The term of office of the County Supervisor which begins on June 30, 1953, shall expire on December 31, 1956.

Thereafter and commencing January 1, 1957, the regular terms of office of the supervisor shall be for four years and until his successor qualifies. Section 2. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 14th day of February, 1952.
716 An Act To Amend Subsection (7) Of Section 1781, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Amended By Act No.
921 Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions Of The General Assembly, 1950, Relating To Hunting Season In Chesterfield County, To Change The Date Of Open Season For Deer.
1781, 1942 Code, amendedopen season on deer, Chesterfield County.Subsection (7) of Section 1781, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as amended by Act No.

921 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1950, is amended by striking the word and figure October 1st in the last line between the words from and to and inserting in lieu thereof the word and figure August 15th, so that when amended Subsection (7) shall read as follows: (7) The open season for hunting certain game in Chesterfield County shall be as follows: the open season for hunting quail and partridges shall be from Thanksgiving day to February 15th, inclusive; the open season for hunting squirrel shall be from October 1st to February Ist, inclusive; the open season for hunting deer, bucks only, shall be from August 15th to January Ist, inclusive. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.

717 An Act To Amend Section 968, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To The Establishment And Jurisdiction Of The Municipal Courts In Cities Having A Population Of Fifteen Hundred And Not Over Twenty Thousand, According To The Last Census, So As To Allow The Mayor And Council Of The City Of Aiken To Increase Or Diminish The Salary Of The City Recorder Of Aiken During His Term Of Office.

968, 1942 Code, amendedsalary of recorder, Aiken.Section 968, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is IO amended by adding at the end of the section the following paragraph to read as follows: The salary of the city recorder in Aiken may be increased or diminished during his term of office by the mayor and city council. 718 An Act To Make Appropriations To Meet The Ordinary Expenses Of The State Government For The Fiscal Year Beginning July 1, 1952, To Regulate The Expenditure Of Funds Therefor, To Provide For The Issuance Of $5,000,000.00 In Bonds For Permanent Improvement At The 8.

State Hospital And To Pledge A Sufficient Amount Of The States Income Tax To The Payment Thereof, To Provide Automatic Property Liens To Secure The Payment Of Fees For Care And Treatment At The State Hospital, To Authorize A Loan Or The Issuance Of Bonds In The Sum Of $200,000.00 For Permanent Improvements At The State Penitentiary And To Pledge Certain Penitentiary Revenues To The Payment Thereof, To Amend Act No.

211 Of The Acts Of 1945 Relating To Taxes On The Sale Of Alcoholic Liquors, To Repeal Section 95 Of Act 379 Of The Acts Of 1951 Relating To Bottled Drinks, And To Further Define The Terms Bottle And Bottled Drinks As Used In section 2532 To 2554 Code Of Laws 1942, To Define The Term Pure Fruit And Vegetable Juices As Carried In Act 539 Of The Acts Of 1946 As Amended, To Authorize The Use Of Business License Meter Impressions In Lieu Of State Revenue Stamps, To Provide For The Disposition Of Fees Paid To The Probate Judges Of This State By The Tax Commission, To Remove The Gasoline Tax On Aviation Gasoline For The Fiscal Year 195253 And To Impose The Retail Sales Tax Thereon, And Further Relating To The Fiscal Affairs Of The State Of South Carolina.

Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina Section 1 For the fiscal year 195253, except as hereinafter specifically provided, all general state revennes derived from taxation, licenses, fees, or from any other source whatsoever, and all institutional and departmental revenues or collections, including income from taxes, licenses, fees, the sale of commodities and services, refunds, and income derived from any other departmental or institutional source of activity, shall be remitted to the State Treasurer, as collected when practicable, but at least on or before the last day of each month, for credit to the General Fund of the State.

Provided, however, That refunds of such collections by state institutions, when properly approved by the authorities of same, may be made before remittance to the State Treasurer, so that, to such extent, the remittances, and the accompanying report or statement, shall be on the basis of net income.

Provided, further, That revenues derived from the General Retail Sales Tax, and the States portion of revenue derived from the Alcoholic Liquors Tax, shall be credited to a Special School Fund, and no payments shall be made from this fund except to cover appropriations herein made for the support of the public school system of the State, but any amount of such appropriations in excess of revenues credited to the Special School Fund shall be paid from the General Fund of the State.

Subject to the terms and conditions of this Act, the sums of money set forth herein; if so much be necessary, be, and the same are, hereby appropriated out of the State Treasury, to meet the ordinary operating expenses of the State Government applicable to the fiscal year 195253, and for such other purposes as may he hereinafter specifically designated.
