737 An Act To Amend Subsection (b) (1) Of Section 703586, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To Initial Determination Of Claims For Benefits Under The South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law, So As To Clarify Who May File Appeals From Such Determination.
TU OO Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1.

703586, 1942 Code, amendedinitial determination of claims for unemployment compensation benefitspayment of benefitsappeals.Subsection (b)(1) of Section 703586, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, relating to initial determination of claims for benefits under the South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law, is amended by striking out all of the subsection and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be subsection (b) (1): (b) (1).
An examiner designated by the commission shall review the claim.

An initial determination thereon shall be made promptly and shall include a determination with respect to whether or not benefits are payable, the week with respect to which benefits shall commence, and the weekly benefit amount payable.

In any case in which the payment or denial of benefits will be determined by the provisions of section 703585 (d), the examiner shall promptly transmit all of the evidence with respect to that subsection to the commission.
The commission shall designate a special examiner to make an initial determination with respect thereto on the basis of the evidence so submitted and such additional evidence as he may require.

The claimant or any other interested party may file an appeal from such determination within five days after notification thereof, but not later than seven days after the date of such notification was mailed to his last known address.

The term any other interested party shall include the last employer or employing unit, whether subject to the act or not and whether benefits may be charged to its account or not, and the last covered employer or any employing unit whose account may be charged with benefits.

If an appeal is duly filed with respect to a matter other than the weekly benefit amount or maximum amount of benefits payable, benefits with respect to the period prior to the final decision of the commission shall be paid only after such decision: provided, that if an appeal tribunal affirms an initial determination allowing benefits, such benefits shall be paid regardless of any appeal which may thereafter be taken, and provided, further, that if benefits are paid pursuant to a decision which is finally reversed in subsequent OOU aU proceedings with respect thereto, no employers account shall be charged with benefits so paid.

If subsequent to such initial determination benefits with respect to any week for which a claim has been filed are denied for reason other than matters included in the initial determination, the claimant shall be promptly notified of the denial and the reasons therefor, and may appeal therefrom in accordance with the procedure herein described for appeals from initial determinations. Section 2. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
738 An Act To Repeal Section 7035106, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To A Stamp Plan For The South Carolina Unemployment Compensation System.

7035106, 1942 Code, repealedstamp plan for unemployment compensation system.Section 7035106, Code of T.aws of South Carolina, 1942, relating to a stamp plan for the South Carolina unemployment compensation system, as amended by Section 3 of Act No.
209, Acts and Joint Resolutions of South Carolina, 1943, is repealed.
739 An Act To Amend Section 703599 (m) (1), Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Defining The Word Wages Under The South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law, So As To Further Define Wages.

703599, 1942 Code, amendedwages defined in Unemployment Compensation Law.Section 703599 (m) (1), Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, defining the word wages under the South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law, as amended by Act No.

239 of Acts and Joint Resolutions of South Carolina, 1949, is amended by striking out all of Section 703599 (m) (1) and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be designated Section 703599 (m) (1): (m) (1) Wages means all remuneration paid for personal services, including commissions and bonuses and cash value of all remuneration paid in any medium other than cash.
The reasonable cash value of remuneration paid in any medium other than cash shall be estimated and determined in accordance with rules prescribed by the commission.

Provided, however, that the term wages shall not include that part of remuneration which, after remuneration equal to three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) has been paid to an individual by an employer with respect to employment during any calendar year, is paid to such individual by such employer with respect to employment during such calendar year.

If an employer (hereinafter referred to as the successor employer) during any calendar year acquires substantially all the property used in a trade or business of another employer (hereinafter referred to as the predecessor employer), or used in a separate unit of a trade or business of a predecessor, and immediately after the acquisition employs in his trade or business an individual who immediately prior to the acquisition was employed in the trade or business of such predecessor, then, for the purpose of determining whether the successor employer has paid remuneration with respect to employment equal to three thousand dollars ($3.000.00) to such individual during such calendar year, any remuneration with respect to employment paid to such individual by such predecessor during such calendar year and prior to such acquisition shall be considered as having been paid by such successor employer.

Provided, further, that the term wages shall not include remuneration with respect to employment paid to an individual in a calendar year by an employer in this state, which, when added to remuneration with respect to employment paid to the same individual by the same employer in the same calendar year in another state or states exceeds the sum of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00), and the employer has paid contributions to such other state or states on the wages paid therein to such individual during the applicable calendar year.

Provided, further, that the term wages shall not include any amounts received from the State of South Carolina or the federal government by members of the South Carolina National Guard, the United States Naval Reserve, the Officers Reserve Corps, the Enlisted Reserve Corps, and the Reserve Corps of Marines as drill pay, including longevity pay and allowances. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect as of January 1, 1952. Approved the 21st day of February, 1952.

740 An Act To Amend Subsections (b) And (c) (1) Of Section 703588, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To Coverage Under The South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law So As To Further Provide For The Termination Of Coverage In Certain Cases.

703588, 1942 Code, amendedtermination of employer unemployment compensation coverage.Subsection (b) of Section 703588, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, relating to coverage under the South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law, is amended by striking out all of the subsection and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be subsection (b) : (b) Except as otherwise provided in subsection (c) of this section, an employing unit shall cease to be an employer subject to this act only as of the first day of January of any calendar year, only if it files with the commission by the thirtieth day of April of such year an application for termination of coverage and the commission finds that there were no twenty different weeks within the preceding calendar year, within which such employing unit had eight or more individuals in employment subject to this act.
For the purpose of this subsection, the two or more employing units mentioned in Paragraph (2) or (3) or (4+) of Section 19 (f) shall be treated as a single employing unit.

Provided, however, that any employer who shall have rendered no employment and paid no wages in South Carolina for a continuous period of one calendar year shall have the privilege of submitting an application for termination of coverage upon the resumption of employment in South Carolina. Section 2.

Sameterm of coverage of volunteer employers.Subsection (c) (1) of Section 703588, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, relating to coverage under the South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law, is amended by striking out all of the subsection and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be subsection (c) (1): (c) (1) Anemploying unit, not otherwise subject to this act, which files with the commission its written election to become an employer subject hereto for not less than two calendar years, shall, with the written approval of such election by the commission, become an employer subject to the same extent as all other employers, as of the date stated in such approval, and shall cease to be subject hereto as of Janaury first of any calendar year subsequent to such two calendar years, only if by the thirtieth day of April it has filed with the commission a written notice to that effect. Section 3. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect as of January 1, 1952. Approved the 21st day of February, 1952.
741 An Act To Amend Section 703587 (c) (3) (I), Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Amended By Act No.

816, Acts And Joint Resolutions Of South Carolina, 1950, Relating To Rates Of Contributions Under The South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law So As To Further Provide And Limit Reduced Rates Of Contributions.

703587, 1942 Code, amendedcontribution rates of employers under Unemployment Compensation Lawnonemployment due to entry into the Armed Forces.Section 703587 (c) (3) (1), Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as amended by Act No.

816, Acts and Joint Resolutions of South Carolina, 1950, relating to rates of contributions under the South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law, is amended by striking out the section and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be designated as Section 703587 (c) (3) (1): section 703587 (c) (3) (1).
Each employers rate shall be two and seventenths per cent, except as otherwise provided in the following provisions.

No employers rate shall be less than two and seventenths per cent unless and until there shall have been thirtysix consecutive calendar months throughout which any individual in his employ could have received benefits if eligible; provided, however, that on the first day of the calendar quarter following the quarter during which such thirtysix consecutive months is accomplished the commission shall compute a rate based upon the employers experience through such preceding quarter and subject to the provisions of Section 703587, Code of Laws 1942, which rate shall be applicable to the employer from the first day of such quarter until a new rate is effective following computation on the next regular computation date; provided, further, that if the commission finds that an employer ceased to render employment solely due to the closing of the business because of the entrance of one or more of the owners, officers, partners, or the majority stockholders into the armed forces of the United States, or any of its allies, or of the United Nations after January 1, 1951, such employers account shall not be terminated; and, if the business is resumed and employment rendered within two years after the discharge or release from active duty in the armed forces of such person or persons, the employers experience shall be deemed to have been continuous throughout such period.

The reserve ratio of any such employer shall be the total contributions paid by such employer minus all benefits, including benefits paid to any individual during the period such employer was in the armed forces, charged against such employers account, divided by the average of his annual payrolls for the three most recent fiscal years during the whole of which, respectively, such employer has been in business and has rendered employment.

This provision shall not be construed to authorize cash refunds and any adjustments required hereunder shall be only by credit certificate; and, provided, further, that no employer shall be permitted to pay his unemployment compensation tax at a reduced rate for any quarter when a tax execution issued in accord with Section 703594, 1942 Code of Laws, as amended, with respect to delinquent unemployment compensation tax for a previous quarter shall be unpaid and.outstanding against such employer.

The commission is hereby authorized to waive this provision in those instances in which such an employer shall comply with any agreement entered into providing for installment payments of delinquent unemployment compensation taxes placed in execution. Section 2. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect January 1, 1952. Approved the 21st day of February, 1952.

742 An Act To Amend Section 703587 (c), Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Last Amended, Relating To Contributions Under The South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law, So As To Further Provide Conditions For The Transfer Of Accumulated Reserves And Experience Ratings To Certain Successor Employers.

703587, 1942 Code, amendedtransfer of experience rating accounts under Unemployment Compensation Law.Section 703587 (c), Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as last amended, relating to contributions under the South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law, is amended by adding a new subsection to be designated subsection (4) as follows: (4).

No transfer of experience rating accounts, in whole or in part, shall be permitted under the provisions of Section 703587 (c) (3) (IV) and 703587 (c) (3) (V) unless all unemployment compensation taxes based on wages paid by the transferring employer prior to the date of the transfer shall be paid by the transferring employer when due or assumed by the acquiring employer. Section 2. RepealAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect on July 1, 1952. Approved the 21st day of February, 1952.

743 An Act To Amend Section 2200 Of The Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To Collateral Security For Deposits Of Funds Of The State Of South Carolina, So As To Further Define The Properties Which May Be Pledged As Collateral Security For Such Deposits.

2200, 1942 Code, amendedsecurity for deposit of State fundsfailure of officials to remit.Section 2200 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is amended by striking out all of said section and inserting in lieu thereof the following: section 2200.

Any such depository may, instead of such surety bond in an approved surety company, furnish, as surety for such deposit or deposits, United States Government bonds, Federal Farm Loan bonds issued by Federal Land Banks pursuant to the Federal Farm JI.oan Act as amended, Federal Intermediate Credit Bank debentures issued by Federal Intermediate Credit Banks pursuant to the Federal Farm Loan Act as amended, debentures issued by Central Bank for Cooperatives organized under the Farm Credit Act of 1933, and bonds or other obligations of the State of South Carolina or any political subdivision thereof.

Said surety shall be filed with the proper officers within one week after deposit shall be made, or at the time of deposit, if required; provided, that any state or county officer who neglects or fails to remit to the state treasurer as required by law shall become responsible on his official bond for any loss the state may sustain by reason of such neglect or failure to remit. 744 An Act To Amend Section 9049 Of The Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To Investments And Loans By Savings Banks, Banks, Trust And Insurance Companies, Judges Of Probate, Executors, Administrators, Guardians And Trustees, So As To Further Define The Properties In Which Such Investments May Be Made, Or On Which Loans May Be Made, By Including Federal Intermediate Credit Bank Debentures And Debentures Issued By The Central Bank For Cooperatives.

9049, 1942 Code, amendedbonds and debentures banks, trust and insurance companies and fiduciaries invest inSection 9049 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is amended by striking it out and inserting in lieu thereof the following: section 9049.

Any savings bank, banking institution, trust company or insurance company, organized under the laws of this state, and any judge of probate or person acting as executor, administrator, guardian, or trustee, unless it is otherwise provided in the instrument creating the trust, may invest in, or lend money on the security of: Federal Farm Loan Bonds issued by the Federal Land Banks pursuant to the Federal Farm Loan Act as amended,bonds issued by the Federal Farm Mortgage Corporation pursuant to the provisions of an act of Congress known as the Federal Farm Mortgage Corporation Act, Federal Intermediate Credit Bank debentures issued pursuant to the Federal Farm Loan Act as amended, and debentures issued by Central Bank for Cooperatives organized under the Farm Credit Act of 1933.

Any savings bank, banking institution, trust company or insurance company,organized under the laws of this state, or any judge of probate or person acting as executor, administrator, guardian, or trustee making an investment or loan authorized by this section shall not be chargeable in his or its account for a greater rate of interest than the amount actually received on the investment or loan. Section 2. Repeal.all acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
745 An Act To Amend Section 9051 Of The Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Amended By Act No.
276 Of The Acts Of 1947, Act No.
756 Of The Acts Of 1948, And Act No.

191 Of The Acts Of 1951, Relating To The Investment Of Trust Funds By Fiduciaries, So As To Further Define The Properties In Which Trust Funds May Be Invested By Including In Such Investments Federal Intermediate Credit Bank Debentures And Debentures Issued By The Central Bank For Cooperatives.
9051, 1942 Code, amendedinvestments of trust funds by fiduciaries.Section 9051 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as amended hy Act No.
276 of the Acts of 1947, Act No.
756 of the Acts of 1948, and Act No.
191 of the Acts of 1951, is amended by striking out all of the section as amended and inserting in lieu thereof the following: section 9051.

(a) Trust funds in the hands of any trustee, guardian, committee, executor, administrator, or other fiduciary may be invested by the fiduciary in such securities or property as may be authorized by the will, deed, order, decree, gift, grant, or other instrument creating or fixing the trust, and, when not otherwise provided in the instrument, may be deposited in whole or in part at current savings bank interest rates in any bank which is a member of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, or in any Federal Savings and Loan Association, or may be invested in whole or in part in all or any of the following: bonds or notes of the United States; Federal Farm Loan Bonds issued pursuant to an Act of Congress known as the Federal Farm Loan Act and acts mandatory thereof and supplementary thereto; bonds issued by the Federal Farm Mortgage Corporation pursuant to an Act of Congress known as the Federal Farm Mortgage Corporation Act; Federal Intermediate Credit Bank debentures issued pursuant to the Federal Farm Loan Act as amended; debentures issued by Central Bank for Cooperatives organized under the Farm Credit Act of 1933; bonds or obligations of any state of the United States; bonds or obligations of any political subdivision or municipal corporation of any such state; bonds or obligations secured by first mortgage of real estate in any state of the United States; preferred or common stock of any corporation; shares of any management type investment company or investment trust which is registered under the Federal Investment Company Act of 1940 as from time to time amended; and shares of any building and loan association organized and existing under the laws of this state when such shares are insured by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

(b) When the investment of trust funds is in corporate bonds, notes, or obligations secured by mortgage of real estate, such bonds, notes, or obligations shall have been outstanding for a period of not less than five years, and no default in payment thereon shall have occurred within a period of five years next preceding the date of purchase; but this requirement shall not apply where such corporate bonds, notes, or obligations have been issued for the purpose of refunding a prior issue if the prior issue, at the time of such refunding, had been outstanding for a period of not less than five years without default, if the refunding bonds, notes, or obligations bear interest at a rate no higher than that borne by the issue so refunded, and if the total principal amount of the refunding bonds, notes, or obligations so issued does not exceed the total principal amount of the issue so refunded.

(e) The combined aggregate total so invested in common stocks or preferred stocks of any corporation and in shares of such management type investment company or investment trust shall not exceed thirty (30%) per cent of the corpus of the trust, and the aggregate total so invested in the stock or stocks of any one corporation or in shares of any one such management type investment company or investment trust shall not exceed ten (10%) per cent of the corpus of the trust; but this subsection shall not apply to any funds of a minor ward as to which the testator or donor making gift of such funds or other property shall, in the will or other written declaration filed with the probate court, expressly authorize the minor wards guardian to invest without limitation in such corporate stocks or shares of such management type investment company or investment trust as is permitted by this section, nor shall such funds or property of the minor ward be considered in determining the percentage of any other funds or property of the minor ward that his guardian may invest in accordance with this subsection.

({) No investment shall be made: (1) in any stock, bond, note, or obligation of the corporate fiduciary ; or (2) in any stock, bond, note, or obligation of any corporation or in shares of any such management type investment company or investment trust of which the individual fiduciary or any person related to him within the third degree is a director, officer, or employee; or (3) in any stock, bond, note, or obligation of any corporation or in any sharcs of any management type investment company or investment trust where the fiduciary, individual or corporate, or any person related to the individual fiduciary within the third degree is the owner or holder, by pledge or otherwise, of more than five (590) per cent of the total outstanding capital stock of such corporation or of more than five (59) per cent of the shares of any such management type investment company or investment trust.

(1) When any trustee, guardian, committee, executor, administrator, or other fiduciary shall invest the trust fund in his or its charge in whole or in part in the manner authorized by this section, such fiduciary shall not be chargeable in his or its account at a greater rate of interest, as to such funds so invested, than such funds shall have so earned.

(j) The duly appointed guardian of the estate of a minor may invest in endowment insurance and educational insurance policies in insurance companies licensed by the Insurance Commissioner or duly dumesticated to do business in this state; but before any guardian of the estate of a minor shall invest in such policies of insurance, they shall be approved by order of the probate court as to the insurance company and as to the investment.

160, Acts And Joint Resolutions Of South Carolina, 1947, Relating To The Mayor And Councilmen Of The City Of Greenwood, So As To Further Provide For The Salaries Of The Mayor And Councilmen Of The City.

2609, 1942 Code, amendeddogs exempt from taxes property.Section 2609, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, relating to capitation tax on dogs, as amended by Act No.

so that the section when amended shall read as follows: section 2609.

No dog which is not returned for taxation, as required in this section, shall he held to be property in any of the courts of this State.
1008 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1950, shall be held to be property in any of the courts of Lexington County.

2610, 1942 Code, amendedno dog tax, Greenwood County.Section 2610, Cod of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, relating to capitation tax on dogs, as amended by Act No.

There shall be levied on all dogs on January first of each year, in the State of South Carolina an annual license of one dollar and twentyfive cents ($1.25) per head.

There shall be levied on all dogs, irrespective of age, in Laurens County, an annual tax of one dollar each, said property to be listed at the same time and in like manner as other personal property is now listed, and the tax thereon to be collected at the same time and place as other property taxes are now collected.

All taxes collected in pursuance with this section shall be credited to the respective school districts in Laurens County from which the same shall be collected to be used in support of the schools of the district.

It shall be the duty of the trustees of the several school districts in Laurens County to report to the county auditor on or before the first day of March, each and every year, the number of dogs owned in their respective district, in accordance with the terms of this section: provided, that such report on the part of the trustees shall not relieve the owners of dogs from making an assessment of their property mentioned herein. Section 4. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 21st day of February, 1952.

748 An Act To Amend Section 2737, Code of Laws of South Oarolina, 1942, As Last Amended, Relating To Assessment Of Property For Taxation So As To Further Provide For Boards Of Equalization In Florence County.

2737, 1942 Code, amendedboards of equalization, Florence County.Section 2737, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as last amended, relating to assessment of property for taxation, is amended by adding at the end thereof the following: Provided, further, there is hereby established in each of the four school districts of Florence County a district board of equalization.

Each board shall consist of fifteen members who shall be appointed by the Governor fur terms of four years upon the recommendation of a majority of the Legislative Delegation from Florence County, including the Senator.
Each board shall elect a chairman and a secretary and the boards shall meet at the times and places designated by the County Auditor for Florence County.

The boards established under the provisions of this act shall be in addition to the Equalization Boards for the City of Florence and the Town of Lake City in Florence County, provided for by Section 285912 and Section 285913, respectively.

Provided, further, there is hereby established a Board of Equalization for Florence County which shall be composed of the chairmen of the four district boards of equalization together with the Chairman st the City of Florence Equalization Board and the Chairman of the Lake City Equalization Board.

The county board of equalization is hereby authorized and empowered to hear appeals from the district boards and is empowered to modify, reverse, or alter assessments by the district boards. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
749 An Act To Prohibit The Operation Of Motor Vehicles On A Portion Of Magnolia Beach In Georgetown County, And To Provide A Penalty Therefor.

Operation of motor vehicles on Magnolia Beach in Georgetown County.It is unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle at any time on that portion of Magnolia Beach in Georgetown County between the inlet separating Magnolia Beach from Pawleys Island, and Murrells Inlet on the north.
Any violation of this act shall be deemed a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or by imprisonment of not more than thirty days.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 21st day of Bebevath 1952.
750 An Act To Amend Section 1 Of Act No.
343 Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions Of The General Assembly, 1947, Entitled An Act To Create A School District No.
25 In Berkeley County, Etc., Approved May 8, 1947, As Amended By Act No.
1025 Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions Of The General Assembly, 1950, So As To Further Provide For The Boundaries Of Said School District.
Act 343 of 1947 amendedSchool District No.
26, Berkeley Countytrustees.Section 1 of Act No.
343, Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1947, entitled An Act To Create A School District No.
25 In Berkeley County, Etc., approved May 8, 1947, as amended by Act No.

1025, Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1950, is further amended by striking out the section and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be known as Section 1: section 1. There is hereby created a school district No.
26 in Berkeley County embracing the area lying South of Goose Creek and extending in boundaries to the Charleston county line, to be known as Highland ParkRemount Road School District.

The said school district is hereby declared to be a body corporate and as such is authorized to use a seal, to sue and be sued, to issue notes, bonds or other certificates of indebtedness and in all respects to enjoy the same rights, privileges and benefits, and exercise the same rights, privileges and benefits as are now exercised and conferred under the laws of this state.
The board of trustees of said school district shall consist of three members selected as now provided by law. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
751 An Act To Repeal Section 7413, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To The Value Of Property Which Municipalities Of Less Than One Thousand Inhabitants May Own.
7413, 1942 Code, repealedvalue of property municipalities under 1,000 own.Section 7413, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is hereby repealed.

565 Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions Of The General Assembly, 1951, Approved May 18, 1951.

Act 565 of 1951 repealedreferendum on consolidation of school districts, Greenwood County.An act entitled An Act To Authorize The County Board Of Education Of Greenwood County To Formulate A Plan Or Plans With Reference To The Consolidation Of School Districts, And To Provide Means For Obtaining The Wishes Of The People With Reference To Them, being Act No.

753 An Act To Change The Manner Of Paying Compensation To The Treasurer Of Hampton County, And To Fix His Salary.

Treasurer receive salary in lieu of fees, Hampton County.The countys share of the salary paid to the Treasurer of Hampton County shall be a sum which, when added to the amount paid by the state, will total fiftyfour hundred dollars ($5,400.00) annually.
The Treasurer of Hampton County shall pay into the Hampton County Treasury all fees paid to him.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon the expiration of the term of office of the present Treasurer of Hampton County.
Approvecl the 28th day of February, 1952.

754 An Act To Provide For A County Unit System Of Developing, Operating, Maintaining And Financing The Public Schools In Horry County; To Provide For The Expenditure Of Funds On Hand Of The Various School Districts Heretofore Existing In Horry County; And To Make Provisions Relative To School Properties, Indebtedness And Levies.

Horry County Board of Educationappointmentquorumtermsvacancy.The central authority of Horry Countys educational system shall be the Horry County Board of Education consisting of eight members, one of whom shall be the Horry County Superintendent of Education, ex officio, so long as he is elected by the people, and the other seven shall be appointed by the Governor upon the recommendation of the Senator and members of the House from Horry County.
A majority of the county board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business.
The present board and the additional member to be appointed pursuant to this act shall continue in office until 1954.
All vacancies shall be filled as prescribed in this act.

The appointments made following the 1954 terms shall be staggered so that two members terms shall expire after the first year, two after the second year, two after the third year, and one after the fourth year.
The members appointed alter 1954 shall draw lots to determine the length of their terms of office and all appointments made thereafter shall be for four years.
Duties and powers.The Horry County Board of Education shall have the following duties and powers relative to the public schools in the county : 1.
Promulgate rules and regulations and adopt administrative policies for the efficient operation of the schools.
Employ all personnel necessary for the efficient operation of the school system of the county.
Fix uniform supplements in salaries.
Issue bonds to construct, repair, and maintain buildings, and pledge capital outlay funds from state, federal, and local tax sources for their repayment.

Before issuing any bonds under the provisions of this act, the board shall either (1) secure the written consent of the Senator and members of the House from Horry County or (2) submit the question to the qualified electors of the county.

In case an election is ordered the voting precinct shall be the same as in the general election and the board shall have the power to appoint the managers of election, canvass the ballots and declare results.
In case the election is held during a general election it shall be done in accordance with existing state laws.
No special registration shall be required for any special election held hereunder.
The board shall prescribe and have prepared the necessary ballots for special elections.
Build, maintain and repair all school properties.
Issue shortterm notes in anticipation of taxes, state aid and other funds for the operation of schools.
7 Exercise the right of eminent domain.
8 Contract for services, equipment, and supplies.
9 Cause semiannual or annual audits to be made and published.
Approve all expenditures against the Horry County school fund.
Direct a continuing school census and enforce the State Compulsory Attendance Law.
Conduct surveys and, upon results obtained, approve curricula, supervisory program, auxiliary services, or any part of the educational program delegated by the state to the county board of education.
Arrange with adjoining counties and states for the interchange of pupils or educational services.
Provide necessary funds, not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), to the attendance teacher for needy and indigent school children.
Provide not less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), if so much be necessary, for freight on school lunchroom products and supplies.
Provide an amount sufficient to cover all teachers of Horry County under the Workmens Compensation Act.
Superintendent of educationThe Horry County Board of Education shall employ a county superintendent of education on the basis of professional qualifications.
The superintendent so employed shall act as secretary of the county board.
The tenure of the superintendent and his salary shall be at the discretion of the caunty board ; however, the present superintendent of education shall continue in office until his term expires.
All vacancies occurring in this office shall be filled by the county board.
Advisory boards of trusteesThe Horry County Beard of Education may appoint advisory boards of trustees.
The hoards of trustees shall consist of three or more members whose terms shall he staggered so that the term of one member shall expire each year.

When properly requested by the patrons of a school the county beard of education shall cause an election to be held for the purpose nf nominating trustees and the trustees so nominated shall be appeinted by the county board of education.
When an election is held for the purpose of nominating trustees it shallbe under the supervision of the county board of education as herein provided.
Notice of the election shall be published twice consecutively in at least two county paners and the second publication shall be at least six days prior to the date of election.
The names of candidates shall be presented to the hoard of education and any person may present his own name or the name of another.
Five days prior to the election date, acceptance ef candidates names shall cease.

The board of education shall prepare tallots and appoint managers who shall conduct the election at a centrally located school between the hours of 8:00 a. m. and 4:00 p. m. As soon as reasonable following the election the board of education shall meet, canvass the ballots and declare the results.
The advisory boards of trustees shall assist the Horry County Board of Education in ,administering the affairs of their respective schools, Section 5.

Budgetstaxes.The advisory boards of trustees, suPerintendents or principals of the several schools of the county shall prepare a budget for the next succeeding school year and submit it to the county board of education on or before February first of each year.

The county board of education shall prepare a budget based on the budgets submitted by the trustees, superintendents or principals and shall determine the necessary millage, not to exceed forty mills, for the operation of schools for the next succeeding school year.
This budget shall be submitted to the Senator and House Members of Horry County on or before March first of each year.
The Senator and the House Members shall instruct the county auditor to levy the millage which in their discretion is necessary for school purposes on or before March fifteenth.
Boardofficersmeetingsexpensessurplus funds.
The county board of education shall meet annually on the second Tuesday of July, at 5:00 p. m., and shall eclect one of its members as chairman and another as vicechairman.
The board shall hold a regular meeting at least monthly thereafter and special meetings as necessary.
The members of the board shall be paid the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00) annually to cover expenses of attending meetings.
Members shall also be paid for official travel other than attending meetings at the rate of seven cents per mile when approved by the county board of education.

All unexpended and uncommitted funds on hand of any school district in the county resulting from the issuance of bonds for school improvement or construction shall be expended by the county board of education for school improvement and construction to benefit the people comprising the former particular districts in which they were originally intended to be expended.

All funds on hand of any former school district in the county which are the proceeds of a tax levy made for the purpose of issuing school bonds for school improvement or construction and such bonds have not been issued, shall be expended by the county board of education for school improvement or construction to benefit the people in the former districts in which the tax was collected.

Propertiesliabilitiesfinances.The county board of education shall be vested with and take title to all property both real and personal that is now being used for school purposes and all property that is now owned by any school or school district in Horry County, and shall assume all school assets and liabilities of the present schools and districts.
Horry County shall in all cases be the unit to be used by the county board, of education for financing and receiving all local, state and federal funds for educational purposes.
Levy and collection of taxes records disbursements.The Auditor of Horry County shall levy the school taxes as provided in this act.
All levies shall be set by the auditor after receiving written instructions signed by the Senator and the Members of the House of Representatives.
It shall be the duty of the county treasurer to collect all school taxes and to receive all school funds and to keep an accurate record of the receipts and disbursements of these funds.

The treasurer shall pay out these funds only on special vouchers prepared for the purpose of carrying the signatures of two bonded persons designated by the county board of education to sign such vouchers.
It shall be the duty of the treasurer and the county board of education to make arrangements whereby vouchers issued to individuals and corporations may clear at par through regular banking channels.
Should the Senator and Members of the House of Representatives fail to direct the amount of the levy annually the auditor shall use and levy according to the last direction by him received.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 28th day of February, 1952.
755 An Act To Authorize The County Board Of Education Of Pickens County To Appoint Two Additional Trustees For The School District Of Pickens County.

Additional trustees for School District of Pickens County.The County Board of Education of Pickens County is authorized to appoint two additional members of the Board of Trustees for the School District of Pickens County.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 28th day of February, 1952.
756 An Act To Amend Section 31 Of Act No.
868 Of The Acts Of 1950, As Amended By Section 4 Of Act No.
183 Of The Acts Of 1951, Providing For Meetings Of The Board Of Education Of Anderson County And Prohibiting The Members Thereof From Receiving Pay, So As To Remove Such Prohibition.
Act 868 of 1950 amendedAnderson County Board of Educationmeetingsappealsbudgets.Section 31 of Act No.
868 of the Acts of 1950, as amended by Section 4 of Act No.
183 of the Acts of 1951, is further amended by striking out the first paragraph of Section 31, as amended, and inserting in lieu thereof the following : section 31.

The County Board shall hold a regular meeting at least monthly and such special meetings as it deems necessary, and shall have all powers and authority now provided by law, in addition to the powers and authority which may herein be given it. The section when so amended shall read as follows: section 31.

The County Board shall hold a regular meeting at least monthly and such special meetings as it deems necessary, and shall have all powers and authority now provided by law, in addition to the powers and authority which may herein be given it.
All meetings shall be open to the public.
Minutes of all regular and special meetings shall be kept by the secretary and filed by him in a permanent record.
Appeals from all decisions of the County Board shall be to the Court of Common Pleas and thence by certiorari to the Supreme Court.

The County Board shall annually prepare a budget for the following fiscal year including the necessary costs of conducting the operations of its office and the office of the Superintendent of Education and the countywide levies hereinbelow provided for, and such other items relative to the operation of the educational system of this county as it deems advisable, and submit same to the legislative delegation of said county. Section 2. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
757 An Act Creating The Calhoun County Historical Commission; To Provide For The Membership, Their Terms Of Office, Powers, And Duties.

Calhoun County Historical Commissionappointment termsvacancy.There is hereby created the Calhoun County Historical Commission to be composed of seven members who shall be appointed by the Governor upon the recommendation of the majority of the legislative delegation, including the Senator.

The original appointments shall be made as follows: two for a term of two years, two for a term of four years, and three for a term of six years, thereaiter all appointments shall be made for six years.
All vacancies shall be filled as above prescribed.
Officers.Immediately following the appointment of the members to this commission they shall meet and elect one of its members chairman and one of its members vicechairman.
The officers so elected shall serve for one year or until their successors have been elected.
Duties and powers.The commission shall have the following powers and duties: 1.
Procure documents, transcripts, and other materials relating to the county as they may deem necessary or important.
Take care and custody of the archives of the county.
Adopt a seal and make rules for its own government.
Have direction and control over the marking of historical sites.
Acquire historical sites by purchase or otherwise at its discretion.
Employ a secretary who shall serve at the pleasure of the commission, receive such remuneration as the commission may determine, and perform such duties as the commission may direct.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 28th day of February, 1952.

758 An Act Creating The Darlington County Farmers Marketing Commission; To Provide For The Appointment Of Its Members And To Prescribe Their Terms Of Office, Powers And Duties; To Provide For The Issuance Of Bonds, Not To Exceed Sixty Thousand Dollars ($60,000.00), For The Erection Of Buildings And Operating The Market And Facilities And To Provide For The Payment Of The Same.

Darlington County Farmers Marketing Commission appointmentterms.There is hereby created the Darlington County Farmers Marketing Commission which shall be composed of seven members who shall be appointed by the Governor upon the recommendation of a majority of the Darlington County Legislative Delegation, including the Senator.
The membership of the first appointed commission shall be staggered; two shall be appointed for a term of two vears: two for a term of four years and three for a term of six years.
After the expiration of the terms of the original appointees their successors shall be appointed for a term of six years.
Immediately after the appointment of the first commission and at the first mecting in each year thereafter one of the members shall be elected chairman and one secretary.
Buildings and facilitiesThe commission shall erect such buildings and provide such facilities as it deems proper in order to foster and improve farming in the county.
All buildings and facilities shall be located upon lands now owned by the county or upon lands to be donated to the county.

Operationfeespersonnel.The commission shall have the power to fix rules and regulations regarding the operation of the market and facilities, set all fees and charges for the use of the market and facilities and employ all personnel and fix their salaries.

Issue bonds.The Darlington County Farmers Marketing Commission is hereby authorized to issue and sell not exceeding sixty thousand dollars ($60,000.00) of Darlington County bonds to be used for erection of buildings and operating the market and facilities provided for in this act.
The bonds shall be of such denominations, shall be payable at such place or places and shall bear such rate or rates of interest, not to exceed three per cent per annum, as the commission deems best.
All bonds shall mature within ten years from their date.
The bonds so issued may be sold at public or private sale in the discretion of the commission.

Payment of bonds.There is hereby levied upon all the taxable property in Darlington County an additional one mill which shall be collected by the treasurer of the county as other taxes are collected by law.

The proceeds from this levy shall be used to pay for the principal and interest of the bonds provided for in Section 4 as same become due, and the commission shall fix maturities of the bonds so that they will be paid in full by this one mill levy within ten years from the dates of the bonds.
The levy of the additional mill shall cease upon the retirement of all the bonds provided for herein.

Execution of bonds.The bonds shall be executed on behalf of Darlington County by the Chairman of the Darlington County Farmers Marketing Commission and shall be countersigned by the Treasurer of Darlington County.
The facsimile signature of these officials shall be a sufficient signing of the coupons attached to the bonds.
Pledge to pay bonds.The full faith and credit and taxing power of Darlington County is hereby irrevocably pledged for the payment of the bonds and the interest on the same.
Repeal.All acts or parts of acts Snconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effetcive.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 28th day of February, 1952.
759 An Act To Change The Fiscal Year For Richland County Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1.
Fiscal year, Richland County.Beginning July 1, 1952, the fiscal year for Richland County shall be from July first through June thirtieth.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 28th day of February, 1952.
760 An Act To Increase The Pay Of Petit Jurors And Grand Jurors In Sumter County From Three Dollars To Five Dollars Per Day.

Pay of jurors, Sumter County.All petit jurors and grand jurors serving in Sumter County shall receive the sum of five dollars per diem and in addition thereto the jurors shall be paid mileage as now provided by law.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 28th day of February, 1952.
761 An Act To Further Amend Act No.
868 Of 1950, As Last Amended By Act No.

183 Of 1951 Relating To The Consolidation Of School Districts In Anderson County On Petition Of The Board Of Trustees Of Any District, So As To Provide For An Election On The Question Of Consolidation.
Act 868 of 1950 amendedelection on school district consolidations, Anderson County.Amend Section 32 of Act No.
868 of 1950, as last amended in Section 5 of Act No.
183 of 1951, by striking out the entire section, as amended, and inserting in lieu thereof the following : section 32.

The county board of education may order and hold special elections at such times as it deems advisable for the purpose of determining the will of the people on consolidation of school districts in the county.

At such elections the qualified electors of the county shall have an opportunity to vote on the question of any proposed consolidation or change in the method into which the county is then divided into school districts and the county board shall be bound by the result of this election.

Provided, however, that at the first election held after the effective date of this act the question of consolidation of school districts shall be presented to the qualified electors of Anderson County by having printed on each ballot the following: Do you favor a one school district plan for Anderson County, or do you favor more than one school district for Anderson County?

I Favor One District O I Favor Not Less Than Three Districts Nor More Than Five Districts O Those voting in favor of one district for the county shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the words I favor one district, and those voting in favor of more than one district for the county shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the words I favor not less than three districts nor more than five districts.

0) Prior to the holding of the first election, as provided herein, the said election shall be fully advertised in all newspapers having general circulation in Anderson County, at least ten days before the election; with such additional data as will fully apprise the qualified electors of the county of the time, place and purpose of the election. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
762 An Act To Provide For The Appointment Or Election Of School Trustees In Lexington County; To Prescribe Their Terms Of Office; And To Terminate The Office Of The Present Trustees.
School trustees, Lexington Countyappointmentterms.The County Board of Education of Lexington County shall appoint seven trustees for School Districts No.
The terms of office of the initial appointees shall be as follows: one for one year, two for two years, two for three years, and two for four years.
After the expiration of the initial appointments the terms in these districts shall be four years.
The board shall appoint five trustees for School Districts No.
4 and 5 whose terms of office shall be as follows: one for one year, two for two years, and two for three years.
After the expiration of the initial apointments the terms in these districts shall be for three years.

Election.Upon the receipt of a petition signed by forty per cent of the qualified voters of any school district directed to the county board of education the board shall order an election to be held on or before the first Tuesday in February of the year in which the term of the trustee expires for the purpose of nominating a trustee or trustees.
The person receiving the highest number of votes shall be declared the nominee.
The county superintendent of education shall prepare the ballots, name the managers and designate the polling precincts.
Polls shall be open between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. Qualifications to vote in the election shall be the same as required by the general election laws of this state.

All candidates must be qualified voters and must file an affidavit to that effect with the county superintendent of education on or before the second Tuesday in February of the year in which the election is to be held As soon as reasonable following any election held under the provisions of this act the county board of education shall meet, canvass the ballots, declare the results, and commission the nominee as a trustee.
Commencement of termsvacancy.The terms of office of the trustees appointed or commissioned pursuant to this act shall begin immediately thereafter and the office of all former trustees shall expire.
The terms of office of all future trustees shall commence on the first day of March in the year in which they are appointed or commissioned.
All vacancies created on the board of trustees shall be filled by appointment by the county board of education for the unexpired term.

Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed Section 3. ,Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor Approved the 28th day of February, 1952.

763 An Act Creating The County Board Of Education For Lexington County; To Provide For The Appointment Of Its Membership, Their Terms Of Office; And To Terminate The Office Of Certain Members Of The Present Board.

Lexington County Board of Educationappointment terms.There is hereby created the Lexington County Board of Education which shall consist of six members one of whom shall be the superintendent of education, ex officio.
The members shall be appointed by the Governor upon the recommendation of a majority of the Legislative Delegation of Lexington County, including the Senator.
The members appointed under the provisions of this act shall be qualified electors of the several school districts of the county.
The terms of office of the initial appointees shall be staggered so that one term will expire each year.
All terms of office after the initial appointments shall be for five years.

Terms of incumbents.The terms of office of the members of the present county board of education except that of the county superintendent of education shall terminate as of July 1, 1952, at which time the appointments of the new members shall be made.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 28th day of February, 1952.
764 An Act Providing For The Levying Of Taxes For The Operation Of Schools In Lexington County And For The Distribution Thereof.

Tax levy for schools, Lexington County.The Auditor of Lexington County is hereby authorized to levy annually a uniform tax of twenty mills on all real and personal property in Lexington County for the purpose of operating the county schools.
The receipts from the tax shall be divided among the five districts of the county on a per pupil basis by the county superintendent of education.
The division shall be based upon the legal enrollment of Lexington County pupils for the previous year in the schools of the respective districts.

Where pupils of adjoining counties are legally enrolled in the schools of Lexington County and where the area in which such students reside levies and pays over to the Treasurer of Lexington County a twenty mill levy, then the distribution of the twenty mill levy shall be based upon the legal enrollment of all students attending schools within the districts.

Determine levy annually.The board of trustees of each of the school districts in Lexington County shall on or before the first day of June of each year notify the county auditor in writing the millage required for operation of the schools in their respective districts for the ensuing school year.
The notice so directed to the auditor shall be his authority for levying millage in excess of the unifrom twenty mills upon all of the real and personal property within the school district.
The additional levy shall be placed to the credit of the district in which it is levied and expended within that district only.

765 An Act To Consolidate The Existing School Districts In Kershaw County Into A School District To Be Designated As The School District Of Kershaw County; To Provide For A County System Of Developing, Operating, Maintaining And Financing The Public Schools In Kershaw County; To Provide For The Assumption By The School District Of Kershaw County Of School District Indebtedness; To Provide For The Exercising Of Power Of Eminent Domain, The Issuance Of Notes And Bonds, And To Prescribe The Duties And Powers Of The Trustees And Local Area Trustees And Superintendent Of Education And To Repeal Act No.
879 Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions Of The General Assembly, 1950, Relating To The Schools And School System In Kershaw County.
School trustees, Kershaw Countyelectionterms.
tThe central authority of Kershaw Countys public educational system shall be a board of trustees composed of nine members.
These members shall be citizens of Kershaw County and qualified electors.

Eight of said members, one from each of the attendance areas provided for in Section 4 of this act, shall be appointed and commissioned by the Governor, provided that each board of local area trustees provided for in Section 4 of this act shall nominate from among its membership one member of the county board of trustees to be commissioned, and who also serves as chairman of local area board of trustees, and the ninth member shall be selected at large by the other eight members of said board and shall likewise be appointed and commissioned by the Governor.

Provided, however, that in any attendance area, upon a petition signed by fifty per cent of the patrons of attendance area, who are qualified electors and submitted to the county superintendent of education thirty days prior to the expiration of the terms of a trustee, that the county superintendent of education shall designate a time and place and give due notice of a meeting to be held in the attendance area for the purpose of allowing patrons who are citizens to nominate by a twothirds majority of those voting a qualified elector who shall be appointed and commissioned by the Governor as trustee.

The terms of office of the members of the board shall be four years, except the initial terms of the members of the board shall be three for four years, three for three years, two for two years, and one for one year, and these terms shall be determined by casting of lots.

In order to provide for stability and an experienced board the initial appointments to the board shall be the present members of the county board of education, excluding, however, the county superintendent of education.

Duties and powers.The board of trustees shall have the following duties and powers relative to the public schools in said county: (1) Upon nomination by superintendent of education, employ all personnel necessary for the efficient operation of the schools except as otherwise provided in this act.
(2) Adopt administrative policies.
(3) Fix local supplements in salaries.
(4) Plan and construct new buildings.
(5) Issue from time to time bonds to construct and repair buildings and pledge capital outlay funds from state, federal, and local tax sources for their repayment.
(6) Operate a building maintenance and repair program.
(7) Issue shortterm notes in anticipation of taxes and state aid funds,which notes or note shall mature not later than one year from the date thereof.

(8) Exercise the right of eminent domain in securing necessary property, and in the exercise of such rights the board of trustees shall follow as near as practical the procedure prescribed for condemnation by municipal corporations.
(10) The board shall assume all duties and authority delegated to county boards of education under provision of the 1951 school act.
(11) Contract for services, equipment and supplies.
(15) Provide for all school elections.
(16) Fix the length of the school term.

(17) Conduct surveys and upon the result obtained reorganize attendance areas, the curriculum, the supervisory program, auxiliary services, or any part of the educational program delegated by the state to the said board of trustees.
(19) Adopt budgets and budgetary controls and recommend tax levies to county delegation on countywide basis sufficient to meet the educational needs of Kershaw County.
Superintendent of educationThe county superintendent of education shall be secretary and executive officer of the county board of trustees.
It shall be his duty to appoint local area trustees as provided in Section 4 of this act.

It shall also be his duty to effectuate the policies of the said board of trustees and to recommend to said board from time to time such changes in procedure and policy as will, in his opinion, improve the school system in the county.
The duties and authority of the Kershaw County Superintendent of Education shall be as now provided by law, except so far as the same may be inconsistent with the provision of this act.

The superintendent of education shall (1) nominate all staff members and other personnel necessary for the carrying out of policies of the county board of trustees, (2) assign all personnel employed, (3) contract for all services, supplies and reports with approval of board of trustees, (4) prepare annual budgets which budgets are to be approved by board of trustees.
Attendance areaslocal area trustees.Each of the former high school districts of Kershaw County shall hereafter be designated as attendance areas.
It shall be the duty of the county superintendent of education to appoint an odd number of local area trustees for each attendance area of the county whose authority shall be advisory in all cases.
These trustees shall serve for a term of four years, provided the initial appointments may be for a shorter term in order that expiration dates of terms may be staggered.

Local area trustees of attendance areas in the county shall have authority to nominate a local superintendent of schools, teachers and other personnel in the attendance area subject to election by the county board of trustees.
Trusteesmeetingspay.The county board of trustees shall meet annually on the fourth Friday in April and elect one of its members as chairman and another as vicechairman.
The board shall hold regular meetings at least monthly thereafter and special meetings as necessary.

Members of the board shall receive ten dollars per diem for attendance at board meetings and in addition shall be reimbursed for travel expenses incurred in carrying on official business of the board at the legal rate, provided that the money shall be paid from the general school fund.

Budgetstax leviesThe county board of trustees shall approve budgets for the schools of the county and shall annually recommend to the county legislative delegation a tax levy to be applied uniformly to all property in the county and which, in the opinion of the board, is required to guarantee an adequate program of public school education to all children in the county.
The levy so imposed by the county legislative delegation shall be entered by the county auditor and collected by the county treasurer in the same manner as are other taxes on property.

Proceeds of this levy shall be credited by the county treasurer to the county board of trustees, and the county treasurer shall pay out such funds only on special vouchers prepared for the purpose and carrying the signature of the chairman or vicechairman, and the county superintendent of education each of whom shall be bonded in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
Act 879 of 1950 repealedKershaw County school system.Act No.
879 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1950, relating to the Kershaw County schools is hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall become effective July 1, 1952. Approved the 29th day of February, 1952.

766 An Act To Amend Section 17671, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Amended, Relating To NonResident Fishing Licenses, So As To Provide For A Temporary Fishing License For NonResidents In York County.
