Applicants for registrationqualificationsTo be eligible for registration by the board as a physical therapist, each applicant must: (a) Be at least twentyone years old; (b) Be of good moral character ; (c) Have obtained a high school education or its equivalent as determined by the board ; (d) Be a graduate of a school of physical therapy approved by the appropriate subbody of the American Medical Association, if such school existed at the time of his graduation; or if graduated prior to 1936, then the school or course which was approved by the American Physical Therapy Association at the time of his graduation ; (e) Either (1) pass to the satisfaction of the board an examination conducted by it to determine his fitness for practice as a physical therapist; or (2) be entitled to registration without examination as provided in Section 5 or Section 6 of this act.

Application for registration Unless entitled to register under Section 5 or Section 6 of this act, a person who desires to be registered as a physical therapist shall apply to the board, in writing, on a blank furnished by the board.
He shall embody in that application evidence under oath, satisfactory to the board, of his possessing the qualifications preliminary to examination required by the preceding section.
He shall pay to the board a fee of ten dollars at the time of filing his application.

Persons may register by October 1, 1952.The board shall register as a physical therapist any person who (1) applies for such registration on or before October 1, 1952, and (2) at the time cf the passage and approval of this act is a member of or is eligible far membership in the American Physical Therapy Association and/or the American Registry of Physical Therapists; and (3) is residing in the state at the time of the passage of this act.
At the time of making such application, such applicant shall pay the board a fee of five dollars.

Reciprocal registrationThe board may, in its discretion, register as a physical therapist, without examination, on the payment of a fee of ten dollars, an applicant for registration who 1s a physical therapist registered under the laws of another state or territory, if the requirements for registration of physical therapists in the state or territory in which the applicant was registered were at the date of his registration substantially equal to the requirements in force in this state and if the state or territory whence the applicant comes accords a similar privilege of registration without examination to holders of certificates as registered physical therapists under this act.

Examinations.The board shall examine applicants for registration as physical therapists at such times and places as it may determine, provided that the board shall meet at least once each year for this purpose and that notice of at least one meeting each year D pub ished in a newspaper of genera circulation in e state ten days in advance of such meeting.

The examination shall embrace such subjects as the applied sciences of anatomy, neuroanatomy, kinesiology, physiology, pathology, psychology, physics, physical therapy, as defined in this act, as applied to medicine, neurology, orthopedics, pediatrics, psychiatry, surgery, medical ethics, technical procedures in the practice of physical therapy as defined in this act In case of failure at any examination the applicant shall have the privilege of a second examination on payment of the regular fee.

In case of a second failure the applicant, to be eligible for a third examination, shall in addition to the requirements for previous examination have further pursued his studies for such time as the board may designate, and furnish satisfactory evidence thereof The grade required for passing the examination before the board shall be an average of not less than seventyfive per cent on all subjects examined upon and not less than sixty per cent on any individual branch Section 8.
Registrationcertificatespermits.The board shall register as a physical therapist each applicant who proves to the satisfaction of the board his fitness for registration under the terms of this act.

It shall issue to each person registered a certificate of registration, which shall be prima facie evidence of the right of the person to whom it is issued to represent himself as a registered physical therapist, subject to the conditions and limitations of this act The board may, upon request, issue to each properly qualified applicant for registration on licensure a temporary permit which will authorize such applicant to practice physical therapy until the next meeting of the hoard.
The applicant will pay a fee of two dollars for this privilege, none of which shall be returned, nor will it be applied to the fee for regular registration Section 9.
Extension of registrationannual feeinactive list.

Every registered physical therapist shall, on or before January 1 1953, and, on or before January 1, in each year thereafter, apply to the board for an extension of his registration and pay a fee of two dollars.

Registration that is not so extended shall automatically lapse The board may in its discretion revive and extend a lapsed registration on the payment of all past unpaid extension fees A person licensed under the provisions of this act desiring to retire from practice temporarily, shall send a written notice to the board Upon receipt of stich notice, the board shall place the name of such person upon the inactive list.
While remaining on this list the person shall not be subject to the payment of any renewal fees and shall not practice physical therapy in the state.
When such person desires to resume practice, application for renewal of license and payment of renewal fee for the current year shall be made to the board.

Grounds for refusal, suspension or revocation of registration.The board, after due notice and hearing, may refuse to register any applicant and may refuse to renew the registration of any registered person, and may suspend or revoke the registration otany registered person (a) Who is habitually drunk or who is addicted to the use of narcotic drugs ; (b) Who has been convicted of violating any state or federal narcotic law : (c) Who is, in the judgment of the board, guilty of immoral or unprofessional conduct ; (d) Who has been convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude ; (e) Who is guilty, in the judgment of the board, of gross negligence in his practice as a physical therapist ; (t) Who has obtained or attempted to obtain registration by fraud or material misrepresentation ; (g) Who has been declared insane by a court of competent jurisdiction and has not thereafter been lawfully declared sane; or (h) Who has treated or undertaken to treat ailments of human beings otherwise than by physical therapy and as authorized by this act, or who has undertaken to practice independent of the prescription.
direction or supervision of a person licensed to practice medicine or surgery without limitation.

ViolationspenaltiesAny person who is not registered under this act as a physical therapist, or whose registration has been suspended or revoked, or whose registration has lapsed and has not been revived, who uses in connection with his name the words or letters R.P.T, Registered Physical Therapist, Physical Therapist or Physio Therapist or any other letters, words or insignia indicating or implying that he is a registered physical theraPist, or who in any other way, orally or in writing or in print or by sign directly or by implication, represents himself as a registered physical therapist shall be guilty of misdemeanor and for each offense, Upon conviction by any court of competent jurisdiction, shall be fined in any sum not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisonment in the county jail for a period of not less than thirty nor more than ninety days, or both, at the discretion of the court, and that each day of such violation shall constitute a separate offense.
Onehalf of such fine shall go to the informant and the other half to the state.

False oath or representationpenaltiesA person who willfully makes a false oath or affirmation in any case in which an oath or affirmation is required by this act, or who obtains or attempts to obtain registration by any fraudulent representation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and for each offense, upon conviction by any court of competent jurisdiction, shall be fined in any sum not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisonment in the county jail for a period of not less than thirty days nor more than ninety days, or both, at the discretion of the court.

Treatment of human ailments by registrants and others.A person registered under this act as aphysical theraapist shall not treat human ailments by physical therapy or otherwise except under the direction, supervision and prescription of a person licensed to practice medicine or surgery.

shall be construed as authorizing a registered physical therapist or any other person to practice medicine, surgery, osteopathy, homeopathy, chiropractics, naturopathy, magnetic healing or any other form, branch or method of healing as authorized by the laws of the State of South Carolina.

Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction by a court of competent jurisdiction, shall be punished as set out in Section 5165 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942.

Practice of other forms of therapy, massaging or related treatment.Nothing contained in this act shall be construed to limit or prevent the practice of any other form of therapy, massaging, or related treatment by any person not registered under the act, if such person does not in any way represent himself to be a registered physical therapist.

Provided, that nothing in this act shall be construed to prevent a person, duly licensed, to practice chiropractic medicine under the existing laws of this state, to practice that form of the healing art herein defined as physical therapy.

Provided, further, that nothing in this act shall be construed to restrict, inhibit or limit the practice of chiropractic medicine as now practiced in South Carolina and as taught by accredited schools or colleges of chiropractic medicine.
Provided, that nothing contained in this act shall affect any duly licensed naturopathic doctor in the practice of his profession af naturopathy in this state.
Rules records finances reports.The board is authorized to adopt reasonable rules to carry this act into effect and may amend and revoke such rules at its discretion.
The board shall keep a record of its proceedings under this act and a register of all persons registered under it.

The register shall show the name of every living registrant, his last known place of business and last known place of residence, and the date and number of his registration and certificate as a registered physical therapist.

The board shall during the month of January of every year compile a list of registered physical therapists authorized to practice physical therapy in tke state and shall mail a copy of the list to the superintendent of every known hospital, and every person licensed to practice medicine and surgery in the state.

Any interested person in the state is entiled to obtain a copy of that list on application to the board and payment of such amount as may be fixed by the board, which amount shall not exceed the cost of the list so furnished.

The beard is authorized to have and to use an official seal bearing the words: State Board of Examination and Registration of Physical Therapists in South Carolina, All moneys coming into the possession of the board shall be held by the secretarytreasurer of the board asa special fund for meeting the expenses of the board and carrying out the provisions of this act, and for the promotion of physical therapy education and good standards of physical therapy in this state and he shall give such bond as the board shall, from time to time, direct, the expenses of such bond to be paid out of the funds of the board.
All disbursements from the funds of the board must have the approval of the president.

The board shall make an annual report of its proceedings to the Governor at the close of each fiscal year, which report shall contain an account of all moneys received and disbursed by it pursuant to this act.

Investigations prosecution of violators.The board shall investigate every supposed violation of this act coming to its notice and shall report to the proper solicitor all cases that in the judgment of the board warrant prosecution.

Every police officer, sheriff, and peace officer shall investigate every supposed violation of this act that comes to his notice or of which he has received complaint, and apprehend and arrest all violators.
It shall be the duty of the attorney general and of the several solicitors to prosecute violations of this act.

Invalidity.If any provision of this act or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of the act which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of this act are declared to be severable.
Short titleThis act may be cited as the Physical Therapists Practice Act.
Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 29th day of February, 1952.

791 An Act To Amend section 499636, 499641 And 499642, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Amended, Relating To Assistance To Children In Need And Aid To The Needy Blind, So As To Provide For Children Born Within One Year Immediately Preceding The Application For Assistance; To Disregard The First Fifty Dollars Per Month Of Earned Income For Blind Recipients; And To Provide For Examinations By Either Optometrists Or Physicians Skilled In Diseases Of The Eye.
499636, 1942 Code, amendedaid grant dependent childappeals.Section 499636, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, relating to aid to dependent children, is amended to read, as follows: section 499636.
The county department shall make an investigation and examination of the circumstances of such child.
Such investigation and examination shall be made in accordance with rules prescribed by the state department.
A report of such investigation and examination shall be made in writing and shall become a part of the records of the county department.

If such child is found to be in need and to have resided in the State of South Carolina for one year immediately preceding the application for such aid or to have been born within one year immediately preceding the application, if the parent or other relative with whom the child is living has resided in the state for one year immediately preceding the birth of such child, the county department shall grant such aid as may be necessary for the support of such child in its own home or in the home of one of its relatives as set forth in this chapter, in a manner compatible with decency and health.
In case application for aid for a dependent child is rejected by the county department, appeal may be made to the state department as elsewhere provided in this chapter. Section 2.
499641, 1942 Code, amendedaid grant blind.Section 499641, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as last amended by Act No.
242, Acts of 1947, relating to aid to the needy blind, is amended to read as follows: section 499641.

Within available appropriations and subject to the rules and regulations of the state department, the amount of assistance which any person shall receive shall he determined by the county department after making such investigation as is necessary or required by the state department.
The investigation shall be made with due regard to the resources, necessary expenditures, and other pertinent conditions existing in the case of each applicant.
In making the investigation the first fifty dollars a month of earned income shall not be considered.

The amount of assistance given shall be sufficient, when added to other income and means of sttpport of the recipient, to provide such person with a reasonable subsistence compatible with decency and health. Section 3.

499642, 1942 Code, amendedmedical examination for determining blindness.Section 499642, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, relating to aid to the needy blind, is amended to read as follows: section 499642.

The state department shall designate the procedure to be followed and shall establish a register of optometrists and physicians, skilled in the diseases of the eye, from which the e applicant may select one to conduct a competent medical examination for determining his blindness.
The state department shall pay for such examination.
No application for assistance shall be approved until the applicant has been examined.

Any recipient of assistance shall submit to reexamination as to his eyesight when required to do so and shall furnish any information required by the state department. Section 4. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
792 An Act To Amend Section 2736, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, By Providing For The Establishment Of Tax Districts In Newberry County.

2736, 1942 Code, amendedtax districts, Newberry Countyappointment of boards of assessors.Section 2736, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is amended by adding thereto the following proviso: Provided, that in Newberry County each of the seven school districts established by a reorganization order of the county board of education in 1951, by authority of Act No.

379 of the Acts of 1951, shall constitute a tax district, and provided, further, that the boards of assessors for the said tax districts shall be appointed by the county auditor. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
793 An Act To Amend Section 703599 (p), Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, So As To Further Define A Benefit Year Under The South Carolina Unemployment Compensaton Law.

703599, 1942 Code, amendedbenefit year defined for Unemployment Compensation Law.Section 703599 (p), Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, which defines a Benefit year under the South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law, is amended by striking it out and inserting in lieu thereof the following : section 703599 (p) Benefit year with respect to any individual means the one year period beginning with the first day of the first week with respect to which the individual first files a valid daim for benefits, and thereafter the one year period beginning with the first day of the first week with respect to which the individual first files a valid claim for benefits after the termination of his last preceding benefit year.

Any claim for benefits made in accordance with Section 703586 (a) shall be deemed to be a valid claim for the purpose of this subsection if the individual has been paid the wages for insured work required under Section 703584 (e). Section 2.
Application This act shall apply to all benefit years established on and after the effective date hereof.

704 An Act To Require That Any Person Making A Written Statement Before Any State, County, Or Municipal Investigation, Be Furnished A Copy Of Such Statement; And To Prohibit The Subsequent Questioning Of The Maker Of The Statement On The Contents Thereof In Any Future Hearing Or Oriminal Judicial oceed Se Shown nat ne Maker Was Given ng Unt: Reasonable Time In Which To Read The Statement, And Was Furnished The Required Copy.

Public employee taking copy of statement from another shall give copy to such person.Whenever any person employed by the State of South Carolina, or any county, city or municipality thereof, or any part of any such governing body, shall take a written statement in any investigation of any kind or nature from any person, the person receiving or taking the written statement shall give to the person making the statement a copy thereof and shall obtain from the person making the statement a signed receipt for the copy so delivered Section 2.

Examination of witness in criminal proceeding concerning written statement made to public employee.No witness in any preliminary hearing or in any criminal judicial proceeding of any kind or nature shall be examined or crossexamined by any examiner, solicitor, lawyer or prosecuting officer concerning a written statement formerly made and given to any person employed by the State of South Carolina, or any county, city or municipality thereof or any part of any such governing body, unless it first be shown that at the time of the making of the statement the witness was given an exact copy of the statement, and that before his examination or crossexamination the witness was given a copy of the statement and allowed a reasonable time in which to read it Section 3.

Admissibility of such statement in evidence.Unless the provisions of Section 1 and 2 have been complied with, no such statement shall be admissible in evidence in any case, nor shall any reference be made to it in the trial of any case Section 4. RepealaAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed Section 5. Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor Approved the Ist day of March, 1952 (R862, H1562) No.
795 An Act To Amend Section 3 Of Act No.

809 Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions Of The General Assembly, 1948, Relating To The County Government Of Anderson County, So As To More Specifically Define The Duties Of The Supervisor In Connection With The County Courthouse.
Act 809 of 1948 amendedduties of supervisor in regard courthouse, Anderson County.Section 3 of Act No.

809 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1948, is hereby amended by adding after the word buildings on line 2 the following: , including the county courthouse and the employment of the janitor thereof,, so that when so amended Section 3 shall read as follows: section 3.

The supervisor shall, subject to such limitations as may be herein placed upon him, have charge of the buildings, including the county courthouse and the employment of the janitor thereof, and maintenance of roads, the county chaingang, and county prisoners, and is charged with the care and supervision of all county property not specifically falling under the care and supervision of said board.
The supervisor shall have charge of all road construction and maintenance.

It is hereby declared to be the best policy for the county that there be expeditious improvement and surface treating of all county roads in accordance with acts passed by the General Assembly of this state to the end that there shall be an equitable distribution of road improvement and surface treating of roads in each township throughout the county.

Said board is hereby vested with all authority and power requisite and is directed that as the present bonded indebtedness of Anderson County for roads is liquidated to yearly issue, an equal amount of new bonds of the county in the place of those liquidated until such time as all county roads shall have been surface treated; Provided, that no bonds shall be issued under the provisions of this section unless a majority of the members of the General Assembly from Anderson County, including the Senator, shall have authorized same in writing.

Provided, that the clerk of court shall have charge of the court room and jury rooms of Anderson County Courthouse. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect January 1, 1953. Approved the 29th day of February, 1952.

796 An Act To Amend Section 28534 Of The Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Established By Act 186 Of The General Assembly For 1951, To Further Define And Fix The Powers And Duties Of The Delinquent Tax Collector For Colleton County.

28534, 1942 Code, amendedduties and powers of delinquent tax collector, Colleton Countydeeds ratifiedspecial deputy sheriff abolished.Section 28534 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina for 1942 as enacted by Act 186 of the General Assembly for 1951 is hereby amended by striking out subsection (c) of Section 28534 and substituting in place thereof the following so that subsection (c) of Section 28534 shall read as follows, to wit: (c) The Sheriff of Colleton County is hereby relieved from the duty of collecting delinquent taxes, and the delinquent tax collector is charged with this duty and to that end is authorized to collect executions, levy, advertise and sell property for taxes and make title thereto and order possession thereof to be delivered to the purchaser with all the powers as now by law conferred upon the sheriff for similar duties.

It shall be the duty of the sheriff upon the written order of the delinquent tax collector to take possession of property sold for taxes and to which the title has been made and to deliver the possession thereof to the purchaser at such tax sale.

All tax executions heretofore issued by the treasurer to the sheriff shall be delivered to the delinquent tax collector and all future executions shall be delivered to the delinquent tax collector for collection.

The delinquent tax collector shall make appropriate deeds or bills of sale to the purchasers at tax sales for all property sold by either the delinquent tax collector or the Sheriff of Colleton County and for which deeds have not been executed and delivered by the sheriff, and all such deeds executed and delivered by either the Delinquent Tax Collector or the Sheriff of Colleton County prior to the effective date of this enactment are hereby ratified and confirmed.

797 An Act To Provide A Tax Of Five Mills For School Purposes; To Prohibit The Levy Of Local Millage For Retiring Certain Notes Or Bonds; And To Repeal Certain Tax Levies For The High School Districts Of The County.

Tax levy to pay school district indebtedness, Oconee CountyThe Auditor of Oconee County is hereby directed to levy and the treasurer of the county to collect annually, commencing with the tax year beginning January 1, 1952, a five mill tax upon all taxable property in the county, for the purpose of redemption of any notes or outstanding obligations of any school district of the county outstanding on the date of the consolidation of school districts by the county board of education pursuant to authority of Act No.
The tax provided for herein shall be used to retire such indebtedness as owed prior to the date of consolidation of the school districts, section 2.

No local millage to retire certain notes or bonds.Commencing with the tax year beginning January 1, 1952 no local millage shall be levied for the purpose of retiring notes or bonds incurred prior to the date of school district consolidation referred to in Section 1.
RepealAct No.

164 of 1949; and that portion of Section 5640 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, which provides a three mill unifo tax upon each of the high school districts of the county are hereb repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 29th day of F ebruar

798 An Act To Establish A Civil And Criminal Court For A Certain Portion Of Darlington County; To Prescribe Its Jurisdiction, Powers, And Duties; To Provide For Its Officers And Their Compensation; And To Repeal Act No.
270 Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions Of The General Assembly, 1951, Relating To The Civil Court Of Darlington County.

Civil and criminal court for portion of Darlington County.There is hereby established a civil and criminal court for Darlington County except that portion of the county formerly known and designated as Pond Hollow School District with such jurisdiction, powers and rules as herein provided.
The civil and criminal court so established shall be inferior to the circuit court and appeals therefrom shall be to the circuit court.

Court of recordsealjurisdiction and presumption.The court shall be one of record except as provided in Section 17, and have a seal inscribed with the words Civil and Criminal Court of Darlington, and the same presumption in favor of its jurisdiction and the validity of its judgments and decrees shall hold as in the case of judgments rendered by circuit courts.
General provisions applicableentry of judgments.

All general laws and statutory provisions applicable generally to the circuit courts of this state and trial of cases therein, shall apply to the court and to the conduct and trial of cases therein except as provided in Section 17; but any judgment rendered, other than that upon the verdict of a jury, may be entered upon the day of such rendition.

Pleadings procedure practice evidence.The same form of pleadings and the same rules of procedure, practice and evidence shall obtain in the court as is provided by law for the trial of civil cases in the circuit courts, except as provided in Section 17.

Jury trialEither party may demand a jury trial in such cases in which a trial by jury is granted as a right under the Constitution and laws of this state, but such demand must be made on or before the first day of the term, or upon the call of the calendar on the first day of the term, and the failure to make such demand shall be a waiver of the right, where not inconsistent with this act.

Jurisdiction of judge.In all cases within the jurisdiction of the court and pending therein, the judge shall have the same jurisdiction both in open court and at chambers, as is possessed by circuit judges over cases pending in circuit courts over which they are presiding, or in the circuits in which they are residents, except as provided in Section 17.

Appeal.tin all cases of which the court shall have jurisdiction except as provided in Section 17, the right of appeal shall be to the circuit court, in the same manner and pursuant to the same tules, practices and procedures as now govern appeals from circuit courts, except that the record need not be printed.

Civil jurisdictionjudge act as special refereeThe court shall have concurrent jurisdiction with the court of common pleas in all civil cases and special proceedings, except cases at law where the amount demanded in the complaint exceeds one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or when the value of the property involved exceeds one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), but such jurisdiction shall not extend to cases where the title to real estate is in question.

The court shall have concurrent jurisdiction with the court of common pleas of the county in actions relating to divorce from the bonds of matrimony and all matters affecting the custody and maintenance of children.
The judge of the court may act as special referee in such matters as the circuit court shall deem advisable to refer to him.

Terms.The court shall be held at the discretion of the judge at such times as he may deem necessary and continue for such time as is required to dispose of the business before the court; however, the court shall always be open for cases and hearings such as can be disposed of without a jury.

Jury commissionersjurorsstrikes.The board of jury commissioners as constituted by law for the drawing of the jurors for the circuit court shall constitute the board of jury commissioners for the drawing of jurors to attend the sessions of the court except as provided in Section 17.

The commissioners shall, upon the order of the court at such times as shall be fixed and after five days notice of such drawing, draw a panel of petit jurors from the jury box (whether a jury has been previously drawn or not), and shall immediately issue to the sheriff a venire containing the names of the persons drawn as petit jurors, which venire shall be returnable at such times as may be named by the court, and the persons so served shall be the jurors, and the law relating to the qualification, drawing and summoning of jurors of the circuit court, shall apply, except as otherwise provided in this section.
Not more than eighteen persons shall be drawn and summoned to attend at the same time at any session of the court, unless the court shall order otherwise.
Jurors drawn and summoned shall appear and attend upon the sessions of the court for which summoned until excused or discharged by the judge.

Service as a juror in the court shall not be held to exempt a juror from service as such in the circuit court, in the same year, nor shall a juror be required to serve in such court more than once in the same year.

The plaintiff and defendant in a cause shall, each, be allowed to strike three jurors, from a panel of twelve to be prepared from the venire by the clerk so that the number of jurors remaining shall be six who shall try the case or cause.

Clerkrecords.The clerk of the circuit court shall be ex officio clerk of the court, and shall keep such calendars, minutes and records and the cases pending, and attend and perform the duties as required of him by law as clerk of the circuit court.
The costs and fees of the clerk in cases in the court shall be the same as those allowed in similar cases in the court of common pleas.
The county board of directors of Darlington County shall provide all books necessary for keeping records of the court.
Sheriff.The sheriff of the county shall attend upon all sessions of the court, and shall execute the orders, writs and mandates as required by law of him in the circuit court.
The costs and fees of the sheriff in cases in the court shall be the same as those allowed in similar cases in the court of common pleas.

. Pay of jurors and witnesses.Jurors in attendance shall receive as compensation for their services the same per diem and mileage as is allowed jurors in the circuit court and witnesses in attendance shall receive the same compensation as witnesses in attendance upon the circuit court except as provided in Section 17.

Judge appointment term oath powers.It shall be the duty of the Governor to appoint a resident attorney at law of Darlington County as judge of the civil and criminal court by and with the advice and consent of the Senate.
The first appointment made under this act shall be for a term commencing on date of approval of this act and continuing to July 1, 1956, and until his successor shall be appointed and qualified.
Each appointment thereafter shall be for a term of four years commencing on July 1, 1956, and until his successor shall be appointed and qualified.
He shall possess all the powers in respect to preserving order or punishing for contempt of court as now possessed by circuit judges except as provided in Section 17.
He shall not charge on the facts but shall declare the law only.
The salary of the judge shall be such as the General Assembly may provide and shall be paid by the county in monthly installments.

All vacancies in the office of the judge of the court shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term by the Governor in the same manner as herein provided for the appointment of the judge for the full term.
BailiffsThe judge of the court may appoint a sufficient number of bailiffs, not to exceed two, to attend upon the court, and to be subject to the orders thereof.
The bailiffs shall have the same power as the constables of the county, and shall receive such compensation as is now received by bailiffs in the court of common pleas.
Cases transferred to.All cases now pending in the Civil Court of Darlington County as created by Act No.

270 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions, 1951, are hereby transferred to the Civil and Criminal Court of Darlington and all cases in the Court of Common Pleas for Darlington County, within the jurisdictional limits of the civil and criminal court may, upon motion by the plaintiff, be transferred to the civil and criminal court docket.

Concurrent jurisdiction with magistratescriminal and civil matters.The Civil and Criminal Court of Darlington shall have concurrent jurisdiction with the courts of magistrates within its jurisdictional boundaries and may try all causes both criminal and civil heretofore triable by magistrates and in the same manner as to practice, procedure, and drawing of jurors and their services.
In all matters before the judge under this section, his powers, duties and responsibilities shall be those of a magistrate.
Appeals in matters arising under this section shall be to the circuit court and in the same manner as from the courts of magistrate.

Causes transferred from Civil Court of Darlington County to.All causes both civil and criminal now pending in the Civil Court of Darlington County are hereby transferred to the Court created under the terms and provisions of this act.
Stenographer.The judge shall appoint for the court an official stenographer, who shall receive such compensation as the General Assembly may provide.
OfficeThe Board of Directors of Darlington County shall provide suitable office space in the court house for the judge and all necessary office equipment and supplies.
Act 270 of 1951 repealedcivil court for portion of Darlington County.Act No.
270 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1951, is hereby repealed.
Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Invalidity.If any part of this act shall be declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court of South Carolina it shall not affect the remaining portions of this act.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 29th day of Fesmary, 1952.

799 An Act To Create The Fort Hill Natural Gas Authority, To Define Its Service Area, To Prescribe Its Functions And Powers, To Authorize Said Authority To Borrow Money, To Confer Upon It All Powers Contained In Chapters 187 And 189, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina For 1942, As Now Or Hereafter Amended, To Make Provision For The Disposition Of The Revenues And Earnings Of Such Authority, And To Make It Unlawful To Hurt Or Damage The System Or Property Of The Authority Or To Obtain Gas Therefrom Except In Accordance With The Regulations Of The Authority And To Prescribe Penalties For Violations Thereof.

Whereas, the Towns of Easley, Liberty, Central and Clemson, in Pickens County, the Town of Williamston, in Anderson County, and the Town of Seneca, in Oconee County, propose to make application to the Federal Power Commission that it require the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Company, whose main transmission line extends through northwestern South Carolina, to furnish each of them an allotment of natural gas for the use of the inhabitants of such towns and their surrounding environs; and, Whereas, it is considered likely that other nearby towns may likewise seek allotments of natural gas; and, Whereas, it is deemed that the most economical method by which such towns can avail themselves of such gas, if allotments therefor be granted, is through the construction of a transmission line system designed to serve all of the towns named supra, and such others whose corporate authorities shall elect to participate in the project as hereinafter authorized ; and, Whereas, it has been further determined that the most propitious and economical method of effecting the construction of such project and financing the same is through the establishment of an authority which shall be empowered: (1) to cause the construction of the Project; (2) to finance the same through loans payable from the earnings of such system; and, (3) to operate and maintain the same for the benefit of the municipalities which it serves, Now Therefore, Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1.

Fort Hill Natural Gas Authorityfunctionsystem defined.There is hereby created a body corporate and politic of perpetual succession to be known as the Fort Hill Natural Gas Authority (hereinafter sometimes referred to as the authority).

It shall be the function of the authority to cause the construction of a natural gas transmission line from the transmission line of Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Company, at or near Belton, which shall extend from that point in as direct a route as possible in such fashion as to enable it to supply distribution systems in each of Williamston, Easley, Liberty, Central, Clemson and Seneca.

The authority shall also be empowered to make further extensions of such transmission line, and to construct extensions therefrom designed to serve distribution systems for populated areas and towns located throughout its service area.

The transmission line, such distribution systems, the component parts of all, all apparatus, and equipment incident thereto or used or useful in the operation thereof, and all additions, improvements and extensions to any of the same, shall henceforth be referred to collectively in this act as the system.

The authority shall be further empowered to continuously operate and maintain such system and shall have the further functions and duties prescribed in this act, and shall have all of the powers herein granted.

Service area.In order that the system of the authority shall not unduly compete with other natural gas systems, it shall only be empowered to serve customers within its service area, under the conditions afterwards enumerated in this section.
The service area of the authority shall extend laterally for fifteen miles on each side of its transmission line.

Within such service area, the authority may build extensions, laterals and distribution systems, provided, always: (1) that no line, extension or system shall be located within the corporate limits of any incorporated municipality, without the consent of the corporate authorities of such municipality ; and, (2) that no distribution system shall be constructed and no gas shall be transported to or sold in any town which operates a municipal natural gas system, or in any town which may have granted or may have undertaken to grant any franchise to any privately operated natural gas system.

No municipality or other public body shall operate a competing system within the service area, provided, that this provision shall not be construed to deny to anyone the right to construct transmission lines through the area.

Appointmenttermsvacancypay.The authority shall consist of a board of six members as follows: There shall be one member, who shall live in the corporate limits of Williamston, or ae within one mile therefrom; there shall be one member, who shall live in the corporate limits of Easley, or within one mile therefrom; there shall be one member, who shall live in the corporate limits of Liberty, or within one mile therefrom; there shall be one member, who shall live in the corporate limits of Central, or within one mile therefrom; there shall be one member, who shall live in the corporate limits of Clemson, or within one mile therefrom; and there shall be one member, who shall live in the corporate limits of Seneca, or within one mile therefrom.

Such membership shall be filled by appointment by the Governor, upon the recommendation of the Senator from the county m which the above named towns be located, except that for the purpese of this portion of this act the Town of Clemson shall be construed to be located in Pickens County.

Two of such members shall hold office for a term expiring July 1, 1954, two others shall hold office for aterm expiring July 1, 1956, and the remaining two shall hold office for a term expiring July 1, 1958, or in the case of all members until their successors shall have been appointed and shall have qualified.
As scon as practicable, following the appointments, the members of a the authority shall meet and org: d anize by electing one of their members as chairman and another as secretary.

They shall then determine the duration of their initial terms by lot, after which appropriate certificates shall be filed with the Governor and the Secretary of State, in order that the records of those offices may show the correct expiration dates of the terms of the members of the authority.

Vacancies either among the initial appointees or among their succe SSOTS er in office occurring by reason of death, resignation, refusal to serve, or otherwise, shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments for the remainder of the term of office in which the vacancy shall have occurred.

Upon the expiration of the terms of office, successors shall be appointed in the same manner as the orginal appointments were made for terms of six years, expiring SIX years from July first in the year in which the term of office of the previous appointee expired.

As soon as practical certified copies of the organization proceedings shall be filed in the office of the clerk of court for each county in which the proposed main transmission line will lie. The members shall serve without salary, but shall be compensated for any actual expenses incurred by them on any oficial business of the authority.

Member towns municipal contracts(a) The Towns of Williamston, Easley, Liberty, Central, Clemson and Seneca shall be deemed member towns of the authority as soon as the corporate authorities of such towns adopt resolutions approving such membership ; the adoption of which resolutions being hereby authorized.

(b) In order to make it possible for other towns within the service area of the authority to make use of any supply of natural gas which may be allotted to them or to the authority by the Federal Power Commission, the authority and the corporate authorities of such towns are respectively authorized to enter into contracts, on mutually agreeable terms, by which: (1) the town will become a member town of the authority, or, (2) the town will purchase transmission service for its own distribution system through the transmission system of the authority.

In the latter case, such contracts shall extend for such period of time as the authority and the said corporate authorities shall determine, and shall be upon such terms as shall be mutually agreed upon.

Powers.In order that the authority shall be fully empowered to construct the system, to operate it, and to enlarge and extend the same within the limits of the service area, it shall have the following powers: (a) To have perpetual succession.
(b) To sue and be sued.
(c) To adopt, use and alter a corporate seal.
(d) To make bylaws for the management and regulation of its affairs, and to define a quorum for its meetings.
(e) To acquire, purchase, hold, use, lease, mortgage, sell, transfer and dispose of any property, real, personal or mixed, or any interest therein.
(f) To build, construct, maintain and operate a system of transmission lines designed to serve its service area, and from time to time to enlarge and extend the same.

(g) Subject to the limitations contained in Section 4, supra, to build, construct, maintain and operate distribution systems within such service area, designed to serve such service area, and from time to time to enlarge and extend the same.
(h) Subject to the limitations contained in Section 4, to build laterals and make connections to serve customers within its service area.

(i) To purchase, manufacture, produce and transport, or in any other manner, secure supplies of natural or manufactured gas, or both, and to enter into contracts for the acquisition of such gas, of such duration as the authority shall approve.
(j) To enter into contracts, by which it shall transport for others supplies of natural or manufactured gas, of such duration as the authority shall approve.

(k) To enter into contracts of long duration for the sale of intertuptible gas only, but all of such contracts shall contain a provision permitting the authority to increase the price charged its customers for gas if the authority, in turn, shall be required to pay more for its gas than it did on the occasion that such contract was entered into, and no contract of any sort shall be entered into which shall not in all respects be subordinate to any covenant or undertaking which the authority may make in the proceedings taken in connection with the issuance of any bonds or other obligations of the authority.

But, no contract of any sort shall be made respecting the sale of firm gas allocated to the authority, which shall be sold in accordance with such schedule of rates as shall from time to time be in effect, (\) To prescribe, place into effect and to revise, whenever it wishes or may be so required, a schedule of rates and charges for all firm gas furnished or sold by its system.

(m) To make use of county and state highway rightsofways in which to lay pipes and lines, in such manner and under such conditions as the appropriate officials in charge of such rightsofways shall approve.

(n) Subject always to the limitations of Section 4, Article VIII of the Constitution, to make use of the streets and public ways of any incorporated municipality for the purpose of laying pipes and lines, (0) To exercise the power of eminent domain for any corporate function; provided such powers of eminent domain shall not be exercised in order to acquire the property of any natural gas comPany subject to regulation by the Federal Power Commission.

Such Power may be exercised through any procedure prescribed by Chapter 182, Code of Laws of South Carolina for 1942, or by following the procedure for the exercise of eminent domain by the State 'ghway Department, prescribed by Article IV, Act 329 of 1951 (47th Statutes at Large, page 479, et seq), as such statutes are NOW constituted or as they may hereafter be constituted, following any amendment hereafter made to any of them.
(p) To appoint officers, agents, employees and servants and to prescribe their duties and to fix their compensation.

The power herein granted shall be deemed to extend to the authority the right to contract with any municipality in which the distribution system of the authority shall be located for the operation of any part of its system.

(q) To make andenter into contracts with the various municipalities herein mentioned for service and/or maintenance of the distribution systems and for collection of charges for service or for gas on such terms as may be mutually agreed upon by the authority and such municipalities.
(r) To make contracts for construction, engineering and other services with or without competitive bidding.
(s) To borrow money and to make and issue negotiable bonds, notes and other evidences of indebtedness, payable from all or any part of the revenues derived frem the operation of its system.

The sums borrowed may be those needed to pay all costs incident to the construction and establishment of the system, and any extension, addition, and improvement thereto, including engineering costs, construction costs, the sum needed to pay interest during the period prior to which the system, or any extension, addition or improvement thereto, shall be fully in operation, such sum as is needed to supply working capital to place the system in operation, and all other expenses of any sort that the authority may incur in establishing, extending and enlarging the system.

Neither the faith and credit of the State of South Carolina, nor any county, municipality, division or subdivision shall be pledged for the payment of the principal and interest of the obligations, and there shall be on the face of each obligation a statement, plainly worded, to that effect.

To the end that a convenient procedure for borrowing money may be prescribed, the authority shall be fully empowered to avail itself of all powers granted by Chapters 187 and 189, as now or hereafter constituted, it being the intent of this provision that future amendments and modifications of Chapters 187 and 189 shall be deemed to amend and revise correspondingly the powers granted by this section.

In exercising the powers conferred upon the authority*by Chapters 187 and 189, the authority may make all pledges and covenants authorized by any provision of either chapter, and may confer upon the holders of its securities all rights and liens authorized by either chapter.

Specifically and notwithstanding contrary provisions in either of said Chapters 187 and 189, if contrary provisions there be, the authority may: (1) Covenant and agree that upon it being adjudged in default as to the payment of any installment of principal or interest upon any obligation issued or in default as to the performance of any covenant or undertaking made by it, that in such event the principal of all obligations of such issue may be declared forthwith due and payable, notwithstanding that any of them may not have then matured.

(2) Confer upon a corporate trustee the power to make disposition of the proceeds from all borrowings and of all revenues derived from the operation of the system, in accordance with the resolutions adopted by the authority as an incident to the issuance of any notes, bonds, or other types of securities.

(3) Declare that such obligations and the interest thereon shall be exempt from all state, county, municipal, school district, and all other taxes or assessments, direct or indirect, general or special, whether imposed for the purpose of general revenue or otherwise.
(4) Dispose of its obligations at public or private sale, and upon such terms and conditions as it shall approve.
(5) Make such provision for the redemption of any obligations issued by it prior to their stated maturity, with or without premium, and on such terms and conditions as the authority shall approve.
(6) Covenant and agree that any cushion fund established to further secure the payment of the principal and interest of any obligations shall be in a fixed amount.
(7) Covenant and agree that no free service will be furnished to any person, firm, corporation, municipal corporation, or any other subdivision or division of the state.

(8) Prescribe the procedure, if any, by which the terms of the contract with holders of its obligations may be amended, the number of obligations whose holders must consent thereto, and the manner in which such consent shall be given.

(9) Prescribe the events of default and the terms and conditions upon which all or any obligations shall become or may be declared due before maturity and the terms and conditions upon which such declaration and its consequences may be waived.
(t) To do all other acts and things necessary or convenient to carry out any function or power committed or granted to the authority.

Disposition of net revenues.All net revenues derived from the system, whose disposition the authority shall not have covenanted or contracted to otherwise dispose of, shall be paid over to the municipalities which shall be member towns of the authority in the proportion that the sale of firm gas within the corporate limits of each member town bears to the aggregate sales of firm gas within the corporate limits of all member towns, provided, that the authority may impose upon municipalities becoming member towns subsequent to the completion of the project suitable conditions designed to require such member towns to pay their equitable share of the cost of the project.

Rates.The rates charged for services furnished by the system, as constructed, improved, enlarged and extended shall not be subject to supervision or regulation by any state bureau, board, commission or other like instrumentality or agency thereof.

Property exempt from taxes.All property of and income of the authority shall be exempt from all taxes levied by the state, county or an municipality, division, subdivision or agency thereof, direct or indirect.

Restriction of StatuteSo long as the authority shall be indebted to any person, firm or corporation on any bonds, notes or other obligations issued pursuant to the authority of this act, the provisions of this act and the powers granted to the authority shall not be in any way diminished or restricted, and this provision of this act shall be deemed a part of the contract between the authority and the holders of such obligations, but this section shall not be construed to prevent the enlarging of the service area of the authority, if such be done by appropriate amendatory statute.

Penalties.It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully injure or destroy, or in any manner hurt, damage, tamper with, or impair the system of the authority, or any part of the same, or any apparatus or equipment incident thereto, or used or useful in the operation of such system, or to obtain gas therefrom except in accordance with the regulations promulgated by the authority.

Any person so offending shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than INU WAU, WU one hundred dollars, or shall be imprisoned for not more than thirty days at the discretion of the court, and shall be further liable to pay all damages suffered by the authority.
InvalidityIf any part of this act shall be held unconstitutional, such unconstitutionality shall not affect the remainder of this act.
Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent with this act are hereby repealed to the extent of such inconsistencies.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 3rd day of March, 1952
800 An Act To Amend Section 4 Of Act No.
308 Of The Acts Of 1951, Which Amends Act No.
606 Of The Acts Of 1948, Relating To The Commission Form Of Government For The City Of Camden, 80 As To Change The Time Of Elections.
Act 606 of 1948 amendedmayor and commissioners, Camdenelectiontermsvacancy.Section 4 of Act No.
308 of the Acts of 1951, which amends Act No.
606 of the Acts of 1948, relating to the commission form of government for the City of Camden, is amended by striking the entire section and inserting in lieu thereof the following : section 4.

If a majority of the voters voting at the election herein ordered vote in the affirmative, then and in that event subsection (3) of Section 76221, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as set forth in Act No.
606 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1948, is hereby amended by striking out subsection (3) and by inserting in lieu thereof the following which shall be subsection (3).

(3) If a majority of the voters voting at the election shall vote in the affirmative, that is, in favor of such commission form of government with a city manager, then a special general election shall be held in the city to be voted on by the qualified electors of the city on the second Tuesday in June, 1948, whereat there shall be elected from the city at large a mayor who shall be paid a salary of seven hundred fifty ($750.00) dollars a year, and two commissioners who shall each be paid a salary of five hundred ($500.00) dollars per year.

Beginning with the regular election hereinafter provided for on the second Tuesday in May, 1952, the term of office for the mayor shall be for a period of four (4) years and until his successor shall have been elected and qualified.

The terms of office of the four (4) commissioners shall be for a period of four (4) years and until their successors shall have been elected and qualified, provided that, in the election to be held on the second Tuesday in May, 1952, there shall be elected two (2) commissioners for a four (4) year term and one (1) commissioner for a two (2) year term in such manner that in the elections for 1954 two commissioners shall be elected for four (4) year terms and in 1956 two commissioners and the mayor shall be elected for four (4) year terms.

In the election to be held on the second Tuesday in May, 1952, the two (2) candidates for commissioner receiving the highest number of votes at the election shall be for the longer term, to wit, four (4) years and the candidate receiving the third highest number of votes, or in the event of a runoff, the highest number of votes, if two shall have been declared elected in the first election, or the second highest number of votes, if only one shall have been declared elected on the first ballots, shall be declared elected to fill the twoyear term hereinabove provided.  Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 3rd day of March, 1952.
801 An Act To Provide For The Election Of Trustees For The St. Matthews And Cameron Centralized High School Districts In Calhoun County.

Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1. , Election of trustees, St. Matthews and Cameron Centralized High School Districts, Calhoun County.The Calhoun County Board of Education shall cause an election to be held on the first Tuesday of March, 1952, and every even year thereafter for the purpose of electing trustees for the St. Matthews and Cameron Centralized High School Districts.
Notice of all elections shall be published at least ten days in advance in a newspaper of general circulation in the county and posted in three conspicuous places within the districts.
The voting precincts shall be the same as those used in the general election and no special registration shall be required to vote.

Number and terms for 8t. Matthews.The number and terms of office of the trustees of the St. Matthews Centralized High School District shall be as follows: At the St. Matthews and Dixie precincts the trustee receiving the highest number of votes shall serve for four years and the trustee receiving the next highest number of votes shall serve for a term of two years, Ft.

Motte one trustee for four years, Bellville one trustee for two years, Bethel one trustee for four years, Sandy Run one trustee for two years, Sunny Plain one trustee for four years, Murph Mill one trustee for two years, and Center Hill one trustee for four years.

Number and terms for Cameron.The number and terms of office of the trustees for the Cameron Centralized High School District shall serve as follows: At the Cameron precinct the three trustees receiving the highest number of votes shall serve for a term of four years and the two trustees receiving the next highest number of votes shall serve for a term of two years.

At the Midway precinct the trustee receiving the highest number of votes shall serve for a term of four years and the trustee reciving the next highest number of votes shall serve for a term of two years.

At the Creston precinct the trustee receiving the highest number of votes shall serve for a term of four years and the trustee receiving the next highest number of votes shall serve for a term of two years.
Term after 1952.All trustees elected under the provisions of this act after the year 1952 shall hold office for a term of four years.
Duties of board of education.The board of education shall name the managers of elections, shall canvass the ballots, and declare the results of the election.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 3rd day of March, 1952.
802 An Act To Repeal An Act Entitled An Act To Create An Elementary School District In Oconee County... Etc., Designated As Act No.
85 Of The Acts Of 1951.

Act 85 of 1951 repealedelementary school district, Oconee County.An act entitled An Act To Create An Elementary School District In Oconee County Etc., approved April 4, 1951, and designated as Act No.
8&5 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of 1951, is hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 3rd day of March, 1952.
803 An Act To Fix The Apportionment Of Representatives Of The General Assembly.

Apportionment of Representatives.Until the next apportionment, the representatives of the several counties in the House of Representatives shall be as follows: Abbeville, one; Aiken, three; Allendale, one; Anderson, five; Bamberg, one; Barnwell, one; Beaufort, two; Berkeley, two; Calhoun, one; Charleston, ten; Cherokee, two; Chester, two; Chesterfield, two; Clarendon, two; Colleton, two; Darlington, three; Dillon, two; Dorchester, one; Edgefield, one; Fairfield, one; Florence, five; Georgetown, two; Greenville, ten; Greenwood, two; Hampton, one; Horry, three; Jasper, one; Kershaw, two; Lancaster, two; Laurens, three; Lee, one; Lexington, three; McCormick, one; Marion, two; Marlboro, two; Newberry, two; Oconee, two; Orangeburg, four; Pickens, two; Richland, eight; Saluda, one; Spartanburg, nine; Sumter, three; Union, two; Williamsburg, two; and York, four.

Time effectiveThis act shall be effective upon the filing in his office by the Secretary of State of South Carolina of a certificate that the above stated apportionment is in accordance with the Constitution of South Carolina.
Further time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 3rd day of March, 1952.
804 An Act To Amend Subparagraph (c) Of Paragraph (2) Of 8ubarticle III, Article VII, Act No.
379 Of The Acts Of 1951, Of The Retail Sales And Use Tax Of The State, Relating To Livestock, So As To Include Baby Chicks And Poults Within The Term Livestock.
Act 379 of 1951 amendedlivestock includes baby chicks and poults in sales and use tax law.Subparagraph (c), paragraph (2), subarticle III, Article VII, Act No.

379 of the Acts of 1951, is amended by adding another sentence thereto as follows: The term livestock shall be construed to include baby chicks and poults., so that when so amended subparagraph (c) shall read as follows: (c) The gross proceeds of sales of all livestock by whomsoever sold.
The term livestock shall be construed to include baby chicks and poults. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect July 1, 1952. Approved the 4th day of March, 1952.

805 An Act To Amend The First Paragraph Above Subsection (1) And Subsection (4) Of Section 6156, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To Sanitation And Drainage Commissioners And Their Powers In Certain Counties, So As To Exempt Darlington County From The Provisions Thereof.

6156, 1942 Code, amendedDarlington County exempted.The first paragraph above subsection (1) of Section 6156, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, relating to sanitation and drainage commissioners and their powers in certain counties, is amended by striking out on line 2 the word Darlington, so that when amended the first paragraph above subsection (1) shall read as follows: The county board of road commissioners of the counties of Abbeville, Beaufort, Chester, Colleton, Dillon, Florence, Greenville, Horry, Laurens, Marion, Marlboro, Oconee, Pickens, Spartanburg, York and Union, respectively, are authorized, in addition to the duties now imposed on them by law, to act as commissioners of health and drainage, and are empowered as such commissioners of health and drainage to act as follows, to wit: Section 2.

SameDarlington County exempted.Subsection (4) of Section 6156, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, relating to the powers of the commissioners, is amended by striking out on line 12 the word Darlington, so that when amended subsection (4) shall read as follows: (4) In cases where the general health of the county or neighborhood be seriously affected by the condition of any mill dam, the county commissioners of said county shall have the power to remove the cause of such nuisance; but a fair compensation must be paid to the owner thereof, the same to be assessed upon the property of those benefited by the removal of such nuisance.

They shall further regulate the condition of all mill dams in said county by requiring the owners thereof to furnish such mill dams with a substantial floodgate, if in their judgment the health of the neighborhood or the drainage of the land above the dams requires a floodgate to be placed in the dam, to be opened at and kept open for such times as the said county commissioners shall direct: provided, that in Florence and Pickens Counties the powers herein conferred shall apply to mill ponds and dams only: and further, that this subdivision shall not be construed to oust the court of general sessions of jurisdiction to abate any mill pond as a nuisance.

Any person or fersons ordered by the board of county commissioners to put in a foodgate in any mill dam under the provisions of this subdivision who shall fail to do so shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars, or be imprisoned for not exceeding one year. Section 3. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 3rd day of March, 1952.

806 An Act To Provide For A Meeting Of The Citizens In Each Bchool District In Florence County To Elect Boards Of Trustees, To Provide For Budgets For School Purposes In Each District, And To Provide For The Approval Of Same And Approval Of Tax Levies Within Each District.

Annual school district meetings, Florence county.On or before the fifteenth day of May 1952, and on or before the fifteenth day of April of each year thereafter, the board of trustees of each school district in Florence County shall call a meeting of the citizens of the district, such meeting to be held within the school district.
The time and place of such meeting shall be advertised in a newspaper of general circulation within the district at least once, ten days prior to the meeting.
The persons entitled to vote at the meeting shall have power to appoint a chairman and a secretary and to adjourn the meeting from time to time until business is completed.
It shall be the duty of the chairman of the meeting to keep a correct record of all of the proceedings and to file the same in the office of the county board of education.

Budgets.The board of trustees of the district shall submit to the citizens at the meeting provided for in Section 1 hereof, a proposed budget for the operation of the school or schools within the district, together with the estimated millage necessary to carry the budget into effect, which budget and millage shall only be adopted by majority vote of the qualified electors who return real or personal property for taxation, present at the meeting.
Such electors attending the meeting shall have the right to change, alter, reject or amend any budget proposed by the board of trustees.

Election of trustees.In any year when trustees are to be elected by any school district in Florence County, they shall be elected by a majority vote of the qualified electors present at the annual meeting provided for in Section 1 of this act.

Tax levycollectionThe chairman of the board of trustees of each district shall within one week after the fixing of the budget and millage as hereinabove provided, certify the same to the county auditor who shall levy such millage upon all taxable property within the school districts.

The Treasurer of Florence County shall collect the taxes so levied and the proceeds derived therefrom shall be kept by the treasurer and be disbursed to the individual districts upon warrants issued or drawn by the school districts.
No tax levied under the provisions of this act shall be repealed at any subsequent meeting.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 3rd day of March, 1952.
807 An Act To Amend Section 2446, Code Of Laws, 1942, As Amended By Act No.
379, Acts Of 1951, So As To Provide That No Gain Or Loss Shall Be Recognized On Any Final Distribution Of The Assets Of A Corporation In Certain Cases.
2446, 1942 Code, amendedno gain or loss recognized on final distribution of the assets of certain corporations.

, Code of Laws, 1942, is amended by adding at the end thereof the following: No gain or loss shall be recognized on any final distribution of the assets of a corporation if liquidation occurs during the period from January 1, 1951, to December 31, 1952, and if the liquidation is coincident with the condemnation or threat of condemnation, of all the real properties or business locations of the corporation, by the United States Government. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 3rd day of March, 1952.
808 An Act Increasing The Number Of School Trustees In Oconee County.
Additional school trustees, Oconee County.The County Board of Education in Oconee County shall appoint four additional school trustees.
The additional appointments and all future appointments shall be made from the former high school districts of the county so that each of the former high school districts shall be represented.
The terms of office of the trustees so appointed shall be staggered and shall hold office for such terms as are now provided by law.
Time effective This act shall fae effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 3rd day of March, 1952.
809 An Act To Provide For A Board Of Assessors And Equalization For The Property Taxes In Saluda County.

Saluda County board of assessorsappointment.The Auditor, Treasurer and Foreman of the Grand Jury of Saluda County are hereby authorized and directed to appoint and name a county board of assessors to consist of ten taxpayers of Saluda County whose duty it will be to look after the valuation, assessment and return of property for taxation in Saluda County and who shall serve for one year and shall be appointed during the month of March of each year.

The ten men named by the Auditor, Treasurer and Foreman of the Grand Jury of Saluda County shall have the duty of equalization of property for taxes as now provided for under the general law of this state.

The ten men who shall compose the County Board of Assessors and Equalization of Saluda County and who will be appointed as above set forth, shall be selected so that each section of Saluda County shall have representation on said board.

Oathduty.Before assuming their duties as members of the Board of Assessors and Equalization of Saluda County, each shall take an oath that he will fairly and impartially assess and equalize property values for the purpose of taxation, which said oath shall be filed in the office of the Clerk of Court for Saluda County, South Carolina.

The ten members of the board shall be charged with the duty and responsibility of fairly and justly equalizing all of the property of Saluda County and make every effort to see that all property is properly assessed for the purpose of taxation.
Pay.Each member of said board so appointed shall receive the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) per year for his services rendered in the capacity of tax assessor for the county.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 3rd day of March, 1952.
810 An Act To Provide Funds For Operating Expenses Of The High School District Or Districts Of Saluda County And Regulating The Allotment And Expenditure Thereof.

Credit certain delinquent taxes to high school districts, Saluda County.Any and all delinquent taxes collected by virtue of the levies heretofore existing for the Saluda County High School Building Fund shall be credited by the county treasurer to the high school district from which it is collected.

Apportionment of certain funds to high school districtsAny balance in the high school building fund when this act shall become effective shall be transferred to the county board of education account and any balance that is in the county board fund shall be carried forward in the county board of education account, and shall be apportioned out to the high school district or districts on or after December 1, 1952, upon the basis of the daily average attendance per resident pupils of Saluda County by the said beard.
Provided, the area lying within Saluda County which has been or may be consolidated with BatesburgLeesville High School District No.
3 of Lexington County shall not share or participate in these funds.

Use of alcoholic liquor tax and beer and wine tax.All alcoholic liquor tax and all beer and wine tax accruing to Saluda County for school purposes shall be credited to the county board of education account, and shall be for the use of the county board of education as a county board fund.

Any part of these funds not used by the county board shall be apportioned to the high school district or districts in the county that have a high school building or plant located in the district or districts in Saluda County.

Budgetstax levies.In order to further provide for the operating expenses of the schools of Saluda County the trustees of each high school district of the county shall on or before July the fifteenth of each year furnish to the county board of education a request of their financial requirements for the ensuing year.

The county board of education shall examine such request and approve the same for such an amount as in the judgment of the board is necessary and proper, and said county board shall direct the Auditor of Saluda County to place upon each school district a tax levy as shall be sufficient to raise the amount approved by the county board, and the treasurer shall collect the tax so levied and place the same to the account of the district from which it was collected and pay the same out only upon the warrant or warrants of the trustees of the district.
In no event shall the tax for said purpose be more than twelve mills in any one year.

Approval .and payment of claims.Any supplement paid teachers or adult bus drivers and all other expenditures for school purposes, including insurance premiums on buildings shall be approved and paid by the trustees out of funds of their district.
Time effective.This act shall become effective as soon as Saluda County has its school district or districts reorganized under the provisions of Act No.
379 of the General Assembly of 1951, and such reorganization approved and confirmed by the State Educational Finance Commission.
Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent with this act are hereby repealed. Approved the 4th day of March, 1952.
811 An Act To Provide For The Election Of School District Trustees For Richland County.

Boards of school trustees, Richland County.The board of trustees of each school district in Richland County, established by the Richland County Board of Education pursuant to the provisions of Section 7, Article III of Act No.

379 of 1951, shall consist of five members, and their qualifications, powers and duties shall be such as are generally devolved upon school trustees by the state and specifically by the laws of Richland County.

Appointmenttermselection.The Richland County Board of Education upon the reorganization of the school districts in the county, as provided herein, shall appoint a board of trustees of five members in each of the newly created districts, two of the terms shall expire December 31, 1954, two of the terms shall expire December 31, 1956, and one term shall expire December 31, 1958.

Thereafter successors to the five original members shall be elected in the general election to be held in November prior to the expiration date of a commission, and shall be commissioned for a full term of six years.
A term shall always begin on the first day of January and shall expire on the last day of December.
