Vacancy candidates employment.Any vacancy for any cause occurring among the elected trustees, other than by expiration of a commission, may be filled at any time by the Richland County Board of Education for the remainder of the unexpired term, or for a full term as the case may be.
No person otherwise qualified for such nomination shall be required to pay any assessment or other fee as a condition to such candidacy.
No member elected to any of the boards shall be employed in the county schools as a teacher or otherwise and acceptance of such employment shall automatically operate as a resignation as trustee.
Number and appointment for School District No.
5.The trustees for Richland County School District No.

5, as to their number and the manner of their appointment, shall be determined in accordance with the provisions in effect on the effective date of this act for the election of trustees for School District No.
Exemption.Richland County School District No.
1 is exempt from the provisions of this act.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 4th day of March, 1952.

812 An Act To Consolidate The Existing School Districts In Fairfield County Into A School District To Be Designated As The School District of Fairfield County; To Provide For The Management And Operation Of The District, The Appointment Of School Trustees, Their Powers, Duties And Terms Of Office; And To Provide For Other Matters Relating To The Schools Of Fairfield County.

The School District of Fairfield County.The six existing school districts of Fairfield County are hereby consolidated into a single school district whose area and boundaries shall be coextensive with the area and boundaries of.
Fairfield County, and shall be known as The School District of Fairfield County.

Body politic and corporateThe School District of Fairfield County is hereby declared to be a body politic and corporate and is vested with all the rights, privileges and responsibilities as other school districts possess under the provisions of the General Law of South Carolina.

Board of trusteesappointmenttermvacancyduties devolved on.The public educational system of Fairfield County shall be directed and managed by the Board of Trustees of The School District of Fairfield County.
They shall be residents of the district and shall be appointed by the Governor upon the recommendation of a majority of the members of the Fairfield County Legislative Delegation.
The regular terms of office of the members of the board shall be for four years and until their successors are appointed and qualify.

The following named persons shall constitute the initial members of this board: Sam M. Brice, Woodward, S. C.; Ray Brooks, Rion, S. C.; Albert H. McMeeckin, Monticello, S.C. ; Howard Yarborough, Jenkinsville, $8.
C.; R. W. Thomas, Ridgeway, S. C.; Joe H. Owens, Winnsboro, S.C.
They shall hold office until April 30, 1955, and until their successors have been appointed and qualify.
Any vacancy occurring in the board shall be filled for the unexpired term as provided for the original appointment.

Any and all duties which are now or which may hereafter by any special or general law be devolved upon the County Board of Education of Fairfield County are hereby imposed upon and devolved upon the Board of Trustees of The School District of Fairfield Olan LU Tine County.

All remittances and reports required by law to he made by any department of the Government to the county beard of education shall be made to the Board of Trustees of The School District of Fairheld County as established under this act.

Property vested in.Title to all school property in Fairfield County, real or personal, which is now or has been heretofore used for school purposes, as well as that which may be hereafter acquired, shall vest in The School District of Fairfield County.
All monies standing to the credit of any school district shall vest in and become the property of The School District of Fairfield County on the effective date of this act.

Liability of former districtsissue bonds if election thereon favorable.The School District of Fairfield County assumes all liabilities, obligations and indebtedness of the several school districts heretofore existing.
The full faith, credit and taxing power of the district is hereby pledged to the payment of any outstanding indebtedness of the several school districts.
An amount sufficient to pay the interest on bonds of the districts and, at maturity, the principal thereof, shall be included in the annual budget prepared by the board ot trustees.

The Board of Trustees of The School District of Fairfield County is hereby authorized and empowered to issue and sell coupon bonds of The School District of Fairfield County, payable to bearer, in such denominations and amounts as the board may decm necessary, not to exceed eight per cent of the assessed valuation of the property of the district for taxation, and bearing a rate of interest not to exceed icur per cent per annum, payable annually or semiannually, and at such times as the board may deem best.
The question of issuing the bonds authorized herein shall be first submitted to the qualified voters of the district at an election to be held at such time as the board may determine.
The board is hereby authorized and empowered to conduct such election, to appoint the managers, and to declare the results thereof.
The board shall give notice of the election for not less than ten days prior to the election in a newspaper published in the county, or having a general circulation therein.

The board shall provide ballots at each of the voting places on which shall be printed or written the words: Shall The School District of Fairfield County issue bonds in an amount not exceeding eight per cent of the assessed valuation of the property of the district, the proceeds of which shall be used for school purposes?

In favor of the issuance of bonds 0 Opposed to the issuance of bonds [J Those voting in favor of the issuance of the bonds shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the words In favor of the issuance of bonds, and those voting against the issuance of the bonds shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the 99> square after the words Opposed to the issuance of bonds.

If a majority of the votes cast in the election shall be for the issuing of bonds, the board shall issue the bonds, which shall not run longer than twenty years from the date of issue, and shall mature serially at such time as the board may determine.

The bonds shall be sold at not less than par and the proceeds therefrom shall be used by the board of trustees for the purpose of erecting public schools and library buildings, and for equipment for maintaining the public schools and libraries in the county, or for paying indebtedness incurred for school purposes, or for remodeling, enlarging or improving the existing school facilities of the county, and such bonds and coupons shall constitute a lien upon all school property within the district.
The full faith, credit and taxing power of The School District of Fairfield County is irrevocably pledged for the payment of the principal and interest of the bonds as they mature.

It shall be the duty of the county auditor to levy, and the county treasurer to collect, annually, upon all of the taxable property within the county, a sum sufficient to pay the interest on such bonds and provide a sinking fund for the payment of the bonds when: due, and the coupons thereof may be received for taxes upon property within the county.

All bonds issued under and in pursuance of the provisions of this act shall be signed by the Chairman of the Board of Trustees of The School District of Fairfield County and the County Treasurer; provided, the signatures of the treasurer and the chairman of the board may be lithographed or engraved upon the coupons attached to such bonds, and such lithographed or engraved signatures shall be a sufficient signing thereof.

The proceeds of the sale of such bonds as are contemplated herein shall be deposited with the county treasurer and shall be receipted for by the treasurer, and paid out upon warrants drawn by the board of trustees.
All bonds issued or sold under the provisions of this act shall be exempt from all state, county or municipal taxes.
Further duties and powers.In addition to the powers and duties now provided for by law, the board of trustees shall have the following powers and duties: 1.
Employ a superintendent of education who shall be selected on the basis of professional qualifications as a public school administrator.
The superintendent shall be possessed of specific training and experience in the administration of the business affairs of public schools.
The tenure of the superintendent shall be at the pleasure of the board of trustees.

The board shall fix the salary and traveling allowance of the superintendent ; 2, Upon the recommendation of the county superintendent of education, they shall employ any personnel necessary for the efficient operation of the schools, except as otherwise specified in this act; 3.
Adopt administrative policies ; 4.
Plan and construct new buildings; 5.
Issue bonds to construct and repair buildings and pledge capital outlay funds from state, federal and local tax sources for their payment, under conditions stated herein; 6.
Operate a building maintenance and repair program; 7.
Issue shortterm notes in anticipation of taxes and state aid funds, and pledge such revenues to the payment thereof; 8.
Exercise the right of eminent domain in securing necessary property ; 9.
Determine and evaluate the educational program; 10, Contract for services, equipment and supplies.
The board shall establish and maintain a central purchasing system for the purchase af all school supplies and equipment used by the several schools in Fairfield County ; 11.
Cause regular audits to be made, and publish annual and special Teports ; 12.
Keep an accurate record of board proceedings; 13.
Direct a continuing school census and enforce the state compulsory attendance act; I+. Provide for all school elections ; 15.
Fix the length of the school term; 16.
Administer state aid to public schools and fix the minimum amount of supplement to be paid to the teachers in the several schools within the county ; 17.
Arrange with adjoining counties for interchange of pupils or educational services ; 18.
Adopt budgets and budgetary controls, and set tax levies on countywide basis sufficient to meet the educational needs of Fairfield County ; 19.

Conduct surveys, and upon the results obtained reorganize attendance areas, the curriculum, the supervisory program, auxiliary services, or any part of the educational program delegated by the state to the county board of education or to school trustees ; 20.

The board of trustees is hereby granted the authority to draw warrants upon school funds in the hands of the treasurer for the payment of any services contracted for by the board, for the payment of insurance premiums, including workmens compensation premiums for the district, for the payment of withholding taxes from salaries, and for the payment for any acts authorized by the board of trustees pursuant to the duties of the board, as set forth in this section.
Duties and powers of superintendent of education.The Fairfield County Superintendent of Education shall be charged with the following duties and responsibilities: 1.

Act as secretary and executive officer to the Board of Trustees of The School District of Fairfield County ; 2 Recommend all personnel to be employed by the board; 3 Assign all personnel employed ; 4 Prepare and administer annual budgets; 5 Operate the school building and maintenance program; 6 Develop a guidance and instructional program, and exercise such powers as are necessary for the administration of all of the responsibilities belonging to the board of trustees; 7.
To carry out all duties and responsibilities as directed by the Board of Trustees of The School District of Fairfield County.

All responsibilities and authority heretofore vested in the county superintendent of education, except membership on the Fairfield County Board of Education, shall devolve upon the Fairfield County Superintendent of Education, as provided for in this act.
Area advisory trustees.The board of trustees is authorized from time to time to set up and designate areas from which it shall appoint advisory trustees.
In each of the areas so established there shall be appointed not less than three nor more than five of such advisory trustees.

Provided, that in the area including the Town of Winnsboro, there shall be at least five of such trustees, two of whom shall be appointed upon the recommendation of the Mt. Zion Society, and the remaining three from the area at large.
At least one of these advisory trustees shall be a resident of the Winnsboro Mill Village area.

In the event, however, that the board of trustees shall change any attendance area, it shall have the right to terminate the term of office of any advisory trustee who resides in the area consolidated or transferred to another area.
The local trustees of the high school attendance areas shall have the authority to recommend to the board suitable teachers, superintendent and other school personnel within the attendance areas.
Trusteesmeetingspay.The board of trustees shall hold regular meetings at least once a month, and special meetings as often as necessary.
The members of the board shall receive ten dollars per day for each meeting they attend, and shall receive seven cents per mile for travel to and from the meetings.

Funds credit to districtAll funds in the hands of the county treasurer, arising from tax levies on the property in the several districts heretofore existing, as well as such sums as he may hereaiter receive from any such levy, shall be by him placed to the credit of The School District of Fairfield County.

Tax leviesbudgets.The Board of Trustees of The School District of Fairfield County is authorized and empowered, by resolution duly adopted, to determine and fix the amount of the levy needed to operate the schools in the district for any one year and shall on or before the first day of April of each year notify the auditor of the county of the amount of the levy, and file with him a certied copy of the resolution.

It shall thereafter become the duty of the auditor of the county to levy, and of the treasurer to collect, the tax as requested and directed by the board, upon all of the taxable property in the district, as other taxes are collected; provided,the tax levy for such purpose shall not exceed thirty mills in any one year.

On or before the fifteenth day of March of each year, each board of area advisory trustees shall submit to the Board of Trustees of The School District of Fairfield County a proposed budget for the operation of the schools in the area for the next ensuing school year.

District unit for financing and receiving fundstrustees expend and account for funds.The School District of Fairfield County shall be the unit for financing and receiving local, State and federal funds.
The board of trustees shall be charged with the responsibility of the expenditure and accounting of the funds in the hands of the board.

Deposit and disbursement of funds.All school funds of the county shall be deposited in the office of the Treasurer of Fairfield County to the credit of the district, and withdrawn only upon warrants issued by the board of trustees.
RepealaAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 4th day of March, 1952

813 An Act To Consolidate The Existing School Districts Of Lancaster County Into A New School District To Be Designated As The School District Of Lancaster County; To Reconstitute The County Board Of Education; To Provide Terms Of Office Of Its Members And Their Powers And Duties; To Provide For The Appointment Of Members Of The Board Of Trustees, Their Powers And Duties, And Relating To Other Matters Pertaining To The Operation Of Public Schools In Lancaster County; And To Repeal section 5613 Through 56152, Inclusive, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Act No.
49, Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions Of The General Assembly, 1943, Act No.
142, Acts And Joint Resolutions Of The General Assembly, 1945, And All Acts Amendatory Thereto Or Relating To The School System Of Lancaster County.

The School District of Lancaster County.All existing school districts in Lancaster County are hereby consolidated to a single school district whose area and boundaries shall be coextensive with the area and boundaries of Iancaster County, which school district shall be known and designated as The School District of Lancaster County. Section 2.
Board of education appointment terms payvacancy.The County Board of Education for Lancaster County as now constituted is hereby abolished.
From and after the effective date of this act the central authority for Lancaster County school system shall be the Lancaster County Board of Education.

The board shall consist of seven members who shall be appointed by the Governor upon the recommendation of the Senator and at least onehalf of the members of the House of Representatives from Lancaster County.

One of the members of the board shall come from that area fomerly designated as Lancaster High School District ; one member from that area formerly designated as Indian Land High School District; one member from that area formerly designated as Buford High School District ; one member from that area formerly designated as Heath Springs High School District; one member from that area formerly designated as Flat Creek High School District and one member from that area formerly designated as Kershaw High School District, and one member shall be appointed at large.
The Superintendent of Education for Lancaster County shall be exofficio the eighth member of the board and shall serve as secretary and executive officer of the board.

In the initial term four members of the beard shall be appointed for a term of four years and three members of the board shall be appointed for a term of two years, and thereafter thir successors shall be appointed for a term of four years and until their successors have been appointed and qualify.
No appointive member of the board shall hold any other public office.
The board shall by a majority vote elect its chairman.
The members of the board shall be paid such compensation as the General Assembly may provide.

In case of any vacancy occurring on the county board of education the Governor, upon the recommendation of the Senator and at least onehalf of the members of the House of Representatives from Lancaster County, shall make an appointment for the unexpired term.
Duties and powers.The board of education shall have the following duties and powers: (1) Adopt administrative policies.
(2) Fix lucal supplements and.
salaries of all school personnel, including the county superintendent of education.
The board is further authorized to approve any necessary travel expenses incurred by the superintendent of education in his official duties.
(3) Plan and construct new buildings.
(4) Operate a building maintenance and repair program.
(5) Issue shortterm notes in anticipation of taxes and state aid funds and to pledge any such taxes or funds for the payment of the hotes.
The notes shall mature not later than one year from their date.

(6) Exercise the right of eminent domain in securing necessary Property and in the exercise of such rights the county board shall follow as near as practical the procedure prescribed for condemnation by muncipal corporations.
(7) Cause regular audits to be made and prepare annual and special reports of the results of any audit.
(8) Direct a continuing school program and enforce the State Compulsory Attendance Act.
(9) Act upon all claims against the school fund.

Auditor report assessed values.It shall be the duty of the auditor of Lancaster County, and he is hereby required, to furnish to the chairman of the county board of education on or before the fifteenth day of May of each year a statement or statements showing the assessed value of all the property returned for taxation in the school district, together with the poll tax assessed; and in the event he shall not have received from the tax commission the returns to be furnished by it by the fifteenth day of May, he shall use the returns furnished by it for the previous year in making up such statement; the total of the assessed values of the district shall constitute the value which the county board of education shall fix the levy or levies hereinafter provided for.

Budgets.In order to provide the necessary funds for the annual operation of all schools in Lancaster County in excess of all funds received from the state aid allotment for schools in Lancaster County, the county board of education of Lancaster County shall meet annually for the purpose of determining the necessary funds for the operation of the schools for the coming year.
The county board of education shall make a budget for the entire county, with each school as an integral part of the county school budget.
The county board of education shall have authority to determine the amounts of the budgets of the various schools of the county.

After determining the total amount necessary for the operation of all the schools of the county for any fiscal year, the county board of education shall inform the legislative delegation of such amount and a majority of the delegation, including the Senator, shall authorize the auditor to levy such tax as will be sufficient.
The auditor is hereby directed to levy and the treasurer is hereby directed to collect such tax as other taxes are levied and collected.

Taxescollection and disbursement of fundstuition.All funds for school purposes shall be collected by the county treasurer as all other taxes are now collected and the same shall be disbursed to the various schools of Lancaster County by ordei of the county board of education as school funds are now disbursed.
In no case shall expenditures exceed the total of the school budget.
No pupil within the borders of Lancaster County shall be charged any tuition, but all pupils shall be required to attend schools as approved by the county board of education.
Library.The county board of education is authorized and directed to operate the Lancaster County Public Library.
The expenses of the operation of the library shall be defrayed from school funds.
PropertiesacquisitionsaleThe title of all school property, both real and personal, is hereby vested in the Lancaster County Board of Education.

The board in its discretion may buy any real estate necessary for school purposes and may sell any real or personal school property to the highest bidder at public auction, when, in its discretion, the real or personal property is no longer required for school purposes.
The proceeds derived from any such sale shall be placed to the credit of the general school fund.
Trustees appointment term vacancy.The beard of trustees for the district shall be composed of thirty members who shall be appointed by the Lancaster County Board of Education.
They shall serve for a term of two years and until their successors are appointed and qualify.

Five of the members of the board shall come from that area formerly designated as Lancaster High School District; five members from that area formerly designated as Indian Land High School District; five members from that area formerly designated as Buford High School District; five members from that area formerly designated as Heath Springs High School District; and five members from that area formerly designated as Fiat Creek High School District and five members from that area formerly designated as Kershaw High School District.

In appointing the members of the board of trustees the board of education may hold advisory elections in the various areas for the purpose of determining the wishes of the patrons of the local school.
However, the results of any such elections shall not be binding upon the county hoard of education in their selection of trustees.
In case of any vacancy occurring on the board of trustees, the county board of education shall make an appointment for the unexpired term.

Trustees visit and inspect schoolsemployment of personnel The board of trustees shall be charged with the duties of visiting and inspecting schools of the district and make its recommendations to the county board of education as to the improvement of school facilities.
All school personnel shall be employed by the county board of education.

On or before the fifteenth day of April of each year a majority of the members of the board of trustees from each area shall submit to the county board of education its recommendations as to the employment of school personnel.

In the event the county board of education shall decide not to employ any of the persons so recommended, the county board of education shall notify the members of the board from that particular area and the members, or a majority thereof, of the board of trustees from that area shall by May first submit additional names.

In case no recommendations are made, or the county board and the board of trustees fail to agree on the employment of school personnel in any school, then the county board of education shall have full authority in filling the positions.
All employees employed by the county board of education shall serve at the pleasure of the board.

In case of any vacancy occurring during the school year in any member of the school faculty, including superintendents and principals, the vacancy shall be filled by the county board of education in like manner.
Boards of visitorsThe county board of education may appoint boards of visitors for the various schools of the district.
Such boards shall make periodical inspections of their respective schools and shall make recommendations to the board of trustees as to the general condition of the schools and school properties.
Superintendent of education election term purchases.The present superintendent of education of Lancaster County shall serve until July 1, 1953.

His successor shall be elected in the general election to be held in 1952 and in each general election every four years thereafter, and shall serve from July 1, 1953, for a term of four years and until his successor has been elected and qualifies.
The superintendent of education is hereby designated as the purchasing agent for all schools in Lancaster County.

He is authorized to purchase and contract for all supplies and services required for the oneration of the schools and shall have sole authority to employ and discharge all clerical help in his office.
Repeal.Sections 5613 through 56152, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, Act No.
49 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1943, Act No.

142 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1945, and all acts amendatory thereto and all acts or parts of acts pertaining to the school system of Lancaster County inconsistent with this act are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the Ist day of March, 1952.
814 An Act To Provide Legislation For Consolidating A Portion Of Saluda County With The BatesburgLeesville District No.

3 Of Lexington County For School Purposes As Ordered Jointly By The Saluda County Board Of Education And The Lexington County Board Of Education Pursuant To The Provisions Of Article IMT Of Act No.379 Of The General Assembly Of South Carolina For 1951.

Whereas, the Saluda County Board of Education and the Lexingten County Board of Education, having separate meetings, agreed upon and ordered the consolidation of an area of Saluda County with the BatesburgLeesville District No.

3 of Lexington County for school purposes, and a copy of the order of consolidation having been filed with the Clerk of Court of Common Pleas for Saluda Comty, a copy of the order of consolidation having been filed with the Clerk of Court of Common Pleas for Lexington County, and a copy of the order of consolidation having been filed with the State Educational Finance Commission; and Whereas, the State Educational Finance Commission has not yet acted upon this matter and that it is entirely possible and probable that some amendments or changes may be made with reference to the area and boundary proposed to be consolidated by the commissin, and it is the intent and purpose of this legislation that this act all anply with full force and effect upon the area finally consolidated and approved by the State Educational Finance Commission.
Now, Therefore, Ke it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina : Section 1.
Liability of Saluda County area of BatesburgLeesville District No.
3, Lexington County.That the BatesburgLeesville District No.
3 of Lexington County will not assess any of its outstanding bonded indebtedness against the area of Saluda County so consolidated for school purposes.
The area of Saluda County so consolidated will, however, assume a levy identical with that of BatesburgLeesville District No.
3 of Lexington County for any school indebtedness (bonds or notes) that shall be hereafter incurred by the consolidated BatesburgLeesville District No.
3 of Lexington County.

Provided, and it is especially understood and agreed, that the area of Saluda County so consolidated shall not be assessed or called upon to pay any indebtedness, by way of refinancing or otherwise, existing or subsisting at the time of consolidation.

Such area free from Saluda County debt.Prior hereto, Saluda County issued certain notes or obligations in the amount of two hundred and twentyfive thousand dollars ($225,000.00) for school building purposes of Saluda County and at which time the assessed valuation of Saluda County was just a little in excess of three million dollars ($3,000,000.00).
The area now being consolidated with BatesburgLeesville District No.
3 of Lexington County has not received any material benefit from the school building notes or obligations.

Since the issuance and sale of the notes, the assessed valuation of Saluda County has increased more than will be sufficient to take care of the loss by the property now ordered to be consolidated with BatesburgLeesville District No.
The area so consolidated should not in justice and equiy bear any portion of the levy necessary for the retirement of the notes outstanding other than that which they have already paid.
Vherefore, Saluda County shall relieve that portion of the area of Selada County so consolidated with the BatesburgLeesville District No.
3 of Lexington County from the ten mill countywide levy for retirement of school notes as of January 1, 1952, and the area so conschidated with the BatesburgLeesville District No.
3 of Lexington County and such consolidated area shall be debt free.
Such area also exempt from special tax in Saluda County.The area of Saluda County so consolidated with the BatesburgLeesville District No.
3 of Lexington County shall be exempted from the annual Saluda County special operating school levy as of January 1, 1952.
Tax levy in such area.The area of Saluda County so consolidated with the BatesburgLeesville District No.
3 of Lexington County shall assume the annual special operating school levy of the BatesburgLeesville District No.
3 of Lexington County as of January 1,1952.
Further, the area of Saluda County so consolidated will comply with Lexington Countys laws for the purpose of setting up school levies.

In order to provide therefor, the BatesburgLeesville School Board of Trustees shall notify the Auditor of Saluda County on or before June thirtieth of each year, in writing, the millage required for the succeeding school year; and the Auditor of Saluda County shall levy this tax against all of the real and personal property in the area so consolidated with the BatesburgLeesville District No.
Provided, further, the Treasurer of Saluda County shall collect this tax so levied and remit, monthly, the amount so collected tothe Treasurer of Lexington County.
Upon receipt of such tax from the Treasurer of Saluda County, the Treasurer of Lexington County shall deposit the proceeds of such tax to the credit of the BatesburgLeesville District No.
3, in such manner as to insure the counting of the children, from the area of Saluda County so consolidated, for Participation in any Lexington Countywide equalization school levy.
Such area part of districtappointment of trusteesThe area of Saluda County so consolidated with the BatesburgLeesville District No.
3 of Lexington County shall become an integral part of the BatesburgLeesville District No.
3 of Lexington County, and school trustees for BatesburgLeesville District No.
3 of Lexington County shall be appointed by the Iexington County Beard of Education, and one or more of the trustees shall be residents of the area of Saluda County so consolidated.
Such area not share in certain Saluda County revenue.The area of Saluda County so consolidated with the BatesburgLeesville District No.
3 of Lexington County shall not share in any Saluda County beer and wine tax funds that might be earmarked by Saluda County for school purposes.

Elementary school buildingsThat an elementary school building or buildings for the area will be built in compliance with and upon the approval of the State Educational Finance Commission, so as to give to the elementary school pupils, residing in Lexington and Saluda Counties of the consolidated area, reasonable and convenient school facilities.

Consolidation ratified.This act ratifies the consolidation ordered by the Saluda County Board of Education and concurred in by the Lexington County Board of Education, together with any changes or amendments made thereto or proposed by the State Educational Finance Commission.

Invalidity.If any section, paragraph, sentence or proviso of this act shall be held unconstitutional, it shall not impair or invalidate any of the remaining provisions and it is the intent of the Legislature that this act shall become effective in all of its provisions notwithstanding some part thereof that might be held unconstitutional.
e Section 11. Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the Ist day of March, 1952.
815 An Act To Provide For The Condemnation Of Land By Municipal Corporations.

Municipalities may condemn property.Any municipal corporation desiring to become the owner of any land, or to acquire any easement or right of way therein, whether within or without the corporate limits, for any corporate or public purpose, shall have the right to condemn said land or said right of way or easement in the manner hereinafter provided.
Provided however this act shall not apply to any property owned by public service corporations or devoted to public use.

Provided such power of condemnation shall not extend to properties beyond the boundaries of the county in which a municipal corporation is situate and no municipal corporation shall have powers of condemnation beyond the county territorial limits of the county in which such municipal corporation is located.

ProcedureThe condemnation authorized and provided for in Section 1 hereof shall be made in the same manner as condemnations are now made by railroad corporations, as set forth in section 8437 to 8450, both inclusive, of Volume IV of the Code of Laws of 1942, and acts amendatory thereto.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 13th day of March, 1952.

816 An Act To Provide For The Election Of A Mayor, Four Councilmen And Three Commissioners Of Public Works For The Town Of Forest Acres In Richland County And To Validate An Election Held In July 1951.

Mayor, councilmen and commissioners of public works, Forest Acreselectionterm.There shall be an election in the Town of Forest Acres in Richland County on the second Tresday in June 1953, and on the second Tuesday in June every two years thereafter.

In the election provided for herein there shall be elected a Mayor of the Town of Forest Acres, four councilmen, and three commissioners of public works, all of whom shall serve for a period of two years or until their successors shall have been elected and qualified.

1951 election validated.The election of a Mayor, four Councilmen and three Commissioners of Public Works of the Town of Forest Acres held in July 1951 is hereby ratified, validated and declared by the General Assembly to have been held and conducted in accordance with law.
Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 12th day of March, 1952.

817 An Act To Provide For The Levy Of Taxes For The Support Of The Schools Of Darlington County; To Provide For Boards Of Tax Assessors For Each School Attendance Area In The County And For A Board Of Tax Equalization For The County; And To Repeal section 55672, 55673, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To The Annual Levy Of Taxes In Darlington County For Aid Of Weak Schools.

Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1 School tax levy, Darlington CountyThe county board of education shall annually direct the levy of a tax on all the taxable property of the county sufficient to raise an amount to meet the costs of administration and operation of the schools of Darlington County.
The county auditor shall make, and the county treasurer shall collect, the levies herein provided for.
Boards of tax assessors.The Darlington County Board of Advisors shall appoint a board of tax assessors for each school attendance area in the county.
Each board of assessors shall consist of as many members as the board of advisors mav determine, and the members thereof shall serve at the pleasure of the board.
Vacancies, if filled, shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments.
Each board shall meet within two weeks after its appointment and shall organize by electing one of the members as chairman.
Each board shall have the powers and duties of tax assessors generally.

Board of tax equalization The chairmen of the four area boards of tax assessors, together with another person who shall be elected by the four area chairmen, shall constitute the Board of Tax Equalization for Darlington County.

The member elected by the four area chairmen shall serve as chairman of the board of equalization, The board of equalization shall serve as an appeal board to hear and determine appeals from the assessments of property in the county.

Repeal.Sections 55672 and 55673, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, which direct an annual levy of taxes in Darlington County for the aid of weak grammar and high schools in the county, and all other acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed; but all rights and habilities under these section shall continue and may be enforced in the same manner as if this repeal had not been made.
Time effective This act shall take cffect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 12th day of March, 1952.

819 An Act To Amend Section 8555134, Code Of Laws Of Sou Carolina, 1942, Relating To The Boards Of Commissioners Of Elec tric, Water, Fire And Sewer Districts In Unincorporated Com munities, So As To Provide That Such Services May Be Extende To Citizens Outside Of The Districts At Certain Rates Fixed B The Commissioners In Counties Having A Population Betwee FortyOne Thousand (41,000) And FortyThree Thousand (43 000) According To The 1950 Census.
U. Ue we PTaie Re it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1.

8555134, 1942 Code, amendedprovide water, sewerage and fire protection outside of electric, water, fire and sewer districts in unincorporated communities in counties between 41,000 and 43,000, 1950 census.Section 8555134, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is amended by adding at the end thereof the following proviso: Provided, that in counties having a population between fortyone thousand (41,000) and fortythree thousand (43.000) according to the 1950 census, such boards of commissioners may provide water, sewerage and fire protection to citizens outside of such districts in those counties or adjacent counties and charge such rates therefor as they may fix which may be more but not less than the rates charged citizens of such districts for similar services and facilities. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 12th day of March, 1952

820 An Act To Amend Section 2578, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Amended, Relating To Tax Exemptions, So As To Provide That Property Belonging To Alcoholics Anonymous In Richland County Be Exempted From Taxation So Long As It Is Used For Nonprofit Purposes.

2578, 1942 Code, amendedproperty of Alcoholic Anonymous exempt from certain taxes.Section 2578, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as amended, relating to tax exemptions, is further amended by adding at the end thereof the following subsection: The property owned and used by Alcoholics Anonymous, an eleemosynary corporation, located at 2013 College Street in the City of Columbia shall be exempted from the payment of all county, school and municipal taxes beginning with the year 1952 and shall be exempted so long as the property is used for charitable purposes and is not operated for profit.

In the event the property is used for profit, by sale, lease or otherwise, or shall be deeded to any other person, firm or corporation, or shall cease to be used for charitable purposes, then it shall cease to be tax exempted. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effecitve.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 12th day of March, 1952.

821 An Act To Amend Section 7414, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Amended, Relating To The Levying And Collection Of Taxes For Ordinary Purposes By Towns Of Less Than One Thousand Inhabitants, So As To Provide That The Town Of Ridgeway In Fairfield County Shall Have The Authority To Levy And Collect A Tax For Ordinary Purposes Not To Exceed ThirtyFive Mills.

7414, 1942 Code, amendedtax levy, Ridgeway.Section 7414, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as amended, relating to the levying and collection of taxes for ordinary purposes by towns of less than one thousand inhabitants, is amended by adding at the end thereof the following: Provided, further, that the Town of Ridgeway in Fairfield County shall have authority to levy and collect a tax for ordinary purposes not to exceed thirtyfive mills. Section 2. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 12th day of March, 1952.

822 An Act To Amend Section 2846, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To Tax Assessors For Berkeley County So As To Further Provide For Tax Assessment Areas And A Board Of Assessors For Berkeley County.

2846, 1942 Code, amendedboard of tax assessors, Berkeley Countyareas.Section 2846, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is amended by striking out all of same and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be Section 2846 section 2846.
A board of tax assessors is hereby created for Berkeley County.

The board of tax assessors shall be composed of one member from each of the following areas which shall constitute tax assessment areas or districts for Berkeley County: one from St. Thomas and St. Dennis which constitute old School Districts No.
l and 114; one from St. James Santee which constitute old School Districts No.
2 and 214; one from 2nd St. Stephens which constitute old School Districts No.
314, 4, 41%4, 5 and 514; one from Ist St Stephens which constitute old School Districts No.
6 and 7; one from Ist St. Johns which constitute old School Districts No.
8, 9 and 10 one from 2nd St. Johns which constitute old School Districts No.
11 12, 13, 14 and 15; one from 1st Goose Creek which constitute old School Districts No.
1@, 17 and 19; one from 2nd Goose Creek which constitute old School Districts No.
22, 23, 24 and 25 and one from Hanahan which constitutes old School District No 26.
The members shall be appointed by the Governor upon the recommendation of a majority of the Berkeley County Delegation of the General Assembly.
The members of the board shall hold office for a term of two years from the date of their respective appointments.
Any vacancy occurring on the board by death, resignation, or otherwise, shall be filled for the unexpired term in the manner herein provided for the full term.

The duties now imposed upon, and the authority vested in, and exercised by the Board of Tax Assessors for Berkeley County and the Board of Equalization for Berkeley County are hereby devolved upon and vested in the Board of Tax Assessors for Berkeley County.

Provided, however, for the current tax year the board of tax assessors shall remain as now constituted. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed Section 3. Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 12th day of March, 1952
823 An Act To Create The Berkeley County Waterworks Commission And To Define Its Powers And Duties.

Berkeley County Waterworks Commissionappointmenttermsvacancy.There is hereby created the Berkeley County Waterworks Commission which shall consist of five qualified electors of Berkeley County who are not at the time of their appointment officeholders of Berkeley County.
The members shall be appointed by the Governor for terms of five years upon the recommendation of a majority of Berkeley County Legislative Delegation.
The terms of members first appointed shall be staggered so that the term of one member shall expire cach year.
Vacancies in the commission shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment and the appointment shall be for the unexpired term.
Chairmanpayemployment.The members of the commission shall elect one of their number as chairman.
The members of the commission, including the chairman, shall receive compensation for their services as annually provided in the County Supply Act.

No member of the commission shall be appointed to any office or shall be eligible for any employment in connection with the operation or management of any facility under the control of the commission.

Operate waterworks system.The commission is empowered to acquire, by construction or purchase, and to operate a waterworks system or svstems and furnish water to individuals or firms or corporations for reasonable compensation.
The commission shall have full control and management of any waterworks system or systems acquired by it.

If the commission decides to purchase or construct a waterworks system, or to improve one which it has acquired, it shall have an estimate made of the costs of acquisition or improvement and may issue revenue bonds in the amount of such costs.
The proceeds of the operation of such waterworks system or U On IU systems shall be pledged and applied to the payment of the principal and interest of the revenue bonds issued.

Acquire property.For the purpose of acquiring, establishing or improving waterworks provided for in this act, the commission may condemn lands, water rights, water privileges, or other property necessary or desirable for the purpose of the waterworks system, but just compensation must first be paid to the owner or owners of such property rights or privileges.

The condemnation proceedings shall be instituted by the Berkeley County Waterworks Commission and shall be conducted in the same manner as condemnation proceedings instituted by the South Carolina State Highway Department.

The commission also may enter upon and condemn lands and tenements for the purpose of protecting the water sheds and water supplies from contamination, nuisances or any conditions which may be a menace to the public health.

In lieu of condemning such lands, property, water rights, water privileges, and other property the cemmission shall have the power to purchase them by agreement with the owner thereof at the fair market value thereof.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 12th day of March, 1952.

824 (R980, H1509) An Act To Provide For Taking Over Of County And Municipal Roads By The State Highway Department And To Provide For The Transfer Of Certain Roads From The State Highway Secondary System To Local Jurisdiction.
Highways add to State Highway Secondary System.

The State Highway Department is hereby directed to take over and accept as a part of the State Highway Secondary System the roads remaining in the various county road systems, which have been maintained by the respective counties, or so much mileage thereof, as the availability of funds for construction of secondary state highways in a county may justify; provided, that municipal streets which are extensions of state highways may be added to the State Highway Secondary System in lieu of an equal mileage of county roads.

The roads to be placed in the State Highway System hereunder shall be selected by the State Highway Department by and with the approval of the Senator and at least onehalf of the members of the House in each county.

Maintenance jurisdiction by the State Highway Department of roads added to the State Highway Secondary System pursuant to the provisions of this section shall not commence until construction to state highway standards shall have started.

Remove and add roads to such system.The State Highway Department, with the approval of the Senator and at least onehalf of the members of the House in each county, is hereby authorized to delete and remove from the State Highway Secondary System of roads in any county any roads which are of low traffic importance, and, to substitute therefor, an equal, or less, mileage of other roads of higher traffic importance as determined by traffic surveys and estimates.

Maintenance responsibility for roads deleted and removed from the State Highway Secondary System, pursuant to the provisions of this section, shall transfer from the jurisdiction of the State Highway Department to the jurisdiction of the county or municipality in which such roads are situated, effective upon notice from the State Highway Department of official action deleting and removing the roads from the State Highway System.
Effect on Act 329 of 1951.Nothing in this act shall be construed to repeal or amend Section 13 of Act 329 of the Acts of 1951.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 12th day of March, 1952.

827 An Act To Authorize The Board Of Township Commissioners For Sullivans Island To Impose A Tax, Not In Excess Of TwentyFive Mills, On All Taxable Property On Sullivans Island And To Provide For The Collection Thereof.

Tax levy, Sullivans IslandThe Board of Township Commissioners for Sullivans Island is hereby authorized to impose a tax of not exceeding twentyfive mills a year on all taxable property located in the territorial limits of the Township of Sullivans Island, South Carolina; and the board is specifically granted the power to impose the same penalties for nonpayment of taxes as are imposed by the state and county for failure to pay state and county taxes when due.
The taxes so levied shall be a lien on the property on which they are levied for a period of four years from the levy thereof and for three years after default in the payment thereof.

Levy and collectionThe Board of Township Commissioners for Sullivans Island, South Carolina, shall, by resolution, direct the Auditor of Charleston County to levy such tax, not in excess of twentyfive mills, as it may deem necessary for carrying on good government on Sullivans Island.
When so directed by resolution, the Auditor of Charleston County shall levy the tax set forth in the resolution on all taxable property in the Township of Sullivans Island.

The Treasurer of Charleston County shall collect the taxes so levied and turn them over to the Clerk of the Board of Township Commissioners for Sullivans Island, South Carolina, quarterly, and take his receipt for the taxes, which receipt shall be in full settlement between the township and the county treasurer.

Use of receipts.The taxes levied under this act shall be used by the Township of Sullivans Island for maintenance, repairs to and operation of the equipment of the township, for salaries of its workmen, and for sanitation, policing, and any other expenses of good government.
The taxes shall be accounted for annually to the Comptroller General of the State of South Carolina in the annual report of the township of its receipts and disbursements.
Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent with the provisions of this act are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 6th day of March, 1952.

831 An Act To Fix The Terms Of Office And Provide For The Election Of School Trustees In Colleton County.

School trustees, Colleton Countyterm.The terms of office of all school trustees in the consolidated school districts of Colleton County shall be for a period of six years and until their successors are selected and qualify.
Terms of office shall begin on January first immediately following each gencral election for trustees cected in the general election and shall expire on December thirtyfirst six years thereafter.

The terms of office of school trustees now fixed to expire on December 31, 1953 are hereby extended to December 31, 1954, and the terms of office of trustees now fixed to expire on December 31, 1954 are hereby extended to expire on December 31, 1956.
Election.The school trustees of each school district in Colleton County shall be elected in the general election by the qualified electors residing in each school district.

The county board of education shall divide each school district into school trustee residence areas so that various section of each school district shall have representation on the board of trustees, and at least one school trustee shall be assigned to each residence area but all shall be elected by the vote of the qualified electors residing in the school district..

Times elect.Successors to the two trustees in each of the consolidated school districts of Colleton County whose terms of office expire on December 31, 1952 shall be elected in the General Election of 1952; successors to the two trustees in each of the consolidated school districts whose terms of office expire on December 31, 1954 shall be elected in the General Election of 1954; a successor to the trustee in each school district whose term of office expires on December 31, 1956 shall be elected in the General Election of 1956; and thereafter successors to all of the trustees shall be elected in the general election of the year in which their terms of office expire.

Vacancy.If during the terms of office of any of the trustees a vacancy should occur the same shall be filled for the unexpired term by appointment of the county board of education, but thereafter the successor shall be elected in the next following general election.

Conduct of election vThe Board of Commissioners for county and state elections in Colleton County shall arrange for the conduct of the election of school trustees by the managers of election appointed for the general election for county and state officers.

The Board of Election Commissioners shall furnish separate boxes or otherwise provide for an election of school trustees and shall establish such reasonable rules and regulations as may be necessary to effectuate the purpose of election of school trustees by the qualified electors.
Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent with this act are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall become effective upon it its approval by the Governor. Approved the 6th day of March, 1952
