845 An Act To Provide For The Appointment Of The Boards Of Trustees Of The School Districts Of Anderson County, And For The Number Of Members On Such Boards.

School trustees, Anderson Countyappointment.The boards of trustees of the school districts of Anderson County shall be appointed by the county board of education and such boards shall be constituted as follows: In those districts having a total enrollment in all elementary schools and high schools within the district of less than three thousand (3000) pupils, the board shall consist of five members; In those districts having a total enrollment in all elementary schools and high schools within the district of three thousand (3000) pupils or more, but less than six thousand (6000) pupils, the board shall consist of seven members; In those districts having an enrollment in all elementary schools and high schools within the district of six thousand (6000) pupils or more, the board shall consist of nine members.

Election.Those trustees elected pursuant to the terms of law shall remain in office until the consolidation of the school districts of the county; after which new trustees for the new district or districts shall be appointed as provided for herein.
Provided that on petition of onethird of the qualified electors of the school district, the county board of education shall call an election for trustees.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 22nd day of March, 1952.
846 An Act To Fix The Annual Tax Levy For General School Purposes For Greenville County School District No.

520; To Provide For The Suspension Of One Or More Mills Of Such Levy By The Oru wow rp = oo Board Of Trustes Of Said District; To Provide For The Increase Of Such Levy By An Election To Be Held In The School District; And To Provide For The Manner Of Holding Said Election.
Purpose.The purpose and intent of this act is to provide an exclusive method of increasing and decreasing the tax levy for general school purposes in Greenville County.
Tax levy, Greenville County School District No.
520collection.The Auditor of Greenville County shall levy upon all of the taxable property within Greenville County School District No.

520 for general school purposes for the year 1952 and annually thereafter, unless increased or decreased as hereinafter provided, the same number of mills levied in said district for general school purposes for the year 1951.

The Treasurer of Greenville County shall collect the same in like manner as all other taxes are collected, and place the same to the said districts school account, to be disbursed ior the declared purposes in the manner fixed by law.
The levy made in said district for the year 1951 is hereby declared to be the ceiling levy for operating school purposes.
Vote on tax increase.On or before the first day of July of each year the Board of Trustees of the Greenville County School District No.

520 shall canvas the needs of said school district and if a majority of the members of the board of said district conclude that the tax millage for operating school purposes in said district should be increased therein, they shall, on or before the first day of July, submit in writing to the county superintendent of education a statement showing the amount of the proposed additional levy and the need for the additional fund.
Upon receiving such statement the said superintendent of education shall: forthwith call an election in Greenville County to the end that the voters of the Greenville County School District No.
520 may vote for or against the proposed increase.

In calling such an election he shall post a notice thereof in two or more public places in the county and shall publish a notice thereof in at least one issue of each of the daily papers published in the county.
The notice shall be posted and published at least fourteen days prior to the date of the election, which date shall be fixed by the superintendent of education.
The notice shall give the question to be voted on, the date of the election and the voting places thereof, which voting places shall be selected by the superintendent of education as he deems proper.

All residents of Greenville County qualified to vote in a county general election shall be qualified to vote in such election upon producing to the managers credentials as required in such general elections.
As far as practicable the rules governing such general elections shall be followed.

The superintendent of education shall have a sufficient number of appropriate ballots prepared and placed at the voting places of such election and shall appoint a sufficient number of managers, who shall conduct the election, canvas the results thereof, and certify the same to the superintendent of education.
Levy additional tax if election favorablebond levy.

If a majority of those voting at such election shall vote in favor of the proposed tax millage, the said superintendent of education shall in writing so certify to the auditor of the county, and state the amount of the proposed increased millage.
Thereupon the auditor shall immediately levy the additional tax millage along with the ceiling millage upon all the taxable property in Greenville County School District No.

520 for the ensuing school year, and the treasurer shall collect the same as aforesaid, and subject to the provisions of this act the auditor shall annually thereafter make a like levy upon such property in said school district and the treasurer shall collect the same, provided, however, that the provisions of Section 3 and Section 4 of this act providing for an election shall be applicable only with respect to the levy of taxes for operating school purposes and shall not be applicable with respect to any levy for the purpose of retiring any existing bonded indebtedness of the school district.

If the trustees of the school district shall determine that the credit accuring to the school district from the sales tax for any year shall prove insufficient to pay the bonds of the district maturing in any such year, together with interest on the outstanding bonds of the district, they shall certify to the Auditor of Greenville County the millage required to be levied on all property within the district for the purpose of paying such bonds with interest, and thereupon the auditor shall levy the millage so certified upon all the taxable property in the district and the treasurer shall collect the same.
Election expenses.AlIl expenses incident to the calling and holding of such election shall be borne by the school district.
May decrease tax for one year.lIf at any time a majority of the board of trustees of the Greenville County School District No.

520 shall conclude that one or more mills of the tax levy to be ore ~~ rr levied for operating school purposes under the provisions of this act for the ensuing year in their district or that one or more mills of the ceiling millage as is provided for in this act for the ensuing year may be suspended for one year without materially interfering with the proper operation of the schools in said district, and said majority of the members of such board shall, in writing, so notify the superintendent of education of the county, the superintendent of education shall so notify the auditor in writing and thereupon the levy of the number of mills set out in such notification shall, for that year only, be suspended, and the auditor shall make his levy upon the property in the school district in accordance with such notification.

BudgetsOn or before the fifteenth day of August of each year, the board of trustees of the school district shall prepare and submit to the Greenville County Board of Education and to the Greenville County Legislative Delegation, as information, a proposed budget for the ensuing school year.
Transfer surplus bond funds.If the Board of Trustees of Greenville County School District No.

520 shall determine that the funds credited to said district by the state from the sales tax for debt service shall be sufficient to pay Greenville County School District Bonds as the same shall mature, and that a portion or the whole of the funds in the countywide school fund debt service shall be surplus, they may so certify to the Treasurer of Greenville County and the treasurer shall transfer the sum certified to be surplus to the General Operating Fund of the said school district to be used for general school purposes.

Invalidity.I{ any provision of this act or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of the act which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of this act are declared to be severable.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 22nd day of March, 1952.
847 An Act To Provide For The Maintenance And Operating Expenses Of The Schools In Allendale County, And To Provide Revenue Therefor.

School taxes, Allendale CountyOn or before the fifteenth day of March of each year, the trustees of each of the school districts of Allendale County shall prepare and file with the county board of education an estimate, in itemized form, of the sums of money needed, in their judgment, for the maintenance and operation of the schools in their district for the ensuing scholastic year.

Upon the filing of such budgetary statement, the county board of education shall consider and review the same, and file with the legislative delegation of the county, on or before the first of April next thereafter, a report setting forth its determination as to the needs of the schools for the purposes aforementioned.

Such report shall show all anticipated revenues for maintenance and operating expenses, other than a property tax, and the amount of the levies on the property in the respective districts necessary to raise the needed amounts.
At the same time, the board shall file a copy of its report with the auditor of the county.
Upon consideration thereof, the legislative delegation shall authorize the ad valorem tax found necessary in its judgment.

Thereafter it shall become the duty of the county auditor to levy and the county treasurer to collect a tax on all of the property in the respective school districts sufficient to meet the needs of the schools, as herein provided.

In the event any board of trustees fails to prepare and file a budgetary statement of the sum of money needed for the schools in its district, the county board of education shall prepare and file such statement.
All such reports shall be filed and kept as permanent records in the office of the county superintendent of education.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 22nd day of March, 1952.
848 An Act To Amend Section 1 Of Act No.
502, Acts And Joint Resolutions, 1944, Relating To The Williamsburg County Board Of Education, So As To Increase Its Members From Seven To Eight And To Provide For His Appointment And Term Of Office.
Act 502 of 1944 amendedWilliamsburg County Board of Educationappointmenttermsvacancy.Section 1 of Act No.
502, Acts and Joint Resolutions, 1944, is amended by striking out the entire section and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be designated as Section 1: section 1.

That a County Board of Education for Williamsburg County is hereby created and shall be composed of eight members, two of the members to be appointed from the Kingstree School District and its affiliated districts, two from the Hemingway School Districts and its affiliated districts, and one member shall be appointed from each of the remaining high school districts including the districts affiliated with each of the high school districts, the members to be appointed by the Governor, upon the recommendation of the Senator and a majority of the House Members of the Legislative Delegation of Williamsburg County.

One of the members shall be appointed for a term expiring March 15, 1945, two of the members shall be appointed for a term expiring March 15, 1946, two of the members shall be appointed for a term expiring March 15, 1947, and two of the members shall be appointed for a term expiring March 15, 1948, and one member shall be appointed on April 1, 1952, for a term expiring April 1, 1954.
The member whose term shall expire in 1945 and the members whose terms shall expire in 1946, 1947, and 1948, shall be determined by lot.

At the expiration of each of the above mentioned terms and thereafter when the term of any regular member shall have expired an appointment shall be made in the same manner as prescribed above, which appointee shall serve for a term of four years and until his successor has been appointed and qualified.

When otherwise vacancies are created within the board, appointment shall be for the unexpired term only: provided, that no school trustee or other school official of the several school districts in Williamsburg County shall be appointed a member of the county board of education. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 22nd day of March, 1952.

849 An Act To Amend Subsections (2) And (3) Of Section 3 And Subsections (1) And (6) Of Section 4 Of Act No.157 Of The Acts Of 1945 Known As The South Carolina Retirement Act, As Last Amended, So As To Extend The Final Date For Teachers And Employees Withdrawing Their Election And Becoming Members And Filing Claim For Prior Service And To Extend The Time For Becoming An Employer Under The Act.
Act 157 of 1945 amendedmembers of retirement system.Subsection (2) of Section 3 of Act No.
157, of the Acts of 1945 known as the South Carolina Retirement Act, as last amended by Act No.
148, of the Acts of 1951, is amended by striking cut all of same and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be Section 3 (2): section 3 (2).

All persons who are teachers, state, county or municipal employees on April 26, 1945, or who became such after said date but on or before December 31, 1952, except those specifically excluded under subsection 5 and the persons permitted to exercise the option under subsection (10), subsection (11) and subsection (12) of this Section 3, shall become members as of July 1, 1945, or as of the date of last employment, if later, unless on or before December 31, 1948, they shall have filed with the Retirement Board on a form prescribed by said board a notice of their election not to be covered in the membership of the system and a duly executed waiver of all present and prospective benefits which would otherwise inure to them on account of their participation in the system.
Samewithdrawal of membership or election not to become member.Subsection (3) of Section 3 of Act No.

157 of the Acts of 1945 known as the South Carolina Retirement Act, as last amended, is amended by striking out all of same and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be designated as Section 3 (3) : section 3 (3).

Any teacher or employee who shall have become amember of the system prior to December 31, 1948, may withdraw by filing a nonelection blank at any time on or before December 31, 1948, and any sums paid by such teacher or employee for contributions shall be refunded.

Any teacher or employee who previously has elected not to become a member of the system may withdraw such election and become a member on or before December 31, 1952, with all prior service credits preserved; Provided, however, that such teacher or employee shall be subject to the payment of such contributions, if any, as the Retirement Board may determine to be necessary to avoid any possible discrimination as against teachers and employees coming under the terms hereof at an earlier date. Section 3.
Samemembers file claims for prior service credits.
Subsection (1) of Section 4 of Act No.
148, of the Acts of 1951, is amended by striking out all of same and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be Section 4 (1): section 4 (1).

Under such rules and regulations as the Retirement Board shall adopt, each member, who was a teacher or employee at any time prior to July 1, 1945, and who becomes a member on or before December 31, 1952, shall file a detailed statement of all service as a teacher or employee rendered by him prior to July 1, 1945, for which he claims credit. Section 4.
Sameemployers.Subsection (6) of Section 4 of Act No.
157, Acts of 1945, is amended to read as follows: section 4 (6).

All counties, municipalities, or other political subdivisions of the state, and any agencies and departments thereof including school boards, and any service organization as defined in Section 1 (4) and Section 1 (5), desiring to become employers under Section 3, subsection (7), may avail themselves of the provisions of said Section 3, subsection (7), at any time on or before December 31, 1952, and without loss or prejudice to their affected employees or teachers claims to prior service credits; but such electing employers and their employees or teachers shall be subject to the payment of such contributions, if any, as the Retirement Board may determine to be necessary to avoid any possible discrimination as against employers and employees or teachers coming under the terms hereof at an earlier date; provided, that the compensation received by the employees of such service organizations shall be provided from monies paid by the members as dues or otherwise, or from funds derived from public sources.

Provided, further that the employee contributions prescribed by this act shall be paid from the fund of the service organization. Section 5. RepealaAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.

850 An Act To Provide A System Of County Government For Darlington County And To Provide The Appointment, Powers, And Duties Of The Various County Officers To Be Elected Or Appointed Hereunder And Other County Officers; To Make It Unlawful To Violate Certain Provisions Of This Act And To Impose Penalties For The Violation Thereof; And To Repeal Sections 4227, 4228, 4229, 4230, 42301, 42302, 4232, 4233, 4234, 4235, 4236, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Amended, Relating To The Government Of Darlington County.
Darlington County Board of Directorsappointment termremovalvacancy.A County Board of Directors hereinafter called the board, is hereby created to constitute the County Board of Darlington County.

The board shall consist of six members, who shall be appointed by the Governor upon the recommendation of a majority of the legislative delegation from Darlington County, including the Senator, for a term of three years from the effective date of this act and until their successors are appointed and qualified.

Meetingsofficers.The board shall meet as soon as practicable after its appointment under the terms herein stated, and monthly thereafter at a time to be designated by the chairman, upon five days written notice to the other members of the board, and at such other times as the chairman may designate.
There shall be a chairman and a vicechairman of the board, both of whom shall be elected by the members of the board from their own membership.
The chairman shall preside at all meetings and tepresent the board when it is not in session.
The vicechairman shall act as chairman during the absence of the chairman.
The terms of office of chairman and vicechairman shall run coterminously and end with their term of office on the board.

Duties and powersduties of clerk(a) All executive and administrative duties, powers, and authority necessary for the government of Darlington County which are not inconsistent with the constitution or laws of this state, including all the duties, powers and authority that are now devolved upon, or vested in, the county manager and the Advisory Commission to the Manager, and that are not inconsistent herewith, are hereby devolved upon and vested in the board hereby created.

(b) The board shall pass such rules and regulations as may be necessary to the proper handling of all monies and finances of Darlington County, as shall not be inconsistent with the annual appropriation act, and shall direct the expenditure and payment thereof.

No request for expenditure of any funds not provided for in the annual appropriation act or by special legislation shall be granted unless such request shall first be submitted to the county board in writing and approved by a majority of the members of the said board at a regular meeting or a meeting called for the purpose of hearing such request.
The county legislative delegation shall have no authority to issue an authorization for expenditure of funds between sessions of the General Assembly.
(c) The clerk to the board shall prepare, during the first week of each month, a full statement of all claims paid during the preceding month, to be audited by the board.
The statement shall show the file number of the claim, the amount claimed, the nature of the claim or services rendered, and the name of the claimant.

(d) On or before January 15th of each year the board shall prepare and submit to the legislative delegation of the county an itemized statement of all needful appropriations, together with the estimated revenues accruing to the county from all sources and in such form that the statement may be used as the basis for the annual county appropriation act.
It is also made the duty of the board to make recommendations to the delegation in respect to needful legislation in the interest of an efficient administration of the affairs of the county.

(e) The board shall estimate quarterly the amount of money necessary to meet claims against the county (in accordance with the appropriations made) for the next ensuing quarter and shall not borrow at any one time an amount of money in excess of the estimates.

No loans shall be negotiated for any sum or sums of money by any public officer or officers of Darlington County except upon competitive bids from reliable and responsible bidders, which bids shall be made after notice being mailed to each bank or banking institution within the county.

Any public officer within the County of Darlington who shall fail, refuse, or neglect to comply with the terms and provisions of this section shall be guilty of misconduct in office and it shall be the duty of the Governor, upon the fact being made known to him, to remove the officer or officers summarily from office.

Manager clerk disbursements purchases.(a) The board shall employ a county manager and a county clerk, each of whom shall hold office for the term of one year on a fiscal year basis, beginning July 1, 1952.
Each shall, however, be subject to removal by the board at any time for sufficient cause.

Before entering upon the discharge of their duties, the county manager shall execute a fidelity bond in the sum of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) and the county clerk shall execute a fidelity bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), both of which shall be in favor of the county with a surety company authorized to do business in South Carolina, and the premium on the bonds shall be paid from county ordinary funds.
(b) All vouchers and warrants for the disbursement of county funds shall, after approval by the board, be signed by the county manager and the county clerk.
Such vouchers and warrants and all other records pertaining to the county business shall be placed in the custody of the county clerk who shall preserve them among the records of his office.
The county clerk shall also examine and audit the accounts of all county officers, including magistrates, at such times as the board may designate.
(c) It is made the duty of the county manager to keep the board informed on the financial and other affairs of Darlington County.

The public works of the county, including the supervision of all public buildings, road machinery, chaingang, and jail equipment, and other public property, both real and personal, and the construction, maintenance and supervision of public roads, bridges, and other public works, and the operation and maintenance of the chaingang and jail, shall be under the supervision of the county manager, subject to such rules, regulations, and restrictions as may be promulgated by the board.

(d) The purchase of all supplies, equipment, machinery, groceries, materials, wares, merchandise, and other articles which may be needed by the county from time to time, shall be made by the county manager, subject to such rules, regulations and restrictions as may be promulgated by the board, with a view, first, to serving satisfactorily the purpose and contemplation of such purchases, and second, to securing the widest practicable measure of competition consistent with that purpose.

All materials, supplies, or equipment, the value of which exceeds two hundred dollars ($200.00), purchased directly by the county manager, shall be purchased only after the county manager has secured two or more bids.
All materials, supplies, or equipment, the value of which exceeds two hundred dollars (S200 .00), shall be purchased only after receiving two or more sealed bids.

Road programs.The board shall as soon as practicable after its appointment, and not later than February 1st of each succeeding year, draw up a proposed program for the building of roads, improvements to existing roads, and recommendations for roads to be included in the state primary and secondary systems.

The program shall be designed to cover a period of one year from the date of its preparation and the county delegation shall be governed thereby in all matters properly contained therein and no changes or deviations made except by and with the consent of the majority of the Darlington County Delegation, including the Senator.
Attorney.As legal advisor to the County Board of Directors, there shall be appointed by the board a member of the South Carolina Bar, who is also a member of the Darlington County Bar.
Such appointment shall be made for a oneyear term on a fiscal year basis beginning July 1, 1952, and such attorney shall handle all legal business of the county.

Repeal.Sections 4227, 4228, 4229, 4230, 42301, 42302, 4232, 4233, 4234, 4235, and 4236, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as amended, and all other acts or parts of acts inconsistent with the provisions of this act, are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 25th day of March, 1952.
851 An Act To Amend Section 5355, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Last Amended By Act No.

839 Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions Of The General Assembly, 1948, Relating To School Claims And Payment Thereof, So As To Further Provide For Method Of Ascertaining Claims And Payments In Laurens County, And To Require The Superintendent Of Laurens County School District No.
55 To Post A Bond In The Sum Of Ten Thousand Dollars ($10,000.00).
5355, 1942 Code, amendedpayment of claims, Laurens County School District No.
55.Section 5355, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as last amended by Act No.

839 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1948, relating to school claims and payment thereof, is further amended by adding at the end thereof the following proviso: Provided, however, that the Board of Trustees of Laurens County School District No.

55 shall file with the county superintendent of education, monthly, on forms to be furnished by the superintendent, a statement signed by a majority of the board, showing in itemized form the payroll of the school district and all other claims, and the county superintendent of education shall draw a warrant on the county treasurer against the funds of the school district for the payment of the items shown on such statement, which sum shall be payable to the Superintendent of Laurens County School District No.
The funds shall be disbursed by the Superintendent of Laurens County School District No.

Provided, however, that the superintendent shall file with the superintendent of education a surety bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for the faithful performance of his duties, with the bond being payable to the county superintendent of education and his successors in office. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
852 An Act To Amend Article ITI Of Act No.

379, Acts And Joint Resolutions Of South Carolina, 1951, By Adding A New Section To Be Section 7A, So As To Provide That In Aiken County The County Board Of Education Shall, Ex Officio, Be The Board Of Trustees; To Further Provide For The Powers And Duties Of The Aiken County Board Of Education; To Provide For Area Boards Of Education, Their Duties And Powers; And Repeal section 5518, 55181, 55182, 55183, 55184, 55185, And 5519, As Amended, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942.
Act 379 of 1951 amendedschool trustees, Aiken County.Article III of Act No.
379, Acts and Joint Resolutions of South Carolina, 1951, is amended by adding a new section to be designated as Section 7A: section 7A.
In Aiken County the county board of education shall, ex officio, be and constitute the board of school trustees. Section 2.

District trustees abolishedduties, powers, property and obligations devolved on board of educationboard borrow.All district boards of trustees are hereby abolished, and all duties, powers and functions of the district boards of trustees and the present county board of education are hereby devolved upon the county board of education, and all property, assets, and financial obligations of the district board of trustees are hereby transferred to the Aiken County Board of Education.
The county board of education is further empowered to issue shortterm notes in anticipation of federal aid, state aid or taxes.

Area boards of educationThe County Board of Education for Aiken County is authorized to establish high school attendance areas in Aiken County and appoint in each attendance area an Area Board of Education consisting of five members whose terms of office shall be three years; provided, however, in the beginning two shall be appointed for a term of three years, two for a term of two years and one for a term of one year.

Attendance area budgetspowers of area boards.It shall be the duty of each Area Board of Education together with its area superintendent and the county superintendent of schools to prepare annually a proposed classified budget for the schools in their respective attendance areas and submit same to the county board of education on or before the date of its regular meeting in May.

The Area Boards of Education shall have supervisory control of expending the funds appropriated for said budgets in their respective attendance areas to the extent that they, or their authorized representatives, shall approve all requisitions and/or purchase orders for items designated in their respective budgets.
Provided, that the Area Boards of Education may delegate to a member of their board or boards or to a designated representative chosen by it or them.
who may not be a member of stich board or boards, the actual signing of such requisition and/or purchase orders.
The Area Boards of Education shall have supervisory control of all school property within their respective attendance areas.
No school personnel whose work is confined to one attendance area shall be employed by the county board of education until they have first been nominated by the Area Board of Education.
The Area Boards of Education may determine local supervisory policies in their respective attendance areas provided same is not inconsistent with the policies of the county board of education.

The county board of education may delegate additional supervisory authority to the Area Boards of Education to the extent that it deems necessary for the efficient and effective operation of the public school system in Aiken County.
It shall be the duty of the Area Boards of Fducation to assist the Aiken County Board of Education in administering the affairs of their respective schools.

InvalidityIf any provision of this act, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of the act which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of this section are declared to be severable.
Repeal.Sections 5518, 55181, 55182, 55183, 55184, 55185, and 5519, as amended, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, are hereby repealed.
Further repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect on July 1, 1952. : Approved the 22nd day of March, 1952.
853 An Act To Provide For The Election Of The Trustees Of Greenville County School District No.
520 And To Fix Their Terms Of Office.
Trustees, Greenville County school district No.
520 electionduties and powersvacancy.The Board of Trustees of Greenville County School District No.

520 shall consist of nine members, all of whom shall be residents of the district with terms of office as follows: C. R. Babb, Charles Tidwell and Wayne Hiott whose terms shall expire on the first day of July, 1953; H.
S. Richardson, Brown Mahon and J. H.
Bonds whose terms shall expire on the first day of July, 1954; A.
D. Asbury, James F. Howard and Conway Jones whose terms shall expire on the first day of July, 1955.

Their respective successors to hold office for a term of three years each and to be elected at the time and in the manner herein provided: The county board of education shall order an election to be held on the first Tuesday in June, 1953, as hereinafter provided and thereafter order elections to be held on the first Tuesday in June, 1954, and on the same day ot each year thereafter, to name, respectively, successors to trustees whese terms of office have expired, and shall give notice of the time, place, and purpose of such election by advertisement in a newspaper published in Greenville County once a week for two successive weeks next prior to the election.

The elections shall be conducted by three managers, appointed by the county board of education and it shall be their duty to make all necessary preparation for the holding of such clection, to hold and conduct the same and to canvass the ballots and to declare the results of the election in accordance with the rules and regulations provided for the holding of general elections in this state.

The trustees elected under this section, in addition to the duties and responsibilities now provided by law for trustees of school districts, shall have the following powers and duties: (1) To purchase or erect suitable buildings for the use of the public schools of said school district.

(2) To clect and dismiss superintendents and teachers of the schools in said district, prescribe their duties, term of office, and to fix their salaries, and to cause an examination of said teachers to be made whenever necessary; also, to determine the classbooks and studies to be used in said schools and to make rules and regulations for the government of said schools; and, (3) To fill all vacancies occurring in said board of trustees by death, resignation, removal, or otherwise, during their term of office or service.

854 An Act To Provide For The County Unit System Of Operating, Maintaining, And Financing The Public Schools Of Union County; To Provide For A County Board Of Education, Its Election, Powers, And Duties; To Provide For The Appointment Of A County Superintendent Of Education; To Provide For School Attendance Areas; To Provide For Tax Levies For The Support Of The Educational Program Of The County; And To Repeal section 5661, 56611, 56612, 5663, 5664, And 56641, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Act No.
191 Of The Acts Of 1947, And Act No.
1167 Of The Acts Of 1948, All Of Which Relate To School Affairs Of Union County.

Union County Board of EducationFrom and after the approval of this act, the whole of Union County shall be and constitute the territorial unit for financing and operating the public schools (including school bus transportation) within said county, as well as the unit for receiving all local, state and/or federal funds provided for or allocated to said county for educational purposes; and the central authority for operating the system of public education in said county is hereby vested in the Union County Board of Education (hereinafer referred to as the Board) to be constituted and selected as is hereinafter provided.
Termincumbents.The Board shall be composed of seven members, whose terms of office shall be for four years each.

One member shall be elected from Bogansville Township, one from Fish Dam and Santuc Townships jointly, one from Cross Keys and Goshen Hill Townships jointly, one from Jonesville Township, one from Pinckney Township, and two from Union Township; Provided, however, that the present members of the Board (except the County Superintendent of Fducation who now serves as an ex officio member of the Board) shall remain in office and shall continue to constitute the Board until the expiration of their respective terms as is hereinafter provided.

Elect successors to incumbentstermvacancy.(a) On April 30, 1952, the County Superintendent of Educations ex officio membership on the Board shall expire; and in his place and stead one new member of the Board shall be elected by the qualified electors of Union Township for a term of four years beginning May 1, 1952, and so on every four years thereafter.

(b) On April 30, 1952, the term of Paul J. Free shall expire; and his successor shall be elected by the qualified electors of Jonesville Township for a term of four years beginning May 1, 1952, and so on every four years thereafter.

(c) On April 30, 1952, the term of J. D. Whitehead shall expire; and his successor shall be elected by the qualified electors of Bogansville Township for a term of four years beginning May 1, 1952, and so on every four years thereafter.
(d) On April 30, 1953, the term of W. D.
Dent shall expire ; and his successor shall be elected by the qualified electors of Pinckney Township for a term of four years beginning May 1, 1953, and so on every four years thereafter.

(e) On April 30, 1953, the term of William Coleman shall expire; and his successor shall be elected by the qualified electors of Cross Keys and Goshen Hill Townships jointly for a term of four years beginning May 1, 1953, and so on every four years thereafter.

(f) On April 30, 1954, the term of J. Ryan Jeter shall expire; and his successor shall be elected by the qualified electors of Fish Dam and Santuc Townships jointly for a term of four years beginning May 1, 1954, and so on every four years thereafter.
(g) On April 30, 1954, the term of T.
D. Truluck shall expire; and his successor shall be elected by the qualified electors of Union Township for a term of four years beginning May 1, 1954, and so on every four years thereafter.

(h) Provided, however, that no person shall be eligible for membership upon the Board unless he is either a bona fide resident of or owns real property within the township or group of townships from which he is to be elected and is also a qualified elector.

(i) And Provided, further, that if any present member of the Board whose term is continued hereunder shall for any reason fail to serve out his present term as fixed and determined herein, the vacancy so caused shall be filled for his unexpired term by an election to be held for that purpose within the township or townships affected.

(j) And Provided, further, that if any elected member of the Board shall for any reason fail to serve out his term for which elected, the vacancy so caused shall be filled for his unexpired term by an election to be held for that purpose within the township or townships affected.

Elections(a) As the terms of the several members of the Board expire on April 30th of each year as herein provided, their successors shall be chosen by election within that township or townships to be held on the second Friday in April immediately preceding; Provided, however, that elections to fill unexpired terms as provided for in Section 3 (i) and (j) above shall be held as soon after the vacancy occurs as is practical.
Such elections shall be conducted by or under the supervision of the Board, which shall appoint, fix the compensation of, and pay the box managers for such elections.

Said elections shall be conducted as nearly as is practical in accordance with the provisions of the general law regulating general elections in this state; Provided, however, that prior notice of each election shall be published once a week for two weeks in a newspaper of general circulation within Union County; and provided, further, that only qualified electors shall be eligible to vote at any such election.

(b) The person receiving the highest number of votes in any such election shall be declared elected; and his election shall be certified by the Board to the Secretary of State who shall thereupon issue a commission to such person for the term as herein provided.

Quorumofficersmeetingsper diem.Five members of the Board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business; and a majority of those present at any meeting, provided that at least a quorum is present, may decide any question arising for decision.
The Board shall choose its chairman from among its members as it may determine, but such chairman shall have a vote on all matters to the same extent as any other member of the Board.
The Superintendent of Education hereinafter provided for shall serve as Secretary to the Board.
The Board shall meet during the month of May of each year and at such other times as they may deem necessary or advisable.
The members shall receive five dollars for each meeting attended, not to exceed twelve meetings in any on year.
Superintendent of educationThe present County Superintendent of Education may remain in office until the expiration of his term on June 30, 1953.

But from and after that date, all the duties, powers and functions heretofore vested in him are hereby devolved upon and transferred to the Board ; and the Board may appoint some suitable individual on the basis of professional qualifications as the County Superintendent of Education who shall be the chief administrative officer of the county school system, and shall perform such duties and functions as may be delegated to him by the Board.

Act as trusteesduties and powers.The Board shall serve, ex officio, as the Board of School Trustees for Union Countv, and it is hereby vested with all the powers and functions heretofore vested in the local boards of trustees, and shall have full and complete responsibility, power and authority for the operation of the public schools in Union County on a county unit basis.
The Board shall have and perform all powers, duties and functions with respect to Union County as conferred upon County Boards of Education by Act No.
379 of the Acts of 1951 or by any other general law, and shall also exercise the following powers and functions: (1) Adopt administrative policies.
(2) Fix local supplements in salaries.
(5) Exercise the right of eminent domain in securing necessary property.
In the exercise of such rights the Board shall follow as near as practical the procedure prescribed for condemnation by municipal corporations.
(6) Determine and evaluate the educational program.
(7) Control the transportation system.
(8) Contract for services, equipment and supplies.
(9) Cause audits to be made and publish annual special reports.
(10) Keep a record of Board proceedings.
(11) Direct a continuing school census and enforce the state compulsory attendance act.
(12) Conduct all school elections.
(13) Fix the length of the school term.

(14) Conduct surveys and upon the result obtained reorganize attendance areas, the curriculum, the supervisory program, auxiliary services, or any part of the educational program delegated by the state to the Board.
(15) Arrange with the adjoining counties for interchange of pupils or educational services.
Attendance areasadvisory boards.The Board may divide Union County into school attendance areas, following such geographical lines as it may deem best.

From each of such attendance areas there shall be elected by the qualified electors thereof three citizens to serve as an advisory board or committee with whom the Board may confer with respect to the operation and maintenance of the schools within their areas; Provided, however, that the present boards of school trustees shall remain in office and serve as such advisory boards or committees until the expiration of their current terms.

Budgetstax levy.The board shall annually estimate the funds necessary to carry on an efficient educational program for Union County and the tax millage necessary to provide such funds; and shall certify its findings to the legislative delegation of Union County in budget form.

The delegation may make any changes in such budget that it desires to make and a majority of the delegation, including the Senator, shall certify to the county auditor the necessary millage to raise the funds to meet such budget as finally determined.
The auditor shall then levy the millage on all the taxable property in Union County; provided, however, that the millage so certified and levied shall not exceed twentyseven mills annually.
The county treasurer shall collect the taxes so levied as and when other property taxes are collected.

Property and liabilities of districts The Board shall assume control of all property now being used for school purposes or now belonging to the various school districts and shall assume all outstanding indebtedness by way of bond issue or otherwise of the various school districts; Provided, however, that any unexpended funds on hand to the credit of any school district arising from the sale of bonds shall be expended without unnecessary delay within the school district by which such bonds were issued.

Repeal.Sections 5661, 56611, 56612, 5663, 5664, and 56641, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, Act 191 of the Acts of 1947, Act 1167 of the Acts of 1948, and all other acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed; but all rights and liabilities under the laws hereby repealed shall continue, and may be enforced in the same manner, as if this repeal had not been made.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon ts approval by the Governor. Approved the 22nd day of March, 1952.

855 An Act To Authorize And Empower The County Board Of Education To Levy Annually An Additional County Wide Tax, Not To Exceed 30 Mills, For The Support And Maintenance Of The Public Schools And Public School Transportation In Chesterfield County, And Direct The Apportionment And Distribution Of The Proceeds Of Said, Tax, And Other Revenue Of The County Board Fund, Among The Several School Districts Of Chesterfield County, And For School Transportation Purposes.

Additional school levy, Chesterfield County.The County Board of Education of Chesterfield County is hereby authorized and empowered to levy annually an additional county wide tax, not to exceed thirty mills, for the support and maintenance of the public schools and the transportation of the school children of Chesterfield County.
The proceeds of said county wide tax shall be deposited in and become a part of the Chesterfield County Board of Education Fund, created by the provisions of Act No.
162 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of 1945, as amended.

Distribution of revenues.So long as there shall be more than one public school district in Chesterfield County, the County Board of Education thereof, is hereby authorized and empowered to apportion and distribute the proceeds of said tax, and such other revenue as is available to the credit of said County Board of Education Fund, or any part or portion thereof, among the several school districts of Chesterfield County, for school and transportation purposes, upon the basis of average daily attendance.or annual enrollment, as the County Board of Education shall by resolution determine.

Levy and collection of such tax.The County Auditor is hereby directed and required, when so ordered and directed by appropriate resolution of the County Board of Education of Chesterfield County, to levy annually for school and school transportation purposes, such county wide tax, not to exceed 30 mills, as such resolution of the County Board of Education shall order and direct, upon all of the taxable property in Chesterfield County.
Said annual tax levy shall be designated as the Chesterfield County Board of Education Equalization Tax.

The County Treasurer shall collect said we reae, wr nw op tax and deposit the proceeds thereof in said County Board of Education Fund. Section 4. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 22nd day of March, 1952.

856 An Act To Provide That Where Two Or More School Districts In Chesterfield County Shall Consolidate The Board Of Trustees Of The Consolidated Districts Shall Consist Of Nine Members; To Provide For Their Appointment, Subsequent Election And Terms Of Office.

Trustees for consolidated school districts, Chesterfield Countyelectiontermvacancynomination.W henever two or more school districts of Chesterfield County are consolidated into a single district by resolution of the county board of education, the county board shall appoint a board of trustees of nine members for the consolidated district; provided, however, that the term of office of said trustees shall cease and determine on the 31st day of December stthsequent to the next general election after their appointment by the County Board of Education of Chesterfield County; and, provided, further, that the trustees of such consolidated public school districts of Chesterfield County shall be elected by the resident qualified electors of each of said consolidated public school districts, respectively, in the General Election held next after the consolidation and creation of said Consolidated Public School Districts.
Said school district trustees shall be resident qualified electors of the school districts, respectively, which they are to serve as trustees.
Not less than three of said consolidated school district trustees in each of said school districts, shall be women electors.

In the election of said trustees for said school districts, the three women candidates, in each of said school districts, receiving the largest number of votes cast for the women candidates, shall be declared duly elected trustees of each of said school districts, respectively, and the six other candidates, in each of said school districts, who shall receive the highest number of votes cast in said school district elections, whether men or women electors, shall be declared duly elected; provided, however, if there are less than three women electors, who are candidates in any of said school district elections, that the women receiving the highest number of votes cast for the women candidates, in any school district, shall be declared duly elected as trustees of the particular school district; and, provided further, that if there are no women candidates in any of said school district elections, that the nine candidates receiving the highest number of votes cast in said elections, in each of said school districts, respectively, shall be declared duly elected as the trustees of their respective school districts.

The term of office of the trustees elected under the provisions of this act shall commence on the Ist day of January next after their election and continue for a term of two years and until their successors in office have duly qualified.

Subsequent terms of office of said trustees shall commence on the first day of January following the general election in even years; and, provided further, that any vacancies in said boards of trustees by death, resignation, removal, failure to elect, or otherwise, shall be filled by appointment and commission of the Governor upon the written recommendation of a majority of the members of the County Board of Education of Chesterfield County.

Nomination for election as trustees for said school districts shall be by petition signed by twentyfive (25) or more resident electors of the school district in which the candidate resides and such nomination petitions shall be filed with the County Board of Education not less than thirty (30) days before the date of the General Election in which said trustees are to be elected.

857 An Act To Provide For A County Board Of Education For Spartanburg County; To Provide A Method Of Selection, Its Duties And Functions; To Provide For A County Superintendent Of Education; And To Provide A Levy Of Taxes For School Purposes; To Provide For New School Districts, The Trustees Thereof, Their Selection And Functions And To Repeal Act No.
888 Of The Acts Of 1950, As Amended By Act No.
374 Of The Acts Of 1951, Relating To The School System In Spartanburg County.

Spartanburg County Board of Education.The central authority of the public school system of Spartanburg County shall be vested in a county board of education composed of sixteen members who shall otherwise have no official connection with the public schools of the county and whose duties and powers shall be as hereinafter provided.
Members of the county board of education shall be elected by the qualified electors of the several school districts.
Each of the seven school districts shall have two members except that District No.
7 shall have four members.
The members of the county board of education shall be elected in the general election to be held in November, 1952.
Provided, that the present members of the county board of education shall continue in office until January 1, 1953.
The members from the several school districts shall be residents of the areas as hereinafter set out: District No.
One member shall be a resident of School District No.
1 as the school districts existed on May 6, 1950.
One member shall he a resident of School District No.
4 as existed on May 6, 1950.
3 as existed on May 6, 1950.
2 as existed on May 6, 1950.
8 as existed on May 6, 1950.
9 as existed on May 6, 1950.
11 as existed on May 6, 1950.
12 as existed on May 6, 1950.
Both members shall not be residents of the same school district as such school districts were constituted immediately prior to May 6, 1950.
6 as existed on May 6, 1950.
10 as existed on May 6, 1950.
The four members of School District No.
7 shall be residents of School District No.
7 as existed on May 6, 1950.
(2) Upon the effective date of this act the county legislative delegation shall appoint three additional members of the county board who shall be residents of School District No.
7 and one additional member of the county board who shall be a resident of School District No.
The terms of the members so appointed shall expire December 31, 1952.
The sixteen members of the first county board of education elected shall cast lots for the length of the term of each.

The terms of eight members shall expire at the end of the second year and the terms of the remaining eight members shall expire at the end of four years; provided, however, that the terms of no more than half the members from any district shall expire at the same time.
The succeeding board members from each district to be elected under this act shall be elected at the general election next preceding the expiration of the term of the member he succeeds.
The members so elected shall serve for a term of four years.
The members so elected shall be qualified electors of the same school district and subject to the same residence requirements as the member whose term expires.

Consolidation and boundaries of districts The county board of education shall have the power and duty of consolidating and fixing the boundaries of the several school districts within Spartanburg County as provided by the general laws of this state, but in the event major changes are made in consolidation or fixing boundaries or numerical designation of the seven school districts now existing within Spartanburg County, such changes shall in no wise effect the personnel or make up of the county board of education, the boards of trustees of the various school districts or any other provision of this act.
Officersmeetingstravel.At the first meeting of the county board of education provided for in this act the board shall organize and elect from its membership a chairman and a vicechairman.
Thereafter, officers of the board shall be elected annually at a meeting on the first Tuesday next following January first of each year.
Members of the board shall be reimbursed for any travel expenses incurred in carrying on official business of the board.

Duties and powers of board and superintendent of education.(1) The county board of education shall have general supervision of all phases of the public school program in Spartanburg County except as may be otherwise vested by this act in boards of trustees of local school districts.
(2) The superintendent of educations office shall employ such other personnel as may from time to time be provided for by annual appropriations.
(3) The county board of education shall set up qualifications and make rules governing the personnel and make rules governing other matters pertaining to the schools of the county as a whole.
(4) The county superintendent of education shall be the administrative officer of the county board of education.

It shall be his duty to effectuate the official policies of the board and to recommend to the board from time to time such changes in procedure and policy as will, in his opinion, improve the school system in the county.

Trustees election appointment terms duties and powersbudgetsremoval.(1) In each of the school districts of Spartanburg County as established by the county board of education there shall be a board of trustees of nine members who shall be appointed by the county board of education ; provided, that the present members of the several boards of trustees shall continue in office as hereinafter provided.

Provided, further, that in those school districts which have less than nine members on the boards of trustees, then the county board of education shall appoint additional trustees so that each school district shall have a total of nine trustees.

Provided, further, that upon the peiition of not less unan three nundred fitty quatitied electors of any school district being filed with the county board of education within thirty days after the effective date of this act calling for an election of the trustees in such district then and in that event the county board of education shall call an election to be held within sixty days and not earlier than fortyfive days thereafter to determine the additional members of such board of trustees.

Within sixty days before the term of office of any trustee expires not less than three hundred fifty qualified electors of any school district may petition for an election to determine the successor or successors of such trustee or trustees.
In the event no such petition is filed the county board of education shall appoint such trustee or trustees.
The laws governing the general election in South Carolina shall apply to the election of trustees.
The county commissioners of election shall prepare the necessary ballots, appoint managers for the voting precincts in the district and do all things necessary to carry out such election.
The district in which the election is held shall pay from its school funds the costs of the election.

The managers shall report the results to the county commissioners of the election who shall certify them to the county board of education, which board shall declare the election, hear and pass on any contest and decide such contest.

The decision of the county board of education may be appealed to the state board of education; provided, written notice of appeal is served on the board or any member thereof within a period of ten days after the decision is rendered.

Provided, further, that any petition for an election prepared, signed or presented prior to the effective date of this act shall not be subject to dismissal as premature and if otherwise sufficient shall be the basis for calling an election.

(2) As of the effective date of this act the terms of office of the nine members of each board of trustees shall expire in the following manner: The terms of two members shall expire at the end of each succeeding year wherever possible and the term of the remaining three members shall expire at the end of the fourth year; provided, that the terms of office of the members of the first board of trustees in each district to hold office after the passage of this act shall be determined by casting lots.
Thereafter their successors shall hold office for a term of four years.
Provided, that nothing contained in this act shall prevent any trustee from succeeding himself whether his expiring term shall have been for four years or for a lesser term.
(3) The trustees of each of the school districts provided for herein shall have responsibility for all phases of the school.
program in their respective school districts except as may be vested by law in the county board of education.
Each board shall employ personnel required for the operation of the schools.
(4) It shall be the duties of these boards of trustees to continue the operations of the schools within their districts and to carry out contracts already entered into for the school districts.
Upon their appointment or election, members of each board of trustees shall organize by electing a chairman and a secretary.
They shall, in conjunction with the county board of education as soon as practicable, make out budgets for the school year 195354.

(5) At the beginning of each school year the trustees of the several districts shall prepare a budget for their respective school districts and submit it to the county board of education by July first.
The county board of education shall either approve or disapprove the budget and the budget shall be turned over to the county auditor who shall levy the necessary taxes.

(6) Whenever within the sole discretion of the county board of education it is to the best interests of the schools of any school district that any trustee or trustees be removed from office, the board may remove such trustee and appoint another to serve in his place during the remainder of the term for which he was originally appointed, provided, that the terms of this subsection shall not apply to any trustee elected under the provisions of this act.
Superintendents of schools.Boards of trustees in each school district shall employ a superintendent of schools who shall be the administrative officer of the board.

It shall be the duty of the local superintendent to nominate principals and teachers for the schools in the districts and to supervise the schools, principals, and teachers, together with all phases of the school program in the area constituting the school district.

Financing objective In providing for the finances of the school system of Spartanburg County, the county board of education shall have as its primary objective equalization of funds available for the operation of all schools in the county.

Tax levy.There shall be levied a thirteen mill tax to be applied uniformly to all property in the county to guarantee a minimum foundation program of public school education to all children in the county.
The levy shall be entered by the county auditor and collected by the county treasurer as other taxes on property.
The proceeds of this levy shall be credited by the county treasurer to the county board of education.

The county board of education shall distribute the monies above collected among the several districts on the basis of the number of pupils residing within the county in average daily attendance in each of the several school districts.

Credit of funds.Funds collected or received by the county treasurer for school purposes shall be credited as outlined below: (1) State and federal funds shall be credited directly to the school districts or to the county board of education for which remitted.
(2) Proceeds of the uniform county wide tax for school purposes shall be credited to the county board of education.

The county board of education shall certify: to the county treasurer the apportionment of this fund to each of the several school districts and when so notified, the county treasurer shall make transfers from the county board of education account to each of the school district accounts in accordance with the apportionment by the county board.
(3) Record of all school funds not specifically provided for herein shall be kept as directed by the county board of education.

Assets and liabilities of former districts Any balances appearing on the county treasurers records to the credit of any of the present school districts in the county shall be consolidated into school district accounts according to the grouping of present districts as provided for by the county board of education.

Each of the school districts shall likewise assume the obligation for the payment of any current indebtedness that may be outstanding against any of the former districts provided that nothing herein contained shall be construed so as to impair the obligation of existing contracts of Spartanburg County, all rights of the holders of any such bonds being hereby specifically preserved.

Same.Any bonded indebtedness which may be outstanding against any of the former school districts of the county shall be assumed as an obligation of the entire school area in which the district falls as consolidated by the county board of education and each of the school districts shall likewise assume title to all school property in its area.
Invalidity.If any section or part of this act shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional such declaration shall not affect the validation of other section or parts herein.
Repeal.Act No.
888 of the Acts of 1950 as amended by Act No.
374 of the Acts of 1951, and all acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall become effective upon the signature of the Governor except as has been specifically provided for herein. Approved the 22nd day of March, 1952.

858 An Act To Authorize And Direct The State Highway Department To Add To The State Highway System, Survey And Construct A Road From The Interesection Of Jackson And Boundary Streets In Barnwell To Route 3 South Of Barnwell.

State Highway Department add road in Barnwell County to State Highway SystemState Highway Department construct.The State Highway Department is hereby authorized and directed to add to the State Highway System, survey and construct a road approximately one and fourtenths milles in length from the intersection of Jackson and Boundary Streets in Barnwell southerly and southeasterly to State Route 3 south of Barnwell.
Charging of cost of construction.The cost of this road shall be charged against funds allocated to Barnwell County for Secondary or FarmtoMarket road construction.
Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent with the provisions of this act are hereby repealed to the extent of such inconsistency.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 21st day of February, 1952.
859 An Act To Take From The State Highway System A Certain Section Of Road In Anderson County And To Provide For The Substitution In Lieu Thereof Another Section Of Road In Anderson County.

Section of road near Williamston removed from State Highway System, Anderson County.A section of road designated as Road S4210 from Road S496 approximately two miles west of Williamston southwesterly approximately 2.0 miles to U. S. Route 29 is hereby taken out of the State Highway System.

Substitute another road for same.With the approval of the Senator and at least onehalf of the Representatives from Anderson County, a section of road in Anderson County of approximately equal length may be added to the State Highway System in lieu of the road hereby removed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect immediately upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 21st day of February, 1952.
860 An Act To Repeal Section 56421, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Creating Round Mountain High School District In Oconee County, And To Fix The Effective Date Of This Act.

56421, 1942 Code, repealedRound Mountain High School District, Oconee County.Section 56421, Code of Laws of South Carolina,1942, creating Round Mountain High School District in Oconee County is hereby repealed.
iNt OO WITGIIN: Section 3. Time effective This act shall take effect July 1, 1952. Approved the 22nd day of March, 1952.
861 An Act To Authorize The Trustees And Board Of Education Of Jasper County To Borrow Not Exceeding Thirty Thousand Dollars ($30,000.00) For School Purposes When Necessary, And To Repeal Act No.
889 Of The Acts Of 1950, Relating To The Operation Of Schools In Jasper County.
Act 735 of 1950 amendedschool budgets, Jasper County.Act No.

735, Acts and Joint Resolutions, 1950, entitled An Act To Provide A Budget System For The Operation Of The Schools In Jasper County And To Provide Funds For The Operating Expenses Of Such Schools., is amended by adding at the end of Section 1 the following: Any contract made by the county board of education or any board of trustees in excess of the amount approved in the budget shall be void and of no effect. The section when amended shall read as follows: section 1.

The trustees of each of the school districts in Jasper County are directed to submit to the county board of education of that county, on or before the first day of Apfil each year a budget in such form as may be required by the county board of education for the operation of the schools for the ensuing scholastic year, and at some specified time not later than the fourteenth day of April of each year, each of the board of trustees of the school districts shall meet with the county boards of education for the purpose of adjusting such differences, if any, as may be between the amounts of the budgets as submitted by the boards of trustees and the amount which in the discretion of the county board of education is found necessary for the operation of the schools.

In making such decision, the county board of education shall consider the average per pupil cost of operation within the county for the preceding scholastic year, providing that the county board of education shall not approve budgets, the total of which is in excess of the maximum amount of revenue herein authorized.
Provided, further, that the county superintendent of education shall not pay any claim in excess of that approved in the budget for any school district as approved by the county board of education.
Any contract made by the county board of education or any board of trustees in excess of the amount approved in the budget shall be void and of no effect. Section 2.
Sametax leviesborrow.Section 2 of Act No.
735 of the Acts of 1950, is amended by striking out all of same and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be Section 2: section 2.

The County Auditor of Jasper County shall levy annually upon all property in Jasper County a sufficient tax not exceeding thirtyseven mills to meet the total of the budgets for school purposes as authorized to be fixed under the provisions of Section 1 of this act, and the Treasurer of said county shall collect the tax so levied as other taxes are collected.

The amount of any annual levy shall first be determined by the County Board of Education, the County Treasurer and the County Auditor, and shall be in such amount as these officials determine is necessary to meet the cost of operating the schools and providing transportation for the pupils in the county as authorized in this act.

That in order to meet the appropriations provided for in this act, the Treasurer and Board of Education of Jasper County are authorized and empowered to borrow, as and when needed, such sums as may be necessary, not exceeding a total of thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00), and at a rate of interest not exceeding five per cent per annum, to meet the appropriations and expenditures made under this act.
The said officers shall execute proper form of notes for Jasper County as evidence of such indebtedness and may pledge the taxes herein levied. Section 3.
735, Acts and Joint Resolutions, 1950, is further amended by adding a new section to be known as Section 3A to read as follows: section 3A.

The violation of any of the provisions of this act by the county superintendent of education, the county board of education or any board of trustees is declared to be an act of official misconduct and the official or officials so offending shall be forthwith removed from office. Section 4. RepealAct No.
889 of the Acts of 1950 and all acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 22nd day of March, 1952.

622, 1942 Code, amendedsubstitutes for jury commissioners, Richland County.Section 622, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1952, is amended by adding at the end thereof the following: Provided, that in Richland County, when, at the time for preparing a jury list or at the time for drawing a jury, the clerk of common pleas, the county auditor, or the county treasurer is unable to serve (whether because of a vacancy in the office, disqualification, or any other cause), one or more of the following, as may be necessary, shall act as jury commissioners in lieu of their respective superiors: the deputy clerk of common pleas, the deputy county auditor, or the deputy county treasurer. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.

865 An Act To Amend Section 7243, Code Of Laws Of South Caro lina, 1942, Relating To The Publication Of Statements Of Re.
