866 An Act To Create The Office Of County Manager Of The County Of Chester; To Provide For His Appointment And Term Of Office; To Prescribe His Duties And Authority; To Provide For The Compensation For Such County Manager And To Abolish The Office Of Supervisor Of Roads For Chester County.
COUNTY MANAGER, CHESTER COUNTY APPOINTMENT TERM SALARY.

The Clerk of the County Board of Directors of Chester County shall hereinafter be referred to as the County Manager of Chester County, State of South Carolina, which County Manager shall be appointed by the Chester County Board of Directors upon the recommendation and with the approval of the Chester County Legislative Delegation, and whose term of office shall be for a period of two years commencing with the approval of this act and until his successor has been duly appointed and qualified.
Vacancies occurring in the office of County Manager shall be filled in the original manner and shall be for the unexpired portion of the term.
The salary of said County Manager shall be fixed annually in the Chester County Supply Act.

The County Manager hereinabove provided for shall, before entering upon the discharge of his duties, enter into a bond in the sum of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) conditioned upon the faithful performance and discharge of his duties.
Provided, the Clerk now serving shall be the County Manager for the original term as above provided.
ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER OF COUNTY BOARD OF DIRECTORS DUTIES.

The County Manager shall be the administrative officer of the County Board of Directors and shall administer the affairs of the County Board of Directors and is further authorized, directed and empowered, in the absence of the County Board of Directors or when the County Board of Directors is not in session to perform the duties and to carry out those functions of the County Board of Directors imposed and provided for by Act No.
514 of the Acts of the General Assembly, 1944, and in addition thereto the duties hereinafter prescribed.

The County Manager shall have general supervision of all county buildings, counoy ty farm, nursing and convalescent home, dieting of prisoners in the county jail and the keeping of the books and records of the office of the County Board of Directors, and shall have all other duties of an administrative nature.
All employees shall hereinafter be employed by the said Board upon the recommendation of the County Manager.
The County Manager shall organize and maintain an efficient system of operation for the road department, the county prison stockade and the county shops.
Said system shall include a record of all receipts and disbursements, purchases, etc., and shall also include monthly inventory of all materials, supplies, equipment and machinery on hand.
The inventory is to be made by the County Manager or person or persons acting under his direction.
The County Manager shall make a report at the end of each month to the County Board of Directors showing the work performed during the month, together with the expenditures therefor.

The County Manager shall have in charge and organize and manage the construction, maintenance and repair of the roads, highways, and bridges of the County and shall have adequate authority and full responsibility for the construction and maintenance of roads, highways, and bridges.

The County Manager is hereby authorized and directed to cooperate at all times with the State Highway Department in the highway construction program now jointly engaged in by the State Highway Department and Chester County on roads in the highway system and shall accept supervisory technical assistance made available by the State Highway Department in the program of construction and maintenance of roads in Chester County.
The County Manager shall advise and cooperate with the County Board of Directors, and shall attend all regular meetings of the County Board of Directors.
PURCHASING AGENT DUTIES.
The County Manager shall be the purchasing agent for Chester County and purchase all supplies, machinery, equipment and materials, claims for which shall be approved by the County Board of Directors.
All purchases of supplies, machinery, equipment and materials in excess of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be made by the County Manager by asking for and advertising for public bids.
The County Manager shall ask for and receive two or more bids for any supplies, machinery, equipment or materials to be purchased.
The County Manager in asking for and advertising for bids, shall submit a list of specifications in detail for any purchase or purchases to be made.
After bids have been received from two or more bidders the County Manager shall make purchase or purchases from the lowest bidder.

Provided, further, that when purchases of any supplies, machinery, equipment or materials are made from the South Carolina Highway Department, or any other governmental agency or department, the County Manager shall make said purchases without asking for and advertising for bids, such purchases to be made with the approval of the County Board of Directors and a majority of the Chester County Legislative Delegation.
Provided, further, that under emergency conditions the County Manager shall be authorized to make purchases without asking for and advertising for bids.

Provided, further, that purchases under two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be made by the County Manager without asking for and advertising for bids, and in every such instance said County Manager shall certify on claim for the article thus purchased the reasons therefor.

All claims against the County of Chester for supplies, machinery, equipment and materials arising under and to be paid for out of the appropriations for the departments of the county in charge of the County Board of Directors shall first be approved by the County Manager before being paid.
Provided, further, that any purchase or purchases of any supplies, machinery, equipment, or materials made contrary to the above provisions shall not be paid for out of any county funds.
SUPERVISOR OF ROADS ABOLISHED.
The office of Supervisor of Roads is hereby abolished upon the approval of this act; provided, the salary of the Supervisor of Roads shall be paid through March 31, 1952.
EFFECTIVE: This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 31st day of March, 1952.

868 An Act To Amend Section 47283, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To The Auctioneer For Pickens County So As To Increase The Compensation For His Services To Three Dollars For Each Sale.

Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1..  47283, 1942 Code, amendedauctioneer, Pickens County.Section 47283, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is amended by striking out all of same and inserting the following to be Section 47283: section 47283.
The office of Auctioneer for Pickens County is hereby created.

He shall be appointed by the Governor upon the recommendation of a majority of the members of the Legislative Delegation from Pickens County, and shall serve for two years, and until his successor shall have been appointed as provided for herein.
It is made his duty to act as auctioneer in all judicial sales; tax sales, or sales under levy and execution.
He shall receive as compensation for his services the sum of three dollars for conducting each sale, which shall be taxed as other costs in the action or proceeding are taxed.

In the event that the auctioneer is disqualified, or incapacitated to conduct any sale, he is authorized and empowered to designate some person to act in his place and stead. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 27th day of March, 1952.
869 An Act To Regulate The Office Hours Of County Officials In Chester County And To Further Provide For Their Duties.
Office hours, Chester County.All county offices in Chester County shall remain open Monday through Friday from 9:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. On Saturday all county offices shall be open until 1:00 p.m.

870 An Act To Provide For A County Board Of Health And County Health Department For Spartanburg County And To Repeal section 50573 And 50574, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To Health Facilities In Spartanburg County.

Spartanburg County Board of Health.Spartanburg County shall have and maintain a county board of health under direction and control of the State Board of Health, as now provided by law, for the direction and control of local boards of health in incorporated cities, towns and villages.
Appointmentelectionpay.The county board of health shall be composed of seven members.

One member shall be appointed by the county legislative delegation from citizens of the county at large; one member shall be elected by the membership of the Spartanburg County Medical Society ; one member shall be elected by the membership of the Spartanburg County Dental Society; one member shall be elected by the membership of the Spartanburg County Tuberculosis Association; one member shall be elected by the membership of the Spartanburg County Teachers Association; and one member shall be elected by the Spartanburg County Mental Hygiene Society ; one member shall be elected by the membership of the Spartanburg County Optometrists Society.
That immediately upon their election their names shall be certified to the State Board of Health.
On first meeting of the board one member shall be elected chairman who shall serve for two years.
Members of the county board of health shall serve without pay.
Termvacancy.The members of the county board of health, functioning as such are to serve a term of two years and until their successors have been elected and qualifled.

Provided, that if for any reason the members of the county board of health are not appointed, it shall be the duty of the State Board of Health to appoint such duly qualified residents of the county, to serve on the county board of health as may be necessary.

Duties and powers.The county board of health is vested with all rights, duties, privileges and responsibilities that are now imposed by law upon local boards of health in incorporated cities, towns and villages, and such other duties as are prescribed in this section.

Provided, however, that in carrying out all powers, duties, etc., herein prescribed, the county board of health shall control and direct the activities of the county health department through the director of the county health department.
Health departmentdirectoradditional employes.
The county health department shall function and be under the control and direction of the county board of health.

The county health department shall be under the direction and supervision of a director who shall be a graduate of a reputable medical college, a physician skilled in hygiene, sanitary science, who shall be especially trained and qualified in the practice of preventive medicine.
The director shall be elected by the county board of health upon nomination from a list of at least three qualified nominees of the State Board of Health.

Such additional personnel to carry on the various activities of the county health department shall be appointed according to the Merit System of the State Board of Health and employed as is consistent with the needs of the county.
Such additional personnel shall be appointed by the director of the county health department by and with the approval of the county board of health.
They shall hold office at the pleasure of the county board of health and may be discharged for cause or for failure to meet minimum standards at any time.
All personnel employed shall meet the qualifications prescribed by the State Board of Health.
The director of the county health department shall render reports to the county board of health and to the State Board of Health as may be required.

Further dutiesservices render.The duties of the county health department shall include the control of communicable diseases by all acceptable and approved methods, maternal and child hygiene, preschool and school hygiene, physicalexamination of school children, venereal disease control, sanitation (including sanitation of all foodhandling establishments, dairies, abattoirs, and school sanitation) and all other duties and activities that are usually carried on by organization of like authority and such other duties as may be prescribed by the county board of health and/or the State Board of Health.
Provided, however, that only such services shall be rendered as are consistent with the personnel employed.

The county board of health or the county health department shall have no authority or responsibility directed toward the actual cleaning of streets, collection of garbage, operation of public water supplies, or sewage disposal lines or plants.

The determining if water supplies are of safe sanitary quality and the method of disposal of garbage and sewage as far as being a sanitary method will be of concern and responsibility of the county board of health.

Municipalities may withdraw from jurisdiction of board.Provided further that the duly constituted authorities of any incorporated city, town or village which relinquishes their own rights, duties, powers and privileges as now provided by law and comes under the jurisdiction of the said County Board of Health may, after a period of six (6) months have the privilege of withdrawing from the jurisdiction of the County Board of Health and reverting to their former status as provided by law.

Area jurisdictionmunicipalities may come under jurisdiction.The county board of health is hereby empowered with jurisdiction over all that area lying in the county beyond the incorporated limits of cities, towns and villages.

Provided, further, that if the duly constituted authorities of any incorporated city, town and village desire to relinquish their own rights, duties, powers and privileges as provided by law, they shall have the right to do so, and upon the approval of the county board of health they shall forthwith become within and under the jurisdiction and authority of the county board of health.

Salariesequipmentaccounting for certain costs.Salaries of all personnel of the county health department shall be determined according to the Merit System compensation schedule of the State Board of Health and approved by the county board of health on recommendation of director of county health department.
All equipment and facilities of the county health department shall be under the direction and control of the director of the county health department.
Operating and custodial service costs will be properly accounted for as directed by the county board of health.

Appropriationdisbursements.The necessary appropriation shall be provided by members of the General Assembly to carry out the provisions of this section for the county board of health and county health department, and the money so appropriated shall remain in custody of the county authorities to be paid out on properly prepared vouchers as directed by the county board of health.

Director act as secretary of board.The director of the county health department shall be secretary of the county board of health, and he shall be the custodian of books, papers, instruments, or appliances belonging to the board, or that may be entrusted to his care; he shall summon the board to necessary meetings and shall attend all meetings of the board, unless otherwise ordered, and shall discharge the duties appertaining to the office of secretary.

License handle garbage or clean septic tankscolsection and disposal of garbagelicensed carrierspenalties violate regulations.(1) It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to move, collect, transport, or in any way handle garbage or clean septic tanks for hire in Spartanburg County, South Carolina, without first having obtained from the Spartanburg County Health Department a permit or license authorizing same; provided, however, that any person, firm or corporation may move or dispose of garbage that accumulates on his or its premises without obtaining such license.
(2) The Spartanburg County Health Department is hereby authorized and empowered to regulate the collection, removal and disposal of all garbage within the county.
All disposal plants, equipment, sites, etc., shall at all times be subject to the inspection, approval and regulation of the health department.

The health department is also authorized and empowered to charge a minimum license fee of one dollar per year to each truck, wagon or other conveyance moving, collecting or transporting garbage in the county.

The conveyance shall be subject to inspection and approval of the health department, and if at any time such conveyance is found to be inadequate, or undesirable for such use, the license of same may be revoked by the health department.
Provided, however, that the terms and provisions of this section shall not apply to incorporated cities and towns within the county.

(3) Any person violating any of the regulations of the State Board of Health and/or county board of health after he or she shall have been notified thereof in writing by either the county health officer, a sanitary inspector or a county health nurse, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction shall be imprisoned not less than three or more than ten days or pay a fine of not less than five dollars or more than twentyfive dollars.
50573 and 50574, 1942 Code, repealedSpartanburg County Board of Healthfree venereal clinic.Section 50573 and Section 50574, Code of Laws of 1942 are hereby repealed.

InvalidityShould any part or section of this act be invalidated by court decision on the ground of illegality or unconstitutionality such decision shall render invalid or inoperative only such portion or portions of this act as may be specifically so invalidated, the remainder to continue in full force and effect.
Time effective.This act shall take effect July 1, 1952. Approved the 27th day of March, 1952.

871 An Act To Create A Great Falls Police System, To Create A Great Falls Police Commission, Prescribe The Duties Of Said Commission And Said Policemen And To Further Provide For The Bond Of The Said Policemen.

Great Falls Police System.There is hereby created a police system for the unincorporated community of Great Falls, S C. which police system shall consist of a supervisory commission of four (4) members and one or more competent policemen to be appointed by the said commission, as hereinafter provided.
Commission.The Great Falls Police Commission shall consist of four (4) members, one of whom shall be the Sheriff of Chester County.

Three (3) members of the commission shall be appointed by the Governor of South Carolina upon the recommendation of a majority of the Chester County Legislative Delegation for terms of two (2), four (4) and six (6) years and shall serve until their successors are duly appointed and qualified.
At the expiration of the original term their respective successors shall be chosen for a term of six (6) years each.
OfficersWhen said commission shall have been appointed and commissioned, they shall organize by election of one of their number as chairman and also a secretary, who shall be one of the members.

The Sheriff of Chester County shall be an exofficio member of the Great Falls Police Commission and shall serve without additional compensation until such time as he shall cease for any reason to be Sheriff of Chester County.
Chief of policeThe Great Falls Police Commission shall, after its organization, elect a Chief of the Great Falls Police.
The chief, when so elected, shall be in direct charge of all Great Falls Policemen and shall be responsible for the discipline, conduct and discharge of duties of the Great Falls Police.
Said chief shall make all tules and regulations for the governing of the Great Falls Police, subject to the approval of the Great Falls Police Commission.
The chief and other policemen appointed shall cooperate at all times with the sheriff and other law enforcement officers of Chester County.

Duties: The general duties of the Great Falls Police shall be to maintain law and order in the community of Great Falls and its immediate vicinity and they are hereby given all authority for making arrests, searches and seizures, as is now possessed by constables, deputy sheriffs and municipal policemen.
Policemen nomination vacancy removal.The Chief of the Great Falls Police, when so elected, shall have the exclusive power of nominating all personnel and members of the Great Falls Police Force.
Said nomination or nominations shall be made by the Chief of the Great Falls Police to the Great Falls Police Commission in writing.

Whenever a vacancy or vacancies occur, the Great Falls Police Commission shall, at all times, elect all policemen and other personnel from the nomination or nominations made by the Chief of the Great Falls Police.
The Chief of the Great Falls Police shall have the exclusive power of removing from office any and all policemen or other personnel.
Said Chief of the Great Falls Police shall state his reasons for removing in writing to said person or persons removed.
Said notice to be dated.

Provided, however, that, in the event any policeman or other employee is removed from office by the Chief of the Great Falls Police, then said policeman or employee shall have the right, within ten (10) days after being discharged, to appeal its case to the Great Falls Police Commission for a hearing as to the merits and justice of his removal.

The appeal shall be made to the Great Falls Police Commission in writing within ten (10) days from the date of the removal and the said commission shall hear the appeal at a special called meeting within fifteen (15) days from the date of removal.
Said commission shall either approve or disapprove in writing the action of the Chief of the Great Falls Police.

The commission shall approve or disapprove the action of the Chief of the Great Falls Police by a majority vote of the whole commission and the action of a majority of said commission shall be construed to be the action of the commission.

If said commission disapproves the discharge of such officer or other personnel, then such discharge shall be of no effect and the officer shall resume his duties and receive his compensation in like manner as if he had not been discharged.

Chief report monthly.The Chief of the Great Falls Police must make a monthly written report to the Great Falls Police Commission of all their actions and doings, including all arrests, fines or bonds taken, and any other report requested by the commission, Section 8.

Bond of policemen.All Great Falls policemen shall be required to give bond in such an amount as may be required by the Great Falls Police Commission, not to be less than one thousand ($1,000.00) dollars, the premium to be paid by Chester County.

Salariesexpenses.The Great Falls Police Commission shall, in conjunction with the Chester County Legislative Delegation, fix the salaries, expenses, allowances and the number of policemen to be employed.
All expenses of operation of the Great Falls Police System shall be paid by the County of Chester.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 27th day of March, 1952.
872 An Act Creating The CameronLone Star Centralized High School District No.
2H, In Calhoun County; To Provide For Its Board Of Trustees, Prescribe Their Terms Of Office, Powers And Duties, And To Direct The Trustees Of The Component Districts To Perform Certain Duties.
CameronLone Star Centralised High School District No.
2H, Calhoun County.There is hereby created in Calhoun County a centralized high school district to be named CameronLone Star Centralized High School District No.
2H, composed of Cameron School District No.
2 and Lone Star School District No.
3 as now constituted.
The creation of the centralized district shall be for the purpose of providing and operating high school facilities jointly by the two component districts.
The centralized district shall be a body corporate, with all duties and powers generally attributed to such a district.
Trusteesproperty acquireobligations.The board of trustees of CameronLone Star Centralized High School District No.
2H shall be composed of five members determined as follows: three members to be selected by the board of trustees of Cameron School District No.
2 from among its own membership, and two to be selected by the board of trustees of Lone Star School District No.
3 from among its own membership.
Terms of office of the individual members of the centralized district board shall run concurrently with their terms on the local district boards.

The newly constituted centralized board shall take title to all high school property within the area of its jurisdiction and shall hereafter be liable for all indebtedness incurred for high school purposes.
Present indebtedness shall remain the obligation of the district by which originally incurred.

Elementary and high school budgets.The board of trustees in each of the component districts shall annually meet with the county superintendent of education, not later than May thirtyfirst of each year, and adopt a budget for the operation of elementary schools in the district for the ensuing school year.
They shall also determine the tax levy required to finance the budget and shall ce1tify to the county auditor the levy required.
The certification shal!
be authority to the county auditor to levy and the county treasurer to collect the tax.

The board of trustees of the CameronLone Star Centralized High School District shall likewise meet annually to adopt a budget, determine the necessary levy and certify same to the county auditor with respect to high school needs.
High school employees.The board of trustees of CameronLone Star Centralized High School District No.
2H shall have authority to employ any and all personnel that are in their judgment required for administration and operation of the high school program.
The superintendent employed by the centralized board shall be responsible for general supervision of the elementary schools in the component districts as well as of the high schools.

In order to achieve coordination of the entire school program in the area of the centralized district, the superintendent shall meet formally with the boards of the component districts at least twice annually, and with local school personnel as often as may be necessary for effective and efficient administration.
Buildings and facilitiesThe boards of trustees of Cameron School District No.

3 shall jointly plan the building program and school facility program for the elementary and centralized high schools within the districts and shall jointly make application for funds as is now provided by Act No.
379 of the Acts of 1951.
Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent with this act are hereby repealed.

Time effective This act shall become effective July 1, 1952, provided, that any action deemed necessary prior to this date to arrange for schools for the 195152 school year is hereby authorized. Approved the 7th day of April, 1952.

873 An Act To Amend Section 2 Of An Act Entitled An Act To Provide For And Regulate The Granting Of Divorces From The Bonds Of Matrimony In This State, Approved April 15, 1949, So As To Provide That Divorces On The Ground Of Habitual Drunkenness Shall Be Construed To Include Habitual Drunkenness Caused By The Use Of Any Narcotic Drug.
Act 137 of 1949 amendedhabitual drunkenness as a ground for divorce defined.Section 2 of an act entitled An Act To.
Provide For And Regulate The Granting Of Divorces From The Bonds Of Matrimony In This State, approved April 15,1949, and designated as Act No.

137 of the Acts of that year is amended by adding at the end of the section the following: Provided, that this ground shall be construed to include habitual drunkenness caused by the use of any narcotic drug., so that when amended Section 2 shall read as follows: section 2.
No divorce from the bonds of matrimony shall be granted except upon one or more of the following grounds, to wit: 1.

Habitual drunkenness ; provided, that this ground shall be construed to include habitual drunkenness caused by the use of any narcotic drug. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent with the provisions of this act are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 4th day of April, 1952
874 An Act To Amend Section 106, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Amended By Act No.
157, Acts And Joint Resolutions, 1949, Relating To The Salary Of The Judge Of The Civil Court Of Florence So As To Further Provide For Said Salary.
106, 1942 Code, amendedjudge, Civil Court of Florence commission term oath salary.Section 106, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as amended by Act No.

157, Acts and Joint Resolutions, 1949, relating to the salary of the Judge of the Civil Court of Florence, is further amended by striking out the section in its entirety and inserting in lieu thereof the folloiwng: section 106. There shall be a judge of said civil court who shall be an attorney, resident within the jurisdictional limits thereof, with at least five years actual experience in the practice of law, and who shall be commissioned by the Governor, upon the recommendation of the majority of the members of the bar residing within said jurisdictional limits, said commission to become effective upon confirmation by the Senate.

He shall receive as compensation the sum of seventyfive hundred dollars ($7,500.00) per annum, to be paid in monthly installments by the county treasurer upon the warrant of the board of county commissioners.

The said judge shall be debarred from practice of law in all matters within the jurisdiction of said civil court. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent with the provisions of this act are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 4th day of April, 1952.
875 An Act To Amend Section 4 Act No.
338 Of The Acts Of 1949, Relating To The Area Of The Greenwood Recreation District So As To Further Define Said Area And To Amend Act No.
1238 Of The Acts Of 1950 Relating To The Tax Levy Of The District.
Act 338 of 1949 amendedGreenwood Recreation District.Section 4, Act No.

338 of the Acts of 1949, relating to the area of Greenwood Recreation District, is amended by striking out all of same and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be designated as Section 4: section 4. There is hereby created a district, known as The Greenwood Recreation District, which shall consist of all of the area included within the incorporate limits of the City of Greenwood, together with all of the area outside of the incorporate limits of the City of Greenwood which was included in school district No.
18 on January 1, 1952. Section 1A. Act 1238 of 1950 amendedtax levy.Section 1 of Act No.

1238 of the Acts of 1950, is amended by striking out all of same and inserting in lieu thereof the following: section 1. There is hereby levied upon all of the taxable property within the area known as the Greenwood Recreation District a tax of two mills.
The auditor and other proper officials are hereby directed and empowered to levy and collect such a levy. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.

876 An Act Providing For A Board Of Trustees Of GreenwoodNinety Six School District No.

50; Providing For Their Initial Terms Of Office And Method Of Selecting Their Successors, And Terminating The Terms Of Office Of The Present Boards Of Trustees For All School Districts Now Existing In Greenwood County.
Trustees, GreenwoodNinety Six School District No.
50, Greenwood County appointment terms election vacancy.In the consolidated school district of Greenwood County known as GreenwoodNinety Six School District No.
50 there shall be nine (9) trustees who shall be appointed for aninitial term by the county board of education.
Said appointments shall be so made as to give adequate and proper representation to the rural and urban areas of said district.

The board shall appoint three (3) trustees for a term to expire on December 31, 1955, three (3) trustees for a term to expire on December 31, 1956, and the remaining three (3) trustees for a term to expire on December 31, 1957; and thereafter the term of office of said trustees shall be for a term of four (4) years.
Successors to the members of the board of trustees shall be appointed by the county board of education.
Provided, however, the county board of education shall call for an election of trustees upon a petition signed by not less than ten (10%) per cent of the qualified electors of said district.

The county board of education shall give notice of all elections, at least ten days in advance of such election, by publishing a notice of the election in a newspaper of general circulation in the county and by posting three such notices in conspicuous places within the district.

In the event of any vacancy created on the board by death, resignation, or otherwise, such vacancy for the unexpired term shall be filled in the same manner as provided for in this section for the initial appointment.

No member shall be appointed or elected to the board who is employed in the county schools as a teacher or otherwise, and acceptance of such employment shall automatically operate as a resignation as trustee.

Term of incumbents.The boards of trustees of the present school districts shall continue in office for the purpose of winding up the affairs of the respective existing school districts, but their terms of office shall expire on June 30, 1952.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 4th day of April, 1952.

877 An Act To Authorize The Issuance, Without Cost, Of Certified Copies Of Public Records Of Births, Deaths, Marriages And Divorces, When Same Are Required By The Federal Government In The Administration Of Certain Acts Of Congress, And To Repeal Any Conflicting Provisions Of section 5134 And 8561, 1942 Code Of Laws, As Amended.

Issue certified copy of birth, death, marriage and divorce record free for certain purposes.Officers in charge of public records relating to births, deaths, marriages and divorces shall furnish, without cost, certified copies of such records upon request therefor accompanied by reliable information that same are required by the Federal Government in connection with the administration of (a) the Selective Service Act of 1948, as amended; (b) the Dependents Assistance Act of 1950 (PL No.
771, 81st Congress, approved September 8, 1950), and all Acts of Congress administered by the Veterans Administration.
Repeal.Any provisions of section 5134 and 8561, 1942 Code of Laws of South Carolina, or any act or acts amendatory thereof, in conflict with the purpose and intent of this act are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect ipod its approval by the Governor. Approved the 15th day of April, 1952.
878 An Act To Amend Section 89991, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Amended By Act No.
801, Acts Of 1948, Page 1969, Relating To Claims Filed Against Decedents Estates, So As To Prescribe The Time Within Which Action May Be Brought After Notice Of Disallowance Or Denial Of Such Claims.
89991, 1942 Code, amendedtime institute action on claim against decedent's estate after disallowance.That Section 89991, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as amended by Act No.
801, Acts of 1948, page 1969, be, and the same is hereby amended by striking out all of the said Section 89991 and inserting in lieu thereof the following : section 89991.

Where any claim against the estate of a decedent has been or shall be: (a) filed in the Probate Court in which such estate is being administered; or (b) filed with the executor or administrator of such estate; and such claimant, or his attorney who has filed such claim, shall have received notice in writing, either: (a) from the said Probate Court that such claim has been disallowed; or (b) from the executor or administrator of such estate, or the attorney for such executor or administrator, that such claim is denied and will be contested; such claim shall be forever barred unless within six months after receipt of such notice action shall be brought to enforce such claim. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent with this act are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 15th day of April, 1952.
879 An Act To Exempt From Certain Taxes All Personal Motor Vehicles Of Disabled Veterans For Which A Special License Tag Has Been Issued And To Repeal Act No.
225, Acts And Joint Resolutions, 1947, Exempting From Taxes, Certain Vehicles Acquired Under The Provisions Of Public Law No.

Certain motor vehicles of disabled veterans exempt from taxes.All personal motor vehicles owned by any disabled veteran for which a special license tag has been issued by the state highway department under the provisions of Act No.
985, Acts and Joint Resolutions, 1950, as amended by Act No.
160, Acts and Joint Resolutions, 1951, shall be exempt from state, county and municipal taxes.
Repeal.Act No.
225, Acts and Joint Resolutions, 1947, exempting from taxes certain vehicles acquired under the provisions of Public Law.
663, 97th Congress, and all other acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 15th day of April, 1952.
880 An Act To Amend Act No.

970 Of The Acts Of 1950 Relating To The Annexation Of A Portion Of Beaufort County To Jasper County So As To Further Provide For The Annexation Of The Area Transferred To Hardeeville Township, To Provide For The Dates Of Transfer Of Certain Records And The Dates Of The Accounting Of Indebtedness, And To Provide For The Collection Of Tax Executions Upon Property Within The Area Transferred.
Act 970 of 1950 amendedYemassee Township of Beaufort County annexed to Jasper County.Section 1 of Act No.
970 of the Acts of 1950, is amended by striking out all of same and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be Section 1: section 1.

That portion of Beaufort County lying west of New River and run of Great Swamp, known as and constituting Yemassee Township, be and the same is hereby transferred, annexed to and incorporated within Jasper County, and shall become a part of Hardeeville Township of Jasper County and shall be included in School  District No.
SameBeaufort County auditor furnish tax information.Section 2 of Act No.
970 of the Acts of 1950, is amended by striking out all of same and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be Section 2: section 2.

The County Auditor for Beaufort County shall furnish the County Auditor for Jasper County all necessary information and records as to assessment of taxes in Yemassee Township for the Year 1951, and upon satisfactory performance of said duties and all his other necessary duties to carry this Act into effect, the Auditor for Beaufort County shall be paid the sum of Tifty Dollars ($50.00) by the Treasurer of Jasper County. Section 38.

Samecommission ascertain indebtedness of areapayment.Section 10 of Act 970 of the Acts of 1950, is amended by striking out all of same and inserting in lieu thereof the following to he Section 10: + section 10.

The County Auditors of Beaufort, Jasper, and Ifampton Counties are hereby constituted a commission and empowered and directed to investigate and ascertain all indebtedness of Beaufort County and apportion the same between Yemassee Township and the remainder of Beaufort County according to taxation valuations in Yemassee Township as compared with those of the remainder of Beaufort County for the year 1951, Provided, that the indebtedness shall not include any expenditure, tax, or bonded or general indebtedness, levied or made after the year 1951, and that there shall be levied upon the taxable property in Yemassee Township a sufficient tax to pay the indebtedness so assessed upon it as it becomes due; and further to investigate and ascertain the bonded indebtedness of Bluffton Township and Yemassee Township in Beaufort County for freezer plant and apportion the same between the townships according to taxation valuations in the two townships for the year 1951 and that there shall be levied upon the taxable property in Yemassee Township a sufficient tax to pay the indebtedness so assessed upon it as it becomes due; and further to investigate and ascertain any and all bonded and general indebtedness of Yemassee Township as a unit, and report the same to the proper officers of Jasper County, which indebtedness shall follow Yemassee Township into Jasper County.
A decision by a majority of the commissioners shall control, and each of them shall be paid by Jasper County the sum of Fifty Dollars ($50.00) upon performance of their duties.

The commission shall have the power to employ an attorney and an expert accountant, if they deem it necessary, to aid them in all matters pertaining to the performance of their duties and compensation for such service shall be paid as provided for in the next section hereof. Section 4.
Samecollection of delinquent taxes therein Act No.
970 of the Acts of 1950, is amended by adding a new section to be Section 11A as follows: section 11A.

After the County Treasurer of Beaufort County has issued tax executions for 1951 for unpaid taxes on property in Yemassee Township, he shall deliver same to the Sheriff of Beaufort County who shall transmit them together with any other tax executions for prior years on the property in that township to the Sheriff of Jasper County who shall collect same within one year and transmit the proceeds to the Treasurer of Beaufort County.
The Sheriff of Jasper County shall be entitled to the sherriffs fee for collecting same. Section 5. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 15th day of April, 1952.

881 An Act To Provide A System For Developing, Operating, Maintaining And Financing The Public Schools In Berkeley County, And Providing For The Expiration Of The Terms Of The Present School Trustees.

Berkeley County School District divided into attendance areas.The County Board of Education of Berkeley County shall divide the Berkeley County School District into four attendance areas which shall be known as the Moncks Corner Attendance Area, the St. Stephen Attendance Area, Macedonia Attendance Area and Cross Attendance Area.
Trustees for areasappointment terms.Each attendance area shall have five trustees to be appointed by the county board of education.
The trustees shall have the powers and duties of trustees generally.

The terms of office of the trustees shall be three years, except that of the members first appointed, two shall be appointed for a term of one year, two for a term of two years and one for a term of three years.
The terms of trustees appointed under this act shall commence April 1, 1952.
The terms of the present school trustees of Berkeley County shall expire March 31, 1952.

School budgetstax levies.The trustees of each attendance area in Berkeley County, the county board of education and the county legislative delegation shall furnish to the auditor and the treasurer of Berkeley County, before the second day of September in each year, a Berkeley County school budget.

The trustees shall make their budget estimate for their respective attendance areas and shall make a report of this estimate to the county board of education before the second day of April of each year.

The county board of education and the county legislative delegation shall review and may revise the reports and prepare a complete budget for all schools of the county in quadruplicate form and deliver one copy to the legislative delegation, one copy to the auditor, one copy to the county treasurer and one copy to the superintendent of education.

Before the first day of July of each year the county legislative delegation shall furnish to the auditor and the treasurer of the county a statement showing the general countywide school levy necessary in order to meet the anticipated appropriations of the school budget, after first taking into consideration other available sources of revenue.
Repeal.Subsection (1) of Section 5538, Code of Laws of 1942, and all acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 15th day of April, 1952.

882 An Act To Amend Section 7403, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Last Amended, Relating To Qualifications, Elections, And Terms Of Office Of Officers In Towns With A Population Not Over One Thousand Inhabitants By Increasing The Term Of Such Officers In The Town Of West Union In Oconee County To Two Years.

7403, 1942 Code, amendedterm of intendant and wardens, West Union.Section 7403, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as last amended, relating to the qualifications, elections, and terms of office of officers in towns with a population not over one thousand inhabitants, is further amended by adding at the end thereof the following : Provided, that at the general election to be held in the year 1952 and at each election to be held thereafter for intendants and wardens the intendants and wardens of the Town of West Union in Oconee County shall be elected for a term of two years and until their successors have qualified. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.

883 An Act To Amend Section 2737, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To Township Boards Of Assessors, So As To Provide For A Board Of Tax Assessors For Horry County, To Make Certain Records A Part Of The Auditors Records, And To Repeal Section 1 Of Act No.
789, Acts Of 1950, Providing For A Board Of Tax Assessors For Horry County.

2737, 1942 Code, amendedHorry Oounty Board of Tax Assessorsassistant tax assessors.Section 2737, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as last amended by Acts Nos. 123 and 137, Acts of 1950, is amended by adding to the end thereof the following proviso: Provided, that in Horry County the duties relative to the valuation, assessment, and return of properties for taxation are hereby devolved upon a board to be known as the County Board of Tax Assessors.
The board shall be composed of twelve members as follows: One member from each township in the county and one additional member from the county at large.
The board shall be appointed by the county auditor and shall serve for a term of four years.
The board shall appoint an executive secretary whose term of office shall be four years beginning March 23, 1952.
He shall also be the deputy auditor and shall have other powers and duties as prescribed by the board.
The records of the county board of assessors and of its secretary shall constitute a part of the auditors records.
The board shall appoint assistant tax assessors in the number and for the length of service as is provided in the Annual Supply Act of Horry County.
The salaries and expenses of the board of tax assessors, the executive secretary, and the assistant tax assessors shall be such as are provided in the Annyal Supply Act for Horry County. Section 2.
of Act No.
Acts of 1950. and all other acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 15th day of April, 1952.

884 An Act To Establish A Marketing Commission For Horry County, To Define Its Powers And Duties, And To Provide Penalties For The Violation Of Rules And Regulations Promulgated By The Commission And Of This Act.
Horry County Marketing Commission There may be established under the provisions of this act an Horry County Marketing Commission, hereafter referred to as the commission.

Appointment terms vacancy.The commission shall be appointed by the Senator and the members of the House of Representatives from Horry County, and shall consist of five members, citizens of Horry County, whose terms of office shall be as follows: One for one year, one for two years, one for three years, one for four years, and one for five years.
Vacancies on the commission shall be filled by the Senator and the members of the House of Representatives from Horry County for the unexpired terms.
Officersrecords.The commission shall hold its first meeting within ten days after their appointment, and shall proceed to organize by electing a chairman, a vicechairman, and a secretary.
It shall adopt its own rules of procedure and keep adequate records of its proceedings.
Meetingsquorum.The commission shall meet at least once each quarter and at other times which may be necessary.
It may be called into special session upon three days written notice prior to date of meeting.
This requirement of written notice may be waived by all members of the commission in writing.
Three members of the commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business at any meeting.

Duties and powers.The commission may acquire by purchase or otherwise suitable sites within the county to be used as wholesale farmers markets and erect thereon necessary buildings and operate and maintain them for the handling, classifying, grading, and sale of fruits, vegetables, poultry, eggs, dairy products, livestock, and other farm products.

The commission may employ and fix the salaries of marketing specialists, market managers and other technical or clerical help which they consider necessary to carry out this act, rent sites upon the market property, make charges for the use of the market and its facilities sufficient to defray all costs of operation, maintenance and expansion of the market, give instruction to the farmers of the county, and to the public, in grading, standardizing, packing, and marketing farm produce, cooperate with all other agricultural agencies in promotion of production and marketing of farm produce, enter into contracts with any Federal or state agency for the procurement of funds to be used in the construction or maintenance of market facilities or for the purpose of obtaining any services from these agencies in connection with the operation of the market, make contributions to the State Agricultural Marketing Commission to be used in matching Federal or other funds which, when matched, shall be used in consection with the market, make and promulgate rules and regulations necessary for the maintenance and operation of the market and to carry out this act.

Upon adoption of rules and regulations a copy thereof with any subsequent amendments thereto shall be filed with the County Board of Commissioners of Horry County, and copies shall be posted at one or more conspicuous places on the market.

Appropriation disbursement employees furnish bonds.Upon establishment of the commission there shall be appropriated from the general funds of Horry County the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) to be credited to the account of the commission upon approval of this act.

This fund and all other funds realized from or in connection with the operation of the market shall be paid out only on vouchers signed by the chairman of the commission and countersigned by the secretary thereof, but only that portion of this appropriation shall be used as is matched by a Federal grant or other grant or contribution.

The market manager and each employee of the commission who shall be charged with the duty of collecting and handling funds shall be required to enter into a surety bond in the amount which the commission directs.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 15th day of April, 1952.

Issue receipts for moneys.Any person receiving any of the fees provided for by this act, or receiving other county monies, shall execute receipts in triplicate; one copy to be issued to the person paying the fee or other money, one copy to be retained by the person receiving the money, and one copy to be placed in the hands of the county board of commissioners.

886 An Act To Amend Section 7437 Of The Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, As Amended, Relating To Tax Levies, Penalties And Executions In Towns And Cities Having A Population Over One Thousand Inhabitants, So As To Authorize The Town Of Bishopville,South Carolina,.To Levy For Ordinary Town Purposes An Annual Tax Not Exceeding Four And TwoTenths Per Cent (4.2%) Of The Assessed Value Of All Taxable Property Within The Town; To Validate All Ordinances Heretofore Passed By The Town Council Of Bishopvile Which Levy Taxes Not Exceeding This Amount And To Repeal Act No.
230 Of Acts And Joint Resolutions, 1947, And Act No.
7 Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions, 1951, Relating To Tax Levies In The Town Of Bishopville.

7437, 1942 Code, amendedtax levy, Bishopvilleadditional penalty.Section 7437, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as last amended, is further amended by adding at the end thereof the following proviso: Provided, further, that the town council of the town of Bishopville may levy, as provided herein, an annual tax for ordinary town purposes not exceeding four and twotenths per cent (4.2%) of the assessed value of all taxable property within the corporate limits of said town and it may, in addition to the penalty provided herein for the nonpayment of taxes when due, provide an additional penalty of not exceeding seven per cent (7%) per year on all taxes remaining unpaid, and all ordinances heretofore passed by the said town council of the town of Bishopville, not in excess of the above provision, are hereby validated and ratified. Section 2.

Ordinances validated.aAll ordinances heretofore passed by the town council of Bishopville which levy taxes for ordinary town purposes not exceeding four and twotenths per cent (4.2%) of the assessed value of all taxable property within the corporate limits, are hereby validated and confirmed.
230, Acts and Joint Resolutions, 1947, and Act No.

7 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions, 1951, and all other acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed, but all rights and liabilities under these acts shall continue, and may be enforced in the same manner as if this repeal had not been made.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 15th day of April, 1952.

887 An Act To Provide That The Magistrate Of The First Magisterial District And The Magistrate Of The Seventh Magisterial District Of Chester County Shall Have Countywide Jurisdiction In Civil Matters.

Civil jurisdiction of magistrates of First and Seventh Magisterial Districts, Chester County.The magistrate in the first magisterial district of Chester County, composed of Chester and Blackstock Townships, and the magistrate of the seventh magisterial district of Chester County, composed of Rossville Township and Great Falls, shall have jurisdiction over the entire area of Chester County in all civil matters now triable in magistrates courts.
Nothing contained in this act shall be construed to deprive a magistrate in any other district of Chester County of jurisdictions in civil actions brought in his district.

888 An Act To Amend Section 1327, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To Certain Licenses 8o As To Provide That In Union County The Clerk Of Court May Issue Such Licenses, Upon Payment Of The Sum Of Fifty Dollars, For Periods Of Six Months Or Less; And To Validate Any Licenses Heretofore Issued In The Manner Authorized By This Act.
1327, 1942 Code, amendedissue license for horse trading or fortune telling in Union County for six months or less.

, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, is amended by changing the period on line 12 thereof to a semicolon and adding after the semicolon the following: provided, further, that in Union County the clerk of court may issue such licenses, upon payment of the sum of fifty dollars, for a period of six months or less without such authorization. The section, when so amended, shall read as follows: section 1327.

It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to follow the business of horse trading or fortune telling in any of the counties of this State, by traveling from place to place without first obtaining from the clerk of the court of the county in which they wish to follow their trade, a license permitting them to so do.
Such license shall be issued by the clerks of the court of the counties of this State to any person applying for same upon payment by said applicant of the sum of $100.00.

Said license shall specify the name of the applicant, his or her former residence, and shall be for a period of one year from the issuance thereof: provided, this section shall not be effective in any county until the county board oi commissioners of such county authorize, by resolution, the collection of such tax; provided, further, that in Union County the clerk of court may issue such licenses, upon payment of the sum of fifty dollars, for a period of six months or less without such authorization.

Any person violating the provisions of this section, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not more than $100.00, or imprisonment for not more than thirty days for each and every offense, provided that the provisions of this section shall not apply to livery or sales stable owners, who have a permanent residence within the State. Section 2.

Licenses validated.Any such licenses issued by the Clerk of Court of Union County prior to the effective date of this act, which licenses were issued in accordance with the authorization contained in Section 1 of this act, are hereby validated and confirmed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 15th day of April, 1952.
889 An Act To Amend Act No.
111 Of The Acts Of 1947 Relating To The Workmens Compensation Fund So As To Exempt The Members Of The Boards In Greenville County From The Provisions Thereof.
Act 111 of 1947 amendedWorkmens Compensation Law not applicable to members of boards of Greenville CountyAmend Section 1 of Act No.

111 of the Acts of 1947 by adding at the end thereof the following: Provided, that the memhers of the Greenville County Board of Commissioners and the members of all the other boards and commissions of the said county, including the members of the board of assessors, shall not be deemed employees of Greenville County within the meaning of the Workmens Compensation Law and are hereby exempted from the provisions of the Workmens Compensation Law, and the said County of Greenville shall not be liable for injuries sustained by said board members in the course of their employment. Section 2. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 15th day of April, 1952.
890 An Act To Amend An Act Entitled An Act To The Greenville County Marketing Commission, Etc., Approved April 24, 1948, And Designated As Act No.

829 Of The Acts Of 1948, So As To Authorize The Commission To Construct A Grain Elevator And/Or A Gram Processing Plant On Lands Now Used By The Greenville County Farmers Wholesale Market, Or To Acquire Property Elsewhere Suitable For The Purpose, And To Issue Revenue Bonds To Defray The Cost Thereof.

Act 829 of 1948 amendedGreenville County Marketing Commission issue bonds for grain elevator and grain processing plant.An act entitled An Act To Create The Greenville County Marketing Commission, etc., approved April 24, 1948, and designated as Act No.
829 of the Acts of 1948, is amended by adding immediately after Section 8 of the act the following sections, to be numbered as hereinafter indicated : section 8.

The commission is also authorized to construct a grain elevator and/or a grain processing plant on the lands now used hy the Greenville County Farmers Wholesale Market or.to acquire property elsewhere suitable for such purpose, and to isste revenue bonds to defray the cost thereof, not exceeding, however, in the aggregate five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00).

The commission is empowered to construct and equip, and to remodel, reconstruct and reequip buildings and other facilities to form the whole or a part of a grain elevator and a grain processing plant, and for such purposes may expend any funds in its hands, or to which it may be entitled, and not otherwise appropriated or pledged, and the proceeds of any revenue bonds, whose issuance is authorized in this act.
The bonds shall be payable solely from the revenues derived from the facilities herein authorized to be constructed, for which the proceeds thereof shall be expended.

Neither the faith nor the credit of the County of Greenville, nor of the commission, shall be pledged for the payment of the principal and interest of such bonds, and there shall be on the face of each bond a statement, plainly worded, to that effect.
Nor shall the members of the commission or any other person signing the bonds be personally liable thereon.
In order to avail itself of the authorizations of this section, the commission shall adopt a resolution providing for the issuance of the bonds, and prescribing their tenor, terms and conditions.

Such bonds shall be serial bonds, maturing in equal or unequal amounts, at such times and on such occasions as the commission shall determine, provided, always that the last maturing bonds of any issue shall become due not later than thirty years from their date, and the first maturing of any bonds issued pursuant to this act shall fall due within five years from the date such bonds bear.

They shall bear such rate or rates of interest, not exceeding six per cent per annum, payable annually or semiannually, shall be in such denominations, shall carry such registration privileges, shall be payable in such medium of payment, and at such place or places, and shall be subject to such terms of redemption, with or without premium, as such resolutions may prescribe.

All bonds issued pursuant to this act shall be executed in the name of the commission by its chairman, and shall be countersigned by the County Treasurer of Greenville County, and the seal of the commission shall be affixed or impressed thereon.
The coupons attached to such bonds shall be authenticated by the facsimile signatures of said chairman and the county treasurer, who is in office on the date of such bonds.

Such bonds shall be sold at public sale after notice published at least fifteen days prior to such sale in a newspaper having a general circulation in the State of South Carolina, and in a financial publication published in the City of New York, N. Y.; provided, that if no bid is received upon such notice which is acceptable to the commission, such bonds may be then sold at private sale at any time within thirty days after date for receiving bids as given in such notice; provided, however, that such bonds may, in the discretion of the commission, be sold to the Federal Government, or any agency thereof, or to the State Government, or any agency thereof, at private sale, without any public advertisement.
In all instances, the bonds shall be sold in such way as the commission shall determine to be most advantageous.

The purchase of any revenue bonds issued pursuant to this act by the State Sinking Fund Commission is specifically authorized under such terms and conditions as the State Sinking Fund Commission shall prescribe.

To issue bonds in such amount as shall not exceed the estimate of the cost of the project intended to be constructed from the proceeds of such bonds, plus such further sum as may be needed to pay the interest on such bonds until adequate revenues are derived from such project, which period shall not exceed three years from the date of such bonds.

To covenant that fees or rents will be charged for the use of all facilities afforded by the project, and that the schedule of fees and charges to be put into effect will be designed to produce sufficient revenues to: (a) Pay the cost of operating and maintaining the particular project ; (b) Pay the interest and principal of bonds issued to finance the project, as the same respectively become due; (c) Create adequate reserves to meet the payment of such principal and interest; (d) Provide for contingencies ; and, (e) Provide an adequate reserve for depreciation and obsolescence.
To covenant against the mortgaging or disposal of all or any part of any project, and against permitting or suffering any lien to becreated thereon.
To covenant against the use of any revenues derived from the project for any purpose save those enumerated in this act.
To covenant as to what, if any, additional bonds may be issued, payable from the revenues of such project.

To covenant that all revenues from any project and the proceeds of all revenue bonds be deposited with the county treasurer, who shall be empowered to disburse and segregate the same in accordance with the terms of the resolution providing for the issuance of any bonds.

Such statutory lien shall extend to such project, its appurtenances and extensions, additions, improvements and enlargements, and shall inure to the benefit of the holders of any bonds or coupons secured thereby.

Any holder of any of the bonds or any of the coupons representing interest thereon may, either at law or in equity, by suit, action, mandamus, or other proceedings, protect and enforce such statutory lien, and may, by suit, action, mandamus, or other proceedings, enforce and compel performance of all duties of the officials of the commission, including the fixing of sufficient rates, the collection of revenues, the proper segregation of the revenues of the project, and the proper application thereof.
Provided, however, that such statutory lien shall not be construed to give any such bond or coupon holder authority to compel the sale of such project, or any part thereof.

If there be any default in the payment of the principal of or interest upon any of the bonds, any court having jurisdiction in any proper action may appoint a receiver to administer and operate the project on behalf of the commission with power to fix and charge rates and collect revenues sufficient to provide for the payment of any bonds or other obligations outstanding against such project and for the payment of the expenses of operating and maintaining the same and to apply the income and revenues of the project in conformity with this section and the resolution providing for the issuance of such bonds.

Should, at any time, the commission consider it necessary or desirable to refinance any bonds issued pursuant to the provisions of this act, then it may avail itself of the authorizations of Chapter 189, Volume 4, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, to enable it to refinance, or to refinance and improve, as contemplated by said Chapter. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.

891 An Act To Authorize And Direct The State Treasurer To Remit Certain Funds Received By Him From The United States Government In Connection With The Clarks Hill Project To The County In Which The Transaction Arose.

State Treasurer remit to counties funds received from sale or lease of property belonging to United States in Clark Hill Project area.The Treasurer of South Carolina is hereby authorized and directed to remit all funds received by him from the United States Government, or any agency thereof, when such funds are derived from the sale or lease of any property belonging to the United States Government and located in the Clarks Hill Project Area, to the treasurer of the county in which the transaction arose.
Any funds received by the county treasurer shall be placed in the general county fund.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 23rd day of April, 1952

892 An Act To Amend Chapter 162, Volume 4, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To Motor Bus And Truck Lines, So As To Provide A Two Year Statute Of Limitation For The Recovery Of Undercharges By Motor Carriers And The Recovery Of Overcharges Against Motor Carriers, And To Provide For Extensions Of The Statute In Certain Cases Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina Section 1.

85161, 1942 Code, addedlimitation of action for undercharge or overcharge by motor carrier.Chapter 162, Volume 4, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as amended, is further amended by adding a new section to be known as Section 85161, to read as follows section 85161 (1) All actions at law by motor carriers subject to this chapter for the recovery of their charges or any part thereof.

shall be commenced within two years from the time the cause of action accrues and not thereafter (2) Actions at law for the recovery of overcharges against motor carriers subject to this chapter shall be commenced within two years from the time the cause of action accrues and not thereafter, subject to the provisions of subdivision (4) of this section.

Provided that if a claim for the overcharge has been presented in writing to the carrier within the two year period of limitation, the period shall be extended to include six months from the time notice in writing was given by the carrier to the claimant of disallowance of the claim, or any part or parts thereof (3) The cause of action by a motor carrier for its charges shall for the purpose of this section be deemed to accrue upon delivery or tender of delivery by the carrier (4) Cause of action against a motor carrier for overcharges shall for the purpose of this section be deemed to accrue at the time the charges are paid to the motor carrier.

(5) The term overcharges as used in this section shall be deemed to mean charges for transportation services in excess of those applicable thereto under the tariffs lawfully on file with the Public Service Commission. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 23rd day of April, 1952.

893 An Act To Amend Section 935, Code Of Laws, 1942, Relating To Preliminary Investigations By Magistrates, So As To Provide That Magistrates Shall Hold Preliminary Investigations In Certain Cases When The Warrant Is Issued By A Coroner.

935, 1942 Code, amendedpreliminary hearing on warrant issued by coroner charging crime beyond jurisdiction of magistrateAmend Section 935, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, by adding at the end thereof the following: In instances in which a warrant charging a crime beyond the jurisdiction of a magistrate is issued by a coroner, a preliminary investigation as provided for herein shall be granted, upon demand of the defendant, by the magistrate having territorial jurisdiction. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 23rd day of April, 1952.

804 An Act Relating To The Commitment By The Courts Of General Sessions Of This State Or Any Inferior Courts, Having Concurrent Jurisdiction With The Courts Of General Sessions Of White Females Under The Age Of Twenty Years To The State Industrial School For Girls; Of Negro Females Under The Age Of Twenty Years To South Carolina Industrial School For Negro Girls; Of White Males Under The Age Of Seventeen Years To The South Carolina Industrial School; And Negro Males Under The Age Of Seventeen Years To John G. Richards Industrial Training School For Negro Boys.

Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1. Commitment of white females to The State Industrial School for Girls by Courts of General Sessions.Any white female under the age of twenty years entering a plea of guilty or being convicted in the Courts of General Sessions of this state, or in any inferior court of this state, having concurrent jurisdiction with the Courts of General Sessions, may in the discretion of the trial judge, be committed by that court to The State Industrial School for Girls, subject to all laws or rules and regulations applicable to The State Industrial School for Girls, instead of to the chain gang or state penitentiary.

Commitment of negro females to The South Carolina Industrial School for Negro Girls by such courts.Any negro female under the age of twenty years entering a plea of guilty or being convicted in the Courts of General Sessions of this state, or in any inferior court of this state, having concurrent jurisdiction with the Courts of General Sessions, may in the discretion of the trial judge, be committed by that court to The South Carolina Industrial School for Negro Girls, subject to all laws or rules and regulations applicable to The South Carolina Industrial School for Negro Girls, instead of to the chain gang or state penitentiary.

Commitment of white males to South Carolina Industrial School by such courts.Any white male under the age of seventeen years entering a plea of guilty or being convicted in the Courts of General Sessions of this state, or in any inferior court of this state, having concurrent jurisdiction with the Courts of General Sessions, may in the discretion of the trial judge, be committed by that court to South Carolina Industrial School, subject to all laws or rules and regulations applicable to South Carolina Industrial School, instead of to the chain gang or state penitentiary.

Commitment of negro males to the John G. Richards Industrial Training School for Negro Boys by such courts.Any negro male under the age of seventeen years entering a plea of guilty or being convicted in the Courts of General Sessions of this state, or in any inferior court of this state, having concurrent jurisdiction with the Courts of General Sessions, may in the discretion of the trial judge, be committed by that court to The John G. Richards Industrial Training School for Negro Boys, subject to all laws or rules and regulations applicable to The John G. Richards Industrial Training School for Negro Boys, instead of to the chain gang or state penitentiary.

Application This act shall be amendatory to any of the acts or statutory laws of this state pertaining to the institutions herein named and shall apply solely to those cases where the subjects are committed to the institutions by the Judge of the Courts of General Sessions, or any inferior court having concurrent jurisdiction with the Courts of General Sessions in such matter.
This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 23rd day of April, 1952.

895 An Act To Amend Section 7729, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1942, Relating To The Organization Of Business Corporations, So As To Increase The Maximum Number Of Directors A Corporation May Have From Fifteen To Seventeen.

7729, 1942 Code, amendedmaximum directors for a corporation.Section 7729, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, relating to the organization of business corporations, is hereby amended by striking out on line 8 the word fifteen and inserting in lieu thereof the word seventeen, so that when amended Section 7729 shall read as follows: section 7729.
Where not less than fifty per cent of the proposed capital stock shall have been subscribed by bona fide subscribers, the board of corporators shall call the subscribers together.

At such meeting of the subscribers, a majority of whom in value being present in person or by proxy, the subscribers shall proceed to the organization of the company by the election from themselves of a board of directors, trustees or managers of such number as they may deem proper, not to exceed seventeen in number, which board shall manage the affairs of the corporation until their successors shall have been elected, and shall have qualified according to the constitution and bylaws of the corporation.
The board of directors, trustees or managers shall call for the payment of the subscription to the capital either in whole or in such installments as it shall see fit.

The board of directors, trustees or managers shall elect from their number a president, and they may also elect such person, or persons, as they may see fit as secretary and as treasurer, the latter of whom shall give such bond as they may require: provided, that in case of continuing building and loan associations and other corporations of a like nature issuing stock in monthly series, the declaration may name an amount as the initial capital stock, and a larger amount as the ultimate capital stock, to which the issue of the monthly series may extend, according to the bylaws of said corporation; and when not less than fifty per cent of the initial capital stock shall have been subscribed by bona fide subscribers, the meeting of the stockholders and other proceedings provided for in sections 7726 to 7756, inclusive, may be had: provided, further, that the stockholders of such corporation shall have the power at their first meeting to adopt a bylaw providing for the issuing of preferred stock, having such special privileges and to be issued in such amounts and in such manner as they shall establish by their said bylaws. Section 2.
Repealed..\ll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 23rd day of April, 1952.

896 An Act To Provide For The Branding Or Marking Of Livestock; To Provide For Registration Of The Brand Or Mark With The Secretary Of State And Certification By Him; To Provide For The Recording Of The Certificate By Clerks Of Court; To Make Certain Acts Unlawful; And To Provide Penalties For Violations.

Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1. Definitions The following words and phrases, as used in this act, shall have the following meanings, unless the context otherwise requires: (1) Livestock includes neat cattle, horses, mules, asses, hogs, sheep and goats.
(2) Owner and stock owner mean any person who owns livestock.
Brand livestockone brand per person.It is lawful to brand livestock with the owners brand in accordance with the provisions of this act.
No person shall have or use more than one brand.
Individual brand for wife, minor or guardian.A wife who owns livestock separate from her husband or a minor who owns livestock separate from his father or guardian may have a brand.
The father or guardian of any minor who has a brand shall be responsible for the proper use thereof.

Application for adoption of brandcertificate.After the effective date of this act, any person desiring to adopt any brand for branding livestock, which brand is not then the recorded brand of another, shall forward to the Secretary of State a facsimile of the desired brand together with a written application to adopt the brand.
The application shall state where the brand will appear on the livestock.
A fee of three dollars shall be enclosed with the application.
