Not fish for trout during such closed season.It shall be unlawful for any person to fish for trout in, or to take trout from, any clear water stream in said zone during said closed season therefor; provided, however, that in the event any person fishing for fish other than trout during such closed season for the fishing of trout, shall catch any trout, such shall not be unlawful if such person shall immediately return such trout so caught to the stream from which same was caught.

Possession of trout during such closed season.It shall be unlawful for any person, during the closed season set out in Section 71 above, to have in his or her possession in said zone any trout caught in or taken from any fresh water stream in said zone.

Upon any person being found in possession of fresh water trout in said zone during such closed season, a presumption, subject to being rebutted, shall arise, that such trout was caught in the clear water streams in said zone during said closed season, by the person in possession of same.

When may fish for trout.Subject to the provisions of section 68 through 77, it shall be lawful for any person to fish for and catch trout in said zone at any time except during the closed season therefor.

Fishing regulations.It shall be unlawful for any person at any time to use within said zone or in any of the waters thereof any net of any description commonly called a seine for the purpose of gathering, hemming, or driving fish in any of said waters.

But the provisions of section 68 through 77 shall not Prevent the use of a circular net commonly called a landing net to be used in landing a fish, provided it is not over fourteen inches in diamtter and eighteen inches deep.

The said fish shall be caught only with tod and reel, or rod and line, or pole and line, with single bait or lure in the hands of the operator, or by throwing when not more than one lure and line is used by the person throwing ; provided, that when the pole and line is used, the fisherman may use not exceeding three poles provided the same be used in his view, and he is not required to have the same in his hands all of the time; provided, further, that it shall not be unlawful for a person fishing with pole and line to have in his possession and use at intervals a rod and reel or rod and line; provided, however, baskets and seines not exceeding fifteen feet in length and with meshes not less than one inch square, and trotlines may be used in catching nongame fish in streams and waters south of the main line of the Southern Railway, which said railway line crosses Greenville, Pickens and Oconee Counties; provided, further, seining is hereby permitted in the waters of Keowee River, south of Old Pickens Bridge and seining is hereby permitted in the waters of Twelve Mile River.

Provided, further, that seining in Oconee County be permitted in all streams south of the main line of the Southern Railroad except in Coneross Creek above Lousdale Power Dam, or better known as the High Bridge Road.

Provided, that in Oconee and Pickens Counties trotlines, throw lines and set hooks may be used in the waters of Tugaloo River below the confluence of Talulah and Chatooga Rivers, of Seneca River below the confluence of Keowee and Twelve Mile Rivers and of Saluda below the Saluda dam bridge and in each of said streams to the Anderson County line.

Closed seasons on catching certain fishThe closed season in zone 1 is hereby declared in all waters and streams except that territory lying south of the Southern Railway, against catching large mouth bass and small mouth bass during the month of April and for crappie and bream and warmouth for the month of May.
No bass shall be caught, or if caught, must be immediately placed back in the water under ten inches in length and bream, crappie and warmouth under six inches in length.

Penalties.Any violation of any of the provisions of Section 68 through 76 shall be punishable by a fine of not more than hundred dollars nor less than ten dollars, or imprisonment for not more than thirty days.
Season trap fur bearing animalslicense.It shall be legal to trap fur bearing animals in game zone 1 from Thanksgiving Day to March first of each year.
Each trapper before engaging in trapping fur bearing animals shall be required to purchase a license so to do.
The license shall be sold only by the county game warden of the county for the price of ten dollars per season, and that the revenue derived therefrom shall be placed in the county game fund.

Anyone who engages in trapping without first obtaining the license therefor, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars or imprisonment of not more than thirty days.
Game Zone 2 (Anderson, Abbeville, Laurens, Greenwood, Newberry and McCormick Counties) Section 79.
Open and closed game hunting seasons.There is hereby created open and closed seasons for the hunting of game in Zone No.
(c) The open season for hunting raccoons and squirrels shall be from October first to February fifteenth of each year.
(d) The open season for the hunting of opossum shall be from September first to February fifteenth of each year.
(e) The open season for the hunting of rabbits and quail shall be from and including Thanksgiving Day to February fifteenth of each year.

Provided, however, that rabbits may be hunted without guns, and with dogs only, from September first to Thanksgiving Day of each year, (f) The open season tor hunting of foxes shall be from September first to March first and then only with dogs.

Not hunt during closed seasonquail and squirrel bag limitsIt shall be unlawful for any person to hunt for any of the game hereinabove enumerated at any time other than the open season for hunting of game as set out in Section 79.
It shall be unlawful for any person to catch or kill more than ten quail during any one calendar day, or more than ten squirrels during any one calendar day.

Use of nets and other devices catch fish.It shall be unlawful to use, seines, nets, baskets, or traps for the catching of fish in any back waters caused by the damming of any running stream in said zone, and it shall be unlawful to use a seine, with mesh smaller than one and onequarter inches square for the catching of fish in any of the waters in said zone.

Deputy game wardens.A majority of the legislative delegation, together with the Senator from any county in said zone shall have the privilege in their discretion of authorizing the employment of additional deputy game wardens for not more than three months during the hunting season, and compensation of such wardens shall be made from game fund on hand.

PenaltiesAny violation of any of the provisions of Section 79 through 83 shall be punishable by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars, nor less than ten dollars or imprisonment for not more than thirty days.

Fishing in artificial lakes with area of ten thousand acres and Boyds Mill Pond in Laurens Countybag limitssalelicense catch carp and catfish with split wood basket.(a) It shall be unlawful to catch and carry away from any artificial lake of an area of ten thousand acres or more within Game Zone No.
2 of this state any fish of any kind except by hook and line which shall include poles, rod and reel and natural or artificial bait and no person shall use more than two poles at the same time.

Provided, that the provisions of this section shall include the tributaries upstream of lake or lakes herein mentioned for a distance of one mile above where the water ceases to flow; provided, however, the Director of this state is authorized to issue licenses to persons to catch carp and catfish in the waters of stich lakes by the use of haskets made from split wood, commonly known as split wood baskets.
The license fee shall be one dollar for each split wood basket which the licensee proposes to use.

In his application to the Director any person desiring to be licensed to use split wood baskets in the area shall state the number of baskets which he desires to use and the Director if he elects to license the applicant shall issue to him a license tag which shall have such mark of identification as may be determined or prescribed by the Director.
No license granted pursuant to this provision shall be effective for more than one year or may he for such shorter period of time as the Director may prescribe.

The Director is also authorized to prescribe regulations under which the basket may be operated for the particular purposes herein named VA ACTORS UU not inconsistent with the provisions of this section.

The Director is further authorized when in his opinion these destructive fish have become so reduced in number as not to materially hinder the multiplication of fish of more desirable kind to disconunue the granting of such licenses.
b) It shall be unlawful for any person to take from the waters of any artificial lake of ten thousand acres or more in area of Game Zone No.

2 more than eight bass and/or rock fish, either, or a combination of both, and not more than twenty game fish, which are other than bass or rock fish in any one day and it shall be presumed that any one having in his or her possession in and around or upon said lake a larger amount of game fish than is provided for herein has heen guilty of violating the provisions of this section.
Provided, further, that not more than twentyeight game fish including the eight hass or rock fish hereinbefore mentioned and twenty other game fish shall be caught in any one day by any one person.

(c) It shall be unlawful for any person to take and bag a bass less than ten inches in length and other game fish less than six inches in length from the waters of any artificial lake of ten thousand acres or more in Game Zone No.
The measurements herein provided shall he made from the tip of the head to the tip of the tail.
(d) Tt shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale any game fish caucht from the waters of any artificial lake having an area of ten thonsand acres or more within Game Zone No.

(e) Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars nor more than one hundred dollars or by imprisonment of not less than ten days or more than thirty days.
Provided, the terms of this section shall only apply to artificial lakes within Game Zone No.
Provided, further, that the provisions, the prohibitions and the authority herein provided shall apply to Bovds Mill Pond in Laurens County in Game Zone 2.

Fishing in spillway south of floodgates of Greenwood Hydroelectric Plantdaily bag limitssale.Fishing shall be permitted along, in and on the spillway or race south of the floudgates of the Greenwood Hydroelectric Plant on or near waters of the Saluda Rivers as provided below: The Greenwood County Electric Power Commission shall erect on each side of said race or spillway a fence to run to the edge of the water as follows: Along the Newberry side or steam plant side, said fence shall be erected at a point 225 fron the south side of the floodgate of the hydroelectric power plant, which shall be at or near the end of the riprap or cement abutment on said side.

On the Greenwood side of said spillway or race a fence shall be erected at a point 226 south of the floodgate of said hydroelectric plant, which shall be at or near the end of the riprap or cement abutment on said side; provided, the fence or line to be erected on either side of said race or spillway shall be of such height and so constructed as not to materially interfere with fishing as herein permitted.

No fishing shall be allowed beyond said fence toward the floodgate on the south side of said plant, nor shall any person or persons be allowed beyond this point, either on the land or on the water, by boat or otherwise, except that any person or persons fishing may cast or fish above the fence toward the floodgates of the hydroelectric plant; provided, that no person or persons shall go beyond the fence line to be established in accordance herewith.
No fishing shall be allowed nor shall any person or persons go within three hundred feet of the northern edge of the floodgates on the northern and lake side of said hydroelectric power plant.
Said commission is authorized, directed and empowered to erect a fence, or signs to identify said line so that members of the public shall be fully informed as to the location of same.

The Greenwood County Electric Power Commission is authorized, and directed to establish and maintain proper and suitable no trespass signs so that members of the public shall be sufficiently warned and notified as to the lines established.
Fishing permitted along said areas, as herein provided, shall only be done by hook or line which shall include poles, rods and reels and natural or artificial bait.
O70 WU Ii4 It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale any game fish caught upon the waters of said area.

The provisions of this section shall not affect in any manner the authority of the Greenwood County Electric Power Commission and the acts of the employees, agents, licensees and servants of the Greenwood County Electric Power Commission in carrying on their duties and responsibilities in connection with the operation of said plant.

Any person or persons fishng or going along the area as herein provided shall do so at his or their own risk, and no liability shall be imposed upon the counties or the authority involved in any manner whatsoever.

Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as follows: First offense by a fine of not less than twentyfive dollars nor more than one hundred dollars or by imprisonment of not less than ten days or more than thirty days.
Second offense by a fine of not less than fifty dollars nor more than one hundred dollars or by imprisonment of not less than fifteen days or more than thirty days.
Third offense by a fine of not less than two hundred dollars or by imprisonment of not less than thirty days, in the discretion of the court having jurisdiction.

Rabbitssale(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer to sell, barter or otherwise dispose of any rabbit in Game Zone 2 until Thanksgiving Day, 1950, provided, however, that nothing herein shall apply to the raising and selling of domestic rabbits.
(b) Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and may be fined not exceeding the sum of one hundred dollars or imprisonment not exceeding thirty days.
Game Zone 4 (Cherokee, Chester, Fairfield, Lancaster, Spartanburg, Union and York Counties) Section 87.

Season hunt quail.There is hereby created an open and closed season for the hunting of bobwhite quail in game zone no, 4 of South Carolina, said zone consisting of Spartanburg, Cherokee, Union, York, Chester, Fairfield and Lancaster Counties, towit: the open season for the hunting of bobwhite quail shall be from Thanksgiving Day to February first, both inclusive, of each year.
Any violation of any of the provisions of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars nor less than ten dollars or imprisonment for not exceeding thirty days.
Season hunt squirrelsThere is hereby.
created an open and closed season for the hunting of squirrels in game zone no.

4 of South Carolina consisting of Spartanburg, Cherokee, Union, York, Chester, Fairfield and Lancaster Counties, to wit: such open season shall be from the first day of October of each year until the first day of March of the following year, both dates inclusive, and such closed season shall be from the second day of March until the second day of October, both dates inclusive, of each year.
It shall be lawful for any person to hunt squirrels in the counties comprising said zone during such open season.

It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt squirrels in any of the counties comprising said zone during such closed season, and any person so doing shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, be punishable by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars nor less than ten dollars or imprisonment for not exceeding thirty days.
Seasons hunt dovesbag limit.(a) There is hereby created an open and closed season for the hunting of domestic doves in game zone no.

4 of South Carolina, said zone consisting of Cherokee, Spartanburg, Union, York, Lancaster and Fairfield Counties, towit: the open season for the hunting of domestic doves shall be from September fifteenth to October fifteenth, both dates inclusive.
The bag limit shall not exceed fifteen doves per day for any one person.

(b) In addition to the provisions of subsection (a) hereof, there shall also be an open season for the hunting of doves, domestic and otherwise, in said game zone during such period as the government of the United States of America permits the hunting of migratory birds in said zone.
(c) Any violation of any of the provisions of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars nor less than ten dollars, or imprisonment for not exceeding thirty days.
Game Zone 5 (Kershaw, Marlboro, Chesterfield, Darlington, Lee Sumter, Clarendon Counties) Section 90.
Not kill alligator in Game Zones 5 and 6.It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot or kill an alligator at any time during the year in Game Zone No.
This section shall include Game Zone 6.

Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall pay a fine of not exceeding one hundred dollars, or imprisonment not exceeding thirty days, in the discretion of the magistrate.
Game Zone 6 (Allendale, Bamberg, Barnwell, Beaufort, Berkeley, Charleston, Orangeburg, Colleton, Dorchester, Hampton, Jasper Counties) Section 91.
Open season on rabbits.There shall be no closed season for the purpose of hunting rabbits in state game zone number Six.
Open season on doves.There is hereby created an open and closed season for the hunting of domestic doves in game zone No.

6 of South Carolina, said zone consisting of Orangeburg, Barnwell, Bamberg, Allendale, Hampton, Jasper, Beaufort, Colleton, Dorchester, Berkeley, and Charleston Counties, to wit: the open season for the hunting of domestic doves shall be from November twentieth to January thirtyfirst, both dates inclusive.
Any violation of any of the provisions of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars nor less than ten dollars, or imprisonment for not exceeding thirty days.
Game Zone 7 (Dillon, Marion, Horry, Florence, Williamsburg and Georgetown Counties) Section 93.
Seasons hunt gamebag limits.The laws now applicable in Game Zones 5 and 6 shall not apply to Game Zone, consisting of Georgetown, Horry, Williamsburg, Florence, Marion and Dillon Counties.
There is hereby created open and closed seasons for the hunting of game in Game Zone 7 as follows: (a) There shall be no open season for the hunting of turkeys for a period of two years.
(b) The open season for the hunting of buck deer shall be from September fifteenth to January first, inclusive.
(c) The open season for the hunting of raccoon, mink, muskrat and otter shall be from September fifteenth to March first, inclusive.
(d) The open season for the hunting of squirrel shall be from October first to February first, inclusive.

(e) The open season for the hunting of quail shall be from sunrise to sunset on Thanksgiving Day and Friday and Saturday following, and from the second Monday in December to February fifteenth, inclusive.
(f) There shall be no closed season for the hunting of opossum, rabbit or fox.

Fishing devices not use or possessshooting or gigging fishIt shall be unlawful for any person to set, use or have in possession any fish nets, traps, seines, trotlines or set hooks or to shoot or gig fish in any of the streams, lakes, rivers or their tributaries, or other public streams, both muddy and clear water streams, at any time during the year in Game Zone 7, provided that this act shall not apply to shad, herring, shrimp or prawn fishing in the manner now provided for by law.

Sale or possession of netsset hoo  defined.It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, transport, or have in his possession in Game Zone 7, any fish net for any purpose (shad, herring, shrimp and prawn nets as now provided by law are excepted).

CatfishThe provisions of this act shall not apply to fishermen fishing for catfish below the forty mile limit established by the South Carolina Board of Fisheries, when the fishermen obtain irom the county game warden in the county in which they propose to fish a license to set traps for catfish, and shall pay to the game warden the sum of one dollar for each trap.
Provided, that such trap must be baited with shrimp or menhaden.
Not use light or gig catch fish.It shall be unlawful to use any light or torch or gig for catching or killing fish in the waters of Game Zone 7.

Confiscation and destruction of fishing devices.The game wardens are authorized and directed to confiscate and destroy all fish nets, (shad, herring, shrimp and prawn nets, as now provided by law, excepted) fish traps, seines, trotlines and set hooks in Game Zone 7.
Not shoot or kill alligator.It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot or kill an alligator in Game Zone 7 Section 100.
Possession of fish or game in excess of legal limits.

Any person having in his possession on any lake, stream, river, or their tributaries, going to or coming from such lake, stream, river, or their tributaries, or in the fields or woods, or going to or coming from the fields or woods, any game or fish in excess of the limits set out in this act or in any state act shall be presumed to have killed or caught the same.

PenaltiesAny person violating any one or more of the provisions of this act shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined for the first offense not less than twentyfive dollars nor more than one hundred dollars, or be imprisoned for nut more than thirty days; for the second offense not less than fifty dollars nor more than one hundred dollars, or be imprisoned for not more than thirty days; for the third offense not less than one hundred dollars, or be imprisoned for not more than sixty days; for each subsequent offense the fine or imprisonment shall be doubled.
Repeal.This act supersedes and is intended to repeal any and all acts inconsistent herewith to the extent of such inconsistencies.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 24th day of April, 1952.
899 An Act To Amend Act No.
176 Of The Acts Of 1951, Relating To Game And Fish In Game Zone 7, So As To Provide That Set Hooks May Be Used Under Certain Conditions In Florence County.
Act 176 of 1951 amendedwhen may use set hooks in Florence County.Act No.
176 of the Acts of 1951 is amended by adding a new section, to be known as Section 3A, which shall read as follows: section 3A.

Notwithstanding the provisions of section 2 and 3 of this act, the use and possession of set hooks shall be lawful in Florence County when only cut bait (as distinguished from live bait) is used and when no hook smaller than a No.
Sameconfiscation and destruction of fishing devices.

176 of the Acts of 1951, relating to confiscation and destruction of fish nets, set hooks, etc., is amended by changing the period at the end thereof to a comma and adding the following: except when the use,sale, or possession thereof is lawful under the terms of this act. The section, when so amended, shall read as follows: section 6.

The game wardens are authorized and directed to confiscate and destroy all fish nets, (shad, herring, shrimp and prawn nets, as now provided by law, excepted) fish traps, seines, trot lines and set hooks in Game Zone 7, except when the use, sale, or possession thereof is lawful under the terms of this act. Section 3. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 23rd day of April, 1952.
PART II Local and Temporary (R857, H1855) No.
900 A Joint Resolution Renouncing A Devise Made In Favor Of The State Of South Carolina By The Late Honorable 8.
J. Wall, In And By His Will Dated November 8, 1948, And Probated In Common Form By The Judge Of Probate For The County Of Marion On The 27th Day Of August, 1951.

Whereas, the late Honorable S. J. Wall, of the County of Marion, died on the 20th day of August, 1951, leaving his will dated November 8, 1948, which was admitted to probate in common form by the Judge of Probate for the County of Marion on the 27th day of August, 1951; and, Whereas, this will contains a devise reading as follows: T will, devise and bequeath unto the State of South Carolina, after the death of all my brothers and sisters, my farm located about three and onehalf miles North of the town of Marion known as the Jasper W. Braswell place to be used as a demonstration or experiment farm as a memorial to me for the purpose of advancing the science of agriculture, horticulture, animal husbandry, and such other sciences as are practiced on the farms of South Carolina; Provided, the long leaf pine grove on the West side in front of the main buildings on said farm be preserved as long as said trees can be made to live without being damaged or cut by the act of man and that such trees as may die or be destroyed by storm or otherwise be replaced by new long leaf pine plants so as to maintain the pine grove for educational purposes, and that a suitable marker be placed in said farm with an inscription thereon indicating me as the donor of said farm for the purposes herein named. ; and, Whereas, the State of South Carolina, while highly appreciating the good will of the testator manifested by making this devise, realizes that the same is in the nature of a trust imposing important obligations and responsibilities upon the state, the assumption of which would be of doubtful wisdom and propriety; and, Whereas, the state already maintains an experiment station in Florence County, which is approximately thirty miles from the location of the farm mentioned in the will, making it impracticable for the state to maintain two experiment stations within so small an area.
Devise to State by 8.

J. Wall renounced.The State of South Carolina does hereby decline and refuse to accept the aforesaid devise made in its favor in the will of the late Honorable S. J. Wall, and the State of South Carolina does hereby forever renounce and disclaim the aforesaid devise, including any and every part thereof, and all things incident thereto.
Time effective.This resolution shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the Ist day of March, 1952.

901 An Act To Appropriate The Sum Of Fifteen Thousand Dollars ($15,000.00) From The General Fund Of The State For The Officers Candidate School Of The National Guard Of South Carolina Known As The Palmetto Military Academy.

Whereas, the allotted strength of the South Carolina National Guard is 12,308 and the actual strength, both officers and enlisted personnel, is but 7,502, which leaves the Guard acutely short of both junior officers and enlisted personnel; and, Whereas, the fact of this serious shortage has been recognized by the National Guard Association, which comprises all officers in the South Carolina National Guard, and the Adjutant and Inspector General of the state; and, Whereas, the National Guard Association sponsored a plan which resulted in the organization of an Officers Candidate School, known as the Palmetto Military Academy, to which eligible young National Guardsmen from the various units of the Guard in the state could attend a school for two days each month for a period of eleven months and thereby qualify for a commission; and, Whereas, the Officers Candidate School has now been in existence for approximately one and onehalf years, and during June, 1951, twentyfive young men were commissioned Second Lieutenants; and, Whereas, the efficiency of the school has been so outstanding that it has become an accredited school recognized by the United States Army through the National Guard Bureau; and, Whereas, at the present time approximately one hundred National Guardsmen attend the Palmetto Military Academy, to which students travel at their own expense; and, Whereas, the maintenance of the school requires a small expenditure of funds for pay of instructors and other necessary expenses, including mess hall personnel, lights, fuel and other incidentals, all of which are infinitesimally small as compared to the great contribution to National Defense made by the school.

Appropriation for officers candidate school for National Guardsmen.The sum of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) is hereby appropriated from the general fund of the state, if so much be necessary, to be spent under the direction and approval of the Adjutant and Inspector General of South Carolina for the maintenance and upkeep of the Officers Candidate School.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 12th day of March, 1952.

902 A Joint Resolution Proposing To Amend The Constitution Of 1895 So As To Repeal section 5 Of Article XI Of The Constitution As Amended, Which Provides That The General Assembly Shall Provide For A Liberal System Of Free Public Schools For All Children Between The Ages Of Six And TwentyOne Years, And For The Division Of The Counties Into Suitable School Districts.

Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1. Amendment to article XI,  5, State Constitution, proposedeliminate provisions for liberal system free public schools for children and division of counties into school districts.There is hereby proposed an amendment to the Constitution of South Carolina, 1895, as amended, by repealing Section 5 of Article XI as amended by Ratification Act No.
24 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of 1951 which section, as amended, reads as follows: section 5.

The General Assembly shall provide for a liberal system of free public schools for all children between the ages of six and twentyone years, and for the division of the Counties into suitable school districts. Section 2. Submission to electorsThe proposed amendment shall be submitted to the qualified electors at the next general election for representatives.

Ballots shall be provided at the various voting precincts with the following words printed or written thereon: Shall the Constitution of 1895 be amended so as to repeal Section 5 of Article XI thereof, which reads as follows: The General Assembly shall provide for a liberal system of free public schools for all children between the ages of six and twentyone years, and for the division of the Counties into suitable school districts. ?

In favor of the amendment O Opposed to the amendment O Those voting in favor of the amendment shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the words In favor of the amendment, and those voting against the amendment shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the words , 99 .
Opposed to the amendment (R838, H15S05) No.

903 An Act To Authorize The State Treasurer To Pay To Mrs. Kate T. Moultrie The Sum Of Two Thousand ($2,000.00) Dollars On Account Of Injury Suffered While In The Employment Of The State Training School On June 1, 1941, And Providing For Attorneys Fee.

Appropriation to pay Mrs. Kate T. Moultrie for injury.The State Treasurer is authorized to pay the sum of two thousand ($2,000.00) dollars to Mrs. Kate T. Moultrie on account of injury sustained on June 1, 1941, arising out and in the scope of her employment while employed by the State Training School at Clinton, South Carolina.

That upon the payment of this sum to this employee she shall execute a full release releasing the employer from any and all claims that have arisen or that might arise on account of injuries sustained on that date.
This amount shall be paid and charged against the South Carolina Workmens Compensation fund.
From this amount no more than fifteen (15%) per cent shall be paid as attorneys fee.
904 An Act To Require The Football Teams Of The University Of South Carolina And Clemson College To Play Their Annual Game On Thursday Of Fair Week, 1952.

Play CarolinaClemson football game in 1952.The football teams of the University of South Carolina and Clemson College shall play their annual football game on Thursday of fair week of 1952 under such terms as the boards of trustees may decide.
Approved the 27th day of February, 1952 (R987, H1901) .
905 A Joint Resolution Authorizing The Board Of Directors Of The State Penitentiary To Expend Certain Funds For Permanent Improvements.
Funds expend for permanent improvements on State Farm No.

1 of the State Penitentiary.The Board of Directors of the State Penitentiary is hereby authorized to spend from Gravel Royalty funds now in hand the sum of twentyfive thousand dollars ($25,000.00), if so much be needed, for permanent improvements on State Farm No.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 13th day of March, 1952.
906 An Act To Provide For The Distribution Of The Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1952, Owned By The State Of South Carolina.
Distribution of 1952 Codes.That copies of the Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1952, owned by the State of South Carolina, shall be distributed by the State Librarian as follows: 1.
Twentyfive copies to the Law School of the University of South Carolina and ten copies to the Colored, Normal, Industrial, Agricultural and Mechanical College Law School.
Eight copies to the Legislative Council.
Five copies each to Code Commissioner, Attorney General, Tax Commission and State Highway Department.
Three copies each to the Governor, State Library, Public Service Commission, each member of Committee on Statutory Laws, and to the Library of the Congress.

Two copies each to Secretary of State; Comptroller General; Department of Education; Department of Agriculture; Insurance Commissioner; Supreme Court Library; The Citadel; The Clemson Agricultural College; University of South Carolina; Winthrop College; State Board of Health; Department of Labor; Natural Resources Commission; Employment Security Commission; Research, Planning and Development Board; the Colored, Normal, Industrial, Agricultural and Mechanical College; and the Probation, Pardon and Parole Board.

One copy each to Lieutenant Governor; State Treasurer; Adjutant and Inspector General; each Justice of the Supreme Court; Clerk of Supreme Court; each Circuit Court Judge; each Circuit Court Solicitor; each County Solicitor; each Domestic Relations Court Judge; each Civil and Criminal Court Judge; each Register of Mesne Conveyance where such office is separate; South Carolina School for the Deaf and the Blind; John de la Howe School; Medical College of South Carolina; Aeronautics Commission; Board of Bank Control; Childrens Bureau; State Commission of Forestry ; Historical Commission; State Department of Public Welfare; State Service Bureau; South Carolina Industrial School for Boys; South Carolina Industrial School for Girls; State Penitentiary; John G. Richards Industrial School for Negro Boys; State Hospital; State Training School; Clerk of Senate; Clerk of House of Representatives; each State Library which furnishes this State free a set of its Code of Laws; United States Supreme Court; each Institution of Higher Learning in this State not herein provided for; each Committee Room of the General Assembly ; Speaker of the House of Representatives Office; Lieutenant Governors Office; each County Auditor; each County Governing Board; each County Coroner; each County Master; each County Probate Judge; each County Sheriff; each County Superintendent of Education; each County Treasurer; each County Magistrate; each public library in this State; each member of the 1952 General Assembly; each member of the Committee on Statutory Laws who assisted in the preparation of the Report on Codification of General Statute Law of South Carolina, 1951, who are not now members of the General Assembly; State Educational Finance Commission; State Ports Authority; and Industrial School tor Negro Girls.
Use of undistributed copiesThat all copies of the said Code not distributed as herein provided shall be retained by the State Librarian for the use of the State.

Officials receive copies personally.The provisions of Section 21182 of 1942 Code providing for the disposition of Codes of Laws distributed to officials shall not apply to Codes of Laws distributed hereunder to the Code Commissioner, Members of Committee on Statutory Laws and Members of the General Assembly, and such distributed codes shall be theirs personally.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 23rd day of April, 1952.

907 An Act To Ratify The Action Taken Pursuant To Act 1059 Of The Acts Of 1950 In Apportioning The Amounts Of The Loans Authorized By Such Act Among The Several State Institutions Therein Authorized To Borrow, Viz., The Citadel, Clemson Agricultural College, The University Of South Carolina, Winthrop College, The Medical College Of The State Of South Carolina, And The Colored Normal, Industrial, Agricultural And Mechanical College, And To Enlarge And Further Define The Procedure By Which Said Loans Shall Be Made, And The Covenants And Undertakings Which May Be Made On Behalf Of Said Institutions To Secure The Payment Of The Principal And Interest Of Such Loans.

1059 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina for the year 1950, the colleges and universities of the state listed in said act were empowered to make applications for loans to, and to borrow from, the Federal Government, or any agency thereof, not exceeding ten million dollars ($10,000,000.00), which should be used for the acquisition and purchase of land and in constructing and equipping buildings to be used for housing the members of the faculties or the students of the respective institutions; and, Whereas, it was therein provided that the respective boards of trustees of such institutions should determine among themselves, by agreement, the portions of the aggregate authorization which each institution might borrow; and, Whereas, it was further provided in said act that no institution should apply for a loan without first obtaining the approval of the State Budget and Control Board; and, Whereas, pursuant thereto, an agreement was reached among the boards of trustees of such institutions, which provided that the said borrowing should be apportioned as follows: The Citadel $ 500,000.00 Clemson Agricultural College 2,500,000.00 The University of South Carolina 3,000,000.00 The Medical College of South Carolina 1,000,000.00 Winthrop College 1,500,000.00 The Colored Normal, Industrial, Agricultural 1,500,000.00 and Mechanical College and, Whereas, after consultation between the appropriate federal agency and representatives of one of said institutions, it had been ascertained that question exists as to whether said Act 1059 authorized the detailed covenants and undertakings which are usually required in the making of loans for such projects; and, Whereas, it also appears that prior to making such loans, it may be required by the appropriate federal agency that a showing be made that private financial sources will not make the loan on reasonably similar terms, which requirement necessitates the removal of the limitation in Act 1059 of 1950 that such loan be made only to the Federal Government, or any agency thereof; and, Whereas, the interest rate applicable on federal loans of this sort is prescribed by regulations and varies from time to time, which variations indicate the desirability of enlarging the limitation as to the interest to be paid from three per centum (3%) to three and onehalf per centum (3149) ; and, Whereas, by reason of all of the foregoing, the General Assembly is minded to validate the proceedings heretofore taken and above recited, and to further define and enlarge the powers granted to the respective boards of the institutions listed in said Act 1059 in consection with any loan made pursuant to said authorization.

Recited provisions in preamble ratifiedstate institutions of higher learning borrowuse of proceeds.The proceedings heretofore taken and above recited stand ratified, approved and confirmed, and the respective governing bodies of The Citadel, Clemson Agricultural College, The University of South Carolina, The Medical College of the State of South Carolina, Winthrop College and The Colored Normal, Industrial, Agricultural and Mechanical College are hereby specifically authorized and empowered, but only with the consent and approval of the State Budget and Control Board, to borrow the sums set opposite the name of each respective institution, that is to say: $ 500,000.00 The Citadel, not exceeding Clemson Agricultural College, not exceeding 2,500,000.00 The University of South Carolina, not exceeding 3,000,000.00 The Medical College of the State of South Carolina, not exceeding 1,000,000.00 Winthrop College, not exceeding 1,500,000.00 The Colored Normal, Industrial, Agricultural and Mechanical College, not exceeding 1,500,000.00 and to apply the proceeds thereof to the acquisition and construction of buildings to be used in housing members of the faculty and/or students of the respective institutions, except that in the case of The Medical College of the State of South Carolina, a cafeteria may be installed in the dormitory building which it proposes to construct, such undertakings being hereafter in this act referred to by the term Project.

Issue revenue bonds.To evidence the loans hereby authorized, the respective governing bodies of the institutions, hereinafter referred to as governing bodies, shall be impowered to issue revenue bonds of such institutions.

Said bonds shall be issued as negotiable instruments, but may be issued with the privilege of registration as to principal, or as to both principal and interest, under such conditions as the governing bodies shall prescribe.
Revenues use pay.The said bonds, both principal and interest, shall be payable solely from the revenues derived from the particular Project financed by the proceeds of such bonds.

Neither the faith and credit of the State of South Carolina, nor of the governing bodies shall be pledged for the payment of the principal and interest of such bonds, and there shall be on the face of each bond a statement, plainly worded, to that effect.
Neither the members of said governing bodies nor any other person signing the bonds shall be personally liable thereon.

Adopt resolutions authorizing issuancematuritiesinterestdenominationsredemption.In order to avail itself of the authorizations of this act and said Act 1059 of 1950, the respective governing bodies shall adopt a resolution providing for the issuance of bonds of their respective institutions, within the limits herein mentioned, and prescribing their tenor, terms and conditions.

The bonds shall be issued as serial bonds, maturing in unequal or equal amounts, at such times and on such occasions as said governing body shall determine, provided always that the last maturing bonds shall become due not later than fifty (50) years from their date, and the first maturing of any bonds issued pursuant to this act shall fall due within five (5) years from the date such bonds bear.

They shall bear interest at a rate not exceeding three and onehalf per centum (314%) per annum, payable semiannually, shall be in such denominations, shall be payable in such medium of payment, and at such place or places, and shall be subject to such terms of redemption, with or without premium, as such resolution may prescribe.

Execution.Such bonds shall be executed in the name of borrowing institution by such persons as its governing body shall determine, and the seal of such borrowing institution shall be affixed or impressed on each bond.
The coupons attached to such bonds shall be authenticated by the facsimile signature of one or more of the persons signing the bonds.

Sale.Said bonds shall be disposed of in such manner as the respective governing bodies shall determine, except that no sale, privately negotiated without public advertisement, shall be consummated without the approval of the State Budget and Control Board.

If any governing body shall elect to sell its bonds at public sale, at least one (1) advertisement thereof shall appear in some newspaper of general circulation in South Carolina not less than 10 days prior to the occasion fixed for the opening of bids.

Exempt from taxesSuch bonds, and the interest thereon, shall be exempt from all state, county, municipal, school district and all other taxes or assessments, direct or indirect, general or special, whether imposed for the purpose of general revenue or otherwise.
Investments.It shall be lawful for all executors, administrators, guardians and fiduciaries, and all sinking fund commissions to invest any moneys in their hands in such bonds.

Authority of institutional governing bodiesTo the end that the payment of the principal and interest of all such bonds shall be adequately secured, each governing body shall be empowered, in its discretion: 1.

To issue bonds in such amount, within the limitation herein provided for, as shall not exceed the governing bodys estimate of the cost of the Project, plus such further sum as may be needed to pay the interest on such bonds until adequate revenues are derived from the Project, which period shall not exceed three (3) years from the date of such bonds.
To pledge the whole or any part of the revenues of the Project for the payment of the principal and interest of said bonds as the same respectively mature.
To covenant that no services or facilities afforded by the Project will be used free of charge.
To covenant to establish and maintain such system of parietal rules as will assure maximum use and occupancy of the Project.

To covenant that an adequate schedule of rents and charges will be established and maintained in such fashion as to produce sufficient revenues to: (a) Pay the cost of operating and maintaining the Project, including the cost of fire.

extended coverage and use and occupancy insurance: (b) Pay the principal and interest of the bonds as the same respectively hecome due; (c) Create and at all times maintain an adequate Debt Service Reserve Fund to meet the payment of such principal and interest ; and, (d) Create and at all times maintain an adequate reserve for contingencies and for major repairs and replacements.

To covenant against the mortgaging or disposing of all or any part of the Project, and against permitting or suffering any lien to be created thereon, equal or superior to the lien created for the benefit of such bonds.

To covenant that the proceeds derived from the sale of such bonds shall be applied solely to the Project, and within the limitations of paragraph 1, supra, to pay interest on such bonds, and that any surplus shall be used solely for the retirement of such bonds.
To make covenants with respect to the use of the Project and its facilities and any services rendered by such Project.

To covenant that all revenues derived from the Project will be duly segregated into special funds, and that such funds will be used solely for the purposes for which the same are intended, and for no other purpose.
To provide for the optional or mandatory redemption of the bonds on such terms and conditions as the resolution authorizing such bonds shall prescribe.

To prescribe the procedure, if any, by which the terms of the contract with the bondholders may be amended, the number of bonds whose holders must consent thereto, and the manner in which such consent shall be given.. 14.
To covenant as to the maintenance of the Project, the insurance to be carried thereon, and the use and disposition of proceeds from any insurance policy.

To prescribe the events of default and the terms and conditions upon which all or any bonds shall become or may be declared due before maturity and the terms and conditions upon which such declaration and its consequences may be waived.
To impose a statutory lien upon the Project.
Such statutory lien shall extend to the Project, its appurtenances and extensions, additions, improvements and enlargements, and shall inure to the benefit of the holders of the bonds secured hereby.
Such project shall remain subject to such statutory lien until the payment in full of the principal and interest of the bonds.

Any holder of any of the bonds, or any of the coupons representing interest thereon, may, either at law or in equity, by suit, action, mandamus or other proceedings, protect and enforce said statutory lien, and may, by suit, action, mandamus or other proceedings, enforce and compel performance of all duties of the governing body, including the fixing of sufficient rates for the services afforded by the Project, the proper segregation of the revenues, and the proper application thereof.
Provided, however, that said statutory lien shall not be construed to give any such bond or coupon holder authority to compel the sale of the Project, or any part thereof.

If there be any default in the payment of the principal of or interest upon any of said bonds, any court having jurisdiction in any proper action may appoint a receiver to administer and operate the Project, with power to fix and charge rates and charges for the facilities of the Project, sufficient to provide for the payment of the bonds and the interest thereon, and for the payment of the expenses of operating and maintaining the Project, and to apply the income and revenues of the Project to the payment of such bonds, and the interest thereon.

To enter into a loan agreement with the United States of America, or any agency thereof, containing such provisions, terms and conditions not inconsistent with this act, as the governing bodies may agree to, and to consent to any modification thereof.
Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed to the extent of such inconsistencies.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 27th day of February, 1952.

The county commissioners shall have equal authority in county matters with the supervisors; Provided, that the statement of affairs of the county shall be posted on the bulletin board in front of the court house and published in the newspapers as now provided by law; that unless the supervisor publishes the statement, it shall be unlawful for the county treasurer to pay the salary of the supervisor; provided, that the county treasurer shall pay all county officers monthly instead of quarterly.

The county superintendent of education, on the fifteenth day of each month shall file with the various school districts in the county a statement showing the amount of monies on hand to the credit of the respective school districts, and the county treasurer shall file with the supervisor, on the fifteenth day of each month a statement showing the amount on hand to the credit of the county, and it shall be unlawful for the county board of commissioners to issue salary vouchers to the county treasurer and the county superintendent of education unless this provision is carried out as herein provided.
The money appropriated above as a contingent fund is to be used and paid out at the direction of the county delegation, or a majority thereof.

The various items herein appropriated for the purposes herein specified shall be used exclusively as provided for in the act, and any transfer of funds from one item to another is hereby specifically prohibited, and any officer who violates this provision shall be deemed and considered guilty of malfeasance in office.

If, owing to the non payment of taxes caused by the extension of time for payment of taxes, or otherwise, there shall not be sufficient funds available for the full payment of the notes executed by the county board to secure the loans for the year 1951, then in that case the county board is authorized to renew such note or notes for any balance or balances which may be due and unpaid for such time as funds may become available for the payment of same.

Any unexpended balance in any department, at the end of the year 1951 with all delinquent taxes, other than school taxes, which shall be collected in 1952 shall be placed in the contingent fund; that the legislative delegation, or a majority thereof, shall direct that this fund be used for county purposes and if it is found that the tax levy can be reduced, the delegation, or a majority thereof, shall instruct the auditor to reduce same.
The salary of the superintendent of the county farm shali not be supplemented by additional remuneration such as groceries and supplies for himself and family.
The Abbeville County Delegation, or a majority thereof, may, at any time, order the discontinuance and storage of any motor car or other equipment owned or hereafter to be owned by Abbeville County.
The county delegation, or a majority thereof, is hereby authorized and empowered to secure the services of a certified public accountant to make an audit of the county books for the year 1952.
The supervisor and county board of commissioners are to employ an attorney and a county physician.

The salaries fixed herein for the clerk of court of common pleas and general sessions and register of mesne conveyance, sheriff, county treasurer, judge of probate and county auditor shall be in full compensation and all fees to be collected by law for items placed in their hands, on and after January 1, 1952, shall be turned over to the county treasurer as provided by Act No.

655 of the Acts of 1936 and all years prior thereto; and the Treasurer of Abbeville County to retain all tax execution fees for the year 1938 and prior thereto and that the Judge of Probate of Abbeville to retain all fees on business done prior to January 3, 1939.
The Abbeville County Delegation, or a majority thereof, may add new items to Item M, Miscellaneous, and to transfer from the Contingent Fund 1952 for the payment thereof.

The supervisor and the county board of commissioners are hereby prohibited from entering into a contract for the county whereby additional legal counsel is employed to prosecute or defend any suit in the state, county, or any official thereof, or agree to pay any legal fees to counsel other than the duly authorized salary of the county attorney whether authorized by the courts, or not, without having first obtained the written consent of the Abbeville County Delegation, or a majority thereof.

The Abbeville County Delegation, or a majority thereof, is hereby authorized and empowered to pay to the members of the Forestry Committee or any other members of a committee authorized by legislation, meeting during the year 1952 the sum of five dollars per day from the Contingent Fund under Item E, provided, however, none of the committee shall be paid for more than twelve meetings during the year 1952.
All authorization for transfers for the 1951 Supply Act of Abbeville County to all departments of county government is hereby ratified, confirmed and validated.

The County Board of Commissioners of Abbeville County is hereby authorized and directed to borrow the sum of thirtyfive thousand dollars ($35,000.00), if so much be necessary, to be credited to the general county fund, and used for general county expenses in the event that the sums herein appropriated should be insufficient to meet the needs of the county for the period covered by this act.

Such indebtedness, if created, shall be evidenced by a note and such note shall bear interest at the rate of one and onehalf per cent per annum, shall be payable one year from date, and shall be signed by the chairman and the members of the county board of commissioners.
The county treasurer is hereby authorized to credit the the proceeds of the loan to the general county fund.
The indebtedness evidenced by the note provided for herein shall be repaid from the proceeds of the tax levy for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1952 for Abbeville County.
All acts or parts of acts inconsistent with this act are herehy repealed.
This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 25th day of January, 1952.

The county commissioners shall have equal authority in county matters with the supervisors; Provided, that the statement of affairs of the county shall be posted on the bulletin board in 7 front of the courthouse and published in the newspapers as now proi vided by law; that unless the supervisor publishes the statement it 1] t ; shall be unlawful for the county treasurer to pay the salary of the supervisor ; provided, that the county treasurer shall pay all county officers monthly instead of quarterly.

60 of Abbeville County shall prepare a budget for cost of operation of the schools, maintenance of buildings and equipment within the district, and determine the number of mills required to be levied to finance same.
They shall then certify at an appropriate date the budget and the millage required for the year to the county board of education.

The county board of education shall review the budget and recommended millage so submitted, making such changes as the board of education may deem necessary, then, with the advice and consent of the Legislative Delegation or a majority thereof, the county board of education shall certify the millage required to the Auditor of Abbeville County, whereupon the county auditor shall levy the required tax upon all the taxable property within the district, and the Treasurer of Abbeville County shall collect the same in like manner as all taxes are collected, and place the same in said district school account, to be disbursed for the declared purposes in the manner fixed by law.
The county superintendent of education, on the fifteenth day of each month shall file with School District No.

60 of the county a statement showing the amount of monies on hand to the credit of the school district, and the county treasurer shall file with the supervisor, on the fifteenth day of each month a statement showing the amount on hand to the credit of the county, and it shall be unlawful for the county board of commissioners to issue salary vouchers to the county treasurer and the county superintendent of education unless this provision is carried out as herein provided.

If, owing to the non payment of taxes caused by the extension of time for payment of taxes, or otherwise, there shall not be sufficient funds available for the full payment of the notes executed by the county board to secure the loans for the fiscal year 19511952 ending June 30, 1952, then in that case the county board is authorized to renew such note or notes for any balance or balances which may be due and unpaid for such time as funds may become available for the payment of same.

Any unexpended balance in any department, at the end of the fiscal year 19511952 with all delinquent taxes, other than school taxes, which shall be collected in the fiscal year 19521953 shall be placed in the contingent fund; that the legislative delegation, or a majority thereof, shall direct that this fund be used for county purposes and if it is found that the tax levy can be reduced, the delegation, or a majority thereof, shall instruct the auditor to reduce the same.
The salary of the superintendent of the county farm shall not be supplemented by additional remuneration such as groceries and supplies for himself and family.
The Abbeville County Delegation, or a majority thereof, may, at any time, order the discontinuance and storage of .any motor car or other equipment owned or hereafter to be owned by Abbeville County.

The county delegation, or a majority thereof, is hereby authorized and empowered to secure the services of a certified public accountant to make an audit of the county books for the fiscal year 19521953 beginning July 1, 1952.

The salaries fixed herein for the clerk of court of common pleas and general sessions and register of mesne conveyance, sheriff, county treasurer, judge of probate and county auditor shall be in full compensation and all fees to be collected by law for items placed in their hands, on and after July 1, 1952, shall be turned over to the county treasurer as provided by Act No.

The Abbeville County Delegation, or a majority thereof, is hereby authorized and empowered to pay to the members of the Forestry Committee or any other members of a committee authorized by legislation, meeting during the fiscal year 19521953, ending June 30, 1953, the sum of five dollars per day from the Contingent Fund under Item E, provided, however, none of the committee shall be paid for more than twelve meetings during the fiscal year 19521953.

All authorization for transfers for the 1951 Supply Act of Abbeville County and for the Supply Act for the period January 1, 1952 to July 1, 1952 of Abbeville County to all departments of county government is hereby ratified, confirmed and validated.

The County Board of Commissioners of Abbeville County is hereby authorized and directed to borrow the sum of seventyfive thousand dollars ($75,000.00), if so much be necessary, to be credited to the general county fund, and used for general county expenses in the event that the sums herein appropriated should be insufficient to meet the needs of the county for the period covered by this act.

Such indebtedness, if created, shall be evidenced by a note and such note shall bear interest at the rate of not to exceed four per cent per annum, shall be payable one year from date, and of commissioners.
shall be signed by the chairman and the members of the county board Section 20.
The county treasurer is hereby authorized to credit the proceeds of the loan to the general county fund.
The indebtedness evidenced by the note provided for herein shall be repaid from the proceeds of the tax levy for the fiscal year 19521953 beginning July 1, 1952 for Abbeville County.
This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 12th day of March, 1952.

Total Item 26 400.00 GRAND TOTAL $480,251.81 Less Estimated Revenue other than Taxes: Beer and Wine Tax 8,237.55 Liquor Tax 46,977.03 Gasoline Tax 109,425.30 Insurance Licenses 15,000.00 For Service Officer 4,800.00 Fines, Commissions and Fees 77,818.56 Income Tax 64,114.05 = Total Revenue other than Taxes $326,372.49 Amount to be raised by taxation $153,879.32 Section 2.

The appropriation herein provided under Item 1, Section 1, or so much thereof as may be necessary, after payment of salaries listed therein, shall be expended for the upkeep and maintenance of the roads and bridges of the county, convict camps, con) victs, operation of the county farm, roadworking organizations a nd payment of all employees which may be engaged for said purposes.

The Supervisor shall have exclusive charge of the county farms and shall keep a record of the cost of operation thereof and all ren derived therefrom and he shall have exclusive charge of the county convicts while they are confined in the county centralized camp and while they are engaged in work on said farms.

The Supervisor shall also have exclusive charge and supervision over the personnel necessary to be employed in the operation of the farms and t management of the convict camp, with the right to hire and disS charge any such employee.

The employment of all guards of prisone shall be with the approval of the county supervisor, and such guard shall be subject to his authority and control while on duty at the county centralized convict camp.

The Supervisor shall inspect all roads and make the same reports required of the commissioners and cooperate with the commissioners in maintaining the roads so as to keep the same in good condition for public use.
All monies received from rents and sale of commodities shall be turned over to the treasurer of the county monthly.

The commissioners shall supervise all county road work in their respective districts, and they shall make requisition to the supervisor for such convicts from time to time as the needs of the roads in their respective districts may require; the commissioners shall be responsible for the convicts under their charge while at work, going to and returning from their work at camp.

And, on Monday of each week, the commissioners shall each file his report with the clerk of the county board which reports shall be kept in the office of the board for inspection of the supervisor and the Legislative Delegation of Aiken County.

The fee that may be charged by the Clerk of Court of Aiken County for the recording, filing, inde ig and/or registering any mortgage or other instrument conveying an interest in or creating a lien on crops growing or to be grown andor personal property and made to any corporation or agency orga A dsunder the Act of Congress known as the Farm Credit Act of 1933, or any amendments thereto, or any other Act of Congress providing for the lending of money on crops and/or personal property, a Regional Agriculturat Credit Corporatic , a Federal Intermediate Credit Bank, the Farm Credit Administration, The Farm Security Administration, The Secretary of Agriculture of the United States cf America, or any other corporation or agency which lends or rediscounts notes or other obligations with or procures loans from a Federal Intermediate Credit Bank, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation or the Government of the United States or any denartment, agency.
instrumentality or officer thereof shall he seventyfive cents (754).

Provided, that a copy or duplicate of such instrument be furnished to the record officer; that Aiken County is specifically excepted from the provisions of Section 3635, Section 3638, Section 3639 and Section 36391, Volume IT, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, Section 4.

No disabled war veteran shall be required to pay any license fee to the County of Aiken to carry on business therein, but said disabled veteran shall first, before carrying on such business, satisfy the one officer, who is to require the license fee that it is his business and that he is disabled.
The county commissioners are authorized and directed to pay any salaries of any officers whose services may be discontinued, such salaries to be paid up to the time of their discontinuance.

The county treasurer and all other officers shall require surety bonds for all deposits in such sums as shall make the deposits safe, and the premium or premiums therefor, unless otherwise provided in the bid for depository agreement, shall be paid by the county treasurer from county funds, unless the deposits consist of special funds, in which event premium or premiums shall be charged to that fund.
The treasurer is authorized to transfer any funds in his office that may be needed for any specific purpose to the ordinary county funds.

Any balance brought forward from the fiscal year 195152, and funds received from any source, including countys part of gasoline tax, and not otherwise appropriated herein, shall be used along with the levy provided for herein to meet the appropriation herein authorized.

Any officer or employee who disregards any of the provisions hereof shall be guilty of misconduct in office and subject to removal in addition to the punishment now provided by law, and shall further forfeit his salary as provided herein.

No bill or claim shall be paid or approved unless the same be itemized and state fully, under oath, what it is for, and signed by the supervisor or someone designated to do so by him giving the kind or quality of the thing or commodity which it represents, in addition to the amount and time furnished.

The auditor, together with a majority of the members of the House of Representatives, and the Senator of Aiken County are authorized to reduce or increase the levy as in their judgment will be necessary to pay the amounts herein appropriated, after taking into full account all other income of the county.

The County Treasurer of Aiken County shall make the best arrangement for interest on deposits to the credit of the county in bank or banks, and shall make the best terms for same and for loans desired by the county commissioners.
Provided, that such bank or banks shall give a surety or surety bonds in company or companies approved by the treasurer to cover any loss on account of any such deposits.

Provided, further, that if the treasurer finds it impracticable to obtain a surety bond from any such bank or banks, he may divide the deposits and loans in such shares and in such banks as may offer the best terms and furnish such bond, or bonds, or other valid lien securities and collateral.Provided, further, that all funds of Aiken County shall be distributed equitably among and deposited in all the banks in Aiken County who desire to carry such funds and who are able to comply with the requirements of this act.

In case the County Commissioners of Aiken County and the Treasurer of Aiken County shall deem it proper to borrow money to finance the countys operations, or to pay any owing by it, or to extend any obligations that Aiken County may owe, the county commissioners are hereby authorized and empowered to issue such notes or other county obligations as a majority of the commissioners and the treasurer shall deem proper, making them in such denominations and for such length of time as they may deem proper, and for the lowest rate of interest they may obtain; and they shall have full power and authority to pledge taxes and to pledge the full taxing power of the County of Aiken for the payment of said obligations; but such obligations are not to exceed any just obligations already incurred and the amount appropriated in this act.
Provided, that a majority of the members of the House of Representatives and the Senator of Aiken County must approve such action of the commissioners and treasurer.

All written authorizations by the present delegation heretofore or hereafter made when filed with the clerk of court are ratified, but shall not be valid until a copy of same be filed with the clerk of court.

Provided, that no special authority for the expenditure of funds shall be made except in cases of emergency upon twentyfour hours notice, previously given, of such special meetings with the purpose of the meeting having been previously stated.
No alterations of the act shall be made by anyone during the year 195253 not herein expressly provided for.
Provided, the Senator, with a majority of the Aiken County Legislative Delegation may make changes or alterations in the terms of this act whenever in their judgment circumstances so justify.

No appropriation shall be paid in full at any time before the fiscal year ends, except for work or commodities completed or delivered and accepted and in no event shall more than onetwelfth (1/12) of the annual appropriation be paid each month unless some satisfactory explanation therefor is made and the Senator and at least a majority of the delegation approve the same, except that the hospital appropriation may be paid quarterly.

The sheriff shall transfer any money on hand unclaimed to the county treasurer, who shall place same in the ordinary county fund to be used for county purposes by the county, taking his receipt for same, specifying the source thereof, if known and should the sheriff ever find it necessary to recall any part thereof, the same shall be refunded.
The laws heretofore enacted as to charges of magistrates and constables in cases of checks issued in violation of the criminal statutes are hereby reenacted.

That where additional appropriations are authorized herein, they shall be paid from any monies on hand not otherwise appropriated, and should there be none, the funds shall be raised as is directed in this act for raising funds under similar circumstances.
In all matters coming before the commissioners, the supervisor as chairman, shall have the right to vote.

The clerk of the county commissioners shall, during the year, file with the clerk of court quarterly reports (on September 30th, December 30th, March 31st and June 30th) of all monies expended specifying the work performed and the commodity purchased, itemizing the articles so purchased and giving the names of the party or parties from whom such purchases are made and the dates thereof, and of all monies due and owing for purchases made by the supervisor, and send a copy of same to each member of the Legislative Delegation of Aiken County.

No more than onetwelfth (1/12) of the appropriation for roads, bridges, ferries, chaingang expenses shall be paid out of each month unless where materials contracted for road work or bridges that become mandatury to keep up this department, and in this case, there must be reduction in proportion to the over amount spent in the next succeeding month so as the amount appropriated shall continue to operate this department, the twelve months, and in no case shall the expenditure be more than appropriated.
Provided, further, that in case of emergency the delegation may write authorities for a sum sufficient to meet the emergency.

In the purchase of equipment, or articles needed in the operation of any branch of the county government, or in the emplovment of any person, firm or corporation, for any service to be rendered to the County of Aiken, preference shall be given citizens of Aiken County, if available, but if not available, same may be purchased from, or such employment given to, any other citizens of South Carolina.
That is to say, in sums not exceeding onetwelfth (1/12) part of the appropriation for the officers in any one month unless otherwise specifically provided for by the terms of this act.

And in the event of the expenditure for any such approPriations, or any part thereof, is rendered unnecessary by reason of the inability of any such officer to operate his or her automobile or for any other cause whatsoever, then the county board of commissioners is authorized and hereby directed to discontinue the payment of the expense allowance to any such officer.

Any unexpended balance of the appropriations referred to in Section 23 remaining for the reasons stated in Section 23, and likewise any appropriations, or any part thereof, herein made for any department or special purpose which may not be needed by the department or special purpose for which appropriated shall be transferred to any other department or purpose when so ordered by the Senator and a majority of the Aiken County Legislative Delegation or revert to the general county funds at the end of the fiscal year.

The Aiken County Legislative Delegation shall meet at the commissioners office at such times as may be necessary to consider any matters of interest to the citizens of Aiken County and to consider other matters which may come before it; the meetings shall be called by the Senator and a majority of the House Legislative Delegation of the county.

The supervisor shall pay over monthly to the Treasurer of Aiken County all monies realized by him from the sale of any county property, including farm commodities, rentals, etc. The supervisor shall at the time of making such monthly remittance, file with the treasurer a verified report showing in detail all articles sold, the prices received therefrom, the party or parties to whom sold and the date thereof.

All county officers shall open and close their offices as follows: Monday through Friday, open at 9:00 oclock A.M., and close at 5:00 P.M., and shall not close during lunch hours; Saturday, open at 9:00 oclock A.M., and close at 1:00 oclock P.M.

Provided, however, that no employees, excepting law enforcement personnel, shall be required to work more than forty hours per week except in case of acute emergency, when the employees shall be paid for such overtime.
Provided, further, that all employees of Aiken County shall be allowed two weeks vacation each year with pay.

The Treasurer of Aiken County shall credit to the subsistence fund of the county jail, and same shall be in addition thereto such funds as may be received from the subsistence of federal prisoners, and any expense of such subsistence shall be charged against the subsistence fund of the county jail herein provided for, and so much as may be necessary for such purpose shall be expended from such source.
This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 27th day of March, 1952.

911 An Act To Authorize The Auditor Of Aiken County To Report That Certain Property Under Condemnation By The United States Government Was Returned For Taxes, Where Such Fact Cannot Be Determined To The Contrary With Reasonable Certainty.

Whereas, in the Savannah River Area, in many cases, it is almost impossible for the Auditor of Aiken County to determine definitely whether or not certain property has been returned for tax purposes ; and Whereas, condemnation proceedings by the United States Government and settlement with the owner for taxes has necessitated that such determination be made.
Now, therefore, Re it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1.

Aiken County auditor report certain property returned for taxation.The Auditor of Aiken County is authorized and directed to report to the landowner and/or the United States that property located within the Savannah River Project, being purchased by the United States, under condemnation or otherwise, was returned for taxes during any year or years in question, where the Auditor cannot, with reasonable certainty, determine that such is not the case.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 6th day of March, 1952.
912 An Act To Authorize And Direct The County Board Of Aiken County To Transfer And Convey By Proper Instrument All School Property Held By It To The County Board Of Education Of Aiken County.

Aiken County Board convey school property to Aiken County Board of Education.The County Board of Aiken County is hereby authorized and directed to transfer and convey by proper instrument all school property, both real and personal, in Aiken County held by it to the County Board of Education of Aiken County.
