914 An Act To Authorize The Board Of Education Of Aiken County To Issue And Sell Not Exceeding Two anaes TwentyFive Thousand Dollars ($225,000.00) In Serial Coupon Bonds To Be Used For The Purchase Or Landscaping Of Lands, The Purchase Of Buildings, Or The Construction, Erection, Equipping, Or Renovation Of School Buildings In The Area Of Former Gregg School District No.
3; And To Provide For The Levy And Collection Of A Tax For The Payment Thereof.
Aiken County issue bonds for improvements in Gregg School District No.

3The Board of Education of Aiken County is hereby authorized to issue not exceeding two hundred twentyfive thousand dollars ($225,000.00) in bonds, the proceeds of which shall be used for one or more of the following purposes: the purchase of lands; the landscaping of lands; or the construction, erection, equipping, or renovation or purchase of school buildings in the area of Gregg School District No.

Bonds.The bonds shall be serial coupon bonds and shall mature at the discretion of the Board of Education of Aiken County and the County Superintendent of Education of Aiken County and shall bear interest not exceeding four per cent per annum payable annually or semiannually.

The bonds shall be signed by the members of the board of education or a majority thereof and the Treasurer of Aiken County, but the signature of the chairman of the board of education lithographed or engraved upon the interest coupons attached to the bonds shall be a sufficient signing thereof.

The proceeds derived from the sale of the bonds shall be deposited with the Treasurer of Aiken County to the credit of the board of education and shall be disbursed and paid out for the purposes herein stated upon warrants drawn thereon and signed by the proper authorities as now provided by law for the payment of ordinary school obligations.

Pledge to pay.The bonds, when executed as above provided, shall be a binding obligation of the county, and the full faith, credit, and taxing power of the county is hereby irrevocably pledged for the payment thereof.

Payment.For the purpose of paying principal and interest on the bonds as they mature, the Auditor of Aiken County shall levy, and the Treasurer of Aiken County shall collect, annually, a tax on all taxable property in the county sufficient to pay the principal installments and the interest becoming due in each year, and the treasurer shall apply the proceeds of such tax, as collected annually, to the payment of the bonds and interest thereon until they have been fully paid.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 22nd day of March, 1952.

917 An Act To Continue The Terms Of Office Of The Present Mayor And Members Of The Town Council Of The Town Of Ellenton In Aiken County To December 31, 1953 And To Confer Additional Powers On This Body, And To Provide For The Filling Of Any Vacancy Arising From Any Cause.
Terms of mayor, councilmen and clerk of Ellenton extendedvacancyadditional powers.The present mayor, Honorable H.
W. Risher, and the present members of the Town Council of the Town of Ellenton, in Aiken County, namely, Honorable A.
P. Miller, Honorable J. E. Steed, Honorable H.
M. Cassels, III, and Honorable Paul H. Culbreath, are continued in office to December 31, 1953, notwithstanding their present terms expire prior thereto.

In addition to the powers now vested in and exercised by the Mayor and Town Council of the Town of Ellenton, they are authorized and empowered to do anything and everything necessary to wind up the business affairs of the Town of Ellenton.

Special authority is conferred upon the mayor and council to sell and convey to the United States of America, or any agency designated by it, the real and personal property owned by the town and any such conveyance may be executed on behalf of the town by the mayor and the clerk of the council.

They are also authorized to receive all monies due the town and, after discharging all legal obligations, to donate these funds to one or more public or charitable institutions as, in the opinion and discretion of these officials, is conducive to the public welfare.
Honorable J. E. Steed shall continue in office as the clerk of the council.

In the event of any vacancy occurring in the office of mayor or in the council, the remaining members of the council, including the mayor, each with one vote, shall have the right and it shall be their duty to select one to fill the vacancy.
Such appointee must have been a qualified elector of the Town of Ellenton within five years immediately preceding the, effective date of this act.

The costs and expenses of the levy, advertising and sale of lands heretofore or hereafter purchased by the Forfeited Land Commission under tax sale, shall be paid by the treasurer on warrants of the county board, approved by the county delegation, out of any funds available therefor; Provided, that the proceeds of the sale of lands sold by the Forfeited Land Commission shall be chargeable with all such costs and expenses, and, if such claims are paid from funds not so realized, then all amounts paid from the general county fund shall be replaced from sales of land when made by the Forfeited Land Commission.
Such obligations shall be signed by the treasurer and the chairman of the county board of directors, attested by the clerk of such board.

The county board of directors is hereby authorized to repay all municipalities of the county for chaingang labor received through the courts of such municipalities by work of the county chaingang upon the streets and drainage of such municipalities; Provided, that such municipalities shall pay for the dieting of all prisoners while so engaged in work upon the streets or drainage of such municipalities, shall be liable for any damage to persons or property caused by the use of such convict labor and machinery, and the county shall not in any way be responsible for such damage.

The legislative delegation is hereby granted full power and authority to direct and provide for the expenditure of such sums as in its discretion may be deemed necessary for any purpose not herein provided.

lendale County to issue any voucher for the sa 1 iry of any officer herein provided for before the end of the month that such officer is entitled to receive such salary.

That before the county directors shall issue a voucher to any magistrate of Allendale County for his salary, such magistrate shall present his docket to the county board of directors showing the disposition of all cases handled by him during each month and also present to the county directors a receipt or receipts from the county treasurer for all fines tiiposcd by said magistrate.

That the Forfeited Land Commission for Allendale County is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to rent all property owned and held by the Forfeited Land Commission of Allendale County and pay the proceeds of all rents so collected to the county treasurer in accordance with the provisions of law now existing and no fees shall be charged for such services by the Forfeited Land Commission nor by the tax collector.

The sums herein appropriated as compensation for the county board of directors shall he in lieu of any expense which they incur in inspection of the various county roads, which inspections shall be made semimonthly by the directors.
All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are herehy repealed.
This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 27th day of March, 1952.

The county health officer is hereby authorized and ditected to treat persons in Anderson County, regardless of whether they live in rural communities or in municipalities, who desire treatment for syphilis and gonorrhea and to charge for such treatment the sum of two and onehalf dollars, and any funds accruing from such treatment shall be used only for the purchase of supplies and drugs for this treatment; Provided, however, that in the event the county health officer finds that such afflicted person is financially unable to pay the above charge, then the official may give such treatment without costs; Provided, further, that in carrying out the treatment herein provided, the county health officer is hereby authorized and directed, if he deems it necessary, to call upon the county physician as provided in Item I9 hereof from time to time to assist in such treatment and it is hereby made the duty of the county physician to render such assistance; Provided, further, that the county health officer is hereby authorized and directed to administer drugs and biologicals to residents of municipalities in Anderson County to the same extent and under the same circumstances as now administered by him to residents of Anderson County living outside of municipalities and in doing this, he is hereby given the right to require the services of the county physician.

For the services as jurors in coroners inquests each person so drawn and who serves shall receive compensation in the sum of two dollars for each inquest, to be paid out of the amount appropriated under Item N.

The county supervisor is hereby directed to pay the members of the Township Boards of Assessors immediately upon completion of their work being certified to by the county auditor, and funds for this payment are provided under Item F of this act.

The county board of commissioners is further authorized to pay to the supervisor from the amount appropriated for road maintenance in Item A1 of Section 2 of this act, the estimated actual expenses of the supervisors travel in the performance of his necessary duties in the supervision of roads and convicts, not to exceed nine hundred dollars ($900.00).
An additional tax of two and onehalf mills on the taxable property of Anderson County is hereby levied for public school purposes.

Of this amount an amount not greater than the revenue realized from the levy of onehalf mill shall be used to pay tuition of high school pupils attending high school from without the district; an amount not greater than the revenue realized from the levy of onehalf mill shall be used to pay the cost of free readers as now provided by law; an amount not to exceed the amount realized by onehalf mill levy in the district or districts sending pupils into high schools outside of Anderson County as tuition to be paid to high schools outside of Anderson County, and this amount shall be prorated on a per pupil basis and shall be all the tuition paid by Anderson County to high school districts outside of Anderson County ; Provided, that all funds raised by the two and onehalf mill levy above referred to, not above allocated or the expenditure thereof hereafter provided, shall be used in the payment of such public school costs in Anderson County, including transportation of school children as provided by law in this state, as the county board of education may deem necessary; Provided, further, that from the amount received by the county board of education from the collection of delinquent taxes, fees and executions and from the sale of marriage licenses, the county board of education is hereby authorized and directed to pay the salary of the assistant county superintendent of education in an amount within the discretion of the board, the salary of the stenographer in the county Superintendents office, not to exceed one thousand nine hundred eighty dollars ($1,980.00) per annum, the salary of the members of the county board of education not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) per annum; the estimated actual expense travel within the county by the superintendent of education not to exceed six hundred dollars ($600.00) per annum; and an amount not to exceed fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for furnishing free textbooks to the poor pupils of the public schools of Anderson County and an amount not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) to purchase books for the circulating library, and the remainder received by the county board of education from the collection of delinquent taxes, fees and executions, shall be used for general school purposes; Provided, further, that out of the money raised by the two and onehalf mill levy provided herein, the county board of education is authorized to use a sum not to exceed nine thousand dollars ($9,000.00) for public school music in various schools of Anderson County under such program as the county board of education, including the county superintendent of education, may deem proper; Provided, however, that out of this sum the county board of education is authorized to increase the salaries of the two musical directors in the same ratio as other county employees; Provided, further, that in the event any school district in Anderson County raises any sum for the purchase of library books, the county board of education is hereby authorized and directed to match such district funds up to but not exceeding twentyfive dollars; Provided, further, that the county board of education is hereby authorized to pay two employees of the circulating library a monthly salary of one hundred sixtyfive dollars ($165.00) each; Provided, further, that no funds coming into the hands of the county board of education from any source, shall be used by the superintendent of education and/or.the county board of education to be distributed among the various school districts of Anderson County as building aid; Provided, further, that the county board of education is authorized and empowered to expend a sum not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for adult education, the same to be paid out of general school funds.

The acceptance by the county board of education of the county of any portion of the funds appropriated in this section shall be construed as a relinquishment of any right of the board and any of the schools in the county to receive any portion of any fines imposed for the violation of any of the criminal laws; Provided, further, that all materials and supplies used by the county board of education and in the office of the county superintendent of education in Anderson County shall be bought and paid for through the office of the county supervisor and board of county commissioners as materials and supplies for other county officers are bought and paid for.

It is hereby made a part of the duties of the superintendent of education for Anderson County to prepare and submit to the board of trustees of the various school districts in Anderson County a detailed statement at the end of every fiscal year, showing all expenditures for the preceding year made from the funds of the respective school districts, for what purpose made and to whom paid.
The report shall also set forth the amount of any funds on hand by each of the districts, together with any outstanding indebtedness and the status of same.

The supervisor or other proper county officer is hereby authorized to pay the premium on the official bonds required of the eight deputy sheriffs of Anderson County, and of the three deputies to serve magistrates in the City of Anderson, the jailor, and the clerks in the office of the county treasurer and tax collector.

All salaries as set out in this act are intended as the annual salary of the person designated and are to be paid upon a monthly basis of twelve equal installments for such time as such person shall be in actual service in their respective positions.

All other items hercin are to be expended upon approximately a monthly basis unless such xpenditure is inconsistent with the purpose of the appropriation, but in no event shall a deficit be allowed in any appropriation made herein.

Out of the appropriation under Item J2, Section 2, one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) shall be held by the Anderson County Hospital, subject to the order of the Anderson County Federation of Womens Clubs, to pay the expenses of patients cared for by the Maternity Fund of the organization.

The remainder of the appropriation shall be paid out in the following manner: The hostital shall consider only cases eligible for the benefits of this fund when on careful examination such patients are found unable to pay for their necessary hospitalization and shall require of such patient an application similar in form to the one now required, and the hospital records of each case, including application, shall at all times be available to inspection by the Supervisor and Board of County Commissioners of Anderson County.

The hospital shall submit to the surervisor and board of county commissioners a monthly statement setting forth the names of the patients and the number of days it was found necessary that they be in the hospital.
The hospital shall then be paid six dollars per patient per day for patients listed on such statements not found by the Department of Public Welfare to be financially able to bear their own expenses.

It shall be necessary that a ze be approved as for charity by the Department of Public Welfare before admission except in cases of emergency: Provided, that as a condition precedent to receiving any of the funds herein appropriated the Anderson County Hospital shall furnish all medication to charity patients: Provided, that the supervisor and board of county commissioners shall include in their quarterly report the amount paid for charity patients.

Out of the amount appropriated herein under Ttem N, the sunervisor and board of county commissioners are hereby authorized and directed to pay the costs of post mortems and lunacy e a <uminations at the rate of pay prescribed by law.
Payment herein previded for shall be made upon certification by the coroner as to post mortems and by the probate judge as to lunacy examinations, Section 12.

The Coroner of Anderson County is hereby authorized to employ the stenographer serving the Special Magistrate in Anderson County, or any other suitable person, to take testimony at coroners inquests in Anderson County and pay for such service not more than five dollars per inquest, said payment shall be made by the Supervisor and Board of County Commissioners of Anderson County out of the funds herein appropriated as Court Expenses, and the payments shall be made upon vouchers approved by the Coroner of Anderson County.

The supervisor and board of county commissioners are hereby directed to pay the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00) to the Solicitor of the Tenth Judicial Circuit for his expenses and for his services in attending Special Magistrates Court.
This sum shall be paid in monthly installments out of the amount appropriated herein as Court Expenses Item D1.

That upon the estreating of any bond and upon the amount adjudged against the bondsmen being paid to the Clerk of Anderson County before judgment is entered upon in judgment roll, then in such event, the clerk is authorized to enter collection of the amount in his fine book and it shall not be necessary for the clerk to enter up judgment in customary judgment roll.

The patients to be treated at State Park as provided in Section 2, J5, herein, shall be designated by the County Legislative Delegation of Anderson County and it is hereby specifically provided that no patient shall be permitted to occupy a bed herein provided for a greater period than six months, Section 16.

Out of the fines collected by the Clerk of Court of General Sessions and paid over to the county treasurer, the county treasurer is hereby authorized to remit to the South Carolina Police Insurance and Annuity Fund such sums as may be due the fund under the South Carolina Law.

The county board of commissioners is further authorized to pay out of the amount appropriated under Item A1 of Section 2 of this act, a sum not exceeding three thousand six hundred ninetysix dollars ($3,696.00) for a county engineer.
Provided, further, that if it will be to the interest of the traveling public the surface treating of a road in the program may be extended to a distance not exceeding onehalf mile.

Any funds now in the hands of the Treasurer of Anderson County, not heretofore or hereby designated to be used for some specified purpose, shall be held by the Treasurer of Anderson County in a fund to be known as the Anderson County Surplus Fund.

Also, any funds coming into the hands of the county treasurer from any source provided by this act, not herein appropriated for some particular purpose, shall, at the close of the fiscal year covered by this act, be added to the Anderson County Surplus Fund as provided for in this section.

The Anderson County Surplus Fund shall not be used for any purpose except upon the written authorization and direction to the County Treasurer of Anderson County by the Senator of Anderson County and at least onehalf of the members of the House of Representatives of Anderson County.
The supervisor and board of county commissioners are hereby authorized to pay the Anderson County Deputy Sheriffs located in the industrial communities, the sum of sixty dollars per month.

As a bounty for the killing of foxes in Anderson County, the supervisor is hereby authorized and directed to pay the sum of two dollars per fox, same to be paid out of money appropriated under Item N of Section 2 of this act.

Before issuing such certificate, the county game warden is hereby required to have the applicant for the bounty produce a sufficient amount of the skin from the head of the fox or foxes as will have the two ears attached thereto.

Any unused funds in the 19511952 budget for the county health department shall be retained by the department and added to the budget made herein for the 19521953 fiscal year to be used by the Anderson County Health Officer and County Board of Health as they may see fit.
If any word, clause, sentence or section of this act be declared unconstitutional, such shall not affect any other word, clause, sentence or section hereof.
This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 4th day of April, 1952.
920 An Act To Transfer Monies Of Anderson County Accumulated Under Section 5 Of Act No.

623 Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions, South Carolina, 1946, Relating To The Issuance And Sale Of Bonds Of The County And The Construction Of Roads In The County, To The Supervisor And County Commissioners Of The County, To Be Used By Them In Constructing, Surface Treating And Resurface Treating Certain Roads In Anderson County.

623 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions, South Carolina, 1946, relating to the issuance and sale of bonds of Anderson County, for the purpose of constructing, surface treating and resurface treating roads in the county, a fund thereby established ] for the payment of bonds and interest thereon issued is great ly in excess of that needed for the retirement of the bonds and will continue to exceed the amount necessary to retire the bonds and interest thereon after transferring therefrom the monies provided to be transferred in this act.
Transfer funds for road improvements, Anderson County.Of and from funds of Anderson County accumulated under Section 5 of Act No.

623 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions, South Carolina, 1946, relating to the issuance and sale of bonds of Anderson County and the construction of roads in the county, the sum of two hundred twentyfive thousand dollars ($225,000.00) is hereby transferred to the supervisor and county board of commissioners of the county to be expended by them in the construction, surface treatment and resurface treatment of the roads designated in the act and any amendments thereto, Provided, that the sum of one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) be transferred as soon as practicable: and that the sum of seventyfive thousand dollars ($75,000.00) be transferred after July 1, 1952.

Apportionment of improvements.E.ach sioner District of Anderson County will receive its equitable share of such improvements, the roads to be improved shall be selected by a majority vote of the six members of the county board of commissioners which membership is composed of the five district commissioners and supervisor, and in selecting the roads for improvement they shall be so chosen as to give each district an equitable share of said improvement.

921 An Act To Enlarge The Territorial Limits Of Homeland Park Water And Sewerage District, In Anderson County, To Extend The Powers Vested In The Governing Body Of The District To The District As Thus Enlarged, To Empower The Governing Body Of The District To Issue Bonds, Whose Proceeds Shall Be Used To Refund Certain Outstanding Bonds Of The District And To Obtain Funds To Provide Further Water Facilities Of The District, To Make Provision For The Payment Of Certain Bonds, And To Further Prescribe The Powers And Duties Of The Governing Body Of The District.
Legislative findings.(1) The General Assembly finds that by Act 1101 of 1950 (46 Stat.

at Large, page 2768), it created Homeland Park Water and Sewerage District, in Anderson County, and committed to the commission established to operate the district the function of providing necessary and adequate sewerage lines, sewerage disposal plants, water lines, and drainage facilities therein, and furnishing water to the consumers thereof in the district, and for furnishing fire fighting facilities and other facilities.
Afterwards, by Act 464 of 1951 (47 Stat.

at Large, page 900), it empowered the Homeland Park Water and Sewerage Commission to issue bonds of the district to the extent of one hundred thirtyfive thousand dollars ($135,000.00), for the purpose of securing funds to provide water for the inhabitants of the district, and for whose payment there was pledged the full faith and credit of the district and the net revenues derived from the operation of the water system to be constructed, or as thereafter enlarged.

As of January 1, 1951, the commission issued one hundred thirtyfive thousand dollars ($135,000.00) of bonds of the district, which are scheduled to mature as follows: $4,000 on January first, in each of the years 1953 to 1958, inclusive; $5,000 on January first, in each of the years 1959 to 1964, inclusive; 1969, $6,000 on January first, in each of the years 1965 to inclusive; $7,000 on January first, in each of the years 1970 to 1974, inclusive; and, $8,000 on January first, in each of the years 1975 and 1976.

Such of the bonds above set forth which mature in each of the years 1953 to 1959, inclusive, bear interest at the rate of three and onehalf per cent per annum, while the remaining bonds bear interest at the rate of three and threequarters per cent per annum.

The bonds maturing subsequent to January 1, 1953, have been made subject to redemption on January 1, 1953, or any subsequent interest payment date, at par, plus accrued interest, plus a redemption premium of five per cent of the face amount of each bond.

(2) The General Assembly now finds that the area surrounding the district is becoming rapidly populated, and that the inhabitants of such surrounding area are in need of, and should be furnished with, similar facilities to those living in the district, for which reason the General Assembly has determined to enlarge the district in the manner provided for in this act.

Estimates of the cost of extending water lines to the area to be added to the district have been made, indicating the necessity of an expenditure of something in excess of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00).
To raise such sum, it is necessary that the district be empowered to borrow.

In view of the fact that the present outstanding bonds have been additionally secured by a pledge of the net revenues of the system, it is deemed desirable to secure further bonds in similar fashion, which would make it necessary to retire the outstanding bonds, and sell a new issue, whose proceeds should be sufficient and would be used: (1), to effect the retirement of the outstanding bonds, including such sums as may be necessary to pay principal and redemption premiums; (2), to pay the costs and expenses of the extensions to the water system; and, (3), to pay any costs and expenses incident to the financing thus contemplated.
The aggregate of all of these is estimated at two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00).

(3) The General Assembly has further decided to enlarge the powers of the commission, by authorizing it to keep the funds derived from the charges made for water in an account, separate and apart from other funds of the district, all of which are now held by the Treasurer of Anderson County.

Homeland Park Water and Sewerage District, Anderson Countyboundaries.Upon the effective date of this act, Homeland Park Water and Sewerage District, in Anderson County, shall be comprised of the territory in the county, lying within the following boundaries: Beginning at the intersection of the city limits of the City of Anderson, with Cleveland Avenue and White Street; thence south along the center of White Street to a branch; thence east along said branch for a distance of four hundred (400) feet; thence south along a line paralleling White Street and at a distance of four hundred (400) feet to the east of where White Street crosses the Piedmont and Northern Railroad and continuing south to a point where said line intersects with Shockley Ferry Road (or U. S.
29 Truck Route); thence southwestwardly along the center of said Schockley Ferry Road (U. S.
29 Truck Route) for a distance of four hundred (400) feet to a point where said Shockley Ferry Road (U. S.

29 Truck Route) intersects with the aforesaid White Street ; thence southeastwardly along said White Street to a point four hundred ersec (400) feet south of the intersection of White Street and the George Albert Lake Road; thence southwestwardly along a line paralleling the George Albert Lake Road and being four hundred (400) feet south therefrom, said line crossing an unnamed road and continuing southwestwardly until it intersects with South McDuffie Street Extension; thence in a southwardly disection along the center of South McDuffie Street Extension to a point where said street intersects with the Anderson Abbeville Highway; thence continuing in a southwardly direction along the center of the Air Line Road to a point where said road intersects and adjoins property of Mrs. Pearl Prince and the Seybt property; thence southwestwardly along a line bounded South by property of Mrs. Pearl Prince and L. C. Drake and bearing South 56 degrees 45 minutes West for a distance of 2430 feet to a point; thence southwardly along a line intersecting Keys Street and continuing along said line bearing South 16 degrees 08 minutes West for a distance of 625 feet to a point on the North of lands of Gary Keys Howard; thence along said property of Gary Keys Howard on a line bearing North 78 degrees 45 minutes West for a distance of 1076.5 feet to a point on Gluck Mill property; thence northwestwardly along Gluck Mill property on a line bearing North 19 degrees East for a distance of 704.9 feet to a point; thence westwardly along Gluck Mill property on a line bearing North 65 degrees 30 minutes West for a distance of 3,105.9 feet crossing Calvert Street and crossing South Main Street Extension and continuing to a point a short distance East of the C.
& W. C. Railroad; thence southwardly along a line just east of and paralleling the C.
& W. C. Railroad for distance of approximately 1050 feet to a point; thence westwardly crossing said C.

& W. C. Railroad and following Gluck Mill property line and passing beyond and west of the dead end of Plainvie w Road for a distance of approximately 1500 fect to a point; thence northeastwardly along a line paralleling Plainview Road and 400 feet west of said Plainview Road for a distance of approximately 1750 feet to a point just south of Masters Drive; thence northwestwardly crossing Masters Drive and continuing for approximately 600 feet to a point intersecting property known as Varennes Heights; thence continuing along the Varennes Heights property on a line bearing South 88 degrees 13 minutes West to a point; thence South 55 degrees 05 minutes West for 223.4 feet to a point; thence North 48 degrees 51 minutes West for a distance of 2773 feet to a point on U. S. Highway No.
29; thence in a northeastwardly direction along the center of U. S. Highway No.
29 to intersection with U. S. Highway No.
20 Truck Route and continuing from that point along the center of U. S. Highway No.
29 Truck Route crossing C.

& W. C. Railroad and continuing to a point where U. S. Highway No, 29 Truck Route intersects with South Main Street Extension; thence from said point of intersection northwardly along the center of South Main Street to the city limits of the City of Anderson: thence eastwardly along the Anderson City Limits Line to the beginning point on the intersection of Cleveland Avenue and White Street.

Plat filingAs soon as may be practicable, the Homeland Park Water and Sewerage Commission shall cause a plat, showing the boundaries of the district, to be made, the original of which shall he filed in the office of the Clerk of Court for Anderson County, and copies or prints thereof shall be filed with the auditor and treasurer of the county.
Powers of commissionAll powers granted to the commission of the district as originally constituted shall extend to and be applicable to the district as herein enlarged.

In addition, the commission shall be empowered to deposit all receipts from the operation of its water svstem in a separate bank account, which shall be subject to withdrawal upon proper order of the commission.

Garbageseptic tanks.In addition to the powers now vested in the commission, it shall be empowered to regulate the colsection and disposal of garbage, and, until a system of sewerage shall be established in the district, may promulgate reasonable rules regarding the establishment and maintenance of septic tanks for the disposal of sewage and other wastes.

Redemption and payment of certain bonds.The discretionary right reserved in the Homeland Park Water and Sewerage District to redeem and pay its outstanding bonds on and after January 1, 1953, is confirmed.

Commission issue bondsuse of proceeds.In order to provide for the redemption of the outstanding bonds of Homeland Park Water and Sewerage District, heretofore described, and in order to provide further funds to extend water lines as far as practicable throughout the district, as it is constituted by this act, including all costs and expenses incident to each, Homeland Park Water and Sewerage Commission shall be empowered to issue two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) of bonds of the district.

Interestmaturitiesredemption.The bonds shall bear such date as the commission shall determine, on or after March 1, 1952, and shall bear such rate or rates of interest as the commission shall approve, payable annually or semiannually.

The bonds shall mature in such annual series or instalments as the commission may prescribe and may, at the discretion of the commission, contain provisions permitting the redemption of all, or a part of the bonds, prior to their stated maturities with or without premiums.

Execution.The bonds shall be executed in the name of Homeland Park Water and Sewerage District by the Chairman and the Secretary of the Homeland Park Water and Sewerage District Commission, under the official seal of the commission.
The coupons appertaining to such bonds shall be authenticated by the facsimile signatures of the chairman and the secretary lithographed or engraved thereon.

SalevThe bonds may be sold by the commission at not less than par and accrued interest to date of delivery, at either public or private sale, and if public sale, the form, manner and occasion of advertisement shall be determined by the commission.

Exempt from taxes.The bonds and the interest to become due thereon shall be exempt from all state, county,municipal, school district, and all other taxes or assessments, direct or indirect, general or special, whether imposed for the purpose of general revenue or otherwise.
This provision shall be deemed a part of the contract, inuring to the benefit of all holders or beneficiaries of the bonds.

Deposit and application of proceeds.The proceeds derived from the sale of the bonds herein authorized shall be deposited with the Treasurer of Anderson County in a special fund, separate and distinct from all other funds.

The treasurer shall immediately set aside such sum as shall be necessary to meet the payment of the principal, interest and redemption premiums on all outstanding bonds of the district and shall apply such sum for such purposes.

The remaining sums shall be held by the Treasurer of Anderson County, and shall be applied to the remaining purposes for which the bonds are issued, and shall be expended upon warrants or orders of the commission.

Payment.For the payment of the bonds, both principal and interest, as the same, respectively become due, there shall be pledged the full faith, credit, resources and taxing power of Homeland Park Water and Sewerage District, and in addition, the net revenues derived from the operation of the water system.

In order to meet the payment of the principal and interest of the bonds as the same shall become due, the Auditor of Anderson County shall annually levy and the Treasurer of Anderson County shall annually collect a tax upen all taxable property in the district, sufficient to pay the principal and interest of the bonds as they respectively become due, provided alwavs that on or before the occasion when such tax must be levied the commission shall remit to the Treasurer of Anderson County the net revenues which it may have derived from the operation of its water system, exclusive of payments made into any Cushion Fund established pursuant to Section 16, infra, and the tax herein ordered levied shall be reduced in each year to the extent of the net revenues which are actually in the hands of the treasurer at the time the tax for such year must be levied, and the tax may be entirely suspended for any vear in case such moneys on hand, applicable as aforesaid, are sufficient to pay both principal and interest then due or falling due in such year and remaining unpaid.

For the purposes of this act, net revenues shall mean all sums realized, directly or indirectly, for charges made for water services, after deducting therefrom such amounts as the commission shall find it necessary to expend in order te operate and maintain the system in good repair and working order, and after making reasonable provision for depreciation and contingencies.

Pledge of net revenues for payment of bonds.The pledge of net revenues authorized by Section 13, supra, shall not be deemed exclusive and closed if, on the occasion the commission shall provide for the issuance of bonds pursuant to this act, it shall reserve the right to issue other bonds on a parity with the bonds issued pursuant to this act, in which event the commission shall be empowered to prescribe the conditions under which it may later issue bonds of the district, secured in whole or in part by a pledge of the net revenues of the district.

In the event that the commission does not elect the privilege granted to it by this provision, it shall so provide in the proceedings taken to issue bonds pursuant to this act, and in any event such bonds shall contain a statement on their face indicating whether the pledge of net revenues, made to secure them, is exclusive, or whether such revenues may be later pledged, in whole or in part.
for any other bonds which the district is now, or may hereafter be authorized to issue.

Operation and maintenance of systemadditional covenants by commissionThe commission shall covenant with the holders of any of its bonds to operate the system in a workmanlike fashion and keep the same in good repair and working order.

It shall also be empowered, in its discretion, to make provision for the establishment of a Cushion Fund to further secure the orderly payment of the principal and interest of its bonds, and to make such other and further covenants as are customarily made in the issuance of revenue bonds, and all covenants which the governing bodies are empowered to make, pursuant to Chapter 187, Volume 4, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1942, as now or hereafter constituted.
Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 20th day of February, 1952
922 An Act To Amend Section 3 Of Act No.

1101, Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions Of The General Assembly, 1950, As Amended, Relating To The Homeland Park Water And Sewerage District Of Anderson County, So As To Provide For The Election Of The Commissioners, To Fix Their Compensation, And Make Other Provisions Relative To The Administration Of The Act.
Act 1101 of 1950 amendedHomeland Park Water and Sewerage District Commissionbond of secretary and treasurer.Section 3 of Act No.

1101 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, 1950, as amended, relating to the Homeland Park Water and Sewerage District, is amended by striking the entire section and inserting in lieu thereof the following: section 3 (A) The district shall be governed by a commission known as the Homeland Park Water and Sewerage District Commission.
The commission shall he composed of five citizens and resident qualified electors of the district who shall be elected by the people of the district.

At the first election the two candidates receiving the highest number of votes shall serve for a period of four years and the three candidates receiving the next highest number of votes shall serve for a term of two years; thereafter the terms shall be for four vears.
Any vacancy occurring shall be filled by appointment by the Governor, upon the recommendation of the legislative delegation, including the Senator, for the unexpired term.

Provided, that the commission shall determine the date of the first election which shall be not more than ninety days after the effective date of this act, and shall advertise such date in a newspaper of general circulation in Anderson County not less than two weeks prior to the holding of such election.
(B) Immediately upon their election, the commission shall meet and elect a chairman and secretary and treasurer from its membership.

Each of the members shall receive as compensation for all services rendered by him the sum of five dollars for each day's attendance upon any meeting of the commission; provided, that no member shall receive more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) in any one year.

The secretary and treasurer shall furnish a bond payable to the commission in a sum not less than five thousand dollars (85,000.00), and in such larger amount as the commission may require, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties.
The surety on such bond shall be a corporation or company duly licensed to do business in this state.

The premium on the bond shall be paid by the commission out of any funds in its hands applicable to such purpose. Section 2. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
This Act became effective March 10, 1952, over the objection of the Governor.

923 An Act To Provide For The Levy Of Taxes For County Purposes In Bamberg County For The Fiscal Year Beginning July 1, 1952, And Ending June 30, 1953, And For The Expenditure Thereof; To Fix The Compensation Of Certain Officers And Otherwise Relating To The Fiscal Affairs Of Bamberg County.

The County Auditor of Bamberg County is hereby directed to levy a tax of five mills on all of the taxable property in Bamberg County, the proceeds thereof to be turned over to the trustees of the Bamberg County Memorial Hospital to be used by them in supplementing other revenue received by the said trustees in operating the hospital during the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1952 and ending June 30, 1953; in the event that said funds are not needed for this purpose during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1953, then the funds are to be held by the Treasurer of Bamberg County until they are needed for said purpose.

The trustees of the hospital are authorized to refer all cases requesting hospital assistance to the Department of Public Welfare of Bamberg County, and the Department of Public Welfare is authorized and directed to investigate and make recommendations as to all such cases.

The County Auditor of Bamberg is hereby directed to levy a tax on all of the taxable property in the County of Bamberg for ordinary county purposes, for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1952, and ending June 30, 1953, the revenue derived from such tax and other funds to be expended in the amounts and for the purposes hereinafter stated, that is to say: Item 1.

Appropriation made under the foregoing section for the Office of Sheriff and the Office of Treasurer of Bamberg County is intended to be full compensation for their respective services, including expenses, in lieu of all tax execution fees, and all tax execution fees collected for said offices shall be by them, respectively, paid over to the treasurer and by him credited to the Genral County Fund.
No charge shall be made by the auditor for entries upon the books of his office of any transfer of real estate by deed or other written instruments.
The commutation road tax shall be considered as a part of the revenue of the county for road purposes, and is not to be expended in addition to the amount appropriated in Item 1 of this act.

The amounts provided for herein for the several purposes shall be expended for the purpose stated and none other, and any unexpended balance in hand at the expiration of the fiscal year shall revert to the general funds of the county.

The appropriation for the contingent fund is to make up for any deficiency in the appropriation of any other item or to cover any contingency which may arise, and is not to be expended without the written consent and authority of the legislative delegation.

No expense allowed under this act shall be paid out in bulk, but is to be for actual expenses incurred in official business, and the supervisor is hereby required to demand and retain proper itemized and verified vouchers for each such expenditure.

It shall be unlawful for the county supervisor or board of commissioners to make any contracts to purchase or to make purchases for an amount exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), without the written consent of the legislative delegation.

Any expense incurred by reason of failure of an officer of the county to perform the duties of his office, as required by law, shall be deducted from the salary of the officer so failing to perform his duty.

No warrant shall be issued to pay any magistrate and his constable until the end of the month, and until such magistrate has filed his report of the proceedings in his court and until such Magistrate shall have filed a bond as provided by law.
The county treasurer is authorized and directed to mail to every taxpayer the same form of notice as provided for under the terms of Section 11 of the Supply Act for Bamberg County for the year 1943.

Section At the end o the scal year the county treasurer, with the approval of the county legislative delegation, is hereby authorized and directed to transfer any surplus appearing in any account to any deficit appearing in any other account, and if the surpluses are not sufficient to cover deficits, the treasurer is authorized and directed to charge the deficit against any surplus funds in hand Section 14.
All marriage license fees hereafter collected by the Probate Judge of Bamberg County shall be retained by him as part compensation for his services Section 15.
The Clerk of Court of Bamberg County is authorized to destroy the record or books of all chattel and crop mortgages recorded prior to the year 1920 Section 16.

Should the trustees of the Bamberg County Memorial Hospital Board find that it needs additional money to temporarily finance a part of the contract for the building of the hospital and nurses home pending the receipt of money from the Federal Government for its portion of the program, then and in that event, the board may request the Treasurer of Bamberg County to borrow money for that purpose.

The Treasurer of Bamberg County, upon receiving such request in writing from the chairman of the board, is hereby authorized to borrow, upon the best available terms, for a period not exceeding six months, in the name of Bamberg County, from any financial institution or from the South Carolina Sinking Fund Commission a sum not to exceed fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), and to pledge the full faith and credit of Bamberg County Section 17.
All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed Section 18.
This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor Approved the 4th day of April, 1952 (R826, H1776) No.

The county jail physician and the county health officer are hereby constituted by the board of physicians to examine all lunacy cases.

Provided, that at the end of the fiscal year 195253 the county treasurer is hereby authorized and directed to transfer any surplus appearing in any account to any deficit appearing in any other account, and if the surpluses are not sufficient to cover deficits the treasurer is authorized and directed to charge said deficit against any surplus funds in hand, upon the written authority of the Legislative Delegation.

In anticipation of the collection of taxes herein provided for, the Board of County Managers and the treasurer are authorized and empowered to borrow, on the credit of the county, such sums as are necessary to carry out the provisions of this act and to pledge current taxes in payment therefor.
Such obligations shall be signed by the treasurer and the chairman of the Board of County Managers, attested by the clerk of such board.

All magistrates hereafter elected and/or appointed before qualifying shall file with the County Board of Managers good and sufficient bond conditioned for the faithful performance of their duties in the sum of $500.00 which said bond shall be approved by the County Board of Managers.

That no lunatics shall hereafter be confined in or committed to the county jail except for a period not exceeding five days awaiting transfer to the State Hospital; and the Probate Judge shall make no charge for any lunacy proceedings held unless the lunatic in question shall actually be committed to the State Hospital.

The County Board of Managers and/or Supervisor are hereby directed to furnish from the chaingang a suitable trusty or trusties to be assigned for work in and about the courthouse and other public buildings and grounds, for the maintenance and upkeep of same, and such shall be under the direction and control of the Superintendent and Maintenance Engineer for Public Buildings.
Provided, the Board of Managers is authorized and directed to assign a trusty from the chaingang as a laborer at the county jail.
The charge for weighing cotton in Barnwell County shall be twenty cents per bale, onehalf of which shall be paid by the buyer and onehalf by the seller.
In the expenditure of the money appropriated in this act, only onetwelfth shall be spent each month, unless upon the written approval of the Legislative Delegation.

There is hereby created a County Board of Health for Barnwell County, which shall be constituted as follows: a medical doctor to be named by the Barnwell County Medical Association, a veterinarian to be named by the veterinarians of Barnwell County, one citizen to be named by the Mayor and Town Council of the Town of Barnwell, one citizen to be named by the Mayor and Town Council of the Town of Blackville and one citizen to be named by the Mayor and Town Council of the Town of Williston.

All expenditures heretofore made for the construction of a new office building and the County health center, the rebuilding, renovation and improvements to the courthouse, the rebuilding of the jail and the prison farm building, and the furnishing and servicing of these buildings, and for any other public places, are hereby approved and ratified.

For aid in construction of joint town halls, health units and/or other public improvements for the protection of health and public conveniences, on account of the impact of population resulting from the construction of the Hbomb plant, there is hereby appropriated $18,000.00 for contributions of $6,000.00 each to Williston, Blackville and Barnwell.
This act shall take effect immediately upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 29th day of February, 1952.
925 An Act To Provide For The Sale And Acquisition Of Certain Lands By The Board Of Managers Of Barnwell County, And To Provide For The Disposition Of The Proceeds.

Barnwell County may convey surplus lands.Upon approval of the Barnwell County Legislative Delegation, the Board of Managers of Barnwell County may convey fee simple title to any lands which are now owned by Barnwell County and are declared by the board of managers to be surplus lands.
Payment of proceeds of salesvThe proceeds of the sales authorized by Section 1 shall be paid into the General Fund of Barnwell County.
Site for hospitalUpon written approval of the Barnwell County Legislative Delegation, the board of managers may acquire land to be used as a location for a county hospital.
In order to pay for the land acquired under this section, the board of managers may apply lands now owned by it toward the purchase price or any part thereof.
Any funds needed for the purchase shall be paid out of the general fund of the county.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 12th day of March, 1952.

926 A Joint Resolution Directing The County Board Of Managers Of Barnwell County To Convey To The Town Of Barnwell A Portion Of The Barnwell County Jail Lot And To Grant To The Town Of Barnwell Certain Easements.

Barnwell County convey lot to Barnwell.The Board of Managers of Barnwell County, South Carolina, is hereby directed, in the name of Barnwell County, South Carolina, to convey to the Town of Barnwell, South Carolina, by deed, without warranty, the fee simple title to the following described lot, to wit: All that certain lot of land in the Town of Barnwell, Barnwell County, State of South Carolina, measuring twentyfive (25) feet on its Northwestern and Southeastern boundary lines and Eighteen (18) feet on its Northeastern and Southwestern boundary lines, and bounded on the Northeast, Northwest and Southwest by remainder of County Jail Lot; and on the southeast by lot of Mrs. Tillie Hogg; said lot being more particularly described on a plat thereof made by S. R. Thompson, Registered Surveyor, on June 29, 1951, and recorded in Plat Book D at page 152 of the records of Barnwell County.

Easement for water mainThe deed authorized in Section 1 shall provide for an easement over, across and under the Barnwell County Jail Lot for the construction, maintenance and operation of a water main across and beneath the surface thereof.
The easement shall be two feet in width and shall extend from the lot described in Section 1 to Main Street as shown by the dotted line on the plat mentioned in Section 1.

The deed shall also provide for liberty of ingress and egress to and from Main Street on and across the adjoining property of the County of Barnwell for the purpose of operating and maintaining a water pump and well constructed on the lot conveyed by the deed.

Easement for sewerage main.The County Board of Managers of Barnwell County is directed to grant, in the name of the County of Barnwell, to the Town of Barnwell, a right of way easement over, across and under the western portion of the Barnwell County Jail Lot for the purpose of constructing, maintaining and operating a public underground sewerage main.

Maintenance of property conveyed.The Town of Barnwell shall maintain in a proper and safe condition the property conveyed under this resolution and shall save the County of Barnwell harmless from any liability which arises in connection therewith after the conveyances provided for in this resolution have been made.
Time effective This resolution shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 14th day of February, 1952.
927 An Act To Provide.
For The Sale Of Certain Lands Owned By Barnwell County And Leased To The Sweetwater Country Club And Golf Course; And To Provide For The Expenditure Of The Proceeds.

Barnwell County may convey certain lands leased to Sweetwater Country Club and Golf Course.Subject to the conditions contained in Section 2 of this act the Board of Managers of Barnwell County may convey fee simple title to all or any part of the land in Barnwell County lying south of State Highway No.
64 toa depth of two hundred (200) feet and lying between the main gate of entry to, and the western boundary of, the Sweetwater Country Club and Golf Course.
This land is a part of the tract of land leased by Barnwell County to the Sweetwater Country Club and Golf Course under Act No.
Approval of saleexecution of deedsuse of proceeds.The sale of the land or any part thereof must be approved by the Barnwell County Legislative Delegation.
Each deed must be signed by the chairman of the county board of managers, the county supervisor, and the President and the Secretary of the Sweetwater Country Club and Golf Course.
The proceeds of the sale of the land or any part thereof shall be expended, upon approval of its officers, for permanent improvements at the Sweetwater Country Club and Golf Course.
Conveyances terminate leasehold interest.All conveyances made under this act shall, as to the land conveyed, terminate the leasehold interest of the Sweetwater Country Club and Golf Course.
RepealAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
928 An Act Relating To The Proceeds Derived From The Sale Of Barnwell County School Or School District Property Located Within The Boundaries Of The Savannah River Project.
Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: ' Section 1.

Credit and expenditure of funds from sale of school property within Savannah River Project, Barnwell County.The proceeds from the sale of all Barnwell County school or school district property, real or personal, located within the boundaries of the Savannah River Project of the Atomic Energy Commission shall be placed to the credit of the County Board of Education and shall be expended at the discretion of the board.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 8th day of February, 1952
