The appropriation under Item 8 of Section 2 is made for the purpose of waking care of the expenses hereinafter provided for in this act, and in addition thereto for the purpose of taking care of emergencies that may arise and unforeseen expenditures during the fiscal year 19521953.
Provided, further, that in no event shall any portion of this appropriation be used for an account for which there is a specific appropriation made in this act.

Provided, further, that if necessary, as much as seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) of this appropriation may be expended for hospitalization of white charity patients who are citizens and residents of Greenwood County.

The finance board shall approve and pay claims out of this appropriation only when submitted in itemized form by the hospital rendering the service, showing the name of each person hospitalized, supported by the affidavit of the proper officer of the hospital, to the effect that he has examined into his financial ability and that he has found such person is financially unable to pay for his hospitalization.

The amounts herein appropriated shall be paid out as near as practicable onetwelfth (1/12) each month during the year 19521953, and if any item on salary has been overpaid for any month, such overpayment shall be deducted the following month.

All accounts shall be kept separate and distinct and expended only for the purposes for which appropriated; Provided, the amounts herein appropriated for the specific items as set out herein shall not, nor shall any part thereof, be used for any other purpose except upon the written consent of the Senator and a majority of the members of the House of Representatives from Greenwood County ; Provided.

further, no claim or bill shall be approved or paid unless same shall state fully, under oath, what it is for, or give the kind or quality of thing or commodity which it represents, in addition to the amount and time furnished.

The money herein appropriated for auto upkeep and travel and for other expenses of county officials shall be paid out only upon itemized claims which have been verified by the official incurring the expenses and approved by the Supervisor and the Clerk to the Finance Board.

For the purpose of assessment returns and collection of taxes for the fiscal year 19521953, the school districts as they existed prior to any consolidation shall be used; and the Board of Assessors shall be appointed from said school districts as has been done heretofore.

The County Supervisor shall on or before the fifteenth day of each month deliver to the Foreman of the Greenwood County Grand Jury and to the secretary of the Greenwood County Legislative Delegation itemized statements of receipts and disbursements of county funds and the purposes for which same are used during the preceding month; and shall cause a copy to be published in a local paper.

The Finance Board of Greenwood County, with the approval of the Senator and a majority of the members of the House of Representatives from Greenwood County, be, and they are hereby authorized and empowered to make such regulations or take such action as may be necessary under the emergency, which may arise before the convening of the next session of the General Assembly, for the financing of the affairs of Greenwood County, both the general county matters and all school matters, with the further provision that a full and complete record of any action taken under the provisions of this section shall be kept by the secretary of the finance board; Provided, before any action is taken by the finance board in connection with this section, it shall call a joint meeting of the members of the Greenwood County Legislative Delegation in the General Assembly and the finance board to discuss such action.

In case of an emergency the Finance Board of Greenwood County may with written approval of the Greenwood County Legislative Delegation borrow sufficient funds to carry out the terms of this act or to meet such emergency, pledging as security therefor any surplus in the sinking fund, general fund, or by tax levy when approved by the Delegation.

All items or articles to be purchased except purchases arising under a regular expense account set up in this act shall be proceeded through the clerk to the finance board, and before any such purchase is made same must be acted on and approved by the finance board.
The board is further empowered to fix charges for tapping and to permit tapping under such conditions and terms as the board may prescribe.

The finance board is authorized and directed to purchase the interest or rights owned by the American Legion in the baseball field located at the Fair Grounds known as the American Tegion Field, for an amount not to exceed fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00), Section 11.

Immediately upon receiving tax duplicates from the County Auditor, the County Treasurer shall cause to be mailed to each taxpayer listed thereon, whose post office address is available, a written or printed notice stating thereon the amount of taxes assessed against the said taxpayer for the current year, with such other information as the said County Treasurer may deem desirable.

This service to the taxpayers being gratuitous, nog obligation shall rest upon the county or State, or County Treasurer for any failure or mistake on the part of the County Treasurer in giving or failing to give the notice.

The Senator and a majority of the members of the Ilouse of Representatives from Greenwood County on recommendation of the County Superintendent of Education and the Trustees of the respective school districts are hereby authorized to determine and fix the levy for school purposes for each school district in Greenwood County.

The School Trustees in each district in Greenwood County are hereby directed to see that all claims presented for payment are duly itemized and verified and shall state the purpose fot which the said claims are drawn and the County Superintendent cf Education is hereby prohibited from approving any claim unless so drawn.

There is hereby levied on all the taxable property of Greenwood County such millage as shall be determined by the Senator and the majority of the Greenwood County Legislative Delegation for the following purposes, towit: salary and travel of rural music school teacher, salary of secretary of rental textbook system, clerical assistance to the board, and compensation and travel expenses of the appointive members of the County Board of Education.
Each of these members shall be paid five dollars per day for cach days attendance on meetings of the board, and travel at the rate of five cents per mile in going to and from the place of meeting.
The Auditor is hereby authorized to put on the books, and the Treasurer to collect and hold the proceeds therefrom, subject to the orders of the County Board of Education for Greenwood County.

The equipment owned by Greenwood County, the chaingang labor and labor of county employees shall not be used except on the public works and for the public purposes of Greenwood County; Provided, however, the finance board may in cases of urgency, by resolution, a record of which shall be kept, permit the use of such equipment and labor in aid of eleemosynary institutions serving the people of Greenwood County on such terms as the board may deem proper.

Any officer or employee who disregards any of the provisions of this act without the written consent of the Senator and a majority of the members of the House of Representatives from Greenwood County kept on file in the office of the County Treasurer, shall be guilty of & malfeasance in office and subject to removal, in addition to the punishment now provided by law.

The Clerk of Court and the Judge of Probate of Greenwood County may make a charge of fifteen cents (15) per hundred words for the recording of all documents required to be typewritten, which are actually typed in the respective offices and for which there is no regular form.

After deducting all necessary payments and expenditures in connection with the outstanding bonds for which the revenue from the gasoline tax for the fiscal year 19521953 has been pledged, the remaining portion of this revenue shall be transferred to the general fund and held by the Treasurer in a special account, together with any balance of the gasoline revenue now held in a special account for the purpose of purchasing road equipment and the construction and improvement of the roads of Greenwood County.

Provided, that fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) of this amount shall be paid to the City of Greenwood, and one thousand twentyone dollars and 22 cents ($1,021.22) to the Town of Ninety Six for the purpose of street improvements.
No portion of this special account shall be expended without the written approval of the Senator and a majority of the Legislative Delegation.

Provided, That the above funds, or so much thereof as might be necessary, may be used for the purpose of building a prison or convict camp and for the purpose of acquiring new or additional lands for courthouse purposes.

To this end the finance board may borrow sufficient funds with the written approval of a majority of the Legislative Delegation to accomplish their ends, pledging not only funds above mentioned or security but also all surplus funds derived from the five (5) mill levy that is now on for the purpose of retiring indebtedness of school building program under Act 1237 of the General Assembly for the year 1950.

Provided, further, the finance board may sell the county property now located near the new Self Memorial Hospital with the written approval of a majority of the Delegation, such sale to be made only on competitive bids after due advertisement with right to reject any and all bids.

A majority of the qualified electors of Greenwood County having voted in favor of financial supporf of Lander College at the election held on May 2, 1951, the Auditor of Greenwood County is authorized and directed to levy, and the Treasurer of Greenwood County to collect, a tax not to exceed four (4) mills on all of the taxable property in Greenwood County, the proceeds of which shall be used in conjunction with other college revenues to defray the operating expenses of the college.
If any clause, phrase, sentence, paragraph, or section of this act shall be held invalid, same shall not affect the validity of remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections.
The cotton weigher at Greenwood shall receive as compensation the sum of twenty cents (20) per bale for each bale .
The provisions of this act are hereby declared to be permanent law.
992 An Act To Make Supplemental Appropriations For County Purposes In Greenwood County For The Fiscal Year 19511952.

Supplemental appropriations, Greenwood County.In order to supplement the appropriations heretofore made for certain county purposes and to make additional appropriations for county purposes, the following sums are appropriated for the purposes hereinafter stated: Increase of Contingent Fund $ 4,000.00 From this appropriation there shall be paid the cost of the plans and improvements in the Clerk of Courts office and any unforeseen expenses.

10,000.00 Improvements at Lander College Per diem allowance to appointive members of the county board of education @ $7.50 per day 800.00 Operating expenses of county health department from February 1 to July 1, 1952 $ 8,307.06 Trade car and radio accessories for sheriff 1,275.00 To supplement salary for clerk of court for fiscal year ending June 30, 1952 600.00 Provided, that the clerk of court is not required to comply with the provisions of subdivision (i) of Section 2 of Act No.
563 of the Acts of the General Assembly, 1951.

TOTAL $ 24,982.06 In the event that there is not sufficient amount in the general fund to meet these appropriations, the County Finance Board is authorized to borrow any sum found necessary on the credit of the county from the county sinking fund commission, and repay the same when funds become available from county revenues.

993 (R1040, H1785) An Act To Authorize The Finance Board Of Greenwood County To Refinance Certain Indebtednss Incurred Under The Provisions Of Act No.547 Of The Acts Of 1949, To Provide Terms And Conditions Of The Obligations, And To Provide A Tax Levy To Pay The Same, And To Authorize The Board To Issue Not Exceeding One Hundred Thousand Dollars ($100,000.00) Of Bonds Or Notes Of The County To Construct And Repair Roads And To Repair The Courthouse, And To Provide For The Payment Of Same.
Greenwood County may refinance debt.The Finance Board of Greenwood County, as established by Act No.
694 of the Acts of 1942, is authorized and empowered to refinance any of the debt which remains unpaid of the two hundred and.

fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) authorized under the terms of An Act To Provide For The Borrowing Of Not Exceeding Two Hundred Fifty Thousand Dollars ($250,000.00) By The Finance Board of Greenwood County; Etc., designated as Act No.
547 of the Acts of 1949.

To that end the finance board is authorized to execute a note or notes or bonds which shall mature at such time, or times, be payable at such place or places, and bear such rate of interest as the board may determine; provided, that any such bond or note shall not mature later than ten years from the date of execution and shall not bear a rate of interest greater than three per cent per annum, which interest may be payable annually or semiannually, as the board determines.
Any such note, notes or bonds shall be issued in the name of Greenwoud County and be signed by the chairman of the board and the treasurer of the county.
Provided, further, that the holder of any unmatured obligation may not be required to have the same refinanced under the terms of this act unless he shall consent thereto.

Borrow improve courthouse and roads.In addition to the refinancing provided for in Section 1 of this act the Finance Board of Greenwood County is authorized and empowered to borrow and to issue and sell bonds or notes of the county, at public or private sale, as they deem best, in a sum not to exceed one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00).
The proceeds from the bonds or notes shall be used for road construction and repairs within the county and repairs and improvements to the courthouse building.
The bonds or notes issued pursuant to this section shall mature at such time or times, be payable at such place or places, and bear such rate of interest as the board may determine.
Provided, the bonds or notes shall not mature later than ten years from the date of issuance.
The board may redeem the bonds or notes before maturity at par and accrued interest as they deem advisable.
Payment.The full faith, credit and taxing power of Greenwood County are hereby irrevocably pledged for the payment of any and all obligations issued pursuant to the terms of this act.

The Auditor of Greenwood County is directed to levy, and the Treasurer of Greenwood County is directed to collect, annually a tax upon all of the taxable property in Greenwood County sufficient to pay the principal and interest on the bonds or notes as they mature.
Apply proceeds from levies on obligations.As the bonds or notes mature, the treasurer is directed to apply the proceeds of the levies to the payment of same.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 4th day of April, 1952.

994 An Act To Authorize The City Council Of Greenwood, South Carolina, To Borrow Not Exceeding One Hundred Thousand Dollars ($100,000.00) To Be Evidenced By General Obligation Bonds Of Greenwood To Obtain Funds For The Purpose Of Acquiring Additional Parking Areas, Improving Parking And Traffic Conditions In The City, And To Provide For The Removal Of The Southern Railroad Freight And Passenger Depot And Other Facilities, To Prescribe The Terms, Conditions And Manner Of Payment Of The Bonds, And To Repeal Act No.
567 Of The Acts And Joint Resolutions Of The General Assembly Of The State Of South Carolina For The Year 1951.

Whereas, Greenwood is now in the process of moving and relocating certain railroad facilities in the center of Greenwood for the purpose of removing certain traffic hazards, enlarging the business district of the city, and providing additional parking space for motorists; and, Whereas, an agreement between Greenwood and the Southern Railroad has been reached providing, among other things, for the removal of the passenger depot, freight depot, and other facilities, in order to provide for the accomplishment of the matters referred to above; and, Whereas, in order to effect the desired improvements, it is found necessary that Greenwood borrow the sum of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) ; and, Whereas, the revenues derived from the citys parking meter system, including those now in operation, those to be hereafter installed in the area above referred to, and those to be hereafter installed elsewhere throughout the city, will be adequate to discharge the principal and interest of the bonds authorized by this act; and, Whereas, if bonds be issued for the aforesaid purpose payable primarily from the special fund, but additionally secured by a pledge of the full faith, credit and taxing power of Greenwood, a lower interest rate will be paid by the city on its bonds, than that which it would pay if the bonds herein authorized were payable solely from the revenues from such sources.

Greenwood issue bonds improve traffic facilities The City Council of Greenwood shall be, and it is hereby, empowered to borrow not exceeding one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) to raise funds to enable it to remove the railroad facilities above referred to, and to develop and improve the area wherein the same are now situate, in order that traffic conditions may be improved and additional parking space for motorists provided within the corporate limits of Greenwood.
The borrowing shall be evidenced by bonds of Greenwood, which may be issued either as a single issue or from time to time as several separate issues.

Such bonds shall bear such date, shall mature in such annual series or instalments, equal or unequal in amount, as city council shall provide, and may he made subject to call and redemption, in whole or in part, in the discretion of citv council, with or without redemption premium.

Registration Such bonds shall be in the form of negotiable coupon bonds, payable to bearer, with the privilege to the holder of having them registered on the books of the Treasurer of Greenwood, and the principal thus made payable to the registered holder (unless the last registered transfer shall have been to bearer) upon such conditions as city council may prescribe.
Places pay.Such bonds shall be made payable at such place or places, within or without the State of South Carolina, as the city council shall provide.
Interest.Such bonds shall bear interest at such rate or rates as the city council shall provide.
ExecutionSuch bonds shall be executed in the name of Greenwood by the mayor and the clerk and treasurer of the city, and its seal shall be affixed or impressed upon each bond.
The coupons attached to such bonds shall be authenticated by the facsimile signatures of the mayor and the clerk and treasurer of the city, who are in office on the date of such bonds.
The delivery of bonds so executed and authenticated shall be valid notwithstanding any changes in officers or seal occurring after such execution or authentication.

Exempt from taxes.The principal of and interest on bonds issued under this act shall be exempt from all state, county, municipal, school disrict and all other taxes or assessments, direct or indirect, general or special, whether imposed for the purpose of general revenue or otherwise.
Investments.It shall be lawful for all executors, administrators, guardians and fiduciaries, and all sinking fund commissions to invest any moneys in their hands in bonds issued under this  act.
Sale.The bonds may be disposed of at public or private sale, in such manner as city council of Greenwood may determine.
Sale price The bonds must be sold at a price of not less than par and accrued interest to date of delivery.

Payment.The full faith, credit and taxing power of the city are hereby irrevocably pledged for the punctual payment of the principal of and interest on the bonds as the same respectively mature, and for the creation of a sinking fund to aid in the retirement and payment thereof.

Such principal and interest shall, however, be payable in the first instance from the net revenues derived from the citys parking meter system, including those now in operation, those to be hereafter installed in the area referred to in the recitals to this act, and those to be hereafter installed elsewhere throughout the city, and so much of the net revenues as may benecessary for the payment of the principal of and interest on the bonds shall be pledged to their payment, and on the occasion of the issuance of the bonds, the city council shall, for itself, its successors, and all municipal agencies, covenant and agree that a schedule of rates and charges, sufficient to produce the revenues needed to pay the principal of and interest on the bonds, shall be put into effect, maintained and revised whenever necessary, so that there shall at all times be sufficient revenues from this source to discharge the obligations incurred by Greenwood pursuant to this act.

If moneys derived from the revenues, actually in the hands of the city treasurer, at the time taxes are levied for any year, are not equal to the aggregate amount of principal and interest then due or payable during such year, the city council shall levy in such year a special tax ad valorem upon all taxable property in the city for the purpose of paying such principal and interest, and the tax shall be in such amount as will, when added to the net revenues from the system, actually in the hands of the city treasurer, be sufficient for the purpose and shall be in addition to all other taxes authorized by law to be levied by the city.

Issuance of additional obligations secured by pledge of revenue.The pledge authorized by Section 10 shall not be deemed exclusive and closed if at some subsequent time the City Council of Greenwood shall be authorized and shall determine to issue further bonds, general obligation or revenue, secured and payable from such source, provided always that no further bonds, payable in whole or in part from such source, shall be issued unless: (1) The average annual revenues derived from such source for the three fiscal years preceding the occasion on which such additional bonds are proposed to be issued shall aggregate not less than one hundred fifty per cent (150)} of the maximum debt service requirements on the bonds authorized by this act, and all additional bonds issued and sought to be issued ; and, (2) It shall be determined by the City Council of Greenwood that the revenues derived from this source will be sufficient to discharge, as they fall due, all principal and interest instalments on all outstanding bonds, payable in whole or in part from this source, and all additional bonds sought to be issued.

Deposit and application of bond proceeds.The proceeds derived from the sale of bonds issued pursuant to this act shall be deposited in a special fund, separate and distinct from all other funds, and be applied solely to the purposes for which the bonds are issued, except that the premium, if any, shall be placed in the sinking fund established by Section 10, and the accrued interest, if any, shall be used to discharge in part the first interest to become due on such bonds.
Should any surplus remain, the same shall be deposited in the sinking fund required by the provisions of Section 10 to be established for the payment of the bonds.
Act 567 of 1951 repealedGreenwood borrow.Act No.
567 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina for the year 1951 is hereby expressly repealed.
Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 21st day of February, 1952.

Gasoline Tax 45 (000.00 Alcoholic Liquor Tax 14,000.00 Beer & Wine Tax 2,500.00 Additional Insurance License Fees 5,000.00 Income Tax 20,000.00 Bank Tax 150.00 Interest School Notes 2,000.00 Forfeited Land Commission Sales 500.00 Rent 400.00 Veterans Service Office 3,600.00 State Library Board Contribution 500.00 Execution Fees and Costs $ 2,500.00 $116,150.00 AMOUNT TO BE RAISED BY TAXATION 42,342.00 Provided, that the county attorney of Hampton County is hereby required to give each county officer of the county advice when requested for same; Provided, that none of the funds herein appropriated shall be expended for the payment of any expense for transmitting lunatics to the State Hospital for the insane; Provided, further, that the Farm Demonstration Agent shall be appointed by the proper authorities by and with the consent of the Legislative Delegation from Hampton County, and shall besubject to removal on request of the Legislative Delegation; Provided, further, that all revenues provided for by law be callected and placed in ordinary county funds to supplement and provide sufficient funds for all ordinary county purposes.
All claims shall have the approval before payment by at least two members of the County Board and such approval by any two members shall be sufficient to constitute the boards approval.
No road tax shall be levied except a commutation road tax of three dollars to be assessed and collected from each male citizen between the ages of twentyone and fiftyfive years, inclusive.
Persons actually in the armed services of the country shall during such service be exempt from payment of such road tax.

All commutation taxes shall be expended on roads and bridges in townships and towns from which the same are collected and all of the commutation tax collected from citizens of incorporated towns by the county treasurer shall be returned to the respective tewns; Provided, that the town authorities of Brunson, Hampton, Varnville, Yemassee, Estill, Scotia and Furman be empowered to collect the commutation tax from residents within their respective corporate limits; Provided, further, that the clerks of the respective towns, on or before September first of each year, furnish a list, duly sworn to, of all persons in their respective towns who are liable to such commutation tax.

The Auditor and Treasurer of Hampton County shall be and they are hereby, constituted a Sinking Fund Commission of Hampton County, whose duty it shall be to handle all funds collected for the purpose of creating a sinking fund for the retirement of all bonds of the county, and the commission shall not deposit said funds in any bank unless such bank shall give surety bond or place with the commission Liberty Bonds, Federal Land Bank Bonds, the State of South Carolina Bonds, Hampton County Bonds, or bonds of any political subdivision of Hampton County as security to safeguard such deposit and such surety shall be not less than one hundred per cent of the amount so deposited.
All time deposits shall bear interest at two and onehalf per cent.
Provided, that with the approval of the county legislative delegation, the auditor and treasurer, as the Sinking Fund Commission of Hampton County, may lend to the county any available funds on hand.

provided that the County by its treasurer and supervisor, upon the direction of the delegation execute its note or notes, with a pledge of taxes collected or to be collected as security for the payment of such note or notes, or treat the same as other funds of the sinking fund commission are treated.

. No public funds of Hampton County shall be deposited in any bank or depository unless the bank or depository shall tender to the Treasurer of Hampton County a security equal in value to the funds deposited.

The security shall consist of either a surety bond executed by a licensed surety company, United States government bonds, bonds of the State of South Carolina, Hampton County bonds or bonds of any political subdivision of Hampton County.

The Auditor and Treasurer of Hampton County constituting the Sinking Fund Commission of Savannah River Bridge projects are hereby authorized and empowered and specifically directed to take all funds refunded to Hampton County on the Savannah River project by the State Highway Department and purchase, if it is possible to do so, as many bonds as the said funds will purchase, and if it is not possible at this time to purchase said bonds on the market, the sinking fund commission is authorized to deposit the funds in some bank, if such will give security therefor, an amount in niarketable securities equal to the deposit, and if this cannot be done, the commission is directed to take the funds and buy liberty bonds therewith.

The county supervisor and the county commissioners are hereby prohibted to issue any check to any magistrate of Hampton County until the magistrate has filed statement of the names of all parties against whom warrants have been issued during the previous months and the disposal of each case and a receipt from the treasurer for the fines and costs collected by the magistrates during the previous month.

All notices by the county supervisor, county treasurer, county superintendent of education, county auditor and other county officers, provided by the statute to be given, may be published in any newspaper published or having circulation in Hampton County; and three hundred dollars ($300.00) set out in Item 4 for the payment in full of such notices as are published in said paper during the year; Provided, however, that the word notices above used shall not be deemed to include notices and advertisements of tax sales, and the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00) is not in payment of the costs of advertising tax sales.
The county supervisor, treasurer, auditor and clerk of court shall compose a board to purchas all books and stationery for the county.
No property owned by Hampton County shall be sold, rented or leased unless the approval of the legislative delegation shall be first secured.

The County in the General Assembly, is hereby authorized and empowered to lend from any available funds of Hampton County, to the school district from the county general fund, or the county contingent fund, such sum or sums of money as may be directed in writing, to any school district in Hampton County in need of funds.
The courthouse and grounds shall be under the custody and control of the Clerk of Court for Hampton County.

Whenever in the conduct of the affairs of the county, it becomes necessary for the county treasurer to expend money for any matters and things not foreseen at this time, and when the legislative delegation shall in writing, signed by both members thereof, then such expenditures made under such authority are hereby validated.

On the maturity or payment of any bonded indebtedness of any school district in Hampton County by the county treasurer, the same may be paid by the county treasurer without securing a voucher therefor from the school district trustees, provided the county superintendent of education authorizes such payment in writing.

Likewise, hereafter the Sheriff of Hampton County shall not be required to serve or summons witnesses in criminal cases except by subpoena duly issued on motion of solicitor or as ordered so to do by the presiding Judge; such witness may be served by mailing a summons to the last known address of such witnesses for which no charge shall be made or collectible; and it shall be the duty of all magistrates in Hampton County to place under bond all witnesses for the state, blanks for same to be furnished by the clerk of court to the various niagistrates.

All persons actually in the Armed Forces of the United States on active duty shall during such service be exempt from payment of road, poll and dog taxes levied for 1952, and/or for any prior year when the above conditions have been met. The county auditor, treasurer, and/or tax collector is authorized to abate or mark Nulla Bona such taxes as may be levied; and the county auditor may approve county claim for refund when such taxes have been paid; and in all the foregoing cases be subject to presentation of satisfactory evidence of service in the Armed Forces.
There is hereby appropriated the sum of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00), if so much be necessary, to Hampton County Hospital for operating expenses.
The county treasurer shall make this fund available to Hampton County Hospital on the demand of the Board of Directors.
Provided, that the county treasurer shall not make said fund or any portion thereof available without first obtaining the written approval of both members of the legislative delegation.

Any additional appropriations that may be necessary in the operation of the hospital may be made by the county treasurer by and with the approval and direction of the legislative delegation of the county.
This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 3rd day of March, 1952.

That amount of millage, not to exceed eight mills so calculated, is hereby levied on all taxable property in the county for the period beginning July 1, 1952 and ending June 30, 1953; Provided, any surplus arising from anticipated revenues of the county shall be invested in government bonds, or suitable securities approved by the treasurer and county board of commissioners.

The county board of commissioners is hereby instructed and required to use the money herein appropriated for the purposes specified and for no other purpose or purposes, and it is hereby forbidden to in any way overdraw or exceed the appropriation herein made for any purpose whatever, except upon the written consent of the senator and a majority of the house delegation.

For the items covered in Section 1 of this act, it shall be unlawful for the treasurer of Horry County to pay from funds in his hands any amount not covered by the appropriation herein made or authorized by the written consent of the senator and a majority of the house delegation.
Any appropriation herein made may be increased or decreased by the written consent of the senator and a majority of the house delegation.

The County Board of Commissioners shall use as much as may be necessary of the amounts appropriated therein for setting up a road program in Horry County, which program shall be carried out by the County Road Commissioners under the direction and control of the County Board of Commissioners.

From the funds provided for Jail in the Administrative Expenses of Section 1 of this act, the jailor of Horry County shall be paid the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per month for his services as jailor and a matron for the jail to be paid the sum of sixty dollars per month, both to be employed by the Sheriff of Horry County ugon approval of the County Board of Commissioners, and the jailor and/or matron shall receive no fees for dieting prisoners.

The Horry County Board of Commissioners shall have the duty to inspect the Horry County Jail at least once a month to see that it is kept clean at all times and that a jailor or deputy sheriff is on duty at all times.

The purchasing agent is authorized to make purchases of all food, supplies, equipment and any and all things necessary for the proper maintenance of the county jail and the food and clothing of the prisoners therein.

The county board of commissioners shall employ a certified accountant for the purpose of auditing semiannually the books, and examining the offices of Horry County, and the county board of commissioners may make payment for such services not to exceed eight hundred dollars ($800.00), as provided in this act.
Each member of the legislative delegation from Horry County shall be furnished by the accountant making the audit, a copy of the audit.
The Senator and a majority of the house delegation may employ a county attorney and pay same an amount not to exceed that provided for this purpose in Section 1 of this act.
The premiums on the bonds shall be paid by the county.

The magistrate and coroner shall be required to put all material state witnesses under bond as now provided by law, and at least ten days before the mecting of the Court of General Sessions shall lodge all papers pertaining to said court with the clerk of court, except cases which happen within the said ten day period, and cases where defendants have demanded preliminary hearings in writing and for good cause the magistrate has been unable to give a preliminary hearing.

Provided, that twenty per cent of the liquor, wine and beer tax allotted to Horry County shall, as received by the treasurer be paid to the Horry County Memorial Library Commission, and the commission shall use the funds for the operation of the Horry County Memorial Library and in the purchase of equipment, books, and other necessaries for the Horry County Memorial Library, and for the equipping and purchasing of equipment for the school libraries of Horry County, the said funds to be spent and allotted to the libraries as the Library Commission, or a majority thereof, shall determine.

In order to carry out the registration of voters in the county, there is hereby appropriated to the county board of registration in Section 1 of this act, a sum of money not to exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), if so much be necessary, which amount shall be used for mileage and expenses necessary in making available facilities of the board of registration to the various section of the county.
No town or community shall be called upon to pay any additional sum or sums for this service.

Provided, however, that in no event shall the members of the county board of registration be paid more than ten dollars each per diem and seven cents per mile for necessary travel and to be submitted as a regular claim for payment to the county board of commissioners.

The clerk of the county board of commissioners and the Horry County Purchasing Agent shall each make a written report to each member of the county board of commissioners of his activities during the month and proposals that he intends to make to the county bvard of commissioners five days prior to the regular meeting of the county board of commissioners.

The county board of commissioners shall furnish to the senator and each member of the house delegation, a statement before the fifteenth day of December of each year, a quarterly statement in detail showing their activities during each quarterly period, along with a report of the financial status of the account and any recommendations that they see fit to make to the delegation.

The county board of commissioners shall furnish to the senator and each member of the legislative delegation, a statement in detail showing a proposed county supply bill for the following year and also any legislation that, in their opinion, they think should be enacted.
No magistrate shall receive any part of fees, com: pensation or mileage in connection with tax execution warrants except the one dollar allowed him by law.
Nc county officials shall receive any fees or compensation unless provided by law.
The house now owned by Horry County, on Second Avenue in the Town of Conway shall be used by the jailor of Horry County as his residence.

Any special authorization for county purposes to be hereafter made from the contingent account in Section 1, Item 2, of this act by the senator and members of the House of Representatives in excess of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall first have the approval of the Board of County Commissioners of Horry County or a majority thereof.
There is hereby imposed a fee of one dollar for each application for marriage license issued in Horry County.
The auditor of Horry County shall assess all automobiles in the county at forty per cent of the value at which they are assessed by the South Carolina Tax Commission.
If any section or porvision of this act shall be held unconstitutional, such unconstitutionality shall not affect, impair, or invalidate any of the remaining section or provisions.
This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 15th day of April, 1952.

1001 A Joint Resolution Proposing An Amendment To Section 5, Article X Of The Constitution Of South Carolina By Adding A Proviso Authorizing The General Assembly To Empower The Corporate Authorities Of The City Of Myrtle Beach To Assess Real Property Served By Sanitary Sewer.
Lines; To Cause The Assessment To Be A Lien On The Property; And To Empower The Corporate Authorities To Issue Sewer Bonds Without The Necessity Of An Election.

Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1. Amendment to Article X,  5, State Constitution, proposedassessment against abutting property and issuance of bonds, Myrtle Beach.There is proposed the following amendment to Section 5, Article X of the Constitution of South Carolina: Add at the end of Section 5 of Article X the following proviso: Provided, the General Assembly may authorize the corporate authorities of the City of Myrtle Beach to levy assessments against real property served by sanitary sewer lines installed by the city for the expenses incurred by the city in the construction of such sanitary sewer lines, which assessments shall constitute a lien upon the property.

The City of Myrtle Beach may be empowered, without the necessity of an election, to issue sewer bonds in an amount not exceeding the aggregate amount of the costs of extending such sewer lines, and to pledge the assessment as security therefor.
The bonds issued shall not be considered a part of the bonded indebtedness of the City of Myrtle Beach within the meaning of any constitutional limitation.

The city may, at its option, assess only a portion of the cost of extending sewer lines within the corporate limits and may pay the remainder itself. Section 2. Submission to electorsThe proposed amendment shall be submitted to the qualified electors at the next general election for representatives.

Ballots shall be provided at the various voting precincts with the following words printed or written thereon: Shall Section 5, Article X of the Constitution be amended so as to authorize the General Assembly to empower the corporate authorities of the City of Myrtle Beach to assess real property served by sanitary sewer lines, to cause the assessment to be a lien on the property, and to empower the corporate authorities to issue sewer bonds without the necessity of an election?

In favor of the amendment O Opposed to the amendment O Those voting in favor of the amendment shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the words In favor of the amendment, and those voting against the amendment shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the oo words Opposed to the amendment .

1002 A Joint Resolution Proposing An Amendment To Article X Of The Constitution Of South Carolina, 1895, By Adding A New Section Which Would Authorize The General Assembly To Empower The Corporate Authorities Of The City Of Ocean Drive Beach To Assess Real Property Served By Sanitary Sewer Lines To The Extent Of The Benefits Resulting Therefrom.

Re it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1. Amendment to Article X, State Constitution, proposed assessment of abutting property by Ocean Drive Beach.There is proposed the following amendment to Article X of the Constitution of this State: add at the end thereof the following: The General Assembly shall be empowered to enact legislation permitting the corporate authorities of the City of Ocean Drive Beach to levy assessments against real property served by sanitary sewer lines, now or hereafter installed, by the city, for the expenses incurred by the city in the construction of such sanitary sewer lines to the extent of the benefits resulting therefrom to such real property. Section 2. Submission to electors.The question of the adoption of the amendment shall be submitted to the qualified electors of this state at the next general election for Members of the House of Representatives of this state, and there shall be furnished at the voting places in this state a sufficient number of ballots with the following question ,plainly printed thereon: Shall the Constitution of South , Carolina, 1895, be amended by adding a new section to Article X, which would authorize the General Assembly to empower the corporate authorities of the City of Ocean Drive Beach to assess real property served by sanitary sewer lines for the benefits resulting therefrom ?

In favor of the amendment C) Opposed to the amend CJ Those voting in favor of the amendment shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the words In favor of the amendment, and those voting against the amendment shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the words Opposed to the amendment. 1005 An Act To Provide That In The Distribution Of Any Funds By The State To Counties On A Basis Of The Population, Jasper County Shall Be As Shown By The Official Census Of The United States Of 1950, Plus The Population Of Yemassee Township Of The Same Census.

Population use for Jasper County in distribution of State funds.For the purpose of the distribution of any funds by the State of South Carolina made to the counties after the effective date of this act, on a basis of population, Jasper County shall be credited with that population shown by the official census of the United States of 1950, plus 1,376 which latter figure represents the population of Yemassee township in the official 1950 census.

1006 An Act To Empower The County Board Of Education And The Treasurer Of Jasper County To Issue Not Exceeding Sixty Thousand ($60,000.00) Dollars Of Jasper County General Obligation School Bonds, To Prescribe The Procedure For The Issuance Of Said Bonds And The Purposes For Which Their Proceeds Shall Be Applied, And To Make Provision For The Payment Of Said Bonds.

Whereas, Jasper County, while divided into several school districts for administrative purposes, provides for the operation of its public schools through State aid and a uniform County tax levy assessed against all taxable property in said County and distributed on the basis of the needs of the several schools of the County irrespective of location, a practice in force over ten years; and, Whereas, it has now been ascertained that a deficit of Sixty Thousand ($60,000.00) Dollars in school operation fund for the fiscal year ending July 1st, 1952, will occur which must be provided for if the schools of the County are to continue to operate; and, Mherceas, by reason of the foregoing, it has been determined to make provision for the raising of such sum through the issuance of school bonds of said County, = Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1.

Jasper County may issue school bonds.The County Board of Education and the Treasurer of Jasper County (hereafter referred to as the Issuing Authorities) shall be empowered to issue general obligation bonds of Jasper County in the amount of not exceeding Sixty Thousand ($60,000.00) Dollars, to be designated as Jasper County School Bonds of 1952.

Maturities interest redemption.Such bonds may be issued as one single issue or, from time to time, as several separate issues; they shall bear such date or dates as the Issuing Authorities shall determine, and the bonds of any issue shall mature in such equal or unequal annual instalments as may be determined by said Issuing Authorities, except that the last maturing bonds of any issue shall mature not later than fifteen (15) years from their date.

They shall be made payable at such place or places as said Issuing Authorities shall prescribe, and they shall bear interest at such rate or rates, payable in such manner, as the Issuing Authorities may determine.

Said bonds may be issued with the privilege to the holder of having them registered as to principal on the books of the Treasurer of Jasper County, and the principal thus made payable to the registered holder (unless the last registered transfer shall have been to bearer) upon such conditions as said Issuing Authorities may prescribe.

Any bond issued pursuant to the provisions of this Act may be made subject to redemption prior to its stated maturity on such terms and conditions, and with such redemption premium as said Issuing Authorities shall prescribe.

SaleAll bonds issued pursuant to this Act shall be sold at not less than par and accrued interest to the date of their respective deliveries, at public sale, and at least ten (10) days prior to any sale, notice announcing the intention to receive bids for the sale of any bonds authorized by this Act, shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the State of South Carolina.

In offering said bonds for sale, the Issuing Authorities may reserve the right to reject any and all bids, and if all bids are rejected, the Issuing Authorities shall be empowered to effect a private sale at a price not less than the best bid received on the occasion of the public offering.

Exempt from taxes.The bonds and the interest to become due thereon shall be exempt from all state, county, municipal, school district, and all other taxes or assessments, direct or indirect, general or special, whether imposed for the purpose of general revenue or otherwise.

Execution.All bonds issued pursuant to this Act shall be executed in the name of Jasper County by the Superintendent of Education of Jasper County and by the Treasurer of Jasper County, under such Seal as the Issuing Authorities shall designate.
The coupons attached to said bonds shall be authenticated by the facsimile signature of the Treasurer of Jasper County, who is in office on the date of such bonds.
The delivery of any bonds so executed shall be valid notwithstanding any changes in officers or seal occurring after such execution or such authentication.

Payment.For the payment of said bonds, both principal and interest, as the same respectively mature, the full faith, credit, resources and taxing power of Jasper County shall be pledged, and there shall be levied and collected by the Auditor and Treasurer of Jasper County, respectively, an ad valorem tax upon all taxable property in said County, without limitation as to rate or amount, sufficient to pay the interest on said bonds and the bonds as they respectively mature.

The taxes, when so levied and collected, shall be held by the Treasurer of Jasper County, separate and distinct from all other funds and used solely for the purposes for which levied and collected under the terms of this Act.

Deposit and expenditure of proceeds.The proceeds derived from the sale of bonds issued pursuant to this Act shall be deposited with the Treasurer of Jasper County in a separate and special fund, and shall be expended upon the warrants or orders of the County Board of Education of Jasper County for the operation of schools of Jasper County during the fiscal year ending July 1st, 1952.
Should any surplus remain, the same shall be retained by the Treasurer of Jasper County and applied to the retirement of the principal of said bonds.
The premium and accrued interest, if any, received from such bonds shall be used to discharge the first instalment of principal and interest, respectively, of such bonds.
The purchasers of any bonds, or any subsequent holders thereof, shall be in no wise responsible for the proper application of such proceeds.
Time effectiveThis Act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 6th day of March, 1952.

The sheriff and deputy sheriff shall receive, in addition to their regular salaries, necessary expenses and five cents per mile for each mile traveled in going and returning when called in and beyond the limits of the county on official business such as searching for fugitives, conveying prisoners to the State Reformatory, to the State Penitentiary, etc. The sheriff shall also receive one dollar per day for dieting each prisoner for each day or fraction thereof while the prisoner is detained in the county jail or otherwise in his custody.

The Magistrates of Kershaw County are hereby required to enter all cases brought before them on their dockets and to show on said dockets what disposition is made of each case, and shall enter on said dockets all cases which may be assessed against the parties of said case, and shall collect the same and shall pay over to the county treasurer monthly all fines and costs in criminal cases which may have been collected by them and shall submit their dockets to the Board of County Directors monthly for audit.
Provided, however, that no magistrate in Kershaw County shall be paid his monthily salary until the above section has been complied with on or before the tenth day of each month.

The appropriations herein made for salaries of the various county officers and other county employees shall be paid to said officers and employees in monthly installments upon individual claims to be submitted to the county board of directors.

The superintendent of roads, chaingang and county buildings shall be elected by the county board of directors, subject to the approval of a majority of the Kershaw County Delegation, and shall, under the supervision of said board and delegation have general charge of the supervision, repair, and maintenance of county roads and bridges, and shall have charge of the county chaingang.

The coroner shall receive, in addition to his regular salary, the sum of five dollars for each inquest in the event he shall employ a stenographer to record the testimony, payment to be made to such stenographer.

The county board of education is hereby authorized and directed to furnish school bus transportation for all activities of the 4H Boys and Girls, Vocational and Agricultural Boys, Home Economic Girls and Junior Homemakers of America in attending inter and intra county meetings pertaining to their respective endeavors.

If circumstances arise, which in the judgment of a majority of the Kershaw County Legislative Delegation, require the expenditure of a greater amount than herein provided for any purposes or should in the judgment of said majority of the delegation, the affairs of Kershaw County increase the expenditure of funds for purposes not mentioned in this act and above enumerated, said delegation or a majority thereof, shall have, and are hereby given the right, by resolution to increase the amount appropriated in any item, and may also appropriate funds for purposes not mentioned or referred to in this act, which resolution or resolutions, shall be filed with the Board of County Directors for Kershaw County as their authority for expending the funds thus appropriated, and the board of directors may borrow, if necessary, such amounts as may be required to make such increase or additional appropriations, and may pledge the full faith and credit of Kershaw County for the payment of the amount so borrowed.

It shall be unlawful for the Kershaw County Board of Directors or Supervisor of Public Road Construction of Kershaw County to offer for sale or dispose of any property or equipment of any kind having a value of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more, without first obtaining the written approval of a majority of the Kershaw County Legislative Delegation.

The Kershaw County Board of Education is hereby authorized and directed to supplement the superintendent of educations salary from the state in an amount so as the total will not exceed fortyfive hundred dollars ($4,500.00).

Provided, further, that the Kershaw County Board of Education is hereby authorized and directed to include in the school budget a sum to be determined by the superintendent of education and the county board of education for the purpose of supplementing the county supervisor of lunchrooms office and to pay expenses and per diem of the Kershaw County Board of Education during the fiscal year 19521953.

All estimates of monies above actual expenses coming to Kershaw County from the South Carolina Highway Department in the farm to market road program of Kershaw County shall be kept in a separate fund by the Treasurer of Kershaw County, and shall be spent by the Kershaw County Board of Directors only upon the approval of a majority of the Kershaw County Legislative Delegation.

The Auditor and Treasurer of Kershaw County are hereby authorized and directed to levy upon all taxable property of Kershaw County not otherwise excluded by law, two mills, the sums raised to be given to the Camden Hospital for the treatment of deserving charity patients whose conditions demand hospital treatment.

This amount shall be spent subject to the following conditions: that no deserving patient shall be turned away as long as there are facilities and room in the hospital; that there shall be no charge for professional services to such patient, and no charge whatsoever except the daily expense of eight dollars and fifty cents per patient; provided, that the fund shall be available for use of the Camden Hospital only upon itemized statements of the actual days spent in the hospital by charity patients, signed by the Chairman of the Camden Hospital Board of Directors and approved by the Kershaw County Board of Directors.

The Duke Foundation payment for charity work of one dollar is to be deducted from the amount of eight dollars and fifty cents leaving seven dollars and fifty cents for charity patients to be paid by the county.

These conditions and provisions are to be interpreted and enforced as meaning that when the Duke Foundation gives one dollar to charity work Kershaw County will give seven dollars and fifty cents, not to exceed whatever amount is raised by the above two mill levy for the year 19521953.

These special funds shall be available only to match in this way funds coming from the Duke Foundation for charity beds and shall be paid only in cases approved as charity cases by the Duke Foundation.
Provided, further, that the charity patients herein referred to must be citizens of Kershaw County.

Provided, however, that out of the above appropriation two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), if so much be necessary, shall be used for the hospitalization of charity patients who can qualify as such under this section in hospitals other than the Camden Hospital, in the event they, because of their particular illness, are unable to obtain at the Camden Hospital the specialized medical services needed.

The Kershaw County Board of Directors is hereby authorized and directed to spend the same amount for the Kershaw County Health Department as was spent during the fiscal year 19511952, such amount to be spent in accordance with a budget as submitted by the Kershaw County Board of Health.
The auditor and treasurer are hereby authorized and directed to levy sufficient taxes to take care of this amount.

The supervisor of road construction and superintendent of maintenance are hereby authorized and directed to mark all county equipment used in the construction and maintenance of roads in letters such as to designate that it is county equipment.
The ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) appropriated herein for recreation shall be spent for surveys, engineering and other expenses necessary in developing the Adams Mill property.
Before such shall be spent it shall be approved by a majority of the Kershaw County Recreation Commission and then only in the event that the county purchases said property for a state park.
1008 An Act To Validate The Action Of The County Board Of Commissioners Of Kershaw County In Purchasing A OneThird Undivided Interest In The Kershaw Health Center.
Pe it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1.

Land purchased by Kershaw County validated.The action of the County Board of Commissioners of Kershaw County in purchasing from Lancaster County a onethird undivided interest in certain property located in the town of Kershaw upon which is located the Kershaw Health Center, and the payment of the purchase price therefor and the acceptance of a deed therefor, is hereby validated and confirmed in every respect.
1009 An Act To Authorize The County Board Of Commissioners Of Kershaw County To Purchase Certain Real Estate.

Kershaw County may purchase Adams Mill Place.The County Board of Commissioners of Kershaw County is hereby authorized and directed to purchase from Henry Savage, Jr., trustee under the last will and testament of George T. Little, deceased, for the consideration of fortyfive thousand dollars ($45,000.00) the following described real estate: All that parcel or tract of land in the State and County aforesaid, lying about 5 miles northeast of the City of Camden, on both sides of what is known as the Adams Mill Road, said place being known as the Adams Mill Place, and containing Twentytwo Hundred twentyseven (2227) acres, more or less, and being now or formerly bounded as follows: North by lands formerly of Young and lands formerly of Perkins, East by Moseley and lands of the estate of E.

E. ee, South by lands of Moseley, the Adams Mill Road separating, property of Truesdale and property of Lee, and by Long Branch separating property of Brown, and West by property formerly of McRae and by Jacobs Branch, property of Polson and property formerly of Elliott, now of Hawkins, and others.
The above described property is that described as Parcel 7 in that deed of W. R. Little, et al.

to G. T. Little, Jr., Ralph Little and Henry Savage, Jr., as Trustees under the Will of George T. Little, deceased, which deed is dated August 13, 1940 and may be found of record in the office of the Clerk of Court for Kershaw County in Book C.S. at page 209.
Approval required.No purchase of the above property shall be made until the written recommendation of the Kershaw County Recreation Commission approving the purchase shall be filed with the board.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 21st day of February, 1952.
1010 An Act To Create The Kershaw County Hospital Board And To Provide For Its Membership, Powers And Duties.
Kershaw County Hospital Boardappointment.There is hereby created the Kershaw County Hospital Board.

The board shall be composed of eleven members who shall be appointed by the Governor in the following manner: one member shall be appointed upon the recommendation of a majority of the Legislative Delegation from Kershaw County, one member shall be appointed upon the recommendation of the majority of the Kershaw County Board of Directors, two menibers shall be appointed upon the recommendation of the Kershaw County Medical Association and shall be members of the association, one member shall be appointed from each of the incorporated cities and towns in Kershaw County upon the recommendation of a majority of the members of the city council from each city or town, one member shall be appointed upon the recommendation of a majority of the Kershaw Ministerial Association and shall be a member of the association, one member shall be appointed upon the recommendation of a majority of the members of the Kershaw Farm Bureau and the Farm Council for Women, this member shall be a member of one of these organizations, one member shall be appointed upon the recommendation of a majority of the members of the Camden Hospital Auxiliary and shall be a member of the auxiliary.
No person shall be eligible for membership on the board who holds any other office of honor or profit.

Termspowers.The initial terms of the members of the board shall be as follows: the members selected by the delegation, the board of directors and the town councils shall serve for a term of two years, the other members of the board shall serve for a term of four years.
Upon the expiration of the initial terms of office, the members of the hoard shall serve for a term of four vears and until their successors are elected and qualify.
The board shall by a majority vote select one of its members as chairman and one as secretary.
The board shall have complete authority in the administration and management of any hospital which may thereafter be erected in Kershaw County.
The board shall have power to purchase any real estate necessary for the hospital and to accept any gifts made to the hospital.

The board shall forthwith assimilate plans for the construction and operation of the Kershaw County Hospital and shall let contracts therefor in the event the erection of the hospital and the issuance of bonds shall be approved by a majority of the qualified electors.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 3rd day of March, 1952.

1011 An Act To Authorize And Direct The County Board Of Directors Of Kershaw County To Issue Not Exceeding Two Million Dollars ($2,000,000.00) Of Bonds Of Kershaw County, The Proceeds Of Which Shall Be Expended For The Erection, Construction And Equipping Of A County Hospital, And For The Purchase Of Real Estate Necessary Therefor; To Provide For The Payment Of The Bonds And To Provide For A iefeenden On The Question Of The Issuance Of The Bonds.

Kershaw County may issue bonds.The County Board of Directors of Kershaw County shall be authorized and empowered to issue and sell not exceeding two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) of general obligation bonds of Kershaw County, the proceeds of which shall be expended for the purposes and in the manner prescribed by this act.
Name denomination maturities interest.The bonds shall be known as the Kershaw County Hospital Bonds of 1952.
They shall be in denominations of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
The bonds may be issued as a single issue or from time to time in several separate issues.
The bonds shall bear such rate or rates of interest, payable semiannually.

as the County Board of Directors of Kershaw County shall by resolution determine, provided that they are sold at an average annual interest cost to the county of not exceeding three per cent per annum.
Execution The bonds shall be executed in the name of Kershaw County by the Chairman of the County Board of Directors and the Treasurer of Kershaw County, under the seal of the treasurer.

Sale.The bonds may be sold by the county board of directors at not less than par and accrued interest to date of delivery, at either public or private sale, and if public sale the form, manner and occasion of advertisement shall be determined by the county board of directors.

Deposit and expenditure of proceeds.The proceeds derived from the sale of the bonds shall be deposited with the county treasurer in a separate and distinct fund, and shall be expended to defray the cost of erecting, constructing and equipping a county hospital, and to defray the cost of purchasing any real estate necessary therefor.
Purchasers of the bonds shall in no wise be responsible for the proper application of the proceeds from the sale of the bonds.

Payment.The full faith, credit and taxing power of Kershaw County shall be pledged for the payment of the bonds and the interest thereon, and the Auditor and Treasurer of Kershaw County, respectively, are hereby authorized and directed to levy and collect annually a tax upon all taxable property in the county sufficient to pay the principal and interest on the bonds as they respectively mature, and to create a sinking fund for the redemption of the bonds and interest at respective maturities.

Election on issuance.Before the bonds provided for in this act shall be issued and sold the question of issuing the bonds shall be submitted to the qualified electors of Kershaw County at the next general election to be held for members of the House of Representatives.

Ballots shall be provided at the various voting precincts with the following words printed or written thereon: Shall the County Board of Directors of Kershaw County issue and sell not exceeding two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) of general obligation bonds for the purpose of erecting, constructing and equipping a county hospital, and for the purchase of necessary real estate?

In favor of the issuance of the bonds O Opposed to the issuance of the bonds O Those voting in favor of the issuance of bonds shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the words In favor of the issuance of the bonds, and those voting against the issuance of the bonds shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the > square after the words Opposed to the issuance of the bonds .

Issue only if election favorable.In the event the results of the election shall favor the issuance of the bonds, then in that case, and that case only, the board shall proceed to issue and sell the bonds as set forth in this act.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 27th day of March, 1952.

1012 A Joint Resolution Proposing An Amendment To Section 1, Of Article V Of The Constitution Of South Carolina Of 1895, Relating To The Judicial Department Of The State So As To Establish A County Court For The County Of Kershaw With Such Jurisdiction As May Be Provided By The General Assembly Of This State.

Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1. Amendment to article V,  1, State Constitution, proposedKershaw County Court.The General Assembly of South Carolina proposes that Section 1 of Article V of the Constitution of South Carolina be amended by adding at the end thereof to be designated as Section 1B the following: A County Court is hereby established for the County of Kershaw with such jurisdiction as the General Assembly may provide. Section 2. Submission to electors.The question of adoption of this amendment shall be submitted to the qualified electors of this state at the next general election for the members of the House of Representatives of this state, and there shall be furnished at the voting places in this state a sufficient number of ballots with the following words plainly written or printed thereon, viz: Shall Section 1 of Article V of the Constitution of South Carolina of 1895 be amended by adding at the end thereof the following: A County Court is hereby established for the County of Kershaw with such jurisdiction as the General Assembly may provide. YES O NO 0 Those in favor of the adoption of such amendment shall strike out the word NO.
Those opposed to the adoption shall strike out the word YES. (R946, H2094) No.

1013 A Joint Resolution Proposing An Amendment To Section 5 Of Article X Of The Constitution, Relating To The Limit Of The Bonded Indebtedness Of Certain Political Subdivisions So As To Permit The County Of Kershaw To Incur Bonded Indebtedness Up To Twenty Per Cent Of The Assessed Value Of The Taxable Property Therein.

Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1. Amendment to article X,  5, State Constitution, proposedbonded indebtedness, Kershaw County.There is proposed the following amendment to Section 5, Article X, of the Constitution of this state, relating to the limit of bonded indebtedness of certain political subdivisions.

Add at the end of the section, as amended, the following : Provided, further, that the limitations imposed by this section shall not apply to Kershaw County and such county is authorized to incur bonded indebtedness to an amount not exceeding twenty per centum of the assessed value of all of the taxable property therein. Section 2. Submission to electorsThe proposed amendment shall be submitted to the qualified electors at the next general election for representatives.

Ballots shall be provided at the various voting precincts with the following words printed or written thereon: Shall Section 5, Article X of the Constitution of this state be amended so as to authorize Kershaw County to incur bonded indebtedness up to twenty per centum of the assessed value of the taxable property in the county ?

In favor of the amendment O Opposed to the amendment O Those voting in favor of the amendment shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the words In favor of the amendment, and those voting against the amendment shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the words Opposed to the amendment. (R872, H1949) No.
1014 An Act To Amend Section 5G Of Act No.

858 Of The Acts Of 1950, As Amended By An Act Ratified February 12, 1952, And Bearing Ratification Number 755, Relating To The Placing Of Candidates On Ballots, So As To Provide That In Municipal Elections In Kershaw County Nominees Shall Be Certified To At Least Thirty Days Prior To The Election.
Act 858 of 1950 amendedplacing of candidates on ballots in municipal elections during 1952, Kershaw County.Section 5G of Act No.

858 of the Acts of 1950, as amended 12, by an act ratified Vebruary 1952, and bearing ratitication number 735, is amended by adding at the end thereof the following: Provided, that in municipal elections in Kershaw County, during the year 1952, the nominees in a party primary held under the provisions of this act by any political party, certified as such by the Secretary of State under this act for one or more offices in a municipality of Kershaw County, to be voted on in the general clection of 1952, shall be placed upon the appropriate official ballot for the election as candidates of such party by the officer, commissioners, or other authority charged by law with preparing the ballot, if the names of the nominees are certified to said officer, commissioners, or other authority, as the case may be, at least thirty days prior to the date of the holding of the election. Section 2. Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 3rd day of March, 1952.
1015 An Act To Authorize The Town Of Kershaw To Enter Into A Contract With The Kershaw Oil Mill For The Purchase Of A Water Filter Plant.

Whereas, the town of Kershaw is faced with a critical water shortage, and, Whereas, the present water supply is inadequate to meet the needs of the town, and, Whereas, Kershaw Oil Mill has proposed the construction of a water filter plant and has agreed to sell the same to the town of Kershaw, and, Whereas, the General Assembly finds that this method is to the best interest of the town of Kershaw.
Now, Therefore, 3e it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1.

Kershaw may contract for purchase of water filter plant.The town of Kershaw is authorized to enter into a contract with the Kershaw Oil Mill for the purchase of a water filter plant to be constructed by the oil mill.
The contract shall contain such terms and provisions as the mayor and city council by proper resolution may determine.

1016 An Act To Provide For The Levy Of Taxes For Ordinary County And Road Purposes For The Fiscal Year July 1, 1952 To July 1, 1953, And To Provide For The Expenditure Thereof In The County Of Lancaster.

A tax of sufficient number of mills, less the estimated revenue to be received by Lancaster County in 1952, to pay the appropriations hereafter made, the amount of such millage to be determined by the county auditor, after consulting with the members of the Lancaster County Legislative Delegation, is hereby levied upon all taxable property of Lancaster County for county purposes for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1952, and ending June 30, 1953, for the amounts and purposes hereinafter stated, as follows, to wit: Section 2.
The fee for witnesses in the Court of General Sessions shall be three dollars per day and mileage, as now provided by law.
The fee for bailiffs, grand and petit jurors and court criers in the Court of General Sessions and Court of Common Pleas shall be five dollars per day and mileage, as now provided by law.
Roads, bridges, convjcts and maintenance of road working organizations $ 50,000.00 The above sum for road maintenance is in addition to the amount to be received from the one cent gasoline tax.

In view of the existing emergency, the Board of County Directors of Lancaster County is not forbidden to expend in any one quarter of the year for road and bridge purposes a sum in excess of onefourth of the total amount appropriated in this supply act, as prohibited in Section 4551 of the 1942 Code.

The Board of County Directors is hereby authorized and directed to use whatever money it may receive by reason of the rental or sale of any equipment or commodities produced by it for county or ordinary purposes, as now provided by law; provided, however, that said sum shall not be deducted from the appropriations made in this supply act.
