1053 An Act To Authorize The County Board Of Spartanburg County To Issue Not Exceeding Three Hundred Thousand Dollars ($300,000.00) Of Bonds Of Spartanburg County To Provide Funds For The Purchase Of Stone, Asphalt, Culverts And Other Road Materials To Be Used In Construction And Surface Treating Roads In The County; To Direct The Manner In Which The Bonds Shall Be Sold And The Manner In Which The Proceeds Thereof Shall Be Expended; And To Provide For The Payment Thereof.

Spartanburg County issue bonds.The County Board of Spartanburg County is hereby authorized and empowered to borrow from or through any agency of the United States Government, any bank, institution or lending agency, or as they deem advisable, not exceeding three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00), to be evidenced by serial coupon bonds, bearing interest not exceeding three per cent per annum payable semiannually, or otherwise, the principal of which shall mature during each year and in such installments as the County Board of Spartanburg County shall determine, but no installment shall mature later than twenty years after date of issue.

Maturities denominations issuance execution saleThe bonds as authorized in Section 1 shall be issued at such time or times and shall mature at such times and shall be issued in such denominations as may be determined by the County Board of Spartanburg County, except as may be otherwise herein specifically provided, and in such amounts as necessary, based upon the requests of the Supervisor of Spartanburg County.
The supervisor shall file with the request or requests general specifications and plans for which funds are necessary for road materials, stone, asphalt and culverts.

The bonds shall be signed by the members of the county board, or a majority thereof, and countersigned by the Clerk of the County Board of Spartanburg County, and the seal of the County Board of Spartanburg County shall be affixed to or impressed on each bond, but the coupons on the bonds need not be authenticated otherwise than by a facsimile signature of the county treasurer.
The principal and interest on the bonds may be payable within or without the State of South Carolina.

The bonds shall be payable to bearer but may be issued with the privilege to the holder of having them registered as to principal on the books of the county treasurer, and the principal thus made payable to the registered holder (unless the last registered transfer shall be to bearer) upon such conditions as the County Board of Spartanburg County may prescribe.
The bonds shall be sold and delivered upon a basis of not less than par and accrued interest.

Payment.So much as is necessary of the one cent gasoline tax distributed to Spartanburg County during the life of the bonds, and for such period thereafter as may be necessary to pay the same, shall be pledged and used and applied to the payment of the principal and interest on the bonds, notwithstanding any different use of said tax now prescribed; except that bonds authorized and issued under authority of Act 611 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1937, and any amendments thereto, in the sum of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) ; bonds authorized and issued under the authority of Act 709 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1939, and any amendments thereto, in the sum of two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) ; bonds authorized and issued under authority of Act 946 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1942, and any amendments thereto, in the sum of one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) ; bonds authorized and issued under authority of Act 812 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1946, and any amendments thereto, in the sum of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) and bonds authorized and issued under authority of Act No.
664 of the Acts of 1949 and any amendments thereto, in the sum of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) are a prior lien until such bonds are fully retired.

If for any reason whatsoever the gasoline tax is insufficient for the prompt payment of the bonds and the interest thereon as they severally mature, then there is hereby pledged, in addition to the revenue from the gasuline tax distributed to Spartanburg County, the full faith and credit of Spartanburg County, and there shall be levied annually upon all the taxable property in Spartanburg County, by the county auditor, and collected by the county treasurer, a tax sufficient to pay the principal and interest on the bonds as they respectively mature.

Deposit and disbursement of proceedsapproval of work.The proceeds of the sale of the bonds shall be deposited with the county treasurer in a special account to be disbursed for the purposes herein stated by the treasurer on warrants drawn thereon by the County Board of Spartanburg County, upon properly itemized and sworn statements of the county supervisor.

Provided, that the prior approval in writing of a majority of the Spartanburg County Legislative Delegation, including the Senator, shall be obtained before any work shall be begun involving the expenditure of any funds from the proceeds of the sale of the bonds authorized herein.

Purchase of road materials.All stone, asphalt, culverts and road materials purchased from the proceeds of the sale of the bonds herein authorized shall be purchased by the County Supervisor of Spartanburg County, subject, however, to the following provisions and conditions, to wit: Prior to each purchase of any such stone, asphalt, culverts or other road materials, the supervisor shall make up necessary and adequate specifications and descriptions of the same and file a duplicate thereof in the office of the County Board of Spartanburg County.

He shall thereupon advertise for bidders to furnish such stone, asphalt, culverts, or other road materials in one or more of the daily Spartanburg papers and publish the same therein not less than one time at least two weeks prior to the date and place of sale, which shall be specified in such advertisement.

The advertisement likewise shall contain a notice to prospective bidders requiring them to make up and file their bids, duly sealed, with the county supervisor, and a duplicate thereof in the office of the county board, none of such bids to be opened until the time specified in the notice of sale for the opening of bids.

The advertisement shall further contain a notice to the prospective bidders that all bids are subject to the final approval or disposal of the county board, and the county board is hereby given the power and authority, after receipt of such bids and the presentation to the board by the county supervisor of his recommendation as to the acceptance or rejection thereof, to accept or reject any and all such bids as may have been made and filed.
In the event of the rejection of all bids, new bids shall be advertised for by the county supervisor subject to the terms and provisions hereinabove set forth.
The County Board of Spartanburg County is directed to have all inaterials shipped in the most economical way.

Use of bond proceeds.The proceeds of the sale of bonds authorized under this act shall be used for the purchase of stone, asphalt, culverts and other road materials, and for the employment of skilled labor for the construction and surface treatment of roads in Spartanburg County.

Provided, the County Board of Spartanburg County is authorized and empowered to use all or any part of the proceeds from the sale of bonds for matching or securing federal aid or any other aid to the extent deemed necessary or advisable by the County Board of Spartanburg County to the end that greater mileage of roads may be constructed and surface treated than would be without such grants or matching of federal or other funds, subject to the proviso contained in Section 4 of this act .

InvalidityThe section and provisions of this act are separable and not matters of mutual essential inducement, and it is intended to confer the whole or any part of the powers herein provided for; and if any of the section or provisions or parts thereof are for any reason illegal, it is intended that the remaining section and provisions, or parts, shall remain in full force and effect.
Bonds exempt from taxes.The bonds, both as to principal and interest, shall be exempt from all state, county and municipal taxes in the hands of the holders.
Time effective.This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 27th day of March, 1952
1054 An Act To Amend Section 3 Of Act No.

54 Of The Acts Of The General Assembly Of 1943, Entitled An Act Creating The Board Of Trustees Of The Spartanburg Tuberculosis Hospital, Prescribing Its Powers, Authority And Duties, So As To Further Provide The Method Of Paying Claims Against The Spartanburg Tuberculosis Hospital.
Act 54 of 1943 amendedpayment of claims against Spartanburg Tuberculosis Hospital.Section 3 of Act No.

54 of the Acts of the General Assembly of South Carolina, 1943, entitled An Act Creating the Board of Trustees of the Spartanburg Tuberculosis Hospital, Prescribing its Powers, Authority and Duties, approved March 25, 1943, is herchy amended by striking out all of the proviso reading as follows: PROVIDED, that all claims against the hospital shall be itemized and verified and approved in writing by a majority of the said Board of Trustees of said Hospital and inserting in lieu thereof the following: PROVIDED, that all claims against the FU aD hospital shall be itemized and verified and shall be payable by vouchers through the county treasurers office when signed by such person or persons as may be designated in the bylaws of the hospital by the board of trustees and when countersigned by the Clerk of the County Board of Spartanburg County or some person under his employ designated by the county board, so that Section 3 when so amended, shall read as follows section 3.

All taxes levied for the maintenance and support of the said hospital shall be collected by the county treasurer, and the funds so collected held by him as a separate fund, to be paid out on order of the County Board of Spartanburg County; PROVIDED that all claims against the hospital shall be itemized and verified and shall be payable by vouchers through the county treasurers office when signed by such person or persons as may be designated in the bylaws of the hospital by the board of trustees and when countersigned by the Clerk of the County Board of Spartanburg County or some person under his employ designated by the county board. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed .

1055 An Act To Amend Act No.
1287 Of The Acts Of 1938 Relating To The Committee For The Spartanburg Metropolitan SubDistrict B In Spartanburg County So As To Fix The Compensation For The Members Of The Committee.
Act 1287 of 1938 amendedCommittee, Spartanburg Metropolitan SubDistrict B, Spartanburg Countyelectionvacancyappointmentpay.Section 1 of Act No.

1287 of the Acts of 1938 relating to the committee for the Spartanburg Metropolitan SubDistrict B in Spartanburg County, is amended by striking out all of same and inserting in lieu thereof the following to be Section 1 section 1.

That in the Spartanburg Metropolitan SubDistrict B where the committee consists of three members and where such memhers were recommended by the Spartanburg Legislative Delegation and appointed by the Governor under the authority of Act No.
1131, Acts of the General Assembly 1930, to serve as the committee for the Spartanburg Metropolitan SubDistrict B, Spartanburg County, such appointments are hereby declared vacant as of July 1, 1938.
That elections be held, noticed, ordered and the results thereof declared as herein provided for elections to fill the terms designated.
The successors of the now existing committee of the SubDistrict B shall be named in an election to be held the second Tuesday in May.

One member of the Committee for the Spartanburg Metropolitan SubDistrict B shall be elected for two years, a second member for four years, and the third member for six years, and thereafter one member shall be elected every two years for a six year term.
The member who is elected for six years shall be chairman and each member elected thereafter shall serve the last two years of his term as chairman.

The elections shall be conducted by three managers appointed by the Committee for the Spartanburg Metropolitan SubDistrict B, and it shall be their duty to make all necessary preparation for the holding of such election, to hold and conduct the same and to canvass the ballots and to declare the results of the election in accordance with the rules and regulations provided for the holding of general elections in this state.
That the expenses of such elections shall be paid, upon properly approved warrants, by the Committee for the Spartanburg Metropolitan SubDistrict B out of the water rent collected.
No member of the committee in office shall be eligible to serve as a manager.

Also the committee shall post notice of the election to be held at three places within the district, one of which shall be on the door of the school house in the district not less than ten days before the election.
Also put notice of the election in one of the daily papers in Spartanburg County not less than ten days before the election is held.

In the event of the death or resignation of any member of the committee the Governor shall appoint, upon a recommendation of a majority of the Spartanburg County Legislative Delegation, a member to fill the vacancy for the unexpired term.

It shall be the duty of the managers within five days after any election to certify the result of such election to the State Election Commission of Spartanburg County who shall, in turn, certify those elected to the Governor of the State of South Carolina and those so certified shall be appointed to serve as the committee by the Governor for the terms designated.

The Committee for the Spartanburg Metropolitan SubDistrict B shall receive such compensation for their services as the committee may fix not to exceed twenty dollars per month for each member thereof; provided, that such compensation shall be paid only from surplus funds of the subdistrict.
Provided, that said surplus funds shall be certified and verified by the special auditor for Spartanburg County. Section 2. Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.

In the purchase of equipment, or articles needed in the operation of any branch of the county government, or in the employment of any person, firm or corporation, for any service to be rendered to the County of Sumter, price and quality being equal, preference shall be given to citizens of Sumter County, if available.

but if not available within the county, then preference on same basis shall be given to persons, firms or corporations of the State of South Carolina, and where not available within the county or state they may be procured to best advantage from other sources.

All county supply purchases (except for schools) shall be made through the office of the county board of commissioners and on purchases amounting to fifty dollars or more, where possible, bids from two or more vendors will be called for.

The Treasurer of Sumter County is hereby author ized, empowered and directed to pay any sum or sums of money from such fund or funds and for such purposes as she may be directed in writing by a majority of the Sumter County Legislative Delegation.

The clerk of court shall have the custody and control of the second floor of the courthouse from the date of the appfoV of this act and no use shall be had of that part of the building without the consent and approval of the clerk.

The expense of jury pay and court, while herein fixed at five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) (Item A120), the commission of assistant tax collectors (Item A200), and the payments due South Carolina Retirement System (Item A213) may vary in accordance with the fixed charges payable under such items, and by reason thereof the appropriations thereunder may not be sufficient.
The county board of commissioners shall publish in at least one newspaper published in the county, a consolidated statement of all receipts and disbursements annually, as of July 1 of each year.

The tax levy for the school districts shall be levied only with the written authorization of the county board of education, and the same shall not be increased or decreased without such written authorization, and only so much tax shall be levied as may be required to raise the amount of the budget approved by the county board of education.

17 may raise or lower the levy for ordinary school purposes as may be necessary to pay the current expenses of the district, and the Auditor of Sumter County shall fix the levy for the district as may be by resolution of said board determined.

The auditor shall reduce the millage of the school districts of Sumter County to such millage as shall raise the amount needed for current expense, as shown by the budget approved by the county board of education for such school districts.
The county auditor shall deliver the tax books to the county treasurer not later than September first of each year.

The Treasurer of Sumter County is directed to pay to the City of Sumter onefourth of all amounts received from the tax on gasoline which is designated for general county purposes to be used for the maintenance of streets in the City of Sumter.

The account hereby limited is designated A101 above and the county treasurer is authorized to pay only the amount fixed by this Section 12, whether more or less than the amount shown under A101 above.
The personal property of the personnel on active duty in the United States Air Force living at Shaw Air Force Base shall be exempt from taxes.

1057 An Act To Appropriate Money For The Ordinary Operating Expenses Of Union County For The Fiscal Year Beginning With July 1, 1952, And Ending With June 30, 1953, And To Appropriate Money For Certain Other Purposes; To Raise The Revenue To Meet Said Appropriations; To Provide For The Levy And Collection Of Taxes For Certain School Purposes; To Prescribe Certain Regulations With Respect To The Government Of Union County During Said Fiscal Year; To Prohibit The Sale Of Wine And Beer At Certain Times In Union County, And To Provide A Penalty For The Violation Thereof; And To Provide For The Assumption By Union County Of Any Operating Deficits Incurred In The Operation Of Wallace Thomson Hospital For Two Years, And To Make Supplemental Appropriations For The Fiscal Year 195152.

For the fiscal year beginning with July 1, 1952 and ending with June 30, 1953, the Auditor of Union County is hereby authorized and directed to levy, and the Treasurer of Union County to collect, as and when other county property taxes are levied and collected, upon all the taxable property in Union County, a tax of such millage as will, when added to all other income or revenue received by said county for general purposes during said fiscal year, produce sufficient funds to meet the sums of money appropriated in Section 1 hereof.

The salary of no employee of Union County shall be increased or supplemented from any county funds above the amount appropriated for such employee in Section 1 hereof, except with the unanimous consent of the Union County Legislative Delegation.

For the fiscal year as aforesaid, the Auditor of Union County is hereby authorized and directed to levy, and the Treasurer of Union County to collect, as and when other county property taxes are levied and collected, upon all the taxable property in Union County, a tax of one mill for free textbook replacements.
The Grand Jury of Union County shall appoint the auditor to audit the books of Union County; Provided, however, that the person or firm so appointed shall be a certified public accountant.
The original of the audit shall be filed with the clerk of court who shall keep the same on file as a public audit, and a copy thereof shall be furnished to each member of the legislative delegation.
In all matters to be decided by the Union County Delgation, its Senator shall be one of the majority except where otherwise provided by general law.

The supervisor and governing board of Union County shall be the sole purchasing agent for all supplies, equipment, machines, etc., used by any officer, agent or department of Union County, and all purchases in excess of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be made on a competitive bid basis after advertisement in the Union Daily Time for a period of ten days prior to such purchases; Provided, that such advertisement shall be published twice during such tenday period.

No vouchers or warrants for purchases made in violation of this section (except emergency purchases provided for in Section 14 hereof) shall be approved for payment by said supervisors and governing board or paid by the county treasurer.
The bookkeeper of Union County shall be the custodian of the courthouse and courthouse grounds and he shall have supervision over the courthouse janitor.

Provided, however, the respective magistrates shall be allowed to retain their costs and fees in all civil matters as a part of their compensation; and the sheriff, as constable for the magistrate at Union County Courthouse, shall likewise be allowed to retain his costs and fees as a part of his compensation.

The Supervisor of Union County shall have general supervision of, and be responsible for, all county roads and bridges, the county chaingangs, and the county home; Provided, however, the captain of the chaingang shall be in immediate charge and control of all persons employed at the county chaingang, and such employees shall be subordinate to the chaingang captain, regardless of their titles or duties, and for sufficient cause the captain is hereby empowered to suspend any such employee or employees for a period of not more than thirty (30) days for any one cause and on any one occasion.

Such suspended employee shall have the right of appeal to the County Governing Board, which body shall hold such hearings as may be deemed necessary to determine the facts and pass on the merits of such suspension, and in its discretion may take the same or similar action to that provided for in the following section of this act in cases where the captain of the chaingang may be suspended by the supervisor.

And in cases of emergency, arising from any cause, where a county road or bridge has become, or is about to become hazardous, dangerous, or impassible to traffic, then the supervisor shall take immediate action on his own initiative, even if it be necessary temporarily to stop work that has been ordered or directed by the governing board, to meet and overcome such emergency, and he shall cause such work to be done as to afford traffic reasonable and safe passage over such road or bridge.

The powers and authority herein granted to the County Governing Board, the county supervisor and the captain of the chaingang shall be in addition to and cumulative with the authority the said governing board, supervisor and captain of the chaingang now have under and pursuant to the laws and statutes of this State.

The County Governing Board is hereby authorized and empowered to elect or appoint the employees of the chaingang and county farms and home for a term of twelve months, beginning January 1, 1953, and thereafter the term of employment of such employees shall begin on January Ist of each year; Provided, however, that any of the said employees may be suspended or removed as prescribed in section 11 and 12 hereof.
The county supervisor and the Union County Governing Board may authorize the clerk and bookkeeper to make purchases not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00) in cases of emergency.

The said clerk and bookkeeper shall give bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties, the premium for said bond to be paid as the premiums for the bonds of other county officers are now paid.
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale any wine or beer in Union County between the hours of 12 oclock Saturday night and sunrise Monday morning.
Any person, firm or corporation violating this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or by imprisonment for not exceeding thirty (30) days.

The right of any person to sell wine and beer in Union County at any time, under a license issued by the State, shall be forfeited, and the license revoked, upon conviction of violating the provisions of this section.
The County of Union is hereby authorized and directed to assume and pay any operating deficits incurred in the operation of Wallace Thomson Hospital for the first two years of such operation.

Any circus, carnival or other such admission charging show or amusement that usually exhibits under a tent or outdoors may exhibit in Union County without payment of any license fee or charge; provided, that such exhibition is made under the auspices or sponsorship of a local eleemosynary association or organization and pursuant to a contract requiring such association or organization to pay the license for such exhibition; and provided further, that such exhibition is first approved as to time and place by the Executive Secretary and Treasurer of Union County Fair Association.

The amount appropriated in and by Item 11C (Hospital Contingent lund) of the Union County Supply Act for the fiscal year 195152, is hereby increased by the amount of $7,000.00 in order to cover the operating deficit of Wallace Thomson Hospital for said fiscal year; and the amount appropriated in Item 10F (Delegation Contingent Fund) of said act, is hereby increased by $1,000.00 to cover contingencies for the remainder of said fiscal year.
This act is continuous, and of continuous force, and continuing into the future until changed by a repealing act of the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina.

If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, phrase, clause, word, or provision of this act shall be held unconstitutional or invalid for any reason, the same shall not affect, impair or invalidate any of the remaining sections, subsections, paragraphs, sentences, phrases, clauses, words or provisions of this act.
1058 An Act To Authorize The Trustees Of School District No.

11 Of Union County To Borrow Not Exceeding Ten Thousand Dollars ($10,000.00) To Be Used For The Purchase Of Real Estate Or To Repay Indebtedness Incurred In The Purchase Of Real Estate, And To Provide A Tax For The Payment Thereof.
11 borrow purchase real estate, Union County.The Board of Trustees of School District No.

11 of Union County is authorized to borrow from the sinking fund of South Carolina not exceeding the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for the purchase of real estate or to repay indebtedness incurred in the purchase of real estate.

The amount so borrowed shall be evidenced by notes to be executed by each member of the board and the treasurer of the county, and shall bear interest at not exceeding four per cent and shall be payable within a period of four years from the date of the notes.

Payment.lIn order to provide for the payment of the loan and interest thereon, the auditor shall levy and the treasurer shall collect an annual tax upon all of the taxable property of the district sufficient to retire the loan plus interest within a period of four years.

The county supervisor may, whenever he and the county board of commissioners deem it wise, hire a civil engineer from time to time when the services of one are needed, the civil engineer to be paid out of Miscellaneous Contingent Fund.

All revenues accruing to the county not otherwise appropriated shall be deposited or invested by the treasurer as a sinking fund for the payment of principal and interest of the county bonded indebtedness and such investments or deposits to be guaranteed by bond of indemnity or other adequate security to be passed on by the board of county commissioners.
All county officers, before making purchases of books or stationery and all other supplies, shall so notify the county board of commissioners in writing and receive the said commissioners approval.

1060 An Act To Make Appropriations For The South Carolina Sanitorium, The Williamsburg County Health Unit, And For Hospitalization Of Indigent Persons For The Fiscal Year 195253.

Appropriation for health purposes, Williamsburg County.There is hereby appropriated from the county health funds of Williamsburg County for the South Carolina Sanitorium three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) ; for the Williamsburg County Health Unit five thousand dollars ($5,000.00); and for hospitalization of indigent persons five thousand eight hundred dollars ($5,800.00).

Provided, that the sum appropriated for the hospitalization of indigent persons shall be expended only upon approved certificates by the board of public welfare of Williamsburg County and shall be expended on per diem basis to be fixed by the board, such basis shall include the cost of room, board, medicine, and anesthetics, etc., and there shall not be expended on any one case a greater sum than seventyfive dollars.

Provided, further, that the board may in extreme or extraordinary cases approve further expenditures but the county shall not be liable for additional sums unless authorization by the board is first secured.
Provided, further, should the sums appropriated herein exceed the amount in the county health fund then the appropriation shall be made from the general county fund.
The appropriation herein made shall be for the fiscal year 195253.

1061 An Act To Authorize And Direct The County Treasurer Of Williamsburg County To Transfer The Sum Of TwentyEight Thousand One Hundred SixtyOne Dollars ($28,161.00) Of The General Fund Of The County To Kingstree School District.

Fund transfer, Williamsburg CountyThe Treasurer of Williamsburg County is hereby authorized and directed to transfer the sum of twentyeight thousand one hundred sixtyone dollars ($28,161.00) from the general fund of the county to Kingstree school district for the purpose of completing and equipping the new elementary school building.

Repeal.All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed Section 8. Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor Approved the 12th day of March, 1952 (R811, S567) No.

1062 An Act To Create A Courthouse Commission For Williamsburg County, To Authorize Such Commission To Employ An Architect To Provide Plans And Specifications For The Repair And Improvement Of The Present Courthouse Of The County And For An Addition Thereto, Prescribing The Powers And Duties Of The Courthouse Commission, And Providing Funds For Payment Of Expenses Incurred By Such Commission Whereas, it is made to appear that it is to the public interest of Williamsburg County to repair and improve the existing courthouse and to make an addition thereto.
Now, Therefore Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina Section 1.

Williamsburg County courthouse commissionelectiontermvacancypay.That there is hereby created a Courthouse Commission for Williamsburg County to consist of five members, to be elected by a majority of the Williamsburg County Legislative Delegation, the elections to be certified to in writing by the chairman and secretary of the Williamsburg County Legislative Delegation and the originals thereof shall be filed in the office of the Clerk of Court for Williamsburg County where they shall be kept and maintained as public records of the County.
The members of the commission shall continue to act for a period of three years, unless the repair improvement and addition to the courthouse is completed prior to that time.

Any vacancy occurring in the membership of the commission shall be filled by a majority of the Williamsburg County Legislative Delegation and such election shall be certified to as hereinabove required for original elections.
The members of the commission shall serve without compensation.

Plans and specifications for improvement of courthouse.That the courthouse commission hereby created is for the purpose of engaging an architect to prepare plans and specifications for repairing and improving the Williamsburg County Courthouse and for the construction of an addition thereto, and such commission is hereby authorized and empowered to engage a suitable architect and employ him to prepare plans and specifications for repairing and improving the Williamsburg County Courthouse and for the construction of an addition thereto; to approve and accept such plans and specifications and draw their warrant on the County Treasurer of Williamsburg County for the purpose of paying such architect and for any other expenses incident to or in connection with the preparation of such plans and specifications.
Provided, however, the total of such architects fees and other expenses shall not exceed the sum of twentyfive hundred dollars ($2,500.00).

Payment of expenses.The commission hereby created shall have the power and authority to draw its warrant on the County of Williamsburg, to be approved by the board of county commissioners for the necessary funds, to be known as planning money and to be used for the payment of architects fees and expenses authorized to be incurred hereby.

Provided, that a record of all sales and dispositions of all products and property of the County Home shall be kept hy the superintendent of the Home and filed annually with the supervisors office.
That the purchase of gasoline, oil and food for the use of the Prison Farm or at the County Home shall be made in wholesale quantities.

In the township of York, a special levy of onehalf (14) mill is hereby made, the proceeds therefrom to be paid by the Treasurer of York County to the York Public Library, and the Auditor of York County is hereby directed to levy and the Treasurer of York County is hereby directed to collect all taxes levied.

The appropriations herein provided shall not in any case be exceeded and any contracts which may be made will in any manner provide for the expenditure of funds in excess of those provided herein shall not be binding upon York County, and it is specifically provided that any person selling supplies or other commodities or rendering service to the county is charged with the duty of ascertaining in advance whether or not the appropriations for that purpose are sufficient to pay for the same; Provided, further, that no revenue to be derived from any levy or appropriation made herein shall be expended or pledged prior to the beginning of the fiscal year 19521953.

No money appropriated for any specific purpose under the provisions of the act shall be used for any other purpose than that named without the written consent of a majority of the York County House Delegation and Senator.
Any amount appropriated in this act may be discontinued at any time by order of onehalf of the House Delegation and the Senator.

In addition to all countywide taxes now levied for school purposes, the auditor shall levy a tax of eight (8) mills to be used for the following purposes and distributed in the following manner: The proceeds from three (3) mills shall be distributed to all school districts in proportion to the ratio that each school districts state aid for school teachers salaries bears to the total school teachers state aid for salaries in the county.

The proceeds from five (5) mills shall be distributed to each high school or high school district in proportion to the ratio that each high school or high school districts enrollment bears to the total high school enrollment in the county.

Provided, however, that enrollment in parochial schools or in state owned and operated schools shall not be counted and shall not be allowed the use of any of the proceeds of the tax imposed in this section.

Provided, further, that the proceeds from the five mill high school tax contained in this section, and the five mill high school tax now imposed by statute shall be used for the sole purposes of payment of bonds and bond interest, or for the payment of short term notes of indebtedness, the proceeds from which was, or shall be used for huilding and/or building improvements and equipment of schools in said districts.

Provided, further, that no school district shall impose a levy of more than ten (10) mills on the property within said district, except to provide for the payment of interest on, and retirement of bonded indebtedness, except upon the written approval of a majority of the York County Legislative Delegation, including the Senator.

The county supervisor and the county board of commissioners are hereby empowered to borrow in anticipation of the revenue hereinabove provided any sum not exceeding the amount appropriated and to not only pledge the revenue hereinabove provided but to pledge the full faith and credit of York County for the repayment of the same.

The money shall be borrowed from the York County Sinking Fund Commission at a rate of interest not exceeding three per cent and to be payable at such time and in such sums as is convenient to the county board of commissioners and the sinking fund commission, and the sinking fund commission is hereby directed to make such loans.

In publishing quarterly statements of the financial condition of York County in various newspapers of the county, the supervisor shall publish only the amount appropriated and the unexpended balances in each appropriation.

All county offices in the York County Courthouse shall observe as holidays Christmas Day, the working day immediately preceding Christmas and the working day immediately following Christmas Day, New Years Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving and July fourth.
All orders heretofore made by the Legislative Delegation are hereby ratified and confirmed, and the appropriations therein contained are approved.
There is hereby levied on York Township as constituted prior to 1949 one (1) mill levy for the use of the maintenance of the York War Memorial.

The Treasurer of York County is hereby authorized and directed to return funds in the amount of Nine Thousand, Nine Hundred and Nine Dollars and Fiftynine Cents ($9,909.59) collected in Fort Mill Township for road work in the township on July 25, 1950, to the Town Council of Fort Mill.
The Council shall expend these funds for public improvements.

For the purpose of creating a contingency fund all money paid to York County for school buses by the State of South Carolina shall after the payment of all indebtedness due the Sinking Fund Commission of York County borrowed for the purpose of purchasing said buses shall be credited to a fund designated as a Contingent Fund and shall be expended by such administrative boards as designated by at least onehalf of the York County House Delegation and the Senator.
Provided, that not more than $50,000.00 shall be used as a contingent fund from the fund arising from the sale of school buses.

1064 A Joint Resolution To Authorize And Direct The County Treasurer Of York County To Refund Monies Paid By Certain Taxpayers For The Fiscal Years 19431949 Upon Land Charged To And For Which Taxes Had Been Paid By Another Taxpayer.

Whereas, the books and records in the offices of the County Treasurer and the County Auditor of the County of York show that Charlie Shipman returned and paid state and county taxes upon a certain tract of land in Bethesda Township, School District No.

6, in York County, South Carolina, containing 155 acres, more or less, and personal property for the years 19431949; and Whereas, the said Charlie Shipman was in possession of said land under a Contract of Purchase and Sale from C.W.F. Spencer and Mary A. White, and was obligated to pay taxes thereon or refund the amount paid for taxes to the said C.W.F. Spencer and Mary A. White; and Whereas, the said C.W.F. Spencer and Mary A. White, without knowledge that the said Charlie Shipman had returned and was paying the said taxes upon the land, paid the state and county taxes for the years 19431949 upon the same property assessed in their names in the same township and district as 150 acres; and Whereas, as a result of the double entry an overpayment of taxes has been made, on account of which there should be refunded to C.W. F. Spencer and Mary A. White the sum of two hundred dollars and sixtynine cents ($200.69), paid by them for the years aforesaid; Now, Therefore, Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1.

Tax refund by York County.That the Treasurer of York County be and he is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to refund to the said C.W.F. Spencer and Mary A. White the aforesaid sum of two hundred dollars and sixtynine cents ($209.69) paid by them as taxes for the years 19431949 on 150 acres of land in Bethesda Township, School District No.
Repeal.aAll acts or patts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.

1065 An Act To Create The York County Public Buildings Commission, To Prescribe Its Functions And Powers, And To Enable The Commission To Issue Not Exceeding Eight Hundred Thousand Dollars ($800,000.00) Of General Obligation Bonds Of York County, To Prescribe The Procedure For The Issuance Of Such Bonds, The Purposes For Which Their Proceeds Shall Be Applied,And To Make Provision For Their Payment.

York County Public Buildings Commissionappointmenttermsvacancy.There is hereby created a Commission in York County to be known as York County Public Buildings Commission, which Commission shall consist of five members, to be appointed by the Governor upon recommendation of at least onehalf of the York County House Delegation and the Senator.
The terms of office of said members shall be for such period of time as may be necessary to accomplish the purposes of this act.

Any vacancy existing in the membership of the Commission, by reason of death, resignation or otherwise, shall be filled in the same manner as provided for in the appointment of the original Commission.
Officerspay.The members of the commission shall select one of themselves as chairman and one of themselves as secretary.

All members shall serve without salary, but shall be paid a per diem of ten dollars ($10.00) per day to cover expense for each day the commission shall find it necessary to hold a regular meeting in consection with the performance and discharge of the duties herein imposed upon the commission.

Buildings and facilities provideThe York County Public Buildings Commission created for the purpose of building, erecting, constructing, equipping and furnishing the following county buildings and facilities: (1) An annex, addition or improvements to the York County Courthouse, at a cost of not exceeding one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) ; (2) A building which shall furnish facilities designed to disseminate among the farmers of York County, for practical purposes, scientific knowledge for the improvement of agriculture and agricultural practices in York County.
(3) A building or buildings to be located in the City of Rock Hill, to house county offices and agencies serving the public interests of York County.

Issue bonds.(1) In order to provide funds for the construction and equipment of the buildings enumerated in Section 3, to pay the cost of any land which must be acquired for such purposes, and to defray any further costs and expenses which may be incurred by said commission in carrying out the functions committed to it, the said York County Public Buildings Commission shall be authorized and empowered to issue general obligation bonds of York County in an amount not exceeding eight hundred thousand dollars ($800,000.00).

(2) Such bonds may be issued as one single issue, or from time to time as several separate issues; they shall bear such date or dates as the commission shall determine, and the bonds of any issue shall mature in such equal or unequal annual installments as may be determined by the commission, except that the last maturing bonds of any issue shall mature not later than thirty years from their date.
They shall be made payable at such place or places as the commission shall prescribe, and they shall bear interest at a rate not to exceed four per cent.

Such bonds may be issued with the privilege to the holder of having them registered as to principal on the books of the Treasurer of York County, and the principal thus made payable to the registered holder (unless the last registered transfer shall have been to bearer) upon such conditions as the commission may prescribe.
Such bonds may be made subject to redemption prior to their stated maturities on such terms and conditions, and with such redemption premiums as the commission shall prescribe.

(3) Such bonds shall be executed in the name of the York County Public Buildings Commission by the chairman and the secretary of the commission, under such seal as the commission shall adopt, it being hereby expressly empowered to adopt a Seal.
The coupons attached to such bonds shall be authenticated by the facsimile signatures of the chairman and the secretary of the commission, who are in office on the date of such bonds.
The delivery of any bonds so executed and authenticated shall be valid notwithstanding any changes in officers or seal occurring after such execution or authentication.

(4) For the payment of all bonds issued by the commission, both principal and interest, as the same respectively mature, the full faith, credit, resources and taxing power of York County shall be pledged, and there shall be levied and collected by the Auditor and Treasurer of York County, respectively, an ad valorem tax upon all taxable property in York County, without limitation as to rate or amount, sufficient to pay the interest on such bonds and the bonds as they respectively mature.
The taxes, when so levied and collected, shall he held by the Treasurer of York County, separate and distinct from all other funds and used solely for the purposes for which levied and collected.

(5) The proceeds of all bonds issued by the commission shall be disposed of as follows: any premium or accrued interest shall be used to pay the first installment of principal and interest of its bonds.

The remainder of the proceeds shall be deposited with the Treasurer of York County in a separate and special fund, and shall be expended upon the warrants or orders of the commission for the purposes provided for by this act.

(6) All bonds issued pursuant to this act shall be sold at not less than par and accrued interest to the date of their respective deliveries, at public sale, and at least ten days prior to any sale, notice, announcing the intention to receive bids for the sale of any bonds authorized by this act, shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the State of South Carolina.

In offering the bonds for sale, the right shall be reserved to reject any and all bids, and if all bids are rejected, it shall be lawful to dispose of the bonds at private sale at a price not less than the best bid received on the occasion of the public offering.

(7) The bonds and the interest to become due thereon shall be exempt from all state, county,municipal, school district, and all other taxes or assessments, direct or indirect, general or special, whether imposed for the purpose of general revenue or otherwise.
This provision shall be deemed a part of the contract inuring to the benefit of all holders or beneficiaries of the bonds.

Sites for buildingacceptance of giftsThe buildings provided for herein, or any one or more of same, shall be built, erected and constructed upon real estate now owned by the county, or upon real estate hereafter acquired by the county.

The commission is hereby authorized to purchase any real estate for the purpose of building, erecting and constructing buildings, or any one or more of same, thereupon, and the title to any real estate so acquired shall be in fee simple.

The commission is authorized and empowered to apply for, receive and accept in and on behalf of the county, any gift or grant or money or any kind of property, or anything of value, from the United States of America, or from any of its agencies, or from any other source whatsoever, as aid in accomplishing the purposes of this act.
Any and all things of value received by the commission, under the provisions of this act, shall be received in the name of the county and held and used by the commission as an agency of the county.

The commission is authorized and empowered to appoint and employ an architect, attorney, secretary, surveyor, and such other officers, agents and employees as are necessary, to carry out the purposes of this act, and to fix their compensation and to execute and deliver contracts, as it deems advisable in carrying out the purposes of this act.
The commission is further authorized and empowered to do all other things reasonably expected to be done, in order to accomplish the purposes of this act.

Eminent domain.In addition to all other powers vested in it, the commission is hereby granted the power of eminent domain to enable it to obtain, through the exercise of such powers, suitable sites for the several buildings, whose construction it is empowered to effect.

Such power may be exercised through any procedure prescribed by Chapter 182, Code of Laws of South Carolina for 1942, or by following the procedure for the exercise of eminent domain by the State Highway Department, prescribed by Article IV, Act 329 of 1951, 47th Statutes at Large, page 479, et seq), as such statutes are now constituted or as they may hereafter be constituted, following any amendment hereafter made to any of them.

And, to that end, the commission shall have full and final authority to determine and designate the sites for the respective buildings whose construction is herein authorized; provided, always, that neither the York County Public Buildings Commission, nor the County of York, shall be under any obligation to accept or pay for any property condemned, and shall in no event pay for any property condemned or purchased except from the funds provided pursuant to the terms and provisions of this act.

Maintenance of buildingsreportsUpon the completion of the building, erection, construction, equipping and furnishing of the buildings as herein provided, or any one or more of same, the buildings and property upon which same are situated and all other property and things of value held by the commission,shall be turned over to the board of directors of the county, and from thenceforth on, the board of directors shall maintain the property, to the end that the purposes for which same were built, erected, constructed, equipped and furnished, may from time to time be met. On such occasion, the York County Public Buildings Commission shall furnish a full account of its actings and doings and of all moncys received and spent, whereupon its functions shall be deemed fulfilled.

InvalidityIn case any section, sentence, portion or provision of this act shall be held unconstitutional, such shall not, in ~~, orr4 any way, affect any other section, sentence, portion or provision of this act.
Repeal.aAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent with the provisions of this act are hereby repealed.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 15th day of April, 1952.

1066 An Act To Authorize The Sinking Fund Commission of York County And The State Highway Commission To Enter Into A Reimbursement Agreement With Respect To Monies Advanced By The Sinking Fund Commission To The State Highway Commission, For The Purpose Of Improving And Constructing Certain Roads In York County.

York County advance funds for road purposesreimbursement.The Sinking Fund Commission of York County is authorized and directed to advance to the State Highway Commission not exceeding three hundred twenty thousand dollars ($320,000.00), or so much thereof as may be necessary, to be used by the Highway Commission in improving and constructing roads in York County.

Eighty thousand dollars ($80,000.00), or so much thereof as may be necessary, of the funds so advanced shall be expended in improving and constructing roads within and adjacent to each of the following towns: Clover, Fort Mill, Rock Hill and York.
No interest shall be required to be paid on any funds advanced under the terms of this act.

The Sinking Fund Commission and the State Highway Commission are authorized and empowered to enter into an agreement whereby the State Highway Commission shall reimburse the Sinking Fund Commission of York County for all monies so advanced from the funds to accrue to York County for the construction of farmtomarket roads in the county.
All such funds, as they accrue, are pledged to the repayment of the monies advanced under this act.
Other than the terms specifically mentioned herein, the above named parties are authorized and empowered to determine all of the terms and conditions of the reimbursement agreement.
1067 A Joint Resolution To Provide For Transferring Of Microfilm Copies Of The York County Records To The Historical Commission Of South Carolina.

Transfer microfilm copies of York County records to State Historical Commission.The microfilm copies of the York County Records now in the custody of the clerk of court of the County shall be transferred to the custody of the Historical Commission of South Carolina under the following terms and conditions: (a) the ownership of the microfilms shall remain, as it now is.

in York County, (b) the microfilms shall be returned to the owner at any time on demand, (c) a copy of the microfilms shall be made from the originals and deposited with the Genealogical Society of Utah, and (d) the originals shall be kept constantly in a humidifying cabinet in the World War Memorial or other fireproof building of the Historical Commission, but may be used for research purposes under the supervision of the staff of the commission.
1068 An Act To Extend Until May 8, 1953, The Provisions Of Act No.
596 Of The Acts Of 1947, Relating To The Establishment And Operation Of The Juvenile And Domestic Relations Court Of CatawbaEbenezer Townships, York County, South Carolina.

Term of JuvenileDomestic Relations Court of CatawbaEbenezer Townships extended, York County.The provisions of an act entitled An Act To Create And Establish A Juvenile And Domestic Relations Court And Commission In Catawba And Ebenezer Townships, Of York County, South Carolina; To Provide For The Appointment Of A Judge, Etc. and designated as Act No.

596 of the Acts of 1947, approved May 8, 1947, are reenacted and are declared to be of as much force and effect as if they had been set forth verbatim in this act, except that the life and operation of the court shall not extend beyond May 8, 1953.

Funds use for operation.In addition to the annual revenue provided in the act for the expenses incident to the operation of the court, there is hereby appropriated from the treasury of the county, if so much be necessary, the unexpended balances arising from the one mill levy on the property in the aforementioned townships for the operation of the court since the establishment of the court.

These unexpended balances, or so much thereof as may be necessary, shall be devoted, in conjunction with the one mill tax levy authorized, to the payment of the expenses incident to the operation of the court from the date of the passage of this act until May 8, 1953.

1069 A Joint Resolution Proposing An Amendment To Article V, Section 21, Of The Constitution Of South Carolina, 1895, Relating To The Jurisdiction Of Magistrates, 80 As To Increase The Jurisdiction In Civil Cases Of Magistrates In York County To Where The Value Of Property In Controversy Or Amount Claimed Is Not More Than Three Hundred Dollars ($300.00).
Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1. Amendment to article V,  21, State Constitution, proposedjurisdiction of magistrates in civil cases, York County.

There is proposed the following amendment to Article V, Section 21, of the Constitution of this state: Add to Section 21 the following proviso: Provided, that in the County of York, the jurisdiction of magistrates in civil cases shall extend to where the value of property in controversy or the amount claimed is not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00). Section 2. Submission to electorsThe proposed amendment shall be submitted to the qualified electors of this state, at the next general election for representatives and shall be submitted in the following manner: Ballots shall be provided at the various voting precincts with the following words printed or written thereon: Shall the jurisdiction of magistrates in civil cases in the County of York be extended to where the value of property in controversy or amount claimed is not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) ?

In favor of the amendment O Opposed to the amendment 0 Those voting in favor of the amendment shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the words In favor of the amendment, and those voting against the amendment shall deposit a ballot with a check or cross mark in the square after the words :9 Opposed to the amendment .

1070 A Joint Resolution Proposing An Amendment To Section 5, Article X, Of The Constitution Of South Carolina, 1895, Relating To Bonded Indebtedness Of Counties, Townships, School Districts, Etc., By Adding Thereto A Proviso Increasing The Debt Limit Of York County.

Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina: Section 1. Amendment to article X,  5, State Constitution, proposedbonded indebtedness of York County.There is proposed the following amendment to Section 5, Article X, of the Constitution of South Carolina, 1895: Add at the end of the section the following: Provided, further, that the limitations as to bonded indebtedness imposed by this section shall not apply to bonded indebtedness incurred or to be incurred by York County, and the bonded indebtedness of York County may aggregate, but shall not exceed, twenty per cent of the assessed value of all taxable property therein.

In ascertaining the bonded indebtedness of York County, the bonded indebtedness of any township, school district, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision of the state, covering or extending over any part of the territory of York County, shall not be considered or taken into effect. Section 2. Submission to electors.The question of the adoption of the proposed amendment shall be submitted to the qualified electors of this state at the next general election for members of the House of Representatives in the following manner: There shall be furnished at the voting places in this state a sufficient number of ballots with the following words plainly written or printed thereon:Shall Section 5, Article X, of the Constitution of South Carolina, 1895, be amended so as to increase the debt limitation of York County to twenty per cent of the assessed value of all taxable property therein?
YES NO Those voting in favor of the amendment shall deposit a ballot with the word NO marked out.
Those voting against the amendment shall deposit a ballot with the word YES marked out. (R1016, H1844) No.
1071 | An Act To Authorize The Trustees Of Leslie School District No.

52, Of York County, The State Of South Carolina, To Issue Not Exceeding SeventyFive Thousand Dollars ($75,000.00) Of General Obligation Bonds Of The School District, To Prescribe The Purposes For Which The Proceeds Of The Bonds May Be Expended, And To Provide For The Payment Thereof.
Leslie School District No.
52 issue bonds, York CountyThe Board of Trustees of Leslie School District No.

52, of York County, the State of South Carolina, is authorized and empowered to issue and sell, either as a single issue or from time to time as several separate issues, not exceeding seventyfive thousand dollars ($75,000.00) of general obligation bonds of the school district pursuant to the provisions of this act.
Maturities redemption interest denomination registration.The bonds shall be issued as serial bonds, maturing in such equal or unequal amounts as the board of trustees may determine.
Each issue or series of bonds shall be in such denomination or denominations, and shall be pavable at such place or places as the trustees may by resolution determine.

Use of proceeds.The proceeds of any issue or series of bonds, issued pursuant to this act, shall, in the discretion of the trustees, be expended for all or any of the following purposes, that is to say: (1) For the purchase of real property for school purposes: (2) For the construction of new school buildings; (3) For the repair or improvement of existing school buildings: and, (4) For equipment for any public schools operated by the school district.
Sale.Each issue or series of bonds, issued pursuant to this act, shall be sold by the trustees at public sale.
Execution.All bonds issued pursuant to this act shall be executed in the name of Leslie School District No.
52, of York County, by the chairman and the secretary of its board of trustees, under the seal of the district, and countersigned by the Treasurer of York County.

Deposit and application of proceeds.The proceeds derived from the sale of bonds, issued pursuant to this act, shall be deposited with the Treasurer of York County in a special fund, separate and distinct from all other funds.

Exempt from taxes.The bonds and the interest to become due thereon shall be exempt from all state, county, municipal, school district, and all other taxes or assessments, direct or indirect, general or special, whether imposed for the purpose of general revenue or otherwise.

Payment.For the payment of the principal of and interest on the bonds as the same respectively mature, the full faith, credit and resources of the school district are hereby irrevocably e pledged, and there shall be levied annually by the Auditor of York County, and collected by the Treasurer of York County, in the same manner as county taxes are levied and collected, a tax, without limit, on all taxable property in the school district, sufficient to pay the principal of and interest on the bonds as the same respectively mature.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 6th day of March, 1952.
1072 An Act To Authorize The Trustees Of Fort Mill School District No.

28, Of York County, The State Of South Carolina, To Issue Not Exceeding Two Hundred Thousand Dollars ($200,000.00) Of General Obligation Bonds Of The School District, To Prescribe The Purposes For Which The Proceeds Of The Bonds May Be Expended, And To Provide For The Payment Thereof.

28, of York County, the State of South Carolina, is authorized and empowered to issue and sell, either as a single issue or from time to time as several separate issues, not exceeding two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) of general obligation bonds of the school district pursuant to the provisions of this act.

Maturities redemption interest denominations registration The bonds shall be issued as serial bonds, maturing in such equal or unequal amounts as the board of trustees may determine, except that the maturity schedule of any series or issue of bonds shall be arranged so that the last annual installment shall fall due not later than twentyfive years from the date such series or issue of bonds shall bear.

The bonds may be issued with the privilege to the holder of having them registered as to principal on the books of the Treasurer of York County and the principal thus made payable tc the registered holder (unless the last registered transfer shall have been to bearer) upon such conditions as the trustees may prescribe.

Use of proceeds.The proceeds of any issue or series of bonds, issued pursuant to this act, shall, in the discretion of the trustees, be expended for any of the following purposes : (1) For the purchase of real property for school purposes ; (2) For the construction of new school buildings; (3) For the repair or improvement of existing school buildings ; : and (4+) For equipment for any public schools operated by the school district.
The form, manner, and occasion of the advertisement for public sale shall be determined by the trustees.
No bonds shall be sold at less than par and accured interest to the date of delivery.
Execution.All bonds issued pursuant to this act shall be executed in the name of Fort Mill School District No.
Exempt from taxes.The bonds, both as to principal and interest, shall be exempt from all state, county, school, and municipal taxes.

Payment.For the payment of the principal of and interest on the bonds, as they respectively mature, the full faith, credit, and resources of the school district are hereby irrevocably pledged, and there shall be levied annually by the Auditor of York County and collected by the Treasurer of York County, in the same manner as county taxes are levied and collected, a tax, without limit on all taxable property in the school district, sufficient to pay the principal of and interest on the bonds as they respectively mature.
AdditionalThe bonds herein authorized to be issued are in addition to all other bonds or notes previously authorized to be issued by the school district for any purpose whatsover.
RepealaAll acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.
Time effective This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the 6th day of March, 1952.

1073 An Act To Prohibit Fishing From Boats Or Similar Devices In Certain Areas Adjacent To India Hook Dam On The Catawba River In York County.
Fishing from floating device in certain areas adjacent to Catawba Dam and Power House prohibited, York County.

It is made unlawful for any person to fish from a raft, boat or any other floating device in the following described areas on the Catawba River in York County: An area lying downstream from the Catawba Dam and Power House of the Duke Power Company in York County, South Carolina, said area extending for a distance of approximately 375 feet downstream from the south or downstream wall of the Power House and extending from the east bank of the river to the southwestern corner of the dam; also an area on the upstream side of the Power House extending for a distance of approximately 100 feet from the northern or upstream wall of the Power House and extending from the eastern bank of the pond to the western wall of the Power House. It is distinctly provided, however, that this act shall not be construed to prevent fishing from any point on the rock pile situate below the India Hook Dam or on the banks adjacent to the areas above described.
The term banks adjacent to the areas above described shall not include any part or extension of the dam.

Anyperson violating the provisions of this act shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than fifty dollars, or imprisoned for not more than thirty days, in the discretion of the trial court.
Time effectiveThis act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. Approved the Ist day of May, 1952.

(a) It is hereby found and declared by the State Reorganization Commission, after examination and investigation, that the combination and consolidation of the following state executive and administrative agencies, to wit, the State Board of Fisheries, and the State Game and Fish Commission, and the office of Chief Game Warden, into one new agency, to be known as the South Carolina Wiildlife Resources Department ; and (i) the transfer of all the functions, duties, powers and authority of the said executive and administrative agencies to the aforesaid South Carolina Wildlife Resources Department ; (ii) the transfer to the aforesaid South Carolina Wildlife Resources Department of all functions, duties, powers and authority in relation to the execution and enforcement of the laws of the State, regulatory, tax, license, or otherwise, in reference to birds, nonmigratory fish, game, fish, shell fish, shrimp, oysters, oyster leases, and fisheries, devolved by law upon or exercised by all officers, employees, persons, and agencies, State, county, or otherwise, including all bird, nonmigratory fish and game wardens, and the chief inspectors and all assistant and deputy inspectors of the State Board of Fisheries, except the functions devolved by law in reference thereto upon the State Board of Health, and except the Bears Bluff Laboratory; and (iii) the transfer to the aforesaid South Carolina Wildlife Resources Department of all functions, duties, powers and authority devolved by law on or exercised by the said executive and administrative agencies, and by the Governor, and by senators and legislative delegations, and by any other officer, person or agency in relation to the nomination, appointment, or employment of the officers and employees of said executive and administrative agencies, and in relation to the nomination, appointment or employment of all bird, nonmigratory fish and game wardens and inspectors of the State Board of Fisheries, chief, assistant or deputy, whether such wardens or inspectors are state, county, or otherwise is necessary to bring about compliance with the provisions of subsection (b) of Section I of Act No.
621 of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly Senate Journal, pp.
Plan 8 has been filed with Secretary of State.

Plan 8 herein checked against 1951 297 in the Regular Session of 1948, entitled An Act to provide for the reorganization of the executive and administrative agencies of the State Government by transfer, consolidation, coordination, combination and abolition of such agencies and functions; to create The State Reorganization Commission and prescribe its duties, powers and functions; and to make an appropriation for the administration of this Act, and to accomplish one or more of the purposes set forth in Section 1 of said Act.

(b) The State Board of Fisheries, and the State Game and Fish Commission, and the office of Chief Game Warden, and each of them, are hereby combined and consolidated into an agency which shall be known as the South Carolina Wildlife Resources Department, as hereinafter constituted.

(c) The head and governing board of the South Carolina Wildlife Resources Department aforesaid shall be a commission to be known as the South Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission, which shall be composed of seven (7) members, one from each congressional district in the State, and one at large, who shall be the Chairman.
Four of the original appointees shall be appointed for terms of office of two (2) years, and three for terms of office of four (4) years.
Their successors shall be appointed in like manner for terms of office of four (4) years, and until their successors shall have been appointed and qualified.
All vacancies on the said commission occurring by reason of death, resignation, removal, or otherwise, shall be filled for the unexpired term in the manner of original appointment.
Each member shall receive compensation in the amount of one hundred ($100.00) dollars per annum, and official expenses as provided by law for state employees on public business.

(d) All of the functions, duties, powers and authority given to, devolved by law upon, or exercised by the State Board of Fisheries, and the Chairman thereof, and the State Game and Fish Commission, and the office of Chief Game Warden, and each of them, and all functions, duties, powers and authority in relation to the execution and enforcement of the laws of the State, regulatory, tax, license,
